name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 12 March 2015 to be resumed.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We are all certainly deeply saddened and shocked by the terrible news that reached us yesterday from France. The plane crash in the French Alps has shaken us all deeply. The cause of this serious accident has so far been unclear, but the plane, which crashed in the mountain range, had 150 people on board, including six crew members and a group of students from the Federal Republic of Germany, from Haltern in North Rhine-Westphalia: 16 young people who were in Spain with their teachers for student exchange have died. An entire city in my own country is in shock. And all the people from other countries – from Spain, from Turkey, from other countries – who have victims to mourn, certainly all of us have sympathy. This also applies to the victims of the terrible terrorist attack at the Bardo Museum in Tunis. The background to this terrible terrorist attack, the fanatical fundamentalism that has no respect for the lives of others, is not new to us. We have been experiencing this time and again and in intensive form over the last few months, and it shocks us. Here, too, our thoughts and feelings are with the families, friends, partners, families of the victims. The relatives of the people who died in Tunis and the relatives of the victims of this terrible plane crash yesterday in France, who now need strength in these difficult hours and days – all these people who have been badly beaten by fate should be sure that at this difficult time the Members of the European Parliament, that our institution in full solidarity and compassion with them, begins the sitting with a moment of silence. I would ask you to stand up for it from your seats! (The House rose and observed a minute's silence)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The minutes of the meeting of 12 March have been distributed. Are there any comments?

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I very much regret that the minutes of the last session do not reflect the incredible assault you carried out, in violation of The Annex XI of our regulation, by delivering to your political opponents our assistants and our parliamentary colleagues, without even having spoken to them, without even asking them for any explanation and by seizing the French Minister of Justice. , Mrs Taubira, your political friend, even though the OLAF investigation, which you seized, had not begun.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Gollnisch, I would like to thank Mr Gollnisch for his First of all, you are wrong. Your comments are recorded in the Minutes. Moreover, legal investigations, which I have to initiate because of the serious suspicion of breaking our rules and the laws in the French Republic, are not to be regarded by me as political acts, but it is my duty to investigate this suspicion of serious crimes and breaches of the rules of the European Parliament without regard for the person. That's what I did, nothing more. (Applause) (The minutes of the previous meeting were approved)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The competent Greek authorities have sent me a request for the waiver of Mr Theodoros Zagorakis' immunity. The competent German authorities have sent me two requests for the waiver of Mr Udo Voigt's immunity. Pursuant to Rule 9 of the Rules of Procedure, these requests are referred to the Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Mr President, your announcements included no announcement that a Member was leaving a political group or joining a new one, or indeed had been expelled from a political group. May I take it, then, that Janice Atkinson remains a member of the EFDD Group and has not been expelled by them, despite the recent revelations about the misuse of her expenses?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I have not received any changes to the composition of the group so far. In this respect, I must answer your question in the answer. I cannot confirm that Mrs Atkinson has left the group.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The final draft agenda of this part-session, as set out in the Conference of Presidents at its meeting on Thursday 12 March 2015 in accordance with Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, has been distributed. In agreement with the political groups, I propose various amendments to the agenda. The sitting today is to be extended until 11 p.m. The Commission's statement on the European Neighbourhood Policy is to be postponed to a later meeting. The statement by the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the recent terrorist attacks in Tunisia will be put on the agenda at 7 p.m. as the first item after voting time. Following the declaration, there may be a round of speakers from the political groups. The resolution on International Roma Day, anti-Gypsyism in Europe and recognition of the commemoration of the genocide of the Roma in the Second World War will be put to the vote at the April I part-session. Are there any objections to these changes?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I want to raise a question and ask for a change to today’s agenda, more precisely in relation to the vote on the report on the request to lift the immunity of Mr Uspaskich. I would ask you to refer this back to the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI). Each of us will have received today or yesterday ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, please wait a moment. We have not yet come that far. I have now called on all the points that have so far been agreed between the political groups. The reports referred by the Committee on Legal Affairs are the same. I will give you the floor in a matter of words. First of all, I would like to ask whether there are any objections to the four points that I have just mentioned here – extension until 11 p.m., neighbourhood policy later, Mrs Mogherini at 7 p.m. and Roma Day at the April I part-session. That is not the case. (Parliament adopted the amendments) The Committee on Legal Affairs has sent me four reports on the immunities of colleagues. These are the reports of Chrysogonos, Zwiefka, Regner and Duda. Pursuant to Rule 9(8) of the Rules of Procedure, these reports will be put to the vote this evening, as has been provided for so far. Mr Verhofstadt now has the floor to do so.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, each of us has received an email from our colleague Mr Uspaskich. He sent the message out yesterday and he repeated this letter today with more content and more information. I would like to give you my input on this. I think there is one principle that is applicable in our House, and that is the right of all of our Members to be treated equally and fairly. I have serious doubts about this in relation to the report on Mr Uspaskich. We have to be 100% sure, in the case of Mr Uspaskich, that there is no fumus persecutionis, to use the Latin term, i.e. that a case has not been mounted against him in order to eliminate him and his party from the political stage in his country. I have to tell you that I have serious doubts about this – doubts that have not, unfortunately, been removed by the report that is on our agenda today. There are many bizarre elements coinciding in this case. First of all, a change in the original charges, a change from an administrative fine to not less than four years’ imprisonment – and that two days before an election! A falsified tax declaration – because it now seems that the signature on this paper is not his signature. And then perhaps the most important thing: the revelation in WikiLeaks that the highest authorities in the country want to hound Mr Uspaskich out of politics. The fact that he is a European of Russian origin does not mean that this is allowed, or that his freedom of movement can be limited, preventing him from participating in the election campaign. On top of all this – and I want to conclude here – the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) has also decided that there could be restriction of his personal freedoms. I have here, by way of example, the decision taken in the case of Mr Severin, who was pursued for corruption, and in his case there was never a decision to restrict his ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his You cannot now debate the immunity procedure here. You must come to your application!

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, my request is very simple, if you see the difference in treatment, for example, between Mr Uspaskich and Mr Severin, if you see the different elements in the dossier. I am not asking that the plenary should say that Mr Uspaskich is not guilty. What I am asking is for the case to be referred, for a short period, from plenary back to the Committee on Legal Affairs, so that the Committee can respond to the doubts we have, and secondly so that they can also exclude ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his First of all, your request relates to Mrs Regner's report and not to other reports. I assume that you now mean only this one report. That is what I understood in your speech. If you request referral back to committee, you must do so 24 hours before the start of the plenary session, or you must do so immediately before the vote. In other words, I cannot put this amendment to the vote now. We are putting it on the agenda for the vote after the debate on International Roma Day. I would therefore encourage you to re-submit this request, which you have just tabled, before the vote begins. Only then can we make the referral back to committee. I now assume, however, that the House agrees that we should first include the four reports – Chrysogonos, Zwiefka, Regner and Duda, scheduled for vote at 7 p.m. – for voting time.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, I am sorry but I have here Rule 188, which says in paragraph 2 that in a case where the political group is asking for referral back to committee you have to put it to the vote immediately. I do not know if you understand the word ‘immediately’, but in Dutch it means ‘onmiddellijk’ – instantly, directly, now, within a nanosecond – and not at the end of the debate.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his You have to read the texts very concretely and precisely. Article 188(2) states that at least 40 Members or a political group may request a referral immediately before or during a vote. However, we are not in this vote, but I am just laying down the voting time. Voting time begins at 7 p.m. Under Rule 188(2), 40 Members or your group can then request referral back. You can try again, but I'm not doing that now.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, what you are saying now is in contradiction with paragraph 1 of Rule 188, which says it is before the agenda is fixed. We are now fixing the agenda and I ask you to refer this back to the committee.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his Put on your hearing aid! I am now citing the article you have mentioned, because this is a far-reaching process: 'Rule 188(1): Referral back to committee may be requested by a political group or by at least 40 Members when the agenda is set or before the debate is opened'. That is what you were referring to. That is the present state of affairs, the present moment. We are in the business when we set the agenda. You can then request the referral back, you are right. But the article goes on: "The intention to make such a request must be announced to the President at least 24 hours in advance." (Interject from Mr. Verhofstadt: "Paragraph 2, Mr President!") But you didn't do that. (Interjede: "That's bureaucracy!") No, this is not bureaucracy, that is the Rules of Procedure that we all have to adhere to here, including myself. I repeat: you can request that this report be rebuttcutated before voting time begins at 7 p.m. And now we are continuing on the agenda. (Interjede from Mr. Verhofstadt: "This is a bureaucratic procedure. I didn't know that you were a bureaucrat – but OK.") Mr Verhofstadt, I would like to thank Mr Verhofstadt for his I am very surprised that the chairman of a group which is otherwise known for insisting on compliance with the Rules of Procedure is talking about bureaucracy when the President applies the Rules of Procedure. I strongly reject that! Someone with your political experience also knows that I am right. But I understand, of course, your political affliction. ***

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, Thank you for your words of sorrow and remembrance at the beginning of this sitting. We have indeed requested that we have a debate on the subject: Resilience of the Monetary Union, and we ask that this debate be held following the statement by the European Council and the Commission. The reason is this: there is talk everywhere in the public and in the media about the possibility of Greece leaving the euro – but not in the European Parliament. It is incomprehensible that this is not an issue here, but it is clear in some respects that it is difficult to get closer to this issue because there is no legal possibility of leaving. As a result, all the arrangements that may be made for leaving take place behind closed doors – in transparent, in secret. In other words, citizens have no way of evaluating in any way how they would be affected. It is completely unclear what an exit would be like if it were to proceed in an orderly manner, as we all hope. That is what we should be discussing here. We should also discuss whether there should not be rules governing such an exit in the event that it occurs.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In 1970, a German mark cost nine drachmas. Thirty years later, in 2000, a German Mark cost 170 drachmas. This evolution of exchange rates reflects the evolution of competitiveness. If the eurozone did not exist, a German mark would cost 250 drachmas today. But no, the creators of the eurozone have said that the relationship is fixed for all eternity: a German mark costs 176 drachmas! That is why the euro is too cheap for Germany and too expensive for Greece. And that is why Greece has no chance of surviving in the eurozone. I would therefore like to support Mr Lucke's request. What we need is a system for leaving the eurozone.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The question of the resilience of monetary union depends to a large extent on compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact. At the heart of the Pact is the acquisition of a budget that is balanced, at least in the medium term. The failure to meet such a target in several Member States has led to dire results. The European Parliament is currently working on the so-called Berés report, which deals substantially with the stocktaking of the application of the six and two-pack. That is why the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is in favour of a serious and deep debate on the resilience of monetary union and is therefore also proposing to make the Berés report a key debate.  We welcome, in principle, the proposal that has been made here, but we recommend that the same debate should not be held twice in a short space of time.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council (meeting of 19 and 20 March 2015) (2014/2943(RSP)).

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, let me first of all convey my deepest condolences to the families of the victims of yesterday’s Germanwings tragedy. I would also like to express my sympathy and solidarity with the governments of all affected nations. Our thoughts are with you today. Now I would like to report to you on the Spring European Council which was an absorbing summit with a long, heavy agenda. We took the first concrete steps towards an Energy Union with all its dimensions. Our discussion focused mostly on energy security. Leaders agreed that in future all gas contracts, both between governments and businesses, need to be more transparent to make sure that they comply with our rules and do not endanger our energy security. The details will be settled in legislation to be proposed very soon by the Commission. I hope our ambition will be supported by this Chamber. We also agreed to explore how European companies might cooperate to buy gas in bulk. This is a timely discussion. Our dependence on external suppliers is a major weakness and I am glad leaders wished to address it. Finally, we agreed to step up Europe’s climate diplomacy ahead of the Paris Climate Summit in December. In the presence of the ECB President, Mr Mario Draghi, we discussed the European economy. The outlook for our economy is improving, at least according to the latest forecasts. Oil prices have declined faster than expected. The ECB is implementing quantitative easing. The euro has depreciated. However, no monetary initiative, no matter how big, will work without structural reforms at national level. The time to reform is now when the wind is blowing in our favour. We still have around five million unemployed young people in the European Union, so nobody can sit down and relax. And neither should this House relax in its efforts to agree the European Investment Fund that will help us provide the investment that Europe needs so badly. We had a good debate on TTIP. The aim remains clear: to reach an ambitious, comprehensive and mutually beneficial agreement by the end of 2015. Leaders shared the view that we now all need to communicate the potential benefits to the public. In our sessions dedicated to foreign affairs we discussed both the Eastern and Southern dimensions of our neighbourhood policy. Europe should continue to use its diplomatic weight and to act as a stabilising factor. Based on the contribution of foreign ministers, the European Council debated the security situation in Libya. We are determined to support fully the United Nations talks aimed at securing an immediate ceasefire and the establishment of a government of national unity. We gave a clear sign that we stand ready to support an agreement as soon as it is reached. We also discussed the rise in uncontrolled migration in the context of Libya. The European Union is already taking some measures and these should be stepped up. The European Council also welcomed the intention of the Commission to submit a European Agenda on Migration in May. However, the single best step to control migration is the re-establishment of central authorities in Libya. Our meeting took place the day after terrorists attacked the Bardo Museum in Tunis, where many lives were lost. We were unanimous in our support of Tunisia’s young democracy, its economic and social development, as well as in the fight against terrorism. Tunisia is a shining example of hope and therefore we need to do our best to support it. Together with the High Representative, I will visit Tunisia and the region next week to review the state of play and see how Europe can help to stabilise the situation. Now turning to the East. This was the last meeting of leaders ahead of the Eastern Partnership summit in Riga. We confirmed our commitment to the six partner countries and highlighted the need to focus on strengthening democratic institutions. Finally, we agreed to step up our support to the peace process in Ukraine and to link our sanctions regime to the complete implementation of the Minsk Agreement. That is the best hope for ensuring that the deal brokered by President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel is respected. We agreed that if the situation worsens we are ready to take further measures. In the meantime, the European Union will continue to support reform efforts in Ukraine. I commend Parliament’s current work to finalise financial assistance to Kiev. Let me close with a word on Greece, which is so important to the future of the eurozone and the European Union. I held an informal meeting on Greece at the request of Prime Minister Tsipras. The aim of this meeting was very simple: to rebuild mutual trust and avoid misunderstandings. I think we were successful in this. We agreed to speed up the implementation of the Euro Group agreement of 20 February 2015. Prime Minister Tsipras promised to present additional reform plans soon. Let us hope that this clears the way for a solution. Given that the format of this meeting received particular attention, let me mention that I asked the European Council if members preferred to discuss the Greek question at a Euro Summit, to be held immediately if needed. Leaders did not think this was necessary, or indeed useful at this stage. In the coming weeks and months, I will continue to do all I can to help in this difficult situation. I look forward to our debate.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is I would like to begin by saying what you said at the beginning of the debate in the introduction: yesterday's plane crash left us all deeply affected. And what happened in Tunisia last week, in the country where Spring Day is sprouting and continues to sprout, has also affected us. Sometimes it is – and it is actually sad – that other people's deaths make us better. We sometimes become better people through such events. But we quickly forget that again. I would like us to remember for a long time what you have recalled here, and I think you are quite right to do so. There is little to add to the president-in-office of the Council about the course of the European Council, unless it is to point out that we are currently dealing with an improbably broad recovery plan. I am not talking about the Commission's investment plan, but about the side effects of this plan. Oil prices have been revised down by 50%. This is an economic injection of EUR 100 billion per year. If we have to correct the investment plan upwards by EUR 100 billion, we do not know how to do so. But it happened! The price of oil has fallen by 50%, the exchange rates of the euro by 30% in direct relation to the US dollar. Taken together, the two are an insane recovery plan. And it is up to the governments, as well as the Commission and the Council, to make full use of these new opportunities for economic reception! I was very pleased that the European Council, like the Council of Finance Ministers, approved the European Commission's investment programme. I have noted very well, Mr President, that you yourself stated in your speech to the European Council that the European Parliament will make a great effort to bring the legislative process to a good end by mid-June. Which does not mean that everything the Commission has proposed should be 'nodded off' by Parliament one-to-one. However, we need a decision by the European Parliament by mid-June so that we are able to implement and launch this investment programme as quickly and efficiently as possible. Nevertheless, I would like to point out once again – even if this might get on the nerves of some here – that we urgently need this initial guarantee of EUR 16 billion in budgetary resources and EUR 5 billion in EIB funds. We need to be able to present investors with a plan that will provide this reinsurance option. How this is done in detail is not only a matter for Parliament, but also for Parliament. I am confident that, in a sensible way, we will find ourselves not somewhere in the middle, but at the centre of common sense, so that all this can be done as it should be done. We agreed on the basic lines of the Energy Union in the European Council on the basis of a list of proposals from the European Commission, which will soon be materialised in the legislative process. This is a very important concern to me! I made it clear here in this Parliament – but in Strasbourg, which is actually the seat of Parliament, – on 15 July, when discussing the priorities of the then new Commission – it is getting older and older, Mr Timmermans is also growing, he is getting bigger as the Commission gets older – that the Energy Union is an important priority for the then new , is now an aged Commission. We have delivered, that was also Parliament's wish, we have done so, and this is an important matter! There are four fundamental freedoms in the European Treaties – in the Treaty of Rome – and I would like us to add a fifth without having to make treaty changes: we also need the free movement of energy in Europe! Ergo we must end the national silos that exist and the geo-blocking in the field of energy supply. I was very pleased that weeks ago in Madrid we had a summit with the French President and the Prime Ministers of Portugal and Spain to ensure the energy supply of the Iberian Peninsula for the future. Portugal is on the periphery of Europe without being a peripheral country, because Portugal is an important Member State of the European Union, but in terms of energy policy the supply situation in Portugal, and partly in Spain, is very unsatisfactory. We are trying to remedy this through the policies that have been put in place. We talked about TTIP and I asked the Prime Ministers to to make it clear what the situation and the view of things are. And all the Prime Ministers, regardless of what they have announced in their capitals after the end of the European Council, have committed themselves to the aim of concluding this free trade agreement, if possible, by the end of the year. This does not change the fact that we all – not just some – think that we should not sacrifice fundamental European values on the altar of this free trade agreement, should, and want. But this is being negotiated in detail. And the Commission has been given the task of regularly reporting to the European Council on the progress of the discussions. As far as Greece is concerned, I would not like to elaborate too much on this but we had this meeting under the leadership of Donald Tusk for the reasons indicated because, during the last European Council, the Member States did not like to discuss this in a formal meeting of the Euro Group at the highest level. So the President of the Council decided to form a smaller group, mainly to put people in touch who never speak to each other. It was very helpful. We think that the Greek government would be best inspired to present us with a list of immediate reforms to be undertaken. Prime Minister Tsipras, with whom I talked last night, is ready to present these reforms by the end of this week or the beginning of next week. These reforms will be examined by the groups that have been created – a technical group, a fact-finding mission in Athens and the so-called Brussels Group, a more politically-oriented group. Then after the assessment that will be given by the three institutions – IMF, Commission and ECB – the Euro Group will be in charge of putting this under its mediation in order allow us to proceed in the best way possible. I must admit that I have been very pessimistic in recent weeks because no progress what soever was made, but now we are back to normal and I think that we will come to a conclusion that will be in favor both of Greece – and we love Greece – and the European Union. Monsieur le Président, lundi prochain, je me rendrai avec Federica Mogherini. Le président de la République ukrainienne me fait l'honneur de me demander de coprésider le Conseil des ministres. Il est vrai que, depuis de trop longs mois, je n'ai plus présidé un Conseil des ministres, et je dois donc me rendre Kiev pour ce faire. Lors de cette occasion, je rendrai compte des nombreuses contributions – notamment de Rebecca Harms – la position du Parlement sur l'Ukraine. J'ai d'ailleurs pris note, Rebecca, que le groupe des Verts n'était, ma grande tristesse, pas enthousiasmé par les propositions de la Commission sur l'Union de l'énergie. Je demanderai donc au commissaire de venir s'expliquer devant vous.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Mr President of the Commission, this Spring Council has indeed been very much a discussion. I will start by mentioning this Energy Union, which is particularly important for us. I note that the Member States have supported the five pillars of this union: energy security, internal market integration, energy efficiency, decarbonisation and, of course, research and development. We can rejoice, because we have to accelerate the movement! And translate this Energy Union into concrete action as soon as possible. Member States must therefore be involved in this area and should not be wary of strategic issues. Let me emphasize some priorities. Firstly, energy security, which is primarily achieved by achieving a more integrated internal energy market. Member States must implement the existing rules before adding any more. Without regional cooperation to achieve this internal energy market and without firm application of the legislation of the third energy package, the Energy Union will be impossible. We need better connections and efficient use of existing networks. This is an essential condition for this internal market. Secondly, the European Union needs to better manage its supplies through a real diversification of its energy sources. It must reduce its energy dependence and promote energy efficiency, especially in buildings. This will make the European Union more competitive. Thirdly, innovative technologies must be the spearhead of the European Union. To become the world leader in these renewable energy technologies, we must seize opportunities in these sectors, not only in wind or solar, but also in biomass, electricity storage, CO2 storage and capture, hydrogen and, finally, the nuclear of the future. Support for research and innovation is essential to Europe's competitiveness. The task is therefore great: to strengthen this competitiveness, to develop jobs and to enable our young people to find these jobs on the European continent. As such, I welcome the Council's willingness to insist, in the context of the European semester, on the need to carry out structural reforms in Europe and to clean up public accounts in order to restore growth, which unfortunately remains fragile and heterogeneous. The European Union is now suffering from a lack of investment because investors do not have enough confidence. The Commission must therefore firmly implement the Stability Pact to the Member States. Structural reforms will not be done without a clear incentive to comply with European rules. These reforms are too timid and insufficient in some European countries. Let us not underestimate the terrible consequences of this lack of substantive reforms for the peoples of Europe. Greece is a particularly painful example. Finally, President Juncker's European Fund for Strategic Investments sends a strong signal and is timely. We fully support it because it restores confidence in areas where no more risks are being taken, for lack of long-term hope. I particularly stress the need to preserve research, fundamental or applied, because it is the breeding ground for tomorrow's innovation. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Madam Representative, you have, quite rightly, just said the benefits of the Energy Union and called for stronger, more disciplined action against the Member States. I respectfully ask that the Hungarian Government, led by a certain Viktor Orban, whose party sits in your ranks, is these days signing energy contracts with the Russians that are encrypted for 10 years, 20 years, 30 years in advance, is this acceptable to you?

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: "blue card" answer. Of course, each Member State is sovereign in the choice of its supply, namely its energy mix as well as its supply possibilities. Certainly, such decisions do not go in the direction of harmonising what we have to decide in the context of this Energy Union. I hope that we will be able to convince all Member States that we must indeed cooperate.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. I would like to talk above all about energy policy and also about investment policy. I thought you were a little short of substance when you went into the energy union and the decisions on this. Nevertheless, I would like to congratulate you on the decisions you have taken on the Energy Union. Why? Because the strength of the energy union, under the inspiring leadership of Vice-President Šefčovič, is in the overall approach. Not only the energy security, not only climate - however important - not only the energy poverty or the need for energy of our industry, but the overall approach. If we look at that picture, we actually know what it takes. We know, as is the case in the Energy Union, that we need to move towards a low-carbon economy. That sounds very logical and we may agree in theory, but it remains a bit of a theoretical concept. We must be careful about this, because there was a time when we were at the forefront of new technology, renewable energy and even energy efficiency, especially in Europe. But we're losing that leadership role. There are other economies and regions in the world that are taking over. We must therefore focus on certainty and a total picture. Why don't we do that? Why do we not invest in energy efficiency and renewable energy? Because we have 28 different types of policies, with an energy mix here and an energy mix there, without a clear picture of where we need to go. That is the strength of the energy union and it must be prioritised.  One of these priorities, which has once again been clearly identified in the Energy Union, is energy efficiency, because it is now making that picture complete. Energy efficiency creates jobs, ensures that we meet our climate targets and makes our industries the most energy efficient industries. But here too, we must be careful that it does not stick to theory. And then I'll come up with the investment plan. You have broad support - and I am now addressing Parliament' s President - for that plan. We want more investment. As far as we are concerned, the Energy Union is one of the pillars that lies beneath it, one of the frameworks that determines what investment should be made in. We agree on this, but that is why we are also a little concerned about our discomfort in the European Parliament, and Mr Grossetête has rightly indicated it: another pillar of the Energy Union is research and development. Without research and development, we will not make it. And so it is unacceptable for us to get resources from Horizon 2020 and we must start looking for a good compromise. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I actually learned from Mrs Grossetête whether there is an energy union, and the thesis that it is decarbonisation sounded very clear. This is one of the five pillars. She called for a holistic and realistic thinking. 9/10 of the European economy is based on coal. We cannot strike at something that is the basis of our economy and, in a particular way, the basis in Central Europe. I would like to know what your opinion is on this? Is decarbonisation in your understanding intended to be a dogmatic objective of the Energy Union or is it something that can still be discussed?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Colleague, that is not dogma, that is an absolute objective on which We - I hope - agree. I would like to say something about the east of Europe, because I think we should pay attention to it. We cannot say overnight that we are done with coal and in the long term with gas, although that is the ultimate objective if we are to take our climate responsibility. Transition is the word. You need to make sure that you make resources and know-how available in eastern Europe to make industry as energy efficient as possible. There must be something of the heart. If we look at the proposals that have been put forward in the investment plan project pipeline, you will see almost no energy efficiency projects from the east of Europe. Let us also make energy-efficient companies a top priority in the east of Europe!

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this was supposed to be a summit to demonstrate the strength and the resolve of the EU. Instead, I am afraid it demonstrated a weakness of will. I have to say that I take no pleasure in saying that, for my group wants to see the EU encouraging cooperation in dealing with issues affecting people in the EU countries right across the EU; not kicking the can down the road. On Energy Union and energy policy, we secured a commitment to the proposals put on the table but the detail was put off until another meeting. We need to demonstrate – as Ms Grossetête said – how we are going to encourage diversification of energy sources, better interconnection and energy security so that our countries no longer have to rely on unpleasant regimes in the Middle East or on Russia. On Russia, we welcome the decision to give Minsk a chance but we have been far too slow amongst us in responding to Russian propaganda. And have we forgotten Crimea? What message is the Council giving to Russia? It seems that the EU is saying to Russia: invade first, negotiate second. This was the summit that was supposed to focus on the economy. But the most serious issue holding back our economies – the eurozone and Greece – does not feature once in the Council conclusions. The major issue was relegated to a late-night discussion with a select few leaders. But all 28 countries have a stake in the euro’s future, so why was Greece not discussed in the Council? We were told at the time that this was because the Council President thought that the issue might be ‘a little bit too hot’. I have to be fair and I have to understand, Mr Tusk, that you are a servant of the Council and therefore you were reflecting that decision of the leaders. But I also have to ask you, if Council meetings are not going to discuss the most pressing issues of the day because an issue is considered ‘a little bit too hot’, then what is the point of the Council meeting? So, Mr Tusk, our plea to you – and our plea to the leaders of these summits – is: show that you have the will to stand up to Russia; show that you have the will to take the tough decisions about the euro and show that you have the will to provide solutions. Nothing should be considered ‘a little bit too hot’ for the Council table. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrew LEWER
text: blue-card question. – One other item that was raised on the sidelines of the summit by Prime Minister Cameron was the impact that changes to EU VAT rules that were agreed seven years ago are having on micro-enterprises that have taken advantage of the Internet to set up small businesses. I understand, however, that the reaction of one of the Commission President’s spokesmen when he heard this matter was going to be raised was: ‘Oh, there is just an election on.’ And one of his spokesmen sent you a tweet blaming the Member States. Do you think that is the right attitude for the Commission to take, or is it in conflict with their clear aim to create a digital single market? Yet, when it comes to people raising concerns about obstacles, they simply blame someone else.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Lewer, this was a question to Mr Juncker, but ... (Mr Juncker made to rise) No, no, no, wait a minute. (Laughter) Mr Kamall, I do not know if it is by chance that in the UK there is an election campaign going on but be careful if you answer now on behalf of the Commission, as I do not know how Mr Cameron will react. (Laughter)

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Lewer, I understand, asked a very clear question about the Commission’s attitude to the concerns of many digital micro-entrepreneurs who have had these EU VAT rules imposed on them. I know Mr Verhofstadt and his group have also shared that concern, so this is not really a party political issue. Let us be quite clear about that. I have had some very good meetings with the Commission. It is probably no secret that Mr Timmermans and I had dinner the other night and we discussed this issue ... (Exclamations and laughter) It clearly was a secret, Mr Timmermans. I have now completely reduced your credibility in this Parliament – I have ruined your career! Mr Juncker did not have dinner with me, otherwise that would have been the end of his career as well. Despite the constructive meetings I have had with various people in the Commission, however, I have to say I was a little disappointed by what I considered cheap and shoddy tweets from members of Mr Juncker’s team, and also someone calling themselves the press officer for EU better regulation. This morning there was a cross-party breakfast with MEPs from a number of different groups sitting down with these entrepreneurs, and they were disappointed with the tweets coming out of the Commission. My plea to you, Mr Juncker, is please talk to those ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like Mr Kamall to note that I belong to a pro-European group but I have never been invited to a dinner by ... Actually it was not a dinner, it was a lunch! There is a difference, Mr Timmermans. So next time you will be paying for the dinner with the Liberal Group.  Mr Kamall, you are right about the VAT on small companies who have apps on the Internet. It is ridiculous that we are now starting this VAT system. We could at least exclude the small businesses from that. I know that Mr Ansip, who is responsible for the Digital Agenda, had the idea of putting it on the agenda of the College the next time they discuss the Digital Agenda. Having said that, Mr Tusk, I completely deplore the fact that you have organised a meeting on Greece with a limited format. What type of Union is this? Greece concerns all the countries of the European Union and at least all the countries of the eurozone and it should not be allowed that there are separate and limited meetings of a number of countries about it. I do not think that this is at all acceptable. It is against the interest of the Union and against the interest of the eurozone to do this. (Applause) I know there is always pressure. I had the same thing, I remember, and certainly Jean-Claude had also, in Ghent. Do you remember that, Jean-Claude? The big countries wanted a meeting – I think it was France, Germany and Britain – about Afghanistan after 9/11. They had a separate meeting and they asked me – I was President of the Council – for a separate room. I found the dirtiest room in Ghent to give them for their meeting. The meeting lasted only five minutes. It was so dark in that room that they came out after five minutes and joined the meeting of the whole European Council. So I deplore this. Do not do it. It sends a bad signal to everybody. I have a number of very short questions. What was decided on Greece? We do not know what has been decided on Greece. When are they coming forward with their package of structural reforms, because that is the starting point of every exercise on Greece? Secondly, what is the decision on Russia? We need a proactive line – we already have a debate on this. Have the sanctions been deepened if Russia and Mr Putin go further? And has a positive package also been decided? I mean a positive package for young people, young students and researchers. We need to liberalise to make it easier for them to have visas to our countries. On the Energy Union, I think Ms Van Brempt is quite right that decisions on interconnection require a leading role for the Commission. If no decision is made by the Member States to give a leading role to the Commission to lead the negotiations about energy agreements and interconnections investments, we do not have a real Energy Union.  Finally, I am very disappointed that you did not take a decision on roaming charges and that you continue with this bad decision. Regarding digital, we are still living in the 20th century and not in the 21st century in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, we must say that we do not need dinners or meals to convey our views, we transfer them here, in full transparency, as we convey our views on the Commission and Parliament's committees. As far as the European Union is concerned, ladies and gentlemen, the Council conclusions contained an important reference to the need to safeguard the sovereignty and sovereign rights of the Member States for the exploration and development of natural resources.  However, there is no attempt to pressure Turkey to stop the illegal actions and harassment of the Republic of Cyprus in the exercise of its sovereign rights to explore and exploit its natural resources, as it certainly prevents the resumption of inter-communal talks on a solution to the Cyprus problem. There is no pressure on Turkey to fulfil its contractual obligations, apart from the fact that Turkey in this way affects the overall energy development of the region, but also the energy security of the European Union.  The Council conclusions also mention the importance of exploiting domestic energy sources. However, the role that the natural gas deposits of Cyprus and the wider eastern Mediterranean region can play is overlooked. The same omission can be found both in the Commission communication on energy union and in the Communication on energy security.  Now, as far as economic issues are concerned: the decisions of the European Council have also confirmed the continuation of the neoliberal austerity policies that led to the current crisis. It is not enough, Mr Tusk, to improve the indicators of the economy at a time when people are increasingly sinking into poverty, unemployment and poverty.  As far as Greece is concerned, the European Council, the Commission, the European Central Bank, the Eurogroup must stop financial blackmail. The Greek government is demanding for the country and its people an end to the disastrous policies imposed by the Troika and the memoranda. Let the Greek government implement its programme to address the humanitarian crisis and provide substantial support to the Greek people. Support the efforts of the Greek government and let it implement the reforms that previous governments have not done, and I am referring to reforms that can boost the real economy, but also address the serious problems of tax evasion and corruption, because it has finally been confirmed in practice that leaving the memorandum does not mean getting rid of the policies of harsh austerity.  Apart from Greece and Cyprus, which are in a memorandum of understanding, in countries such as Ireland, Spain and Portugal, which are supposed to have left the Memorandums, the same policies of austerity continue, privatisations, housing divestments, the removal of the social state, the increase in unemployment and the impoverishment of peoples continue. With these policies, the peoples of Europe will never leave the crisis.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question to Mr Verhofstadt. – Mr Verhofstadt, I am glad to see that you are now fighting against the VAT MOSS regulations which are having such a crippling effect on small businesses in my constituency, but I have to ask you this: you have had seven years to get this right. Why have you not? Does it not say something about the structures in this place where it is possible to sleepwalk into a nightmare like this one?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – (inaudible as microphone not switched on) ... that is the first point. The second point and the most important is that it is the intention of the college – from what I have understood – to make an exception for all small and medium-sized companies which are active with apps on the Internet. That is the best way forward and that is also the reason why I said to Mr Tusk that he has to review this bad decision about roaming charges because that also affects that same digital union. Let us not spend time on the bad decisions of the past. For me what is important is that the Commission is now back on the right track.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the We are still in the debate on the Council, last week's summit – well, I understand that. I think it is a good thing that people are laughing at such a debate, and that we are perhaps looking at what has been achieved and not been achieved in a more distant way. Mr Juncker is absolutely right: I was one of those who was very disappointed – perhaps least of what has happened outside the agenda, from the invitation to some special quarrels on the Greek issue. For my impression was that this small side-summit was absolutely necessary in order to control the tensions that had arisen and to get away from an almost inevitable 'graccident' on the way to aid to Greece. That was the word that had a lot of economic activity around this summit, that perhaps – without any real intention – that debates become self-sufficient, that Greece leaves the eurozone, and that we can only collect the rubble here in a few months' time. I am convinced that such a 'graccident' would have dire consequences for Greece, but would also have serious political consequences for the European Union. At the summits that I have been observating for a number of years, I sometimes have the impression that, as long as we cannot solve these fundamental problems of the euro and the euro crisis, other big, courageous decisions for the European Union are literally built up by the fact that this laboratory is all about the euro crisis. Then There is the Energy Union, Mr Juncker. I was one of those who reacted enthusiastically to what Mr Tusk had proposed. I believe that, if the Energy Union is right, we can not only provide optimal climate protection, that we can achieve innovation in large industrial sectors, that we can create security, security of supply, but also security with Russia and other countries on which we depend. But you have to do it right! If we put the old energy mix back in the centre, we can forget about it as a project for the future! Thanks to European generosity in subsidies, nuclear power stations are to be built in England, where the price of electricity is expected to be double to three times the current price of electricity in 45 years' time. Tell me why this is the focus of attention and not renewable energies, which are already making industrial electricity prices unrivalled low in Germany, even if the opposite is claimed! For me, the Energy Union would be what the Treaties for Coal and Steel or Euratom were to the founding fathers of the European Union. If we do this today, we must focus on the new, not on the old. This must be boring for you at some point! Or does a whole new generation of politicians really have to come before something new can be started here? Last disappointment, also towards Mr Tusk: I think it is a pity that the sanctions regime against Russia has not been bindingly linked to the implementation of Minsk. That has been postponed until the next summit. This is a weak point for the EU with regard to Russia. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Harms, I would like to thank Mrs Harms for her work on this I would, of course, like to pick up on the fact that you said that you fear a 'graccident'. I share your concerns there. But do you not agree with me that if a greek accidental exit from the euro is a major danger, it is high time that Greece is not doing better today, but worse off than it was five years ago, and, given that there is a government that does not want to continue the programme, is it high time that an orderly exit of Greece from the euro was prepared by the European institutions?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have always opposed unilateral austerity in Greece in the fight about right or wrong in crisis policy. I know why Greece is in this situation today. There is a homegrown responsibility, but there is also responsibility, which we have often discussed here in this Parliament. We did not support real reforms, but sold unilateral budget cuts as reforms. This has led to this situation. I would like to find the way out for Greece together with the Greeks. That is what my group is advocating. I say to you, Mr Lucke, that I am against allowing us to think at all about someone leaving the euro zone or the European Union. I believe that this actually starts with the dissolution of the European Union as a whole. And I don't think so at all in these times!

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, today I was going to talk about issues ranging from Greece to the EU’s energy policy, but when travelling in I thought all this can wait because I do not believe today should be about political point-scoring. We will have many opportunities to debate and no doubt disagree, Mr Juncker, over the next four years, but today my opinion should be about quiet and unified reflection. What happened yesterday in the French Alps represented a sickening loss of life and one which has been felt right across our great continent. As you all know, I am thoroughly opposed to the European Union and its institutions but I am actually proud to be a European. Indeed, the fact that my colleagues and I do not believe in the structures of the EU does not make us lesser Europeans. I would therefore, on behalf of my group, like to offer my condolences firstly to Germany. Sixty-seven of the 144 passengers who have died were German citizens, including 16 children returning from an exchange trip. Over 40 passengers are believed to be Spanish, and as someone who has lived and worked in Barcelona and someone who still has friends in that great Catalan city, my thoughts are with them at this difficult time. Also on board that tragic flight were Britons, Dutch, Danes and Belgians. This tragedy has touched us all. We must hope for the sake of the families that the salvage operation will be swift and that they get the answers that they need as quickly as possible so that they can understand why this aeroplane fell to the ground and their loved ones lost their lives. I think I speak not only on behalf of my group but I am pretty sure the whole of the European Parliament when I say that our thoughts and our prayers are with the friends and families of those who so tragically lost their lives in the French Alps yesterday. God bless. (Applause)

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to take this opportunity to express our deepest sympathy for the bereaved of this tragic plane accident from the Austrian side and from my party, the Freedom Party in Austria. May all those who mourn now also have sufficient strength and strength to go through these difficult hours. I know that today is not the day of a major political debate, but I do not want to spare you, the majority of this House, one thing. In my view, there is a more than legitimate concern to debate the more than explosive situation in Greece here. It is a question of Greece's possible exit from the monetary union, it is about our prosperity, and it is about purchasing power stability and how Europe is developing. And the majority of this House refuses to allow the European Parliament to debate it. All I can say is that you are ashamed, ladies and gentlemen, that you are preventing a debate on the part of the Social Democrats and Christian Democrats! Nor are you surprised if, at the next European elections, the turnout, which is already below 15% in some states, is even lower editising because of the political disaffection that you are deliberately creating with this behaviour here.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to note that the Council recognises that the crisis in Libya requires the full attention of the European Union, which cannot confine itself to the role of observer. I believe that we have been fugitives and adversarial for too long. I very much hope that the Mediterranean will once again become central to the action of this Union of ours. However, I would like to focus today on the area of growth and employment, in particular EFSI. The guidelines are acceptable, but I would also like to take advantage of Mr Juncker's presence to present to him what I consider to be an essential thing, namely that I am convinced that it is necessary to ensure that sectoral experts with specific knowledge of the situation in the geographic intervention markets are present within the Investment Committee. This presence is essential, Mr President, in order to allow your plan to intervene in those sectors where the benefits to the European market are greatest in the short and long term, while at the same time ensuring that objectives for the cohesion of the European economy are achieved. What I want to say is that the Investment Committee must work to promote European economic cohesion at social and territorial level, while respecting the choice not to allocate resources geographically. We will only achieve the objectives of development and growth if our choices, if the choices that are made, are able to reduce the imbalances between the different regions of the Union. Woe betide us if what we are going to do goes instead to increase the imbalances between the regions. So I'm going to leave this point to your attention.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, Mr Juncker, at the beginning of his speech, referred to the general economic context in which we move and pointed out that some elements are varying positively – the price of oil, the exchange rate of the euro, some macroeconomic magnitudes; but we are a long way from overcoming the problems we have been experiencing for a few years now. When it comes to growth, this year we're going to grow a little over 1%. That's like a third of america, and that growth comes after two years of zero growth or recession. When it comes to unemployment, we double America's unemployment rate, we have very significant long-term unemployment, and we are unable to reduce youth unemployment. Investment is 20% below that which existed before the crisis, and divergences continue to increase within the European Union, putting social cohesion at risk and also putting convergence at risk. In the face of this situation, the Commission is responding. The Commission has presented the investment programme, the investment plan; has put forward a proposal for flexibility in the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact; it has also put forward a political proposal on fiscal transparency and today referred to the need for us to use the new possibilities of oil and the exchange rate. However, the Council is not responding with the same intensity. And I believe that, while we recognise that there is a course of action in the face of the crisis in the hands of the Commission, the Council's position on these problems remains timid, if not a bit autonomous. I therefore ask the Council to adopt the same commitment with the same intensity that the Commission is at least showing. Let me conclude, Mr Sassoli, by pointing out that, to my disgrace, I have not been able to grow like Mr Timmermans since the Commission was introduced at the beginning of July. Unfortunately, my height remains equivalent.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would like to call on everyone to respect the timetable, needless to say, not least because we are a little behind the vote at 7.00 p.m. I have the pleasure of greeting the officers of the carabinieri of the specialization school of the 21st course of the Carabinieri Of Rome, who are here with us today. Thank you for being here.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur I, too, join in mourning with the families of the victims of the attack at the Bardo Museum in Tunisia and the Germanwings plane crash in France and with the peoples to which these victims belonged.  On the Energy Union. Indeed, I could consider the provisions in the Council conclusions as the first steps towards an Energy Union if not for a fairly clear description indicating the directions of development. And so in turn: decarbonization. This dogma from the point of view Polish is not acceptable. Clean coal technologies are being developed in the world's scientific institutes. It is easy to liquidate an entire branch of industry. It is much more difficult to rebuild such a branch and the well-being of people who have been associated with it for generations. The second point: both decarbonisation and the regional approach to creating a common energy market for my central and eastern European region pose a deadly threat and, truth be told, much less protection in terms of energy security than the current legal situation in the European Union. The same is true of the confidentiality of contracts. I would like to remind you that it is to the previous Commissioner Oettinger that we owe a better Polish in energy relations with the Russian Federation than to one of the previous Polish governments.  And now I move on to my subjects. I agree with the conclusions on Tunisia and Libya. I believe that this is the right course of approach, both for the Council and for the Commission.  As far as Russia and Ukraine are concerned, the sledging regime should be clearly linked not to control of the eastern border, but should be linked to Ukraine's regaining control of its territory, including Crimea. I would like to remind you that from September, that is, from Minsk I to February to Minsk II, the situation has actually deteriorated in this regard. And we should think about how to increase these sanctions, not reduce them. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the "blue card" (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mrs. Fotyga, thank you for accepting my blue card. Several of your colleagues from Poland talk all the time about how we should think carefully about whether and how to get off coal as an energy source. I am one of those who is in Croatia against a project that is trying to build a coal-fired thermal power plant.  I ask you what energy needs of Poland you see and how do you think other energy sources should be introduced into Poland?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card answer. – I would like to reply. Certainly for many years we have tried unsuccessfully to implement the LNG terminal in Poland. Nobody knows why it is going so slowly. It should be much faster. It should contribute to the energy mix of Poland and to the security of Poland making us independent from Russia. The same goes for shale gas possibilities. We have been engaged in many projects of this kind and unfortunately there are obstacles to this. Energy efficiency and other resources are also possible.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the President of the European Council has told us about the need for structural reforms in order to bring growth back to the Union. No one denies the need for reform. The crucial question, however, is what kind of reforms these are. Deregulation of the labour market so that labour is delivered disorganized and unarmed to capital does not lead to growth, but to recession. The flattening of social rights and the violent impoverishment of the economically weaker is not a step forward, but a step of reaction and regression.  The crucial, necessary structural reform is the fight against tax evasion and corruption, in particular the large-scale tax evasion and corruption that is being esvolved by multinational large companies. That is what our attention must focus on and that is what european Union policy must combat.  As for Greece in particular, it must be understood that the Troika's policies were largely toxic, led to a humanitarian crisis and must be corrected, as the Greek people concluded in the January elections. This must be done within the framework of European rules and the main elements of these rules are, firstly, respect for fundamental rights, including the social rights of all Europeans, and therefore for Greeks, and secondly, the inexo representative of the participation of states in the euro area. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Marco VALLI
text: "blue card" question. Mr Chrysogonos, I would like to ask you a question. Since they are finding a wall in the Council and do not want to accept these obvious facts that you have reported, would it not be fairer to start assessing, given that this stalemate will then generate even more of a crisis, a possible exit strategy or exit from the euro, or start asking for it in the Council in a strong way?

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. – Exiting the euro area is not provided for in European rules, nor is it the will of the Greek people. The mandate that the Greek government received in the last elections is not to leave the eurozone, or much more than the Union, but to negotiate hard within the existing institutional framework in order to improve the situation of the Greek economy and society in order to give Greece a chance to breathe. Give Greece a chance.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: – Signor Presidente, onorevoli colleghi, nell'ennesimo Consiglio europeo dedicato alla questione greca si parlato ancora una volta la lingua dell'austerit. Sono dispiaciuta che il sig. Juncker non sia pi qui, sig. Tusk, e forse mi si comprender meglio se la parler anch'io, quindi mi permetto di continuare in tedesco. Today we see blackmail in Europe, a daily blackmail against an entire people. German Minister Schäuble blackmails Greece when he says that nothing will happen without Greek reforms. The President of the Eurogroup, Mr Dijsselbloem, is threatening possible capital controls, as in Cyprus, and the ECB is threatening the Greek Government with quantitative easing that will make it easier for banks to operate at the expense of the real economy. Greece has lived beyond its means, that is true. But Germany certainly lived under its means. With the euro, German wages have remained firm and work has become precarious. All this in order to promote crazy exports rather than increasing domestic demand. Of course, a German does not want to lose a penny for a Greek, especially at a time when the German people have to tighten their belts. Instead of fighting the power of high finances, they have used the euro to attack work and turn it into a hiring variable. Monetary union has destroyed European solidarity and the will to integrate. Greece will become a second Cyprus because they refuse to see the problem, which is that monetary union is not working. We need to change the constraints, especially the pointless 3% rule. Exiting the euro is the only solution for Greece.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the decisions of the summit and the multilateral and bilateral meetings that followed are marked by the Agreement of the Greek Government with the European Union, its bank and the International Monetary Fund, in order to proceed with the unpopular reforms that will deal a new heavy blow to workers and give new privileges and capital to business groups.  The Greek government continues the privatisations, the policy of wild taxation, the demolition of the insurance system. These are, after all, provided for in the Memorandums and the Troika, which by another name, remain in place. This is all the more defined by the Treaties of the European Union, the rules and surveillance mechanisms of the Stability Pact and the European Semester. The only way for the people is by fighting to show no tolerance for the government's new unpopular agreement with the European Union to extend the Memorandum, to now show determination to immediately abolish the memorandums and implementing laws, by recovering all losses, by breaking with the European Union, their capital and their power.

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: Mr President, I congratulate the European Council and the Commission on the new way of working: from now on, each summit is devoted to one main subject. This time it was the Energy Union. Mr President of the Council, I invite you to plan now to dedicate a meeting of the European Council in the autumn to the problem of corporate taxation in the Union. Indeed, the difference in the tax treatment of companies has become the major cause of fragmentation of the internal market and inequality between small and large enterprises. Recent revelations in the press have sparked public outrage, so that, as physicists would say, the conditions of temperature and pressure are in place to hope for decisive progress in this area. The European Commission has adopted a tight timetable and Parliament has set up a special committee to support, stimulate and extend its work. But on this subject, everything will depend on governments and the ability of heads of government to be obeyed by their finance ministers. In 1992, top leaders imposed the disappearance of national currencies on finance ministers and central bank governors who did not want them at any price. This is such an important and courageous decision that the European Council will be invited to take, Mr President, under your presidency.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, I would like to support the proposal that has just been made by Alain Lamassoure and Today I will not talk about Greece. I prefer to address the issue of energy by hoping that the European spirit and common sense prevail in solving the Greek problem. Energy is a central issue for the European Union and I am sorry that they have addressed it. According to European Commission data, 53% of this energy is imported, which is equivalent to an annual expenditure of EUR 400 billion. Still, the price of energy in the European Union is 40% more expensive than in the United States.  Portugal, like many other southern countries, believed in the sincerity of the alternative agenda, the European agenda that puts solar, wind and tidal water at the heart of its options and invested heavily to gain competitive advantages in this area. However, when they want to export, these countries run into not a physical mountain, because that technology goes beyond, but with the mountain of lack of political will of other countries and, let's be clear, the weight of some powerful lobbies like the nuclear lobbie. On 4 March, Portugal, Spain, France signed an agreement, which was mentioned here today by Jean-Claude Juncker, under his auspices, for the interconnection of at least 10% of its electricity grids and the creation of the corresponding physical networks. The interconnection target between Portugal and Spain is even higher: it is 11% in 2016 and 15% in 2020.  The last European Council recognised this agreement and said it is a welcome step towards achieving the European Union's 2020 target. The problem is that this 10% target has been reaffirmed numerous times by European leaders in recent years, with major advertising effects and no practical consequences. That is why I hope that the European Union and the Council of Ministers will now be as demanding in fulfilling this agreement as they have been with others that are much fairer and far less important and that the new investment support instruments will be considered as priorities for, after all, promises to give rise to concrete action. Europeans need this. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – You drew attention to the importance of interconnectors between countries in providing connections for transferring renewable energy across the Union, but when I am out visiting small renewable energy producers they are much more concerned about upgrading to the grid so that they can put the energy they produce back into the grid network. Do you think that is also an important part of what we need to provide in the Energy Union?

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – The obviously fundamental problem is a problem that is reasonably solved already in my country and, at the moment, what stands out is the question whether the investments that have been made can in fact lead to a change in the European energy combination or whether they have to be limited to the country where they are produced, where, in fact, there is overproduction capacity and storage difficulty.  So that is the question that is now being asked: is it, in fact, to take advantage of the competitive advantages that we have.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Greek bailout was once again the main issue at the European Council. An informal group has been formed along all the agreed structures of the European Union, with Mrs Merkel and Mr Tusk, Hollande, Juncker, Draghi and Dijsselbloem, who have made important decisions over the heads of others in this composition. We have approved a new aid to Greece, which is supposed to come from unused funds from the European Structural Funds. The Commission has even had to plunder funding for Horizon 2020, for European Basic Research, for the EFSI programme. Where do they suddenly get EUR 2 billion from? I urge clarification. That is no small matter, after all! And, as always, the problems will only be postponed into the future, whether by Mr Juncker, Mr Draghi or the other europeans who are not so sure about the law. The core problem is and remains the euro – "The Greek tragedy second part" writes a local newspaper in northern Germany. "However, the matter must be kept seriously, otherwise all the money that Greece has received is totally lost." This quote is 118 years old. Even then, Greece was lent money. We should finally learn from history!

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: – Mr President, the last European Council took many important decisions for Lithuania and other Member States of the European Union with regard to the Energy Union, the Juncker fund and our Eastern partners. The Energy Union, and especially the connection of the energy islands to the internal energy market, is the guarantee of our energy security. We must make every effort to see that President Juncker’s project, the European Fund for Strategic Investment, overcomes all the obstacles. In view of the Eastern Partnership Summit in Riga, we should send a strong signal to all our Eastern partners that we will continue to support their commitment to fundamental freedoms and values, and at least that we shall never recognise or forget the illegal annexation of Crimea, and that we shall give all possible political, economic and military support to Ukraine. We must remain united.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr. President, Virgin Mary, hail, the Lord after Sou. On the occasion of the double celebration, the Annunciation of the Virgin Mary and the revolution of the Greeks against the Turks in 1821, I wish all Greeks a happy birthday. The Eurogroup's results for Greece on 20 March are that Eurozone leaders agree with what they have already agreed on 20 February. Unfortunately, the Greek people do not know about what has been agreed. Let's speak the language of truth. The memorandum is still here, with additional measures, reforms and unilateral commitments and further bleeding of the Greeks. It just changed the language wrapper of the deal. Frankly, without a reduction in the co-financing of the Structural Funds, without a reduction in the interest rates on the loan facility, there is no provision for economic recovery and job creation. On the subject of Ukraine, let us take into account the will of the Ukrainian people. Either by free elections or by referendum and the results to be used to shape the common foreign policy of the European Union. With russia's announcements and aphorism policies, we are essentially strengthening the Minsk agreement, but also any attempt to resolve the problem peacefully.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to join, on behalf of the Spanish delegation of the People's Party, who have expressed their solidarity with the victims of yesterday's plane crash in the Alps – a tragedy that affects us as Europeans, which we are excited about as Europeans and which must be of concern to us as Europeans – and also to thank the French authorities for their efforts to collect the remains of the victims and to help that the investigation into this accident should be solved in the best possible way. I would also like to congratulate the Council on the agreement of the Energy Union on two reasons: first, because it will serve to make us fight better from Europe against climate change and come closer, stronger and more coordinated – which is important – to the Paris Summit, and secondly because it will help energy interconnections, which not only allow the energy islands to cease to be , but, through at least the Iberian Peninsula, gas from North Africa can reach the rest of Europe.  On the other hand, I also welcome the fact that the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy has been discussed and that it takes into account the danger posed by the establishment of terrorism in North Africa, in particular in Tunisia and Libya, and I request that a clear message be sent to terrorists at the next Summit on 'South Neighbourhood' in Barcelona on 13 April : Europe is going to be a wall, an impassable wall for terror and intolerance.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Mr President, the Energy Union must have as its central element an efficient and functioning internal energy market, ensuring growth and jobs, affordable and competitive prices for individual consumers and industrial consumers, and protecting vulnerable consumers. I believe that important steps have been taken by the Council to integrate energy efficiency between the five dimensions, but what is really missing in the Council's approach is the issue of energy poverty. The Commission wants to eliminate regulated prices, but this measure, in the absence of immediate and concrete action to support those affected by energy poverty, is 50 million people, could lead to a disastrous situation. Given that we are talking about the creation of a common energy market, I would like to ask whether it is also envisaged to create an energy dispatch, indispensable, in my view, for the real functioning of a single energy market in the European Union.
