Last but not least, I welcome the fact that all proposals for the creation of the Energy Union have as their major objective the lowering of the energy price, and we will support all these measures.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: – An agreement was reached at the EU Summit on the creation of a European Energy Union. In principle, the document recognises the autonomous right of Member States to decide their own energy mix. However, the practice is very different: the European Commission increasingly wants to give itself a say and a decision on the energy policy of each Member State. Among other things, it wants to be involved in a country's negotiations with third parties. The President of the EP has already stated that the Community institutions should play the decisive role in relation to the Energy Union, i.e. central decisions should be taken instead of the Member States. However, it should be made clear that the Energy Union should not be achieved through central directives, but in cooperation taking into account the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: – Mr President, let me pick up on a few of the conclusions and this time the glass is half full, rather than half empty. First, I want to commend the biological father of the Energy Union, President Tusk, and the legal father – absent now – Mr Juncker, for the Energy Union chapter. It is a newly born baby, it needs care, but it is good that we have started on that road looking towards the master plan for Energy Union for our prosperity and security. Key to the agreement in this part of the conclusions is the word ‘transparency’. It is obviously about gas contracts. We need to reinforce the European Commission competence. Imagine President Juncker sitting opposite President Putin, Putin knowing everything about our gas contracts and Juncker knowing nothing. It is grotesque. Do we want to refuse to put our side on an equal footing with our partners who are sometimes opponents? Russia sees our cards and we do not see theirs. The European Commission has the right to know what Moscow knows about our gas contracts. Energy independence is also important and, as is regularly stressed, so is the question of sovereignty of our choices in foreign affairs, and we see dangerous cracks there, where the principle of solidarity of the Member States is under threat. I want also to commend the European Commission and President Tusk for staying on course on Russian sanctions. It is not a final legal decision but it is important that it is clearly linked to the complete implementation of the Minsk Agreement and not just the ceasefire.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, it has to be said that it is good that the Council has dealt with the Energy Union, because I firmly believe that it is a project that can bring Europe forward. It is a project in which we can also show people that a European Union with 520 million inhabitants can have a common project, that we can organise progress and stand up for prosperity, because the world has changed in recent years.  We are over 7 billion people on this globe. If we want to generate energy security, but also want to tackle climate protection, and if we want to have a secure but also sustainable energy supply among ourselves, then this can only be done if we tackle things together. That is why we should look at what unites us in this project? I very much welcome the fact that the Commission has taken this initiative. We Social Democrats can agree on many of the things relating to the Energy Union, because the proposals are almost identical to the paper we have launched. There is still a lack of one or the other point, for example on the subject of innovation. As a continent, we are very capable of innovation in Europe. That is what we should also focus on and on the fact that we also have clear legislation at this point. We should not only talk about this, but we need clear legislation so that investors have certainty when they invest money in renewable energy, in sustainable forms of energy production. One thing is certain: every euro we spend now will be tied up for 30, 40, 50 years. That is why we must consider the course for innovation, for a sustainable energy supply and for a sustainable future for all 520 million Europeans.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: – Mr President, I sense a strong commitment for the Energy Union reflected by the Council conclusions. Prioritising the implementation of the third package, accelerating build-up of the PCIs; these are good signs of decisive action to counter the current risk of supply to the European Union. What lags behind, in my opinion, is changing the way our consumers access and perceive energy. Security and solidarity, once reached, must be followed immediately by functioning markets, otherwise we will keep our citizens tied to the paradigm of energy as a fixed price public service instead of a commodity. That is why I support accelerating the development of flexible regional markets for gas which replace bilateral agreements and long-term oil-indexed contracts. Regional cooperation must be streamlined towards aggregating liquidity and building trading hubs. Structured dialogue between national governments, regulatory authorities and TSOs should be facilitated continuously by the Commission and ACER, and deadlines should be set. Once we have succeeded in interconnecting pipelines and grids, we must succeed in interconnecting demand and supply for citizens and companies alike. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – I also agree with the importance of the Energy Union and, as I said, interconnections will help a lot to have higher quality energy, more security and markets can function, but for that they have to function as a system and a system is always limited by the weakest link. Do you not think that concrete actions are lacking in this decision on the Energy Union that will have to be implemented if any country does not cooperate with this strategy? (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: blue-card answer. – As I said, I salute the fact that we are going to accelerate implementation of the third package. I think the vision is right – an interconnected continent with multiple entry points – and if we add to this the market hubs then I think this is a good solution for everyone.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, I would like to refer to what were the discussions and decisions taken in this Council in the field of foreign policy and neighbourhood policy. I would like to begin by mentioning the importance of the decisions that have been taken on the Ukrainian issue, the contribution that the European Union wants to continue to make to the building of a genuine democratic state in Ukraine and, on the other hand, the decisions that have been taken on maintaining sanctions on Russia, without losing sight of the need to maintain an active dialogue with Russia as well. , since we must always have in perspective the need for a strategic partnership with our neighbour. It should also be noted the decisions that have been taken in relation to Libya and the call for a government of national unity to be rapidly constituted in that country, as well as all the considerations that have been made in relation to the Near and the Middle East, in particular in the context of the fight against terrorism, and from this point of view and in that context, I would like to stress here the importance of strengthening the European Union's cooperation with Tunisia. Tunisia is now a border site between civilization and barbarism. It is not the site of clash of civilizations, of a supposed Western civilization in the face of a supposed Muslim civilization. That's not what this is about.  It is truly a confrontation between civilizational values of universal expression and a barbarism that, in the name of Islam, has been imposed in that region. It was in Tunisia that the Arab Spring began and Tunisia has been the great example, the only one, unfortunately, to date, of a success in this process of democratization of an Arab society. What has happened in Tunisia in the last week, which has already been properly condemned and regretted here, must lead us to the notion that we must strengthen cooperation with Tunisia. The current Tunisian President, in an interview with a French newspaper, said that, despite all the rhetorical statements, many countries have not yet provided Tunisia with the support they had committed to and the European Union has special responsibilities and must turn in that direction. Finally, I would like to make a reference to what I consider very important: the decisions that have been taken on migration policy, creating the conditions to ensure the best reception of those who seek European land.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I would be interested to know from Mr Assis – since the digital single market is in the current negotiation – whether he also believes that we can finally abolish roaming surcharges for international roaming for the citizens of Europe. I believe that this would be very important for all of us to eliminate roaming surcharges for our consumers in 2015. Many of our citizens, over 140 million citizens, travel every year. Are you in favour of abolishing roaming surcharges this year?

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. " I fully agree with this concern. Of course, this could contribute to the implementation and affirmation of the European project. Europe is also moving forward in the European process by materialising these ambitions and expectations of the common of citizens, and it is clear that the maintenance of roaming charges are detrimental, in a very concrete way, and so what I can tell you, of course, is that I fully share their concerns and I also call on european governments to make progress , as soon as possible, in order to ensure what you have forethought.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, the results of the liberalisation of the energy sector are in sight. Myrific promises are confronted with harsh reality. The natural monopolies of energy production and distribution were first shredded and then privatized. Now, with the so-called energy union and the internal energy market, the conditions for the advancement of monopolistic concentration on a European scale are created. This is the pure and hard goal, no long as they seek to engage and adorn it with rhetoric that is just that, environmental rhetoric of efficiency and sustainability. Meanwhile, while the new private monopolies are scarcity with fabulous profits in Portugal, EDP last year again generated more than €1 billion in profits. Families, businesses are asphyxiated by an energy bill that has never been higher. However, the deep insistence on the same policies will not bring different results. Both the boosting of the economy and the sustainability of the energy model they require consists in the recovery of democratic public control over this strategic sector.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I have already repeatedly expressed support for the common energy market and the Energy Union. At this point I want to emphasize three things two of which have happened these days. Namely, Mr. Šefčovič was at the opening ceremony for the opening of the TANAP pipeline in Turkey, and this pipeline with its tap arm should be very important for many European countries.  I want to strengthen the interest in building TANAP and TAP, because I think it is a good way to solve the energy problem of one part of the European Union countries.  Secondly, we were recently in Serbia, Montenegro and Albania. I repeat and warn the Commission - the Balkans have tremendously high potentials, thousands of megawatt for renewable sources of hydropower.  Third: the construction of the NLG terminal on Krk, in the north of the Adriatic. I call on the Commission to support this project as well.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Juncker and gentlemen of the Commission, reality belies you, since the Troika continues to tighten the noose around Greece, causing credit suffocation. Yesterday, Draghi, continuing his blackmail policy, also legally banned Greek banks from buying additional Greek government bills. But the Euroworking group also rejected today, illegally, Greece's request to be reimbursed the 1.2 billion euros, which was returned to the EFSF by mistake by the FSF and the Greek government.  The Eurogroup also illegally continues to refuse to repay 1.9 billion euros of usury profits made by the ECB from Greek bonds.  Mr Juncker, today the Greek people are celebrating the revolution of 1821, which took place in order for Greece to regain its national independence. Be aware that the Greek people, inspired by the struggle of '21, are still fighting to regain their national independence today and to throw the Troika and the lenders out of our country.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – It is a pity that Mr Juncker has left, I wanted to ask him how we are going, how we are going, how the Commission is continuing to combat tax evasion and tax havens. But I will ask about two things, or I will say two things that are important from that last Council: that is the debate on the Energy Union and how we will proceed to Ukraine. I think that the Energy Union is one of the best projects ahead of us. It will be important for us to be able to make sure that the Commission is able to stand up and that the Council is able to confirm that the prices that come out of such a project for beneficiaries, for people who are often in a very difficult situation in life, will be acceptable and payable. So that it is not a project that benefits large companies, energy firms, but that it is a project for the benefit of citizens. And very briefly to Ukraine. Mr Tusk, the situation in Ukraine is indeed very bad; This time it is demonstrating against the government. It would indeed be in place if we created more space for Ukraine and if we were not limited to some kind of loans or just to the loans that we are now going to provide to Ukraine, but also to better assess this whole situation from that political point of view.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, we see that the spring summit dealt with many topics, namely from TTIP, the Energy Union, Libya, Tunisia, Ukraine. Many topics were also unavoidable on the agenda, but you still devoted yourself to one topic, which is the Energy Union and it is good practice to dedicate yourself mainly to one topic.  The Energy Union is a topic that is currently preoccupied with all of us, but it is not only about the more than 500 million Citizens of the European Union who are interested in this topic, but it is also about energy investments and it is very important to empower investors to make sure that europe can be invested safely.  I want to support Mr. Tusk's initial presentation. You said that structural reforms must first and foremost be done at national level. I really want to support you in this, because without structural reforms at the national level there will be no growth and development, and we are particularly interested in youth employment, i.e. unemployment, and I ask you to insist on it.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I only have a few remarks to make. First of all, I want to thank Mr Nuttall for devoting all the time he had today to the tragic events yesterday in France involving the Germanwings aircraft. I think he spoke on behalf of all of us and I want to thank him warmly for that. Secondly, many of the Members of the European Parliament have addressed the issue of the Energy Union today and I just want to start by saying there is a common thread between three of the main projects of this Commission – the Juncker plan, investment, the Energy Union and the digital single market. All three of them have as goals the creation of growth and jobs in Europe and not to do this in a traditional way. Because I believe that if Europe thinks it can win in this enormous global competition on the basis of competition on wages or of competition on production costs Europe will lose. Europe can only win if it wins on innovation, if it wins on sustainability, if it wins on making an early transition into sustainable energy resources and sustainable social relations as well, because sustainability is about energy, it is about the economy and it is about social relations.  I would like you to see these three projects connected to one another on that basis. I would like to underscore what has been said by many of your Members that the Energy Union is obviously meant to protect us against blackmail from outside energy sources and producers. Obviously it has a geopolitical importance but, apart from that, it also has the huge advantage of helping us in the transition – which is inevitable – to less dependency on fossil fuels and to a greater use of the huge potential of renewable energy, which does not only contribute to a better environment but which is also a driving force in innovation and creating a new form of jobs and a new form of productivity and a new form of economy for the European continent. Very concretely on the questions regarding VAT, this legislation has come into force recently but it was decided a long time ago. The Commission is carefully evaluating it in a very pragmatic way and obviously the Commission will never want this legislation to have adverse effects on small entrepreneurs who are very often at the cutting edge of creating new employment and creating new forms of business. We will very carefully evaluate the effects. If the effects are not the effects intended by the legislation, or simply not foreseen by the legislation at the time it was drafted because the economy has developed in the digital area in particular and developed far more quickly than we could have envisaged at the time seven years ago, or if there are adverse effects, then certainly the Commission will take that into account. The two speakers on behalf of the ECR can therefore be assured that this has certainly been taken on board and that we had started on it before Prime Minister Cameron raised the issue with us, but we certainly feel encouraged by the fact that he did.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I will be very brief because I know how heavy your agenda is today so I shall say just a few words. When it comes to the questions from Ms Grossetête, Ms Van Brempt and Ms Harms, you are absolutely right that all five dimensions of the Energy Union are important. They are interconnected and mutually reinforcing no doubt, including renewables of course. But at this European Council we have focused our discussions on some of these aspects, in particular energy security, but also the so-called ‘climate diplomacy’, because of the Paris Summit. You will know better than me that the EU took strategic decisions on climate policy for the first time in 2007, and in October 2014 we decided on the framework of climate policy until 2030. We will come back to it in the European Council in view of the outcome of the conference in Paris. You can be sure that it will be one of the most important things in my whole term. And you are absolutely right: I was too brief in my introductory remarks, especially when it came to the Energy Union, but I was given just five minutes and I always try to respect the rules and I am a guest here, so sorry about that. As regards the question from Mr Verhofstadt and this problem with informal meetings in Brussels, the informal meetings in Brussels and also during European Council meetings are not my invention. In fact this is the most common method of work in Brussels. We have dozens of informal meetings every day, especially during our meetings. I can assure you that such a meeting with Mr Tsipras, Chancellor Merkel, President Hollande and the institutions was not a decisive meeting and it was absolutely clear for all of them, and also for the audience and for Member States. What made it more important was that it was a clear request from Prime Minister Tsipras and not from the largest Member States. I have heard it said that France and Germany, as the two biggest Member States, requested this meeting but that is not true. It was the clear request of the Greek Government. The second point is that in fact the leaders of the eurozone Member States asked me – even begged me – to do everything to avoid the risk of confrontation at the highest political level. In fact it is my job to avoid political crises and misunderstandings. We were certainly not ready to take the final decisions at the highest political level. This was also clear from my partners in the eurozone. Regarding Russia, I would like to recall a short part of our conclusion. The European Council agreed that the duration of the restrictive measures against the Russian Federation, adopted on 31 July 2014 and enhanced on 8 September 2014, should be clearly linked to the complete implementation of the Minsk Agreements. You know my position and my opinion but, believe me, this is the highest common denominator today among the 28 Member States. I am in complete agreement with you that perhaps we need a more ambitious and more proactive policy towards Russia and Ukraine but today this kind of agreement is what is in fact possible. I am sure that we should not downplay the significance of these conclusions. There was a very tough discussion about complete implementation. My feeling is that these conclusions about sanctions are relatively tough if I compare them to the mood or atmosphere among some Member States. I feel responsible for this conclusion but I also feel satisfied. I know that in politics almost everything is about impressions and not about facts but, in this case – I mean Russia and Ukraine but also in the case of the Greek crisis – I think the facts are much more important than impressions. I am quite sure that the results of our meeting regarding these two very difficult issues are quite satisfactory.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. I thank the Council and the Commission for being with us here at the highest level. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. – Dear President, Commissioner, colleagues, solidarity is particularly emphasised in the context of the creation of the Energy Union. However, what is the basis for EU solidarity that Gazprom has begun to supply more gas to Italy and Germany after the Italian Prime Minister visited Russian President Putin on 5 March and the head of the German company Wintershall with the head of Gazprom? Does the political agreement on greater transparency in gas purchasing agreements mean that Member States will be obliged to provide the Commission with information on such agreements, or will this remain merely a political declaration? It is a pity that the declared solidarity between eu Member States does not yet mean the real implementation of projects and the united and truly solidarity-based positions and actions of the Member States.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Council seems to welcome the dire situation created by its own policies. It is a matter of being met, as every year, that more structural reforms are needed, that is, more and more deregulation and precariousness. With youth unemployment at 23% in the euro area, the EU's only response has been a timid guarantee, which the Court of Auditors has recently pointed out. Nothing is proposed for the training and qualification deficit of the southern eurozone countries and nothing can be proposed in the context of fiscal consolidation that is undermining growth. However, without a minimum of growth, any drop in unemployment is impossible. The European Council welcomes the Juncker plan, which is just a smokescreen leading to significant windfall effects, with no real increase in the overall amount of productive investment. Until the European Union makes the right diagnosis, and locks itself in a free-trade dogma, which even the most eminent theorists have warned about the disastrous consequences for the most vulnerable public at the end of their lives, the situation will not improve.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – The last European Council discussed very important issues for europe as a whole. Firstly, the European Council considered the Energy Union presented by the Commission, as it is necessary to ensure a secure, sustainable, inexpensive energy supply for all citizens. Our people, their households and businesses are increasingly concerned about making energy affordable and making prices competitive. Unfortunately, energy poverty has also increased during the economic crisis, because heating bills, electricity are huge and not all people are able to pay for them. The European Council has focused on energy security and calls for a strengthening of the legislative framework on security of electricity and gas supply. In addition, energy security can be strengthened by ensuring stable networks, more efficient use of energy and using local resources and secure and sustainable low-carbon technologies. The meeting also discussed the European Semester and the Annual Growth Survey for Employment. The European Council held an exchange of views on the economic situation in Europe and on the implementation of major structural reforms by Member States. It endorsed three main strands of the Annual Growth Survey, namely investment, structural reforms and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation, and asked Member States to reflect these priorities in their future national reform programmes and stability or convergence programmes.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. The conclusions of the European Council meeting of 19 and 20 March represent a step forward for the establishment of the Energy Union. In this respect, I think it is very important for the Council to indicate that it should speed up infrastructure projects for electricity and gas, including interconnections, with particular reference to peripheral regions. It is precisely in these regions and in the most disadvantaged rural areas that energy and gas infrastructure projects could not only ensure important progress towards the full integration of the European energy market, but also deploy considerable social and economic value, promoting job creation, long-term growth and the competitiveness of these areas.  The Council's reference to the importance of reducing emissions and developing the renewable energy market is also positive. I believe that there is no reference to the need to reduce the EU's dependence on the import of fossil fuels. I also believe that the Council has missed an opportunity to insist decisively on the need to support research in the field of energy. It is clear that an increase in investment in research is needed if the new generation renewable energy market is to develop satisfactorily.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. At their summit meeting on 19 and 20 March, European leaders addressed three main issues: energy, external relations and, of course, structural reforms related to the Greek issue. On the subject of energy and the energy union, the commitments, although positive, remain fairly vague for the time being. In addition to deciding to establish the first stages of the Energy Union, the commitment to investment in renewable energy and energy efficiency and, without special specification, to strengthening climate diplomacy in the run-up to the Paris Summit was reaffirmed. With regard to external relations, the leaders decided, as expected, to align the current sanctions regime with the implementation of the Minsk agreements, but the real hot spot remains Greece. The solution cannot be the punishment of the Greek people and the imposition of repeated austerity measures, which have shown their inadequacy to deal with the crisis throughout Europe, but a revision of the Stability and Growth Pact, starting with the 3% rule with regard to the debt-to-GDP ratio.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. The conclusions adopted by the European Council on 19 and 20 March, which endorse the European Commission's framework strategy for achieving an Energy Union, represent a further and encouraging step in defining a forward-looking climate and energy policy launched by the European Union in recent months. As we know, the main problems in this respect remain energy dependence, the fragmentation of energy markets and low investment in interconnections and infrastructure.  As clearly detailed in the Council communication and conclusions, the European energy solution brings together, with a unified glance, all the issues and issues inevitably concerned: environmental sustainability, energy availability, security of supply, energy efficiency, the role of research and innovation, the decarbonisation of the economy and investment in infrastructure. In this respect, we must focus on internal interconnections, and at the same time on diversification of supplies, looking not only to the East but also to the south of Europe's borders. The ENVI Committee, of which I am a member, and Parliament welcome the progress made and will continue to work towards the completion and functioning of the energy market and with a view to COP21 in Paris at the end of the year.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. – The European Union's intention to create the Energy Union should aim to ensure energy security for all EU countries. The European Council quite rightly stressed the EU's obligation to protect the energy reserves of its member countries, which at the same time constitute the energy reserves of the EU itself. It is therefore a basic obligation of the EU to protect in every way the energy reserves located in the Exclusive Economic Zones of member countries.  Unfortunately, turkey is creating a climate of instability and challenges in the Eastern Mediterranean region. Clearly, Turkey is violating the Cyprus EEZ and the sovereign rights of Cyprus, an EU member country. The European Union must, if it really means the European Energy Union in practice, safeguard the European Energy Reserves in every way and send a clear signal of strict sanctions to Turkey.  At the same time, I must denounce Turkey's intention to set up a nuclear power station in Akuyu, a seismic region, endangering the whole region. The fact that Turkey also despises everyone on this issue should concern the EU, in which Turkey is a candidate country.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The European Council has endorsed the European Commission's new energy initiatives. The Council and Parliament must now work and take responsibility for making the Energy Union an ambitious and responsive response to the challenges of energy security, business competitiveness, the transition to a low-carbon economy and finally energy insecurity. Reading the Council's findings, everyone can measure the scope of the challenge this project poses. There is a need to better coordinate disparate and divergent energy policies in network and supply infrastructure, while respecting the competence of Member States in choosing their energy mix. In addition, a common policy framework should be provided adapted to the diversity of energy produced in Europe, from North Sea wind power and Spanish mountains to Latin solar energy, not to mention French nuclear power. Finally, it is necessary to propose public and private funding to meet our ambitions, with the Commission estimating the cost of the Energy Union at 2 trillion by 2025. So here's the content of the challenges that lie ahead and the responsibility we have.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – In the context of the Conclusions of the European Council, I need to talk about the implementation of the Energy Union and the EU's plan to tackle global climate change. I agree with the encouragement of the greatest possible interconnection of European energy networks (in particular gas and electricity lines). Many Member States are severely dependent on energy from certain third countries, which significantly reduces their margins in energy procurement. A country's independence depends to a large extent on its energy dependency, so diversification of energy supplies must be in the fundamental interest of all EU Member States. The important thing is that the EU can provide substantial support for the interconnection of energy networks. It is not a good sign that the so-called "1990s" To finance the Juncker Investment Package, the Commission would realrare a significant amount from the budget of the European Network Finance Facility, which finances the achievement of this objective.  On the other hand, I welcome the fact that the Communication sets out as a priority objective the development of energy efficiency and the strong incentive for the transition to renewable energy production. However, the Commission should refrain from taking any action to prevent the use of renewable energies. For example, we should not limit the planting of useful types of wood that provide biomass raw material, the production of first-generation bioethanol produced from surplus yields, or support for combustion-efficient biomass boilers.  Finally, I do not agree with the significant involvement of agriculture in the scope of the greenhouse gas emission reduction target. Agriculture is responsible for only 10% of emissions, but a significant reduction in emissions, in particular as far as ammonia and methane are concerned, would result in the collapse of European livestock production and a reduction in crop production.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – The Automatic Exchange of Information Between Member States Directive adopted in 2014 covers interest and dividends on accounts and profits from the sale of financial assets. However, it does not include (mostly secret) tax rulings between Member States and multinationals, which is what Lux Leaks has revealed. The Commission proposes to amend Directive 2011/12/EU to extend this automatic exchange of information to tax agreements. In this way, such decisions by tax administrations in favour of undertakings will have to be communicated automatically to all Member States and to the Commission. The proposal has a retroactivity of ten years and no trade or professional secrecy can be claimed so as not to provide the information. It is a positive and necessary measure, but the current proposal has some weaknesses: the information exchanged will not be accessible by citizens; the obligation to exchange is conditional on a cross-border impact of tax arrangements, which may be an escape route; the obligation only affects legal persons (natural persons such as high-ranking actors or footballers could sign such agreements); sanctions are not specified in case of non-compliance with the exchange obligation

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The Energy Union project is nothing new. This is a set of regulations so far. It's an unsolvable single equation with many unknowns. At the same time, can priorities such as energy security, global competitiveness and climate protection be ed up, without modifying the climate and energy package that discriminates against certain countries (e.g. Poland).  A better law guaranteeing energy security is needed, free from existing lobbying influence. Security based on increased energy efficiency and the use of local energy sources is the only recipe for Europe to regain global competitiveness. The real technical efficiency index, rather than the reduction in energy use, as is clear from the current Directive, should become an essential tool for achieving climate objectives. To this end, a directive on energy use must be rewritten, taking into account the physical approach to the efficiency of conversion and generation processes, transmission (efficient networks, pipelines and storage) and end-use (construction and utility equipment).  On the other hand, gross energy efficiency calculated for individual Member States should be calculated using an indicator that takes into account the GDP of those countries (according to Eurostat) at the beginning and end of the calculation period. The EU ETS also needs to be improved as the existing system is inconsistent and does not take into account many factors, including the active impact of technical performance indicators in sectors and the share of RES used to reduce the need to purchase allowances.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The conclusions of the European Council of 19 and 20 March highlighted the framework strategy for the Energy Union and the preparation of the UN Climate Change Conference in Paris this December. The political framework set by the Heads of State or Government continues to place energy union legislation under the responsibility of the Member States and set out a number of principles that are of particular importance for the Hungarian energy strategy. Firstly, the price of energy, the affordability of energy, are sufficiently weighted in the conclusions. The text also states, at the level of principle, that the composition of a country's energy resources should be kept under national competence. Finally, it is to be welcomed that the conclusions specifically emphasise support for energy infrastructure development, which includes better use of existing networks.  Although the concrete legislative proposals implementing the framework strategy are yet to follow, the idea of an Energy Union can be fundamentally supported by these principles. Finally, with regard to the 21st UN Climate Conference, I think it is important to reiterate that the global fight against climate change can only be effective in the future if other developed countries and the major emitters currently developing make ambitious commitments comparable to the EU before the 2015 Paris Conference. The EU has already done its own homework when it has committed to a uniquely high 40% reduction in emissions in line with the 2030 climate and energy framework. Now it's the others' turn.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – Renewed commitment to creating an EU Energy Union is too crucial in the new security situation to be watered down by typical national differences. A working Energy Union means developing coherent energy diplomacy, based on EU core values. I call for the synchronisation of the Baltic states’ energy systems with European continental networks to be speeded up. Remembering the first anniversary of the Russian annexation of Crimea, the EU must take care that this outrageous act against international order will not be overshadowed by further fighting in eastern Ukraine. I congratulate President Tusk on having achieved the highest common denominator in applying restrictions on Russia. However, the slightest rift in unity, or any nervous attempt to shortcut the way back to Realpolitik, could encourage Putin to continue his brinkmanship. We are at a breaking point. Sanctions have started to make an impact. Therefore I encourage all hesitant Member States to make EU policy vis-a-vis Russia more united, more ambitious and more pro-active, to use President Tusk’s terms. The EU has to keep the sanctions going until the Minsk Agreements are fully implemented. That implementation must include Crimea, which was not mentioned by name in Minsk.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. The hungarian prime minister's position on national sovereignty threatens the very ambitious Commission proposal for a European Energy Union. It is no coincidence that several major European newspapers reported disagreements between the Visegrad Four prior to the European summit because of the Hungarian government's pro-Russian energy policy. It is no coincidence that the new Central and Eastern European cooperation with Austria, the Czech Republic and Slovakia is being shaped by the omission of the current Hungarian Government. The Energy Union proposal came to light at an important moment. Russia's territorial aggression against Ukraine, the conflict in eastern Ukraine, has highlighted that Russia is no longer a reliable partner for Europe. Therefore, we cannot build on Russia the security of the eastern half of Europe, Hungary energy supply. We need to establish an Energy Union as soon as possible, guaranteeing EU unity over Russia and transparency in energy supply contracts concluded by Member States.  With regard to energy supply and gas contracts, the Commission's preliminary norm control is the only guarantee that the leaders of the Member States will not conclude agreements with Russia that break up EU unity and at the mercy of member states' energy supplies. I therefore welcome President Tusk's proposal, in which he broke stick with the full transparency of both intergovernmental and trade treaties and the prior eu norm control of the treaties.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Council is once again gargling the pitiful results of its own policies. Here we find the endless exhortations: more and more structural reforms, which will obviously lead to more deregulation and precariousness. It should be remembered that youth unemployment is as high as 23% in the euro area, and that, in the face of this disaster, the EU is offering a slight guarantee, which the Court of Auditors has just listed. In addition, there are no proposals on the lack of training and qualification in the southern countries of the euro area. The main difficulty is the context of fiscal consolidation, which is a drag on any recovery in growth. However, without a minimum of growth, any drop in unemployment is clearly impossible. The European Council, on the other hand, is reassured by the Juncker plan, which is merely an illusion leading to significant windfall effects, without any real increase in the overall amount of productive investment. To save the euro, the European Union has sacrificed a generation. The EU is incapable of making the right diagnosis, obsessed with ultraliberal dogma, which even the most eminent theorists have warned about the disastrous consequences for the most vulnerable audiences at the end of their lives.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – A number of topics were addressed at the European Council from 19 to 20 March 2015, including the issue of a common energy policy. This issue so important for the future of Europe must become a priority on the European Union's agenda and a mechanism to foster cooperation and solidarity between Member States. Such a common energy policy must mean the following elements: - a negotiated common import tariff for gas, oil and other energy sources imported by Member States outside the European area. This will lead to a reduction in treatment inequalities for Eastern European countries, which pay up to 7 times the price of imported energy resources. - fight against inequalities by protecting economically disadvantaged consumers.  Consequently, subsidising access to energy for low-income people and implementing a common and negotiated timetable for the evolution of the tariffs applied must become a European priority, so as not to create new means by which groups or regions are excluded from the benefits of a fairer and greener common market. I therefore support the steps taken by the European Commission and the European Council and hope for the swift implementation of these energy market balancing measures as soon as possible.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I am of the opinion that the course chosen to lead the European Council on EU policy towards Russia of the last year is not delivering the desired results and needs to change.  At a time when our citizens, especially those engaged in agriculture and tourism, expect decisions and policies to support and protect us, the European Council is dragging us into a new cycle of sanctions extensions. They suffer from relations not only at management level, but also millions of citizens and entire economic sectors, especially in Europe. Farmers from my country - Bulgaria, who took the news with fear because they remember what happened after the application of similar sanctions last year - have fallen into relentless competition with thousands of other European farmers for the extremely insufficient compensation exhausted in days. It is our responsibility to banish this fear and give them back the confidence that better times will come for them very soon. Solidarity is becoming more and more alien in the European Union, and the rift between the decisions taken by some European politicians and the real problems and needs of the average European is growing. Solutions must be sought for the good of the average citizen and applied in practice as soon as possible.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - I welcome the conclusions of the European Council meeting reaffirming the EU's commitment to creating an Energy Union based on energy security, solidarity and trust, an integrated European energy market and energy efficiency that contributes to consumption cuts, decarbonisation of the economy, research, innovation and competitiveness. Accelerating infrastructure projects is essential, with the aim of ensuring energy security and a well-functioning internal energy market. It is also important to bring existing national legislation into line with EU energy law and ensure its full implementation and application, especially when it comes to buying gas from external suppliers. The development of a more efficient, flexible market model should monitor enhanced regional cooperation and help integrate renewable energy sources. On external relations, I welcome the commitment to strengthen relations with neighbours and to focus the EU's commitment to its eastern and southern partners. As regards Russia-Ukraine relations, the European Council called on all parties to swiftly and fully implement the Minsk agreements and to respect the commitments made and stressed the responsibility of the Russian authorities in this regard. In relation to Libya, the EU has shown readiness with countries in the region and international partners, to contribute to the implementation of agreements on the formation of a government of national unity, making full use of all its instruments, which is important for democratic processes in the country.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. - I welcome the Council conclusions adopted at last week's meeting on topics that will largely define the future of the European project. This applies primarily to the Energy Union, which has the potential to upgrade the political integration of the Union with the energy one aimed at achieving, in particular, energy security. I hope that the Union's energy policies will be included in the neighbourhood policy review and will be a strong factor in the continuation of the enlargement policy. I am pleased that the Council supported this proposal and I hope that support for this project will be followed by an increase in investments and funds to already existing energy projects. Two existing projects of great importance for Croatia and the neighbourhood are both the LNG terminal on Krk and the Adriatic-Ionian pipeline. One way to achieve this is the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which was also endorsed by the Council at this meeting to be operational as early as the middle of this year. As regards the TTIP negotiations, I appreciate the Council's constructive approach and once again want to stress that the free movement of capital should be preceded by full visa reciprocity and free movement of all Citizens of the Union. Finally, I am pleased that the Council has also recognised the seriousness of the problem of migrant casualties at the union's southern borders, and I hope that the European Agenda for Migration, which we expect in May, will offer adequate solutions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. - The European Council dealt with very important topics. One of the most important was the Energy Union strategy presented by Commission Vice-President Maroš Šefčovič, which will play an important role in Europe's future. Diversification of energy sources, emission reductions, energy efficiency, new technologies and innovations in energy and climate will bring economic growth and savings for both large and small energy consumers. The European Council also addressed an issue that employs both the people of Europe and the media every day. It's a war conflict in Ukraine. I am therefore very glad that the European Council called on all parties involved in this conflict to implement the Minsk agreements quickly and fully and to fulfil their commitments. Monitoring and verifying the implementation of the Minsk agreements must become part of the EU's agenda in order to respond correctly to the duration, strengthening or repeal of restrictive measures against the Russian Federation.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. – Progress on building the Energy Union was the most important event of the last European Council. The proposals on the functioning of the Energy Union are only at a very early stage so far, so their possible harmfulness will depend, in particular, on the specific application of these proposals. In particular, I welcome the removal of the various administrative barriers between countries in the framework of the construction of the Energy Union. However, a great deal of emphasis on 'energy efficiency', which in practice leads to the adopting of absurd regulations, or a great deal of emphasis on the pointless rigour of climate objectives, will be very difficult to benefit the EU economy.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. – Energy union and foreign policy: these are the issues at the heart of the European Council's work, as usual, more attentive to front rhetoric than to the search for credible solutions to revive the economy.  The summit merely endorsed the old approach to the crisis based on structural reforms, private capital and fiscal consolidation (read: austerity), while the Greek issue was addressed on the sidelines of official meetings, silently, after dinner, among a select few leaders. A way of reiterating that the crisis is the sole responsibility of the Greeks and not a matter of common interest, ignoring any link with the austerity imposed with the adjustment programmes, financial speculation or macroeconomic imbalances of the euro.  Yet this summit could be an opportunity to completely review economic governance, to relaunch a strategy against poverty and unemployment, and to start, at the highest political level, a multilateral discussion on the solution of the Greek and eurozone crises, considering all options, including exiting the euro and restructuring sovereign debts.  Unfortunately, the absence of these issues during the summit increasingly convinces me that the basic problem is the continuing inertia of the institutions, the lack of political will and a sense of responsibility. Which is perhaps even more difficult to correct than a liquidity shortage.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The European Council held an exchange of views on the economic situation in Europe in its conclusions and the implementation of the key structural reforms undertaken by the Member States. The European Council again insists on the three main pillars of the Annual Growth Survey (investment, structural reforms and growth-friendly fiscal consolidation) and urges Member States to pass on these priorities in their forthcoming national reform programmes and stability or convergence programmes. This shows that governments remain blind to the social and political reality of Europe, dominated by unemployment, the spread of poverty and the lack of growth prospects. We need a europe that is for citizens, not a Europe tied to the interests of large multinational companies and the financial sector.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The conclusions of the European Council and the Commission of 19 and 20 March 2015 cover a number of important issues for the European Union. Firstly, they concern the Energy Union, which is undoubtedly an important element of the common policy of the Member States. The European Council rightly stressed the importance of accelerating infrastructure work, including the creation of a connection with the outermost regions in order to build a secure internal energy market.  The European Semester, in which the European Council raised a very important topic of EU-US negotiations on the TTIP Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, is also the subject of a statement. The ambitious objective to conclude the ongoing negotiations on a comprehensive and mutually beneficial agreement by the end of the year has been rightly underlined.  The last topic, no less important, contained in the conclusions, is the EU's external relations. Certainly, the ongoing review of the European Neighbourhood Policy should ensure continued engagement with both the European Union's eastern and southern partners in order to strengthen cooperation on mobility, market opportunities and interconnections.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on fiscal policy: – Commission statement on the decision taken on fiscal transparency policy (2015/2601(RSP)) – report by Eva Kaili, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Annual Report on Taxation (2014/2144(INI)) (A8-0040/2015).

name: Eva KAILI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, one of the major challenges of the annual tax report for this year was to employ a more political view on the subject rather than just following the standard path of doing business as usual. The emergence of the LuxLeaks cases during the drafting period has vindicated our view and compelled a political response. It was necessary for the Parliament to take a political position and not to pretend that nothing had happened. This annual tax report is the standard vehicle of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on tax issues. The interest shown in it by MEPs is proved by the numerous amendments tabled on the issue, urging a clear political message. There was a wide range of proposals. More specifically, we can underline the focus on issues related to the requirement for social justice in tax policies. There was widespread concern about the taxation of capital, the taxation of income resources from interest payments, dividends and security returns, as well as on the control of financial vehicles used to facilitate tax evasion. In the same vein, the financial transaction tax still remains very popular. Many colleagues made proposals on its enhancement and expansion, as well as on the use of its proceeds to augment either the EU budget or the fund for climate change and even the European Fund for Strategic Investment. Moreover, the discussion indicated the persistent concern of the Parliament about corporation taxation, especially the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) and the minimum corporate tax contributions. There were many proposals which linked taxation to the competitiveness of European firms, as well as amendments on the way in which SMEs are taxed. Finally, the Parliament is still divided between those who favour coordination and those who favour harmonisation. The recurring coordination failures – as SwissLeaks and LuxLeaks also indicate – prompted many of our colleagues to stress the importance of more harmonisation on tax issues, using the European Semester, and other issues such as access to funding for honest taxpayers. The Parliament, as indicated in the compromise process, attempted to show a responsible stance with very strong support for a set of policies for assisting the fight against aggressive tax planning, tax avoidance and tax evasion, as well as policies to minimise the tax gap. There is also widespread understanding of the necessity for good governance in tax matters, for simple tax systems and tax policies that encourage entrepreneurship, strengthen competitiveness and support SMEs, and, moreover, understanding of the social consequences of tax policies, especially for economically weaker people. There are also issues that we can discuss further in the future, so as to share common ground for common policy initiatives. These issues include a definition of tax havens, sanctions against those who assist in tax fraud, country-by-country reporting, the OECD’s Base Erosion and Profit Shifting, the FTT, and shifting the tax burden from labour. One of the most important contested issues concerned the automatic exchange of information for making tax ruling practices and non—transparent agreements between Member States and multinationals apparent. So, in the light of current developments and public concern, it is extremely important for the Parliament to show its firm stance against any non—transparent practice that reduces legal certainty for taxpayers and distorts intra-market competition. We welcome the Commission’s prompt proposal on tax transparency to fight tax evasion and avoidance, which stresses that the provision of information can no longer be refused on the grounds of inappropriate disclosure of information and of commercial, industrial or professional secrecy. However, we must be very sceptical so long as the set of consequences for those who do not comply is not explicitly identified. Overall, despite the disagreement, we can say that the annual tax report is clear, coherent and focused, and that it lays the basis for a relevant, timely, fair, transparent, socially responsible and business-friendly tax policy for the European Union.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for giving me the opportunity to have an exchange on taxation in Europe with you. The annual report on taxation, which we are discussing today, provides a diagnosis that I fully share. The picture of corporate and personal taxation in Europe is both illegible and too inefficient. The lack of coordination of Member States' tax practices and rules poses fundamental problems for the Whole of the Union. First, tax rules too often segment the internal market in such a way that most European or foreign companies do not have full access to it and face obstacles that hinder their growth opportunities. Second, tax authorities are no longer able - or less able - to properly collect the tax they are owed. Some taxpayers engage in aggressive tax planning to take advantage of the differences and inconsistencies that exist between tax systems. Moreover, it is clear that the Member States themselves are engaged in excessive competition to attract the most mobile tax bases. Thirdly, in the face of the revelation of this inice system, which benefits the most powerful, to the detriment of all others, and which is no longer tolerated because it is no longer tolerable, consent to tax is fading. It is the very heart of the social contract between the citizen and the public authorities that is at stake. We are therefore facing a critical situation that calls for swift and far-reaching action. My goals are the same as yours. First of all, we must restore fiscal justice within the Union and the Member States. Finally, we need to create a real internal tax market, a transparent and predictable framework for businesses to invest and for consumers to regain confidence. And, finally, we need to put taxation at the service of the Union's political priorities, whether it is the digital single market - the Commission was talking about this morning - or the Energy Union. The solutions exist and some have already been known to us for several years. Their implementation will require a commitment from all and, first of all, from most Member States, which have the final say on these issues and who will have to agree on the ambitious solutions we will propose to them. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has made the fight against fraud and tax evasion a top political priority for this Commission and I would like to dwell for a moment on this point. The European Commission, as you know, has just taken a series of strong measures to improve tax transparency in the Union with, first of all, a proposal for a directive on the exchange of information on rulings or - in French - tax rulings. The aim is to make available to all Member States information on the impact of their partners' decisions on their own tax bases, which goes hand in hand with a commitment to promote transparency, beyond tax rulings, so that the European Union remains a pioneer in terms of overall tax transparency. One possibility could be - as you recommend in the annual tax report - to extend to all sectors the current requirement, made to certain industries in the European Union, to make public certain financial information country by country. This is a debate that the Commission is prepared to have with Parliament. The Commission has not yet made a decision on how best to proceed, which will require further analysis, but it intends to work hard to carry out this analysis, which remains a necessary prerequisite for future common positions. The question of where profits should be taxed is also particularly relevant in the European Union, because of its unique characteristics such as the existence of an area with a single currency and an internal market with twenty-eight different tax systems. We have our own rules, our own priorities and our own goals. The Union can draw on the useful work provided by the OECD, but it cannot rely solely on its work. The Commission's work programme for 2015 foresees that it will present, in the light of global developments, an action plan for corporate taxation in the single market, where profits will have to be taxed more systematically where value is created, to bring production closer to taxation. This action plan will help to restart discussions on the ACCIS (or CCCTB) project, which is expected to harmonize the taxable base for many companies operating at the cross-border level in the European Union. This would not only make the internal market more competitive, but also limit the possibilities of corporate tax manipulation, which is a priority for us. This should also include shorter-term actions to enable the EU to implement the solutions that have been agreed at the global level, particularly at the G20 level. It is expected that the Commission will adopt this action plan - the second phase of our approach - before the summer, at the beginning of June, I think. I am sure that your House, through the work carried out in the TAXE and ECON committees, will contribute positively to the preparation of this action plan. I would like to say a few more words on two subjects. First, the financial transaction tax. The implementation of an ambitious tax framework on national financial transactions is a priority that the Commission shares with this Parliament, as outlined by President Juncker in his policy guidelines. Indeed, the Commission encourages tax reforms that involve those who have benefited from costly rescue policies and that broaden the tax base and reduce the tax burden on labour. I welcome the fact that at the last Ecofin Council in January, the Member States participating in enhanced cooperation reiterated their desire to create the conditions for the implementation of a harmonised European national FTT framework from 1 January 2016. I also note that the Member States of Enhanced Cooperation have stated that national FTTs should be based on the broadest possible taxable basis with low rates, while taking into account their impact on the real economy and the risks of relocation. The Commission's services have always offered and will continue to offer technical support to Member States in order to reach an agreement quickly, in a spirit of openness to compromise, while defending the fundamental principles of the Commission's proposal. Finally, with regard to indirect taxes, I would like to point out that the Commission intends to present, during this mandate, a series of reforms to the VAT system to improve its functioning, to reduce its administrative burden in order, in particular, to adopt a definitive VAT regime. The Commission favours and will favour a comprehensive approach because the introduction of scattered ad hoc measures could, particularly in the light of the negotiations in the Council, lead to inconsistent solutions, or even to achieve - we know how it works - any solution. This also applies to thinking about VAT rates. I would like to thank Mrs Kaili for her excellent report and to remind you that I am at Parliament's disposal so that we can move forward together on this essential subject. On 30 March, I will have an exchange with the special COMMITTEE TAXE in the spirit that must dominate, namely the spirit of transparency and collaboration between us.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to welcome the European Commission's new initiative on the tax transparency package. I am convinced that the introduction of automatic exchange of information between Member States on tax rulings meets the requirement of citizens, and they want one simple and fair thing: the taxation of profits to occur in the country where they were made and not to be transferred to another country by individual tax decisions or by accounting fireworks. We are also looking forward to the new action plan that the European Commission has promised against tax evasion and tax avoidance. Secondly, I would like to thank Mrs Kaili, the rapporteur, and the other colleagues with whom we have worked very well in finalising this report. I would like to highlight one important sentence in this report: only through close cooperation between Member States, between Member States and third countries, will we be able to make substantial progress in the fight against tax evasion and the removal of profits.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Commissioner, in my country, Portugal, as in many others, a small company that has managed to survive the crisis, in addition to hardly getting credit, has to pay 23% tax on its profits. At the same time, several large multinational companies, such as Amazon, Starbucks or IKEA, are reportedly able to pay fees of just over 1%, playing with the tax differences between the States of the European Union. By example, if my country does not get enough tax revenue to cover essential expenditure on education, health or old age support, it runs the risk of paying a fine that could rise to 0.5% of GDP for non-compliance with economic governance rules.  However, 19 of the 20 largest Portuguese companies, of which they could most contribute their tax contributions to balance these public accounts, chose to move their place of office to the Netherlands or Luxembourg in order to benefit from the tax advantages offered to them. This practice of tax dumping between countries that share the same market and the same currency becomes unbearable to citizens. The recent proposal by the European Commission makes it mandatory to exchange information between EU countries on tax optimisation practices. It is a step in the right direction that I recognise and thank Commissioner Moscovici, but it is still insufficient. There are a number of measures that need to be taken to combat tax havens, to harmonise the tax base for businesses, to report from country to country. And the effort that is being demanded of citizens also requires that we have a determination in advancing these dossiers. The European Parliament is fully determined to contribute to this new form of tax treatment and we sincerely hope, in addition to the support of civil society, in addition to the support of the Commission, that we will have the same spirit of convergence on the part of the Council. Citizens are what they demand and that is the answer that we have today to give.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Although we have harmonised taxes within the European Union, such as VAT and excise duties, and non-harmonised taxes, such as corporate and personal income taxes, both of these tax areas are very unfavourable. I would like to draw attention to only two points. VAT fraud in most EU countries is already tens of billions of euros per year and is increasing every year. Moreover, there are an increasing number of so-called carousel offences, consisting in multiplying invoices for the sale of goods or services between companies from different countries without carrying out actual transactions and on this basis vat extortion. Increasingly, Member States are defending themselves against this so-called reverse VAT fraud, but this distorts the idea of this tax. In the area of income taxes, we have seen great tax optimisation by large corporations with the participation of luxembourg's tax authorities. My country's budget on these optimizations has lost about 4 billion a year. I hope that the automatic exchange of information proposed by the Commission will bring this optimisation to an end.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – When I indicated a few years ago that I was interested in tax issues, I was a little wary of it, because it was just a dull and dusty subject and it was not politically exciting at all. That has changed dramatically in these days, but I cannot say that the reason for this is so positive. Unfortunately, it was all caused by LuxLeaks and we are now in a situation where ordinary citizens are all worried about the fact that they feel that they have to pay much more tax - the same goes for small business owners - than the big multinationals do. Looks like they're slipping through the cracks. I think it is very good that we are now using the momentum to take steps forward, and that at least requires us to know exactly what we are talking about. We need to have the right definitions together, because in the debate both tax avoidance and tax avoidance and tax avoidance are mixed up. Everything is used interchangeably. The definition of tax haven, what exactly do we mean by that? We must make good agreements on this, so that we can talk about the same thing. We very much welcome the Commission's current proposal for greater transparency. Because to know what you're talking about, that transparency is desperately needed. I do have one more question for the Commission. We all know that this problem is a global problem and not just limited to Europe, so to what extent do you also talk to other major powers about transparency on tax deals?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, the least we can say about tax policy today is that it is inefficient and unfair. What we have seen in recent years, particularly in the crisis years, and this becomes more shocking associated with austerity, has been in the name of competitiveness a huge fall in capital tax, whether in profits or in revenues. In the name of so-called fiscal consolidation, we have seen an incredible increase in the tax rate of both labour and consumption, which, coupled with austerity and recession, has only had very devastating consequences for the periphery of the euro zone. And the result is that, when it's as far as the distribution of income and wealth is, we've become increasingly unequal. We have also seen aggressive tax practices, we have seen scandals associated with tax avoidance and fraud, as well as tax evasion, and we have seen that Lux Leaks is just the tip of the iceberg. European Commission figures show that European citizens lose a trillion euros a year as a result of tax avoidance practices. As we have seen, every year too, there is a permanent injustice. Nineteen of the twenty largest companies in Portugal moved their head to the Netherlands or Luxembourg so as not to pay so much tax. We are in fact witnessing tax dumping.  The package that the Commission is now proposing on tax transparency brings nothing new. These are measures that have existed since 1977 and which the Commission has not implemented. And calling transparency for the exchange of information between tax authorities is, at the very least, exaggerated. Transparency was to be public.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, to the surprise of many, tax has become an issue of great interest during the past year. As corporations and wealthy individuals have found ever more intricate ways to avoid paying their fair share, taxation has become divorced from economic activity and, as a result, public coffers have been starved of revenue and governments have been unable to invest in necessary infrastructure or provide support for their needy citizens. We have reached the stage where it is vital for the protection of our civilised societies that we address the issue of tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. Tax avoidance is also undermining the single market, as the Commissioner pointed out. Transnational corporations are able to cut sweetheart deals with governments and to organise transfer pricing deals that could never be possible for the small businesses that are the backbone of our local communities across the European Union. In our role as the voice of small business and strong local economies, Greens demand that completing the single market should include the requirement of fair taxation across the Union, to ensure fair competition between small businesses and multinationals. In November last year, after the emergence into the public domain of the scandalous deals that had been agreed by President Juncker while he was Prime Minister of Luxembourg, there was a motion for the removal of the whole Commission. However, in spite of deep concerns about certain Commissioners, the Greens’ position was that they should be given a chance to resolve these problems before being dismissed. We challenged Juncker to ‘act or go’. Last week, we saw the Commission’s proposed action and it will not surprise you to know that we were deeply disappointed. The proposal on information exchange between Member States is necessary and welcome, clarifying an obligation which has existed since the 1970s but which has not been properly applied. If it had been applied, it would have ensured that scandalous ‘tax rulings’ could not have been kept concealed. However, this is only one of a number of measures that could and should be introduced to improve transparency on taxation. So I am pleased to welcome the many strong statements focused on addressing the issue of tax competition and tax avoidance included in this year’s annual tax report, especially the repeated call for a compulsory common consolidated tax base. I also welcome the establishment of the special committee to investigate tax affairs across the union. However, as a Green, I was deeply disappointed that, in this year that will culminate in the Paris negotiations on climate change, our most important amendments – calling for ecological taxation, the ending of tax advantages and exemptions granted to the aviation industry, and the phasing out of other fossil fuel subsidies – were rejected. We should all remember that tax, when used strategically, can provide incentives to move our communities towards the sort of future we imagine for our children, a future of sustainability and justice.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we were told that something had to be done after the LuxLeaks scandal, that the Commission would do its fully to combat the problem of tax evasion and tax avoidance favoured by some Member States, as we all knew. Mr Juncker himself, as a great expert in the field, with years of practice in Luxembourg, had guaranteed that he would make a first-hand effort to combat these phenomena which not only harm the Member States but undermine the very concept of the European Union, which is also shown in this area to be a union of mere façade, in which countries only try to impose themselves on each other by more or less lawful means. We would therefore have expected very different measures from those proposed by Commissioner Moscovici last week. The crux of the matter continues to be ignored, either through incapacity or bad faith: the fact that these systems, transparent or not, are in fact legal. We need truly incisive solutions, we cannot confine ourselves to a simple obligation to exchange information between States, while excluding citizens from access to these documents. That is not what we need! There is only one fundamental issue: if the rules are not changed and these practices continue to be formally legal, the situation will never change and we will continue to discuss indefinitely more transparency or less transparency and cooperation, without ever resolving anything. I therefore wonder, together with 500 million European citizens, whether there really is a political will to resolve this distortion. What is the point of talking about a united and united Europe when these practices are allowed?

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The European Union's motto is diversity, but in every case, I repeat, on every issue we demand totalitarian unification. If a portuguese colleague complains that people are fleeing to the Netherlands, let them lower their taxes than in the Netherlands – half of the Netherlands will come to Portugal. Very simple! The aim should be to force governments to compete for companies, to compete, to attract citizens, to attract individual entrepreneurs. Unfortunately, I see that there is a totalitarian tendency in the chamber that everything must be uniform. That is why I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We welcome the fact that the European Commission has now taken the first steps to make progress in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance. These steps were overdue, but they are far from sufficient. It is right and absolutely necessary to start with the automatic exchange of information between the Member States. The Member States must no longer speak out here. The exchange must be mandatory, regular and verifiable. And it is right and absolutely necessary that we fully implement the OECD's global agreements on tax transparency and that we formally create the right conditions for this. And it is right and absolutely necessary for the Commission to take action in introducing a common corporate tax base and to get the legislative process back on track. And it is right and necessary for the Commission to review and improve the work of the Code of Conduct Group. It is also right to put the availability of information and multinationals to the test.
