However, there is no need to create an information bureaucracy for the entire business sector. We are putting the real economy and our European companies in the front row in terms of economic policy in order to achieve an investment offensive, job growth and more innovation across the EU. We are destroying a lot of things with excessive reporting requirements. Anyone who does not look at the additional costs, effectiveness and proportionality when reporting remains blind in one eye. Reporting obligations for the sake of reporting do not support us.

name: Peter SIMON
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Illegitimate but not illegal, tax practices have been tolerated in the EU for far too long. Citizens were often unaware of this - it was only through the things around Luxleaks that came to light a few months ago that they became fully aware of it. Citizens have wondered why large international companies can negotiate the tax rate at the expense of third parties, at their expense, while paying their taxes. If we want to change this, if we no longer want to let illegitimate things happen in this way, then we need transparency. The initiative that the Commission has now launched is a first building block for this. It is no longer possible to look the other way if we achieve a mandatory exchange of information on tax rulings between Member States. However, we have had some commitments in this area in the past. We must ensure that a breach of this is also punishable in future. Only if there are consequences to be feared – I am sure – will Member States fully fulfil their obligations at this point. It is also good that the Commission is now proposing that we should introduce a central register listing tax rulings. However, it would be important for us to ensure that it actually contains all the tax rulings of companies and that this register is not only accessible to the Member States of the European Union, but also to the public, while respecting all tax data protection principles. Such a register should be public! It is to be welcomed that the Commission intends to present proposals for a common corporate tax base in its second tax transparency package in June. However, I would also like to strongly encourage them to do so when it come to the question of what we are doing beyond that, the question of presentation – where do companies pay their taxes? – to lead boldly in country-by-country reporting. Transparency is a prerequisite for illegitimate things to become illegal in the future.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Tax avoidance through various semi-legal and illegal methods costs our budgets a lot of money. I therefore very much welcome the Commission's initiative and the proposal, which, in my opinion, is a first step towards sorting out this area by exchanging mandatory information on tax decisions. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Kaili, for preparing a balanced report. However, there is one controversial subject that I want to say a few words about. In paragraph 25, she proposes that the European Commission consider introducing minimum corporate tax rates in order, and I quote, to 'reduce harmful tax competition between Member States'. I think it's a bad idea, for several reasons. Firstly, Member States are at different levels of economic development: some are able to offer very good business conditions, others simply do not have such resources. This applies to infrastructure or public services, government. Therefore, it is not intentional to set minimum tax rates simply because some states may simply not be able to offer such services to business. And secondly, this is a political decision. Depending on which party wins, the party decides on income distribution and tax policy. We should not interfere in this democratic electoral process.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Madam President, I remember sitting in this Chamber five months ago in the immediate wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, and we were back together again two months ago in the wake of another scandal – SwissLeaks. So I am delighted that finally we have a first response from the Commission. I strongly welcome the measures that the Commission has recommended on tax rulings, but, frankly, we need far more action if we are truly going to meet the expectations of our citizens. I have to say I was very concerned that the Commission’s communication was lukewarm in relation to country-by-country reporting of profits by multinationals. The Parliament has long supported this measure, and I hope that the Commission will let us continue with our internal work promoting it. I also hope that the Commission will be publicly more supportive of immediate action to move ahead with country-by-country reporting. We already have evidence that there is no negative impact from country-by-country reporting in relation to extracting industries and banking. We also know it would have a positive impact on SMEs, who at the moment are not competing on a level playing field with those firms who can shift their profits and hide where economy activity is truly occurring. So I hope the Commission will strongly support the urgent need for country-by-country reporting, and that it will also support the other measures that traditionally we in this Chamber have argued for, not just the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) – and I support what the Commissioner said on this today – but also black-listing of those who evade tax and the tax advisers who help them do it, and having a common definition of tax havens.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – Fiscal competition between Member States is healthy and desirable, but there can only be a real competition when the rules of the game are established and are equal and transparent for all participants. The tax transparency package that the Commission is now presenting is an important first step and is already taking the tax rulings out of the dark. But I expect more. Clear rules, but also equal weapons. That is why we need to use the outrage surrounding LuxLeaks and SwissLeaks to finally take steps towards a CCCTB. After all, with a single taxable corporate tax base, tax avoidance becomes particularly difficult. Competition between Member States remains possible, for example in terms of pricing, but with an open mind.  We all know, ladies and gentlemen, where this dossier is stuck and I support the Commission in its intention to unblock the CCCTB. But perhaps it is not time to put this dossier on the table of the Heads of Government? As a young person, I do not want a Europe of great words and values. My generation wants a Europe of deeds above all.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The discussion of the annual tax report is not a routine event this time. Over the last twenty years, we have repeatedly discussed demands for transparency and against tax dumping, and nothing has happened. The Commission has largely slept in front of it. It is only the development of the last few months that has shown how necessary this is. That is why I also welcome the first steps, because the issue of tax evasion and avoidance has reached a level that goes to the substance of honest taxpayers, hundreds of millions of workers and at least 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises. When I see that tax avoidance is estimated at up to EUR 1 trillion a year, action must finally be taken! So far, it has been the Member States that have not harmonised them with the indirect assistance of the Commission. It is not a question of tax harmonisation at a high level, but only of a strategy against tax dumping and tax avoidance in accordance with Articles 101-109 of the EU Treaty, which do not allow unfair competition even in tax matters.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, I very much welcome the Commission’s proposals of last week and I also welcome the fact that we are moving in relation to the automatic exchange of tax information. I believe European citizens stand united in opposing aggressive tax planning and on making sure that corporates and large businesses pay their fair share. I do not believe, however, that ordinary EU citizens want a fully harmonised tax code, and I think that this is ultimately a matter for the Member States to decide by way of direct elections in each country. However, we have to take an aggressive position when it comes to large corporates which are using all of the facilities to evade taxation. Finally, I want to say this: we also need a radical debate in this Parliament and elsewhere, especially in the Commission, about effective tax rates because there are many countries within the European Union which claim to have a tax rate of 30% but effectively have a tax rate of 8%, 9% or 10%. This debate must focus on effective tax rates because that is the important way to shine a light on this entire area.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I concur completely with my colleague Mr Hayes, who outlined our position as regards this whole dossier. We absolutely agree that tax avoidance, tax evasion, and also the exchange of tax information, are key aspects dealt with in this proposal, and we are in favour of that. But we cannot accept the inclusion of Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCBT) proposals. I note that quite a number of small countries have difficulty with this, and we think it discriminates against them. Competition is the life of trade, and it applies to tax as well in the European Union. For that reason we want to emphasise that we cannot accept this proposal, and we have voted against it every time in the past.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Tax policy has long been a well-recognised topic in the European Union. It has always been postponed and has always been pushed because of a kind of fear and concern about tax harmonisation. Even today, it has been said several times. However, it must be said honestly that tax harmonisation should be such a icing on the torch, and at the moment it should be preceded, in particular, by very strong and unambiguous measures that will prevent tax evasion, but which will also prevent companies within the European Union from always finding that country for their business, which has a preferential rate. An example of this in Slovakia is health insurance. By law, every citizen of the Slovak Republic has to pay for health insurance, yet some companies are domidged in other Member States of the European Union, where the rate is much more advantageous precisely for the provision of this service. That is why tax policy is very important because it protects our employees and protects people in the Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the Rapporteur correctly recognises the need for tax relief for SMEs, but nevertheless, in my opinion, she has not made a strong enough call on Member States with non-financial tax policies to relieve their taxpayers and businesses. Today, we would not be concerned with combating tax evasion and avoidance to this extent if Member States had not literally banished some citizens and businesses to the area of the grey economy through excessive levies and administrative burdens. Accordingly, I do not support the rapporteur's condemnation of those Member States which have sought to establish a stimulating tax system that encourages investment and attracts foreign investors. It's not those countries' fault that they're competitive, it's the others' fault they're not.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, I welcome the content of this annual report on taxation because it is the one that was needed after the 'LuxLeaks' scandal. Transparency is needed on the functioning of the European Finances, more harmonisation and participation for taxpayers to provide initiatives that 'pack' better taxes and productive reality. Taxation must serve the real economy, favor the honest taxpayer, and punish financial prey, avoidance, evasion, and aggressive tax planning. Let's compete with taxation by supporting innovation, not circumvention. Those who practice these conducts, I believe that, in addition to tax sanctions, they should be left out of procurement and public aid. We also need the financial transaction fee that generates own resources for the common institutions, and an urgent VAT reform, which is old, unfair and facilitates circumvention. Finally, congratulations on the planetary approach, because that is what true Europeanists expect from our Union.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: " This debate is a hymn to hypocrisy. Governments like President Juncker have lived for decades with tax evasion practices, even encouraging these practices, and are now suddenly very concerned about tax justice. This report is nothing more than a list of pious intentions that link nothing or anyone. It points to scandals, but uses innocuous and inconsequential formulations that do not point to the real problem. And the problem dates back to the 1980s, to the neoliberal revolution, to the privatization of key sectors of our economy, creating empires that are in our governments and in our institutions.  The reduction of the corporate tax base, the free movement of capital, tax havens, fraud and tax evasion are all daughters of the same disease, which is the subordination of political power to economic power, that is, we change this or everything stays the same.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. in the gallery. In the wake of the Luxleaks scandal, Commission President Juncker, who was involved as the then finance minister and head of government of Luxembourg himself, promised that tax evasion in Europe would finally be stopped. The automatic exchange of information, the register – this is an important first step. But that is far from enough. Right now, the public sector needs money to invest in education, in the greening of the economy and the tax system. That is why it is quite clear to us Greens that at European level, and also in my own country, Austria, a clear 'yes' to the end of banking secrecy, not only for companies, as the Austrian Federal Government is now proposing, but also for private individuals. It is completely incomprehensible why individuals are allowed to continue to evade taxes.  This is not about grandma's savings book, as is often claimed, but about tax fraud, tax avoidance, large-scale tax evasion. This fraud against the citizens must finally come to an end.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you, each of you, for all your contributions. What I take away from this debate is, first of all, a very great convergence of views on the objectives. All of us, whatever our preferences, want to put in place fairer and more efficient taxation in the Union. We want to put in place a transparent and predictable framework for EU companies to compete in global markets. We want to give the tax administrations of the Member States the means to exercise the prerogatives that are theirs and which are now weakened. That is the message I will send to the finance ministers and that we must all pass on to national governments, which, as you know, have an essential role to play in this area - the rule of unanimity is a rule that complicates things - if we want Europe to remain credible in this area. I will make three brief remarks, in telegraphic style. Firstly, in response to some observations, I can tell you that my conviction is that what we are proposing is substantial and that, in terms of transparency in particular, the progress of the package I am going to present next week marks - I do not hesitate to say this - a form of a new era for the European Union: never before has such an ambitious approach been proposed. , which goes far beyond, in fact, the arsenal we have had since 1977.  I would add that this is, of course, a first phase and not an end in itself. The Commission will present a second package before the summer which will include both measures for competitiveness and which will include new steps towards transparency, which I have said is ready to study with you. I mentioned country by country report. Second, it is true that we do not act only for ourselves. We are doing this in a global framework, including the OECD BEPS initiative, as part of the G20 initiative, and I would like to see collaborations with other countries outside the European Union.  I will mention, for example, in an area other than the one we are dealing with today, the agreement on the automatic exchange of banking information, which was signed last week with Switzerland and which will be concluded this summer. It is a real revolution, again, that marks the future end of banking secrecy, in a great country where we know that in this case it has a certain image. Thirdly, I want to assure you of my determination to make a difference, to rely without hesitation on the demands of a public opinion which, today, no longer tolerates certain injustices or practices, to put Member States before their responsibilities. To do this, of course, we need to work together, almost hand in hand, to do this. That is why I will be listening to your proposals. This is also why the work that your Assembly is carrying out in the ECON and TAXE committees on this subject plays an essential role both in terms of public awareness of the current state of taxation in the Union and in defining the solutions to be implemented. I look forward to the results of this joint work.

name: Eva KAILI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for taking the floor and for their contributions. I am especially grateful to the shadow rapporteurs, who made this annual tax report the most political until now, for setting priorities. We will keep working for more common policy initiatives. Unfortunately there is also a set of subjects on which we did not all find common ground, such as environmental issues and other indicators relating to the potential to generate growth and jobs, as well as the issue of protecting and defending whistleblowers – thanks to whom we know how the system works. Allow me also to thank Commissioner Moscovici for his commitment, for listening to us, and for saying that he will present more initiatives by June of this year. Thank you very much, Commissioner. I would also ask the Council to listen to us, as Parliament now has a clear, coherent and to-the-point position in this report, which sets the basis for a relevant, timely, fair, transparent, socially responsible and business-friendly tax policy for the EU. Thank you all, and I hope that we will keep working together to move things forward in the near future.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – The Automatic Exchange of Information Between Member States Directive adopted in 2014 covers interest and dividends on accounts and profits from the sale of financial assets. However, it does not include (mostly secret) tax rulings between Member States and multinationals, which is what Lux Leaks has revealed. The Commission proposes to amend Directive 2011/12/EU to extend this automatic exchange of information to tax agreements. In this way, such decisions by tax administrations in favour of undertakings will have to be communicated automatically to all Member States and to the Commission. The proposal has a retroactivity of ten years and no trade or professional secrecy can be claimed so as not to provide the information. It is a positive and necessary measure, but the current proposal has some weaknesses: the information exchanged will not be accessible by citizens; the obligation to exchange is conditional on a cross-border impact of tax arrangements, which may be an escape route; the obligation only affects legal persons (natural persons such as high-ranking actors or footballers could sign such agreements); sanctions are not specified in case of non-compliance with the exchange obligation.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – I cannot possibly support this report, which seems to believe in everything that is wrong with the European Union. We do not want more tax harmonisation. We do not want a Financial Transaction Tax to drain more money out of the United Kingdom economy. We do not want the EU to get involved with the Member States’ sovereignty and their right to set their own tax policies. We do not want the EU to do things which should be done by the OECD. And we do not want the EU empire-building with its own resources either.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. Let me commend the quality of the annual report on taxation carried by Socialist MP Eva Kaili. This text first underlines the extent of tax evasion and evasion: each year, almost EUR 1 trillion is lost on the tax revenues of the Member States of the European Union, even though public finances have been hit hard by the economic and financial crisis. This resolution contains several strong messages that the European Parliament sends to the Council: the discussions on the financial transaction tax have lasted too long, the 11 Member States participating in enhanced cooperation must take their responsibilities to finally put in place this instrument of fiscal justice. Similarly, the consolidated common corporate tax base, the first step towards tax harmonisation, must be mandatory in the Commission's proposal.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Commission has presented its 'tax package', which aims to make European taxation more transparent. One of the key measures of this initiative is the introduction of automatic exchange of information between EU Member States. If we succeed in getting this measure passed, it will be an essential tool in the fight against tax evasion. I would like to point out that every year tax evasion causes Member States to lose EUR 1 trillion. The fifty largest European companies have domiciled one fifth of their subsidiaries in tax havens. These are billions of euros that are hidden and do not return to the coffers of the states where these companies make profits. A political response is therefore crucial to address this problem. For the Socialists, the tax is fair when it is fairly distributed in order to allow society to make investments that serve the community: roads, schools, hospitals,... Moreover, when this tax is levied mainly on the backs of workers when speculators and large fortunes do not sufficiently participate in the collective effort, this is problematic. I will conclude by saying that this is a satisfactory first step but that further steps are still needed.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: in writing. – I would like to raise the recent changes to EU rules on VAT and the impact they are having on micro-businesses across Europe selling services online. When these changes were negotiated, over six years ago, the aim was to prevent large companies from gaining a competitive advantage by basing themselves in countries with lower VAT rates. This should have helped small online businesses to compete. Unfortunately, these rules are now having the opposite effect. Requirements, including keeping customer records for 10 years and providing proof of buyers’ locations, have proved excessively burdensome for many sole traders selling services such as e—books and craft patterns online. The message from across Europe is clear: the Commission must take swift and decisive action to reduce the burden of this legislation on our smallest and most innovative firms. Digital entrepreneurs will form the bedrock of the EU’s future economic prosperity and competitiveness. We cannot afford to throttle them with excessive regulation.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – The Automatic Exchange of Information Between Member States Directive adopted in 2014 covers interest and dividends on accounts and profits from the sale of financial assets. However, it does not include (mostly secret) tax rulings between Member States and multinationals, which is what Lux Leaks has revealed. The Commission proposes to amend Directive 2011/12/EU to extend this automatic exchange of information to tax agreements. In this way, such decisions by tax administrations in favour of undertakings will have to be communicated automatically to all Member States and to the Commission. The proposal has a retroactivity of ten years and no trade or professional secrecy can be claimed so as not to provide the information. It is a positive and necessary measure, but the current proposal has some weaknesses: the information exchanged will not be accessible by citizens; the obligation to exchange is conditional on a cross-border impact of tax arrangements, which may be an escape route; the obligation only affects legal persons (natural persons such as high-ranking actors or footballers could sign such agreements); sanctions are not specified in case of non-compliance with the exchange obligation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I welcome the fact that we have presented concrete proposals to fight tax evasion and avoidance after the unacceptable revelations of the Lux Leaks and Swiss Leaks scandals. It is clear that we must take stronger action to tackle corporate tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. I support the inclusion of a list of practical demands in the report to make implementation of our proposals more effective. The report includes measures to reduce mismatches between tax systems and rules to extend country-by-country reporting to monitor where business profits are located and where taxes are paid. It also includes common EU criteria to define tax havens. I believe this call for more transparency and regulation represents an important step ahead in the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance and a pragmatic tool to foster growth and strengthen the EMU. I would like to congratulate my colleague Eva Kaili for her holistic approach to the subject of taxation policy.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The Automatic Exchange of Information Between Member States Directive adopted in 2014 covers interest and dividends on accounts and profits from the sale of financial assets. However, it does not include (mostly secret) tax rulings between Member States and multinationals, which is what Lux Leaks has revealed. The Commission proposes to amend Directive 2011/12/EU to extend this automatic exchange of information to tax agreements. In this way, such decisions by tax administrations in favour of undertakings will have to be communicated automatically to all Member States and to the Commission. The proposal has a retroactivity of ten years and no trade or professional secrecy can be claimed so as not to provide the information. It is a positive and necessary measure, although the current proposal has some weaknesses that will have to be corrected in the parliamentary procedure, such as the following: the information exchanged will not be accessible by citizens; the obligation to exchange is conditional on a cross-border impact of tax arrangements, which may be an escape route; the obligation only affects legal persons (natural persons such as high-ranking actors or footballers could sign such agreements); sanctions are not specified in case of non-compliance with the exchange obligation.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Europe must act promptly and effectively to resolve the imbalances created by a lack of fiscal transparency and circumvention and evasion practices. These phenomena, in addition to being illegal and intolerable behaviour, also constitute considerable economic damage to the economy, at a time of such great crisis when every public resource must be found and made available for growth.  The European Parliament is today devoting an important session to the fight against tax evasion. I believe that this is an important sign in response to the Luxleaks and Swissleaks revelations and scandals, which have rightly raised public concern. The next step now is to act politically and legislatively to reduce as much as possible the contradictions and divergences between the various Member States in tax matters, to eliminate the tax havens that still exist within the EU and, above all, to check that the profits of large companies are actually paid in the countries where production and commercial activity is carried out.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. I strongly supported the annual report on taxation because I supported the overall approach that the EP proposes in the field of fiscal policy, which remains the prerogative of the Member States, as it may prove to be a functional tool for promoting growth and the necessary deepening of EMU.  I fully agree with the need to shift the tax burden from labour to other forms of sustainable taxation, so that all economic sectors contribute fairly to growth and the creation of quality jobs. I therefore consider it very important that the Commission has taken up with interest the draft CCCTB directive on the common consolidated corporate tax base, provided that it excludes small and medium-sized enterprises with a cooperative vocation, as called for in the 2012 EP resolution. I fully support the call for the Commission to commit itself to presenting a legislative proposal to introduce a minimum rate on companies to curb unfair competition in tax matters. Finally, I call on the Member States engaged in enhanced cooperation on FTT to rein vigour this cooperation, in order to introduce a tax on highly speculative financial transactions and to introduce new forms of own resources into the EU budget.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – Annual loss in the EU as a result of tax fraud and tax evasion is estimated at EUR 1 trillion. Fighting tax fraud must be a priority.  The European Parliament must be very firm in combating these non-transparent practices that distort competition in the market. We need to have a tax policy that promotes inclusion, transparency and fairness and at the same time encourages good governance and is an effective tool for promoting social justice and reducing economic inequalities. We need policies that combat tax evasion, that reduce tax differences that are not fair, that encourage competitiveness and support SMEs. We also need measures to combat tax havens.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. – There can be no fair tax without publicity. Taxation needs parence and in the 21st century there can be no opacity with social irresponsibility. Under these principles, I would like to make three suggestions to the European Commission's proposal on the amendment of the Directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the field of taxation: 1. The information exchanged must be accessible to citizens and the media. Not just the states. Depriving citizens of access to this information has no justification and cannot be explained in the century of transparency. 2. The obligation to inform States should also include their agreements with natural persons and not just legal persons. 3. States should publish a blacklist of companies committing tax fraud or tax avoidance so that the corporate reputation of companies is affected by tax irresponsibility.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Conservative estimates indicate that Member States lose billions of euros each year as a result of tax avoidance measures. This means that, in times of crisis, the budgetary revenue necessary to pursue an active policy of stimulating the economy is being depleted. However, a much bigger problem is that such actions mean that fair competition rules are being distorted.  The biggest losers of the common practice of tax avoidance or evasion are small and medium-sized enterprises, which are not able to negotiate tax exemptions for themselves. I am therefore grateful to the Commission for taking action so quickly to curb unfair tax policies. The proposed changes are going in the right direction, because transparency should be the cornerstone of countries' activity in this area. Requiring Member States to provide information on individual tax rulings on a regular basis is a good solution, as it will hinder the unfair practices of some governments. However, it is necessary to define these decisions precisely so that it is known which ones need to be notied. Indeed, we can expect some governments to try to circumvent these rules and continue to attract taxpayers.  The Commission's proposal to introduce a European tax identification number is also worth considering. It will undoubtedly facilitate the exchange of information between member states' tax administrations and identify the negative practices of individual companies more quickly.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. – Mr Moscovici, the troika's tax policy imposed on Greece has made the poor poorer and the rich richer. Thus, with the implementation of the Memorandum, the lowest incomes were taxed at 337% while the highest incomes were only 9%.  And yet even today the troika is demanding an increase in indirect taxes, an increase in VAT on the islands, and an increase in the property tax. At the same time, Luxleaks-style tax avoidance policies have left Greece and other countries in the European South with multibillion-euro tax revenues.  That is why tax dumping must stop. Measures must be taken against large enterprises which, through the system of intra-group transactions, are champions in tax avoidance and tax evasion.  Finally, fuel and cigarette smuggling must be hit at the root. We must therefore build a tax system that ensures tax justice at pan-European level.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – The fiscal transparency package presented last week by the European Commission which, in response to the 'LuxLeaks' scandal, aims to combat the secrecy of tax agreements between large corporations and governments is quite vague. To begin with, despite including some improvements in the information received by state tax authorities, it should not be called a transparency package, as it maintains opacity to people by hiding citizens' access to information from such agreements. To achieve a decent level of transparency, it is people who must have the ability to access information. I hope that the tax package for corporations to be published by the Commission in June will go further and be ambitious in advertising the ultimate beneficiary of business structures, with public country-by-country reports on business activity, and that it will try to curb competition between States to reduce tax dumping.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The Annual Tax Report is an important exercise as it addresses issues such as tax fraud, tax evasion and tax havens, which pose a threat to both the nature of the single market and the image of the EU. As an integral part of the European Single Market, the Digital Single Market is also highly dependent on the tax legislative framework the EU is shaping. This framework should enable the core aim of the Digital Single Market – establishing a single market that gives equal conditions for production and trade for any European over the internet. I thus welcome the report, which calls for treating e-products equally with their physical alternatives with regards to taxation issues. Currently, e-commerce presents a major challenge for tax administrations, given the often multi-jurisdictional nature of the transactions and the potential anonymity of the parties. The EU should therefore push for policies that make it easier to do e-commerce. The proposal in the Annual Tax Report that invites the Commission to come up with a clear legislative framework to ensure equality between electronic and physical products is a good first step, yet there is a further need to review all EU tax policy from a Digital Market Perspective.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. – I very much welcome the European Commission's new package to strengthen tax transparency in the European Union. The package represents a promising step towards introducing fairness and fairness into the current opaque tax systems of individual Member States. It is not acceptable that up to €1 billion of potential tax revenue is lost each year through tax fraud and evasion. The fact that the tax burden is not distributed evenly and fairly is inexcusable. Especially at a time of economic downturn and poverty growth, when there are not enough public resources to cover investment. Pressure needs to be put on the Council of the European Union, where even one negative attitude of a Member State can block any progress in this regard. The current Commission proposal is undoubtedly a step in the right direction. The automatic exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States, which may today choose not to provide the information requested, will help to identify tax loopholes and irregularities. However, the package in its current form cannot be the final goal. We should not accept in the long term a situation where multinational supranational companies that concluded a tax agreement more than a decade ago avoided heeded supervision. In order to achieve overall transparency, we must also aim for the creation of a register that will not only serve the tax authorities of the Member States and the European Commission. The register should be open to a broad society and should include both legal and natural persons.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Commissioner, the European Parliament must send a strong political message for immediate measures for tax transparency and taxation combined with social justice. I am pleased that this report lays the groundwork for future parliamentary work in this area, such as the introduction of a consolidated common corporate tax base for European businesses, and the strengthening of transparency in tax rulings. Nevertheless, Member States and the Commission must also play an even more prominent role in combating tax evasion and aggressive tax optimisation. Of course, I welcome the publication of the tax transparency package by the European Commission on 18 March. However, I call for other effective proposals to be put forward in the coming months to step up the fight against tax havens and tax evasion. For example, the Commission should draw up a blacklist of tax havens and countries whose tax practices distort competition before July 2015. The fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion is at the heart of citizens' concerns. This must be a top priority for the Union.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – We have witnessed big public relations and political exercises to project the unacceptable activities of ‘tax havens’ in Europe and elsewhere. Beyond obvious excesses in tax adjudication, which cannot be justified (no matter who does them and how), these exercises have actually targeted the financial services sectors of a number of EU Member States. Most of them, with the exception of the UK, are among the European minnows. Suddenly it seems as if countries which specialise in the provision of financial services should be considered a threat to the integrity of the EU. A recalibration of this approach is needed. The fact is that financial services remain necessary in a globalising world which has accepted neoliberal rules when ensuring that financial flows across nations and continents are managed efficiently. That financial services migrate towards given countries and not others reflects an international division of labour without which some countries would be perpetually in growth mode, others in perpetual stagnation. Increasingly, it is taken for granted that there must be something shady in policies which encourage the provision of financial services. To claim that such provision implies the encouragement of tax avoidance, or indeed evasion, is manifestly false.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. - The european mission's new package of tax transparency measures will oblige the 28 Member States to share data on all tax contracts they have concluded with multinationals. Ensuring stronger cooperation between Member States, as well as their tax administrations, the new measures will significantly improve the transparency of tax solutions in relation to the situation we face today. The Greens/ESS Group has decided to be a leading political force in the fight against tax fraud in the European Union and has proposed the creation of a European Parliament Committee of Inquiry to examine all possible cases of breaches of European tax laws and practices. I am convinced that the Research Committee is the strongest instrument in the hands of the European Parliament and through the supervisory power of MEPs and MEPs represents the power of citizens in the European Union. It only provides comprehensive access to the official documentation of the Member States, the Commission and the Council of the European Union. For these reasons, it is important to make good use of the mandate of the newly formed Special Committee and thus protect the public interest of all citizens and citizens of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – Transparency is one of the fundamental principles of the functioning of the European Union, which must be equally represented in all segments of the functioning of the Union, and in this sense I particularly emphasize financial operations. That is why I am pleased that we are finally discussing tax policy mismatches in EU member states, as well as tax evasion. The fact that many provisions are not interpreted in the spirit of the law and that the payment of obligations is avoided indicate the necessity of changing the tax transparency policy. Such actions are not illegal because they are different in nature from classical tax evasion, but nevertheless, if a procedure is in accordance with the law does not necessarily mean that it is also moral. It therefore encourages that the Commission intensifies its efforts to tackle this problem and does not leave things to chance, as tax transparency is a key element for its solution. Tax evasion and avoidance of taxes in addition to corruption represent the majority of member states' unchaested claims, as recognised by both parliament and the Council. It is therefore important to adopt and more importantly implement effective measures to increase tax transparency in the area of taxation. The Tax Transparency Package is the first step towards generating more revenue in the budget, which will open up room for allocation of these funds to address the economic and social problems in the EU, which are currently a priority.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. – Promoting a fair, simple, stable and transparent tax system must be one of the main priorities at European level. Unfortunately, to date, there has not been the necessary cooperation in Europe in this area, and because of the austerity programmes, we have on several occasions been led to an unprecedented overtaxation of certain occupational categories. It must be understood by all: A low level of taxes is essential not only for the well-being of citizens, but also for competitiveness and the creation of new jobs. We need socially just tax systems that will act as tools for economic growth. At the same time, we need a comprehensive strategy to combat tax evasion.  It should be noted, however, that too often priority is given to small-scale tax evasion, rather than at the level of large multinationals. In order to combat tax evasion, it is necessary to deal effectively with aggressive tax planning and, of course, tax havens. The Commission's new proposal on the mandatory exchange of information on cross-border tax agreements is clearly moving in the right direction. However, tax agreements with third countries must also be made immediately. This could be a realistic alternative, reducing the burden on honest taxpayers and ensuring the additional resources necessary to promote public investment.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. – Transparency in the European Union has become a pillar of the European Parliament and the other European institutions in recent years. For the European institutions, as well as for the Member States, the fight against tax evasion must be a priority. Companies must pay their taxes wherever their profits are generated. The initiatives that are being carried out and also those that are to come within the European Union, both in the field of corporate taxation and the fight against harmful tax practices, as well as in administrative cooperation, should fundamentally promote transparency and information exchange. The proposal for a Directive to establish the exchange of information on tax agreements is of great importance, as it will allow Member States access to the agreements granted to taxpayers by the administrations of other countries, the thus ensuring adequate taxation. I would like to highlight the important work being done by the Special Commission on Tax Resolutions and Other Measures of Nature or Similar Effects, led by our colleague Alain Lamassoure.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European single market is an imperfect market, limited by physical and legal barriers to the movement of goods and services, but also by practices such as tax avoidance and tax evasion and aggressive tax competition between Member States. These practices achieve the confidence of European citizens in the single market. Phenomena such as "Lux leaks" or the encouragement of some countries to companies in other European countries to transfer tax obligations outside their operating territory have to be quickly fought.  The tax package presented by the European Commission, focused on transparency, responds to a need, but it is clearly insufficient. The action plan on corporate taxation announced for the summer, coupled with the report being prepared within the Framework of the European Parliament, has to give a clear signal of tax harmonisation. Transparency is not enough. Active cooperation and destined reduction of harmful tax practices in the EU context are needed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Gabrielius Landsbergis, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine (COM(2015)0005 – C8-0005/2015 – 2015/0005(COD)) (A8-0056/2015).

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, today we will vote on a small part of EU history. We are voting for EUR 1.8 billion of macro-financial aid to Ukraine, which will be the biggest financial package given by the European Union to any third country. But that alone is not as important as the political message that the European Union is united in its effort to help Ukraine and to back it when the help is most needed. It has to be noted that our friends as well as our adversaries are looking for cracks in our unity. Ukraine needs our unity in order to sustain clear reasoning for their reforms. Just yesterday, we had an opportunity to talk to the Ukrainian Minister of the Economy. He gave us a cold but clear overview on the reforms that his Ministry and the Government are undertaking. Fighting the oligarchic structures, battling corruption and addressing inefficiency in the public sector are just a few of the points that he raised. It seemed to me that even the critics should have been convinced that Ukraine is doing its utmost to reform itself. It is chilling to imagine any of our countries going through those sorts of reforms, actually changing dramatically many fields of life that people were accustomed to. That was one reason why a colleague asked if the Minister is sure that the people of Ukraine will keep up with and support the pace of the reforms. We were reassured that, with a clear message from Europe that Europe is standing by them, the people will support and understand the need for reform.  Our foes would rejoice if they saw us disunited and would use it for their propaganda. We already know what they would say: ‘See, Europe cannot help the country that itself wished to sign an association agreement!’ The Council, the Commission, the Committee on International Trade (INTA) and the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) are all calling for agreement on the proposed report without amendments, for one main reason. That reason is that time is of crucial importance here. If we vote ‘yes’ on the report today, the Commission will be able to issue the first tranche of the funds to Ukraine at the beginning of the summer. If we want the country, which is still fighting for its territory, to be able to stabilise its budget and economy, we have to agree on providing the funds as soon as possible. Of course, I have heard critics say that we are not sure whether the money will be used transparently or whether there are enough incentives for reform in the report. I believe, at this stage, that the Commission has provided for enough controls in the document that would be signed with Ukraine after our vote and following approval by the Council. We are, and will remain, in close contact with the Support Group for Ukraine regarding the reforms and regarding transparency in relation to the funds provided. When the situation in Ukraine stabilises, and I want to believe that it will, we will come back to the debate on how we can help Ukraine on its path to reform.  Dear colleagues, I call on you to support this report as presented without amendments, and to demonstrate our resolution to stand by Ukraine.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Landsbergis and the Committee on International Trade (INTA) for their valuable work on this report and for expediting approval procedures. I would also like to thank the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) for its contribution. As you know, the Commission submitted its proposal for a macro-financial assistance operation for Ukraine in the context of the enormous political and security challenges in Ukraine, and a deteriorating economic situation.  Ukraine is confronted by deep recession: its currency has depreciated strongly, inflation has been rising and international reserves have been declining. This shows that the situation is very acute, and Ukraine badly needs international financial assistance as soon as possible. Indeed, international donors led by the IMF have wrapped up a new financial aid package for Ukraine, with the most recent IMF extended fund facility, of 11 March 2015, amounting to USD 17.5 billion. The EU is also contributing with its current Commission proposal for macro-financial assistance (MFA) of EUR 1.8 billion in addition to the previous MFA operations of EUR 1.6 billion in loans. It is intended that this MFA operation will be disbursed in three equal tranches, and this is going to be the highest amount of assistance ever disbursed to a third country in such a short period of time. Of course, a new MFA operation will be subject to the fulfilment of conditions, namely political preconditions concerning respect for democratic mechanisms, human rights and the rule of law. Moreover, Ukraine must satisfactorily implement the IMF programme and, last but not least, must fulfil economic and financial policy conditions to be agreed between the EU and Ukraine in a memorandum of understanding. In this context, potential policy measures in the areas of public finance management, anti-corruption and transparency, the business environment, energy sector reform and financial sector reform are being explored and will be discussed with our Ukrainian partners. I would stress that timing is of the essence here. Ukraine’s most urgent and important financing needs are in 2015, and the first two of the three tranches under the newly proposed MFA operation should be disbursed this year – i.e. the first tranche before the summer break in mid-2015. Contrary to its proposal for last year’s MFA operation of EUR 1 billion, which was based on the urgency procedure, with a Council decision as provided for in Article 213 of the Treaty, the Commission has based the present proposal on Article 212 of the Treaty, which provides for a decision under the ordinary legislative procedure. The current Commission proposal follows precisely established practice for MFA operations – practice also reflected in the Joint Declaration of Parliament and the Council of 12 August 2013 on granting MFA. In view of Ukraine’s urgent financial needs, swift adoption of the current proposal by the co-legislators under the ordinary legislative procedure is very important. Therefore, I am pleased that the International Trade and Foreign Affairs committees upheld the Commission proposal without amendments. I am also pleased that the Council, through Coreper, today agreed to adopt the Commission’s proposal without amendments.

name: Jacek SARYUSZ-WOLSKI
text: draftss author of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. I would like to say that today's decision, which will be made (I am convinced of this) about macro-financial assistance, the next tranche for Ukraine of EUR 1.8 billion is not only a financially important decision, it is a very important political decision.  Ukraine urgently needs support, its financial stability is under threat. Ukraine is not a poor country, it is poorly managed, it needs reforms, it is waging a defence war. It has already lost 25% of its economy and part of its territory – war costs a lot. It is at war and reforming at the same time – it is unprecedented in European history. Fast and generous financial support is therefore needed. War bleeds Ukraine and without financial transfusion and another Ukraine will not cope. Helping Ukraine is a political imperative. The biggest gift to the Russian aggressor would be to allow Ukraine to go bankrupt. We cannot allow this to happen!

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Ukraine is associated with the European Union, the consequence of which should be the Community's commitment to support the country on its path to building efficient and efficient administration, promoting economic development or industrial restructuring. It is also important to reduce poverty and build civil society.  Ukraine is now fighting on many fronts, including the worst, militarily, too, but at the same time it must carry out very costly socio-economic reforms. Without the help of the European Union, it will not be able to cope with these historic challenges. In the name of international solidarity, therefore, we should support the task of financially supporting our eastern neighbour.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Madam President, Ukraine is in a state of war today, a war of survival in the face of aggression by Russia that is carrying out a hybrid war, undeclared but imposed and systematically ruled after the illegal occupation of Crimea. And this should not be forgotten and denied by anyone in this room. Ukraine is a strategic partner for the European Union and the Euro-Atlantic world. European solidarity and support for Ukraine must be, more than ever, substantial, constant and effective. That is why I am convinced that this eurcduty of 1.8 billion, approved by emergency procedure by the INTA Commission - and I am convinced that today it will also be approved by Parliament - is responding to the urgency and maintaining the coherence of our commitments. Ukraine is facing a severe recession, and the crisis will be prolonged because it is the result of serious macroeconomic and structural problems, aggravated by a long-term and predictable long-term conflict in the future. And a message to the Ukrainian government and to the Ukrainian people: for these dramatic, painful reforms to achieve results in wartime, they need the support of the Ukrainian people. We call on the Ukrainian government not to forget for a moment that it must lead these reforms with the Ukrainian people.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – We support this proposal to grant macro-financial assistance to Ukraine.  The following elements are already important to us. This programme is a response to a crisis situation caused by structural problems and exacerbated by Russian aggression. The Government of Ukraine has a responsibility to tackle these long-standing structural problems, such as corruption, selective justice, etc. The conditionality in the MFB programme should contribute to the necessary reforms.  There are hopeful signs. The Verchovno Rada this week made work of greater transparency of the public administration. And today, two senior officials were arrested on suspicion of corruption. Tackling the ukrTransNafta scandal shows that oligarchs are finally getting the signal they need to choose: their business or politics. And that if they choose things, they can no longer be directly part of the power. We must encourage our Ukrainian friends to continue on this path. In this way, our financial contribution can and will really be a lever for more democracy, prosperity, legal certainty and perspective for the people.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, like all the previous speakers the ALDE Group will also support this package because Ukraine is in need of this support. Of course we must be sure that Ukraine reforms – all the other speakers have also said this. Therefore, it would be good, and it is important, that inspectors from both the IMF and the EU are ‘sur place’, that they will be present to advise and to guide. Ukraine is a country of which a part is annexed and a part is occupied by rebels supported by Russia, and therefore it is an immense task for it to survive. But, in order to survive, it should reform.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has To be clear, our group will vote against macro-financial assistance afterwards. To make this clear at once, our group, like others, wants Ukraine to be a sovereign and territorially undivided country. Our group, too, wants Ukraine to develop into a country with functioning democratic structures, but also a country in which people can live socially secure, politically self-determined and democratically free, free from the influence of the oligarchs who continue to operate unhindered. And our group also sees the extremely difficult economic situation in the country and, above all, its people. However, we are voting against it because we believe that the economic policy course linked to macro-financial assistance has already failed in the EU, for example Greece. We are voting against it because we do not accept that Parliament should avoid a debate in an organised way on how to deal with Ukraine's apparent insolvency in the future. We are also voting against it because we believe that the Ukrainian Government needs a clear message from this Parliament: like Moscow, Kiev must refrain from doing anything that undermines the core of Minsk II. There can and must be no military solution in Donbass. And perhaps the forced resignation of an appointed oligarch by an elected oligarch yesterday is a first step in this direction. Alone, I lack faith!

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Verts/ALE). – Mr President, the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance is unreservedly in favour of this proposal, and we believe that it is very important to safeguard the sovereignty of the Ukrainian State by avoiding liquidation. That would be the worst thing that could happen to Ukraine's sovereignty. It is, of course, the case that this macro-financial assistance may not be entirely ideal for the situation in Ukraine. It is necessary, but we would like to see that, in future, Ukraine will also receive more direct aid, which will then be allocated to these reforms, which are primarily about institution building and eradicating corruption, but this proposal is important in order to prevent Ukraine from going into liquidation.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Lega Nord is totally opposed to this type of intervention. It is a wrong choice that fuels further resentment, which tends to continue a trade war against Russia that makes no sense whatsoe worthless. In 2015, we need to talk to Russia, we need to trade, we need to cooperate against international terrorism, we must not play war.  And then it comes as a laughing stock when we talk about the sovereignty of a state that is not even part of the European Union, when for forty years a Member State of the European Union, Cyprus, is half of its territory militarily occupied by that Turkey with which some MEPs sitting in here and talking about peace would like to share the future of the European Union. I would prefer this two billion euros to be allocated to European citizens in difficulty and not used to fuel other wars.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam Vice-President, I welcome and congratulate our rapporteur, My colleague Landsbergis, thank Commissioner Dobrovskis for presenting this €1.8 billion macro-financial assistance package, another important contribution of the European Union to Ukraine's financial stability. Last week we were a delegation from the Budget Committee, the Security Defence Committee and I as chairman of the Delegation to Ukraine in Kiev. We understood the very challenging and difficult situation of stability of Ukraine's public finances, because of the cost of war, because of all the other economic and financial problems that the country is in at the moment. Today's message is an important political message of solidarity, unity of the European Union and a desire to help a country whose large part of the budget goes to the cost of war, defence costs and therefore I consider this €1.8 billion to be an additional contribution to the continuity of our clear political support to Ukraine in a difficult situation when faced with aggression by the Russian Federation.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Madam President, of course I agree with those who say that, in a time of war and given the capital flight that Ukraine is facing, we have no option but to give them support and to express our solidarity with the people of Ukraine. However, I think it is vital that we do not just give the money, but that we insist, as the Commission has indicated it will, that human-rights reforms are genuine in Ukraine, that corruption is properly tackled in Ukraine, that democracy is properly embedded in Ukraine and, above all, that the money does not end up in the pockets of oligarchs. I have heard people say that, of the EUR 1.83 billion, a billion will go to the people of Ukraine and EUR 0.83 billion will end up in the pockets of the oligarchs. That cannot be allowed to happen, so the Commission must monitor this money very closely. We will hear, of course, that the situation in Ukraine at the present time is difficult, but I think the message we have to send as a parliament is that the crisis Ukraine is living through at the present time should be the catalyst for fundamental reform, not the excuse for postponing it.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. As Vice-President of the European Parliament responsible for Eastern politics, I would like to thank the Commissioner, The Vice-President of the Commission, for his contribution. I think that you feel the situation in this region of Europe better than many other Commissioners. Certainly better than your compatriot Piebalgs, who was in charge of energy policy and defended Nordstream, which was really a bad idea.  Yes, aid to Ukraine is needed. Please do not tell nonsense about some kind of war that we are waging with Russia: it was Russia that attacked a country neighbouring the European Union. These are the facts. Economic aid is essential if we do not want Ukraine, ukrainian society to push back towards Moscow. This aid simply belongs to Ukraine. And that's what I wanted to emphasize.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: – Madam President, more than a year ago Ukrainians were protesting in Kiev for closer European integration. A few weeks ago some were back on the streets but for different reasons: heating price increases, inflation and the collapse of the currency. It is our responsibility, as partners and allies of Ukraine, to provide financial support but it is also our responsibility to help Ukraine with long-term rather than short-term solutions. These solutions are reforms – reforms to restore confidence by reinforcing the rule of law, tackling corruption and taking measures to improve the business environment. My country, Estonia, went through these painful reforms for the long-term benefits of a sustainable future. Only Ukraine, as a sovereign country, can deliver these reforms but, as the European Union, we need to ensure that we provide the right assistance that will contribute to changing Ukraine for the better and transforming Ukraine’s future.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – There should be absolutely no money going to Ukraine. You and I know all too well that this government needs EUR 2 billion to continue the war against eastern Ukraine. The government in Ukraine is in no way good. It has no respect for the right of self-determination of peoples including the people of Eastern Ukraine and Crimea. It is bombing civilians in eastern Ukraine, resulting in hundreds of deaths, a war crime for which it must be prosecuted. It complicates the investigation into the downing of flight MH17, which killed 298 people. It does not give any explanation to the six political opponents of the regime who have died in the last two months. I ask the European Commission: do not make yourself complicit in the war crimes of this regime. Don't go to war with Russia and don't throw any hard-earned tax money in the pockets of this corrupt gang.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Ukrainian economy is in a state of serious crisis caused by long-standing structural problems, which have recently been exacerbated by armed conflict. In the current situation, financial support to Ukraine is essential, but it must go hand in hand with deep reforms. And the assistance we are offering, the assistance from the European Union, should be aimed at strengthening the most sensitive areas of the Ukrainian economy.  These changes must concern fiscal stabilisation, improved economic indicators, but also anti-corruption issues, taxes, the improvement of the financial sector and the business environment. And by focusing on these areas, the European Union will certainly increase its contribution to alleviating financial difficulties in Ukraine and will also contribute to supporting the European Union's objectives of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine, as well as broadening our understanding of the policies of our eastern neighbours. The most important element, however, is that our assistance strengthens the Ukrainian Government's commitments to implement economic reforms.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Ukraine remains worrying economically and socially despite recent developments. The European Union cannot now withdraw from aid for the country's growth, and that is why we believe that assistance is needed. The financial assistance proposed by the Commission can make a contribution to the new international aid package to Ukraine, both directly and indirectly, thanks to the mobilisation and contribution of other partners. We are convinced that trade policy interests must be consistent with foreign policy interests and that at this stage we must continue to send out a strong signal to a people in difficulty. The granting of financial assistance also wants to be a signal to the Ukrainian Government to continue with structural reforms. We have seen signs of the increased level of attention being paid to the fight against corruption and to the reform of taxation and public administration. We are convinced that they are steps in the right direction, that they must include more and more citizens as beneficiaries.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Madam President, I have just returned from a joint mission of the Committee on Budgets and the Subcommittee on Security and Defence in Kiev. In Ukraine, the crisis is on all fronts. The war has not stopped, the human cost is heavy: deaths every day and hundreds of thousands of migrants fleeing the fighting zone. The economy is shrinking, inflation is exploding, the currency is collapsing. The new Ukrainian government and its parliamentary majority have the will to carry out comprehensive reforms, but they need effective assistance and financial resources. Of course, we salute the European teams that represent us on the territory. We have met them, but they are not alone: many international institutions are there. That is to say, Commissioner, if we need coordination between international donors and lenders, but also coordination within the services of the European Union, in Brussels, first, and between Brussels and Kiev. We also need to simplify our procedures, reduce our decision-making and payment times so that we can respond in real time to overt emergencies. When there is a fire in the house, the price of water is not discussed. In this dramatic context, the European Union must accept the leadership of the coordination and ensure the right balance between the rigour of aid and the acceptability of conditionality measures by the Ukrainian people, a courageous but suffering people, a people waiting for results to regain hope and confidence in the future. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Ukraine is, in every respect, the test of truth for the European Union.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, I fully support the draft decision to extend macro-financial assistance (MFA) to Ukraine, and for a number of reasons. First, we should provide support to a neighbouring country which is struggling with a massive economic and humanitarian crisis and is the victim of outright military aggression from Russia. This is not only our moral obligation, it is also a very sensible political decision because we are providing support to a pro-European, pro-reform and democratic government and, in this way, we contribute to our own security. Second, the decision to extend MFA is a manifestation of our European solidarity. It is also a sign of our sense of responsibility for stability in the region. It is a sign of our willingness to play an important role in our neighbourhood. Having said that, I have to call on the Commission to make sure that the money is spent on support for the reform process and on state-building in Ukraine because we have to make sure that this assistance benefits all the people of Ukraine.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, I support the rapporteur's position that, without amendments and further delay, financial assistance to Ukraine, whose economy will shrink by 6% this year, is secured as soon as possible. The national currency of wrestling had the most serious 38% drop in value in the world last year.  One million people have left their homes, one and a half million are living in harsh conditions in the conflict area, 20% of the industrial potential cannot be used because it is located in occupied territory, and as many as 1 700,000 children are affected by a crisis whose end is not in sight. The country is estimated to need at least €50 billion to recover. In such a situation, the €1.8 billion we are discussing here is a modest but important contribution to Ukraine's attempts to protect its population, which is threatened by a worsening economic and social situation more than aggression.  The EU needs to pass ukrainian exams because Ukraine is a matter of the future of the European project, a matter of determining values more than geographical borders. Ukraine is part of Europe by both criteria and therefore deserves our full support!

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Madam President, tonight we are discussing EUR 1.8 billion, whereas we know that Ukraine is very likely to need EUR 50 billion, and there is another EUR 17 billion or so coming from the International Monetary Fund. Ukraine is facing massive liquidity problems. Ukraine is on the verge of bankruptcy, and I am absolutely certain that the bankruptcy of Ukraine would be worse than a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. It would be tantamount to that. We will need to go further than this and we know it, and we should not focus on conditionalities which we know Ukraine will not be able to meet. When you are at war, you do not reform the state and save up for winter at the same time. We will have to be much more creative than we currently are. We might even have to conceive of things like opening up the European Stability Mechanism for Ukraine. At the end of the day, either we will be serious or Ukraine will go down.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in voting for this macro-financial aid, we must first of all think of the Ukrainian people who have suffered and are still suffering from the war, the political crisis but also the economic crisis. It is clear that the European Union must help Ukraine, but it is equally clear that this aid must be accompanied by reforms, including the anti-corruption scheme in all areas - including the provision of university degrees - which distorts democracy.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: (ECR). – Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, it is undeniable that Ukraine's economy is in an extremely severe state, the severe economic crisis and the depreciation of the country's currency are indisputable. From this point of view, this loan may be vital and necessary, but I would ask both the rapporteur and the Commissioner for a very strict monitoring of the costs of these funds in order to go where they are needed and not in the hands of those who are currently waging war with each other on the streets of Ukrainian cities.  And one more thing I would ask: let this loan be linked to serious obligations on the part of the Ukrainian government for reforms, especially in the area of preserving the human rights of national minorities, who in the state of Ukraine are actually more than even indigenous peoples. I remind you once again, only the number of the Bulgarian minority there is more than half a million.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, it is of the utmost importance that we grant Ukraine the third macro-financial assistance package of EUR 1.8 billion. This may not be the end of Ukraine’s needs and we must be ready for that. Ukraine needs to go on with its reforms, the most crucial ones being the fight against corruption, reforming the security forces and the taxation system, and making the business environment better. Trust must be restored in the banking sector, avoidance of tax payments must be resolved and transparency enhanced. We need to move on with the consultations on a Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Agreement (DCFTA) and this should not lead to the further postponement of the EU-DCFTA beyond 1 January 2016. Of course, Ukraine’s future depends on when and how the conflict can be resolved in eastern Ukraine. Therefore the sanctions against Russia must be prolonged until the Minsk Agreements are fully implemented. If necessary, sanctions must be broadened. And the occupation of Crimea has to stop.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: – Madam President, the European Union encourages Ukraine to implement reform projects. Such an expression could be moving if we did not know what reforms are planned. It is such conditionality that many countries that have received the troika already know so well: privatisation, free movement of capital to extend the internal market, labour reforms more commendable with the modern paradigm of the European Union and the IMF, called cheap and non-human labour. Moreover, so much was the European Union's willingness to "help" Ukraine, which even supported and incited a coup carried by nationalist, fascist and neo-Nazi forces, a situation which would, of course, result in economic and social calamity as a result of the war. And once again, a pretext for the European Union to help the Ukrainian people. With friends like this, who needs enemies?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would have three comments to make. First, you have repeatedly pointed out that the country is at war. According to the international statutes of the IMF, it is forbidden to intervene in Ukraine because, as you said, the country is at war. I just thought that this House would stick to the rule of law, but that is not the case. Second, our assistance must be conditional. We say that sanctions against the Russians should be maintained to ensure that they will implement the Minsk agreements. In my opinion, the counterpart is true: we must only support and help Kiev if Kiev respects the Minsk agreements, which is not the case today. Third, we interrupted a normal electoral process and then ended up with a bankrupt country: 10,000 dead, 100,000 refugees, purchasing power divided by four and it's not over! Your help will not change this situation!

name: Elmar BROK
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work It is precisely your last remark that makes it clear: we have people on the right here who promote Russian aggression, and we have people on the extreme left who cheer them on. That is why we must recognise that this is about a country in Europe enjoying freedom and that the economic aid that we want to decide on today – I thank the Commission for the presentation – must be further developed by us so that this people has a chance. This is not about normal macro-economic aid, it is about the struggle for freedom of a people whom we must support against the right and left supporters of a dictatorship for the freedom of the whole of Europe.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Ukraine has long been in a very bad economic situation and the conflict has exacerbated this problem. Parliament therefore supported the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, provided that this aid is constantly monitored so that the funds are used to reduce population poverty. At the same time, the representatives of our neighbouring state must urgently take measures to combat widespread corruption and fraud and improve tax discipline. This aid is not the first and certainly not the last.
