When we approved macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in 2010, the resolution also included the condition for the thorough implementation of the necessary structural reforms or the measures to be taken by Ukraine in the field of preventing and combating fraud and corruption. Today is 2015 and we are once again asking Ukraine to do the same. That is why the question is: will we be able to control the flows of this aid for the benefit of the people of the hard-pressed people of Ukraine, and not their oligarchs? Commissioner, please respond.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank the European Parliament for its broad support for the Commission’s proposal, which we could see in the debates. It is important that we are moving forward with financial assistance to Ukraine, given the worsening security and economic situation there. Some colleagues raised the question of whether this financial assistance is sufficient, and quite clearly we will need to discuss further steps, further support, further involvement, with Ukraine in the coming months and years. It is certainly a step forward. Some colleagues also raised the question of the purpose of this macro-financial assistance. It has been outlined very clearly that this assistance can be used only for non-military purposes, but I would like to underline once again the urgency of this decision, in view of Ukraine’s immediate financing needs and the need to make this disbursement to Ukraine before the summer break. As you know, amendments to the Commission proposal could trigger a second reading and significantly delay the adoption process. Therefore, on the basis of the valuable work done by the rapporteur and the Committee on International Trade (INTA), I count on your support for this important financial assistance programme to Ukraine in these difficult times, and I urge you to vote today in favour of the Commission’s proposal without the 12 amendments tabled last week. The President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, is going to Kiev next week and hopes to be able to deliver the good news in person. Thank you for your attention and, I hope, for your support.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I have to say that I am very optimistic. I hear the unanimous voice of support for Ukraine from so many groups in the House, and I hope that in a few moments we will all be proud Members of a European Parliament which made the right decision. We thank you again for all your support and wisdom. (Sustained applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will be held shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – Today we send a strong message to the people of Ukraine and to Ukraine’s neighbours that despite these extremely difficult times, the European Union will continue to support its partner. Since political developments in early 2014, the extreme vulnerability of the Ukrainian economy must also be addressed to secure a peaceful and prosperous future for all Ukrainians. Although Ukraine’s troubles remain far from over, I am confident that this assistance will nonetheless make a difference in providing much-needed help to balance the country’s budget.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – It is unquestionable that the Ukrainian economy needs help because it is severely affected by long-term structural problems due to armed conflict. Since Ukraine has lost access to international debt financing markets, only additional macro-financial assistance from the European Union can fill the external financing gap, because Ukraine will need capital to carry out all the reforms and stabilise the domestic political situation. On the one hand, I must therefore welcome the European Union's commitment and readiness to support countries that are embarking on a path of reform at a time of economic and polar difficulties, but on the other hand it is very important that we are able to trace how the funds provided will be used, especially in Ukraine, which has a fundamental problem with corruption and clientelism. Therefore, if the European Union has embarked on a path of full support for Ukraine, we must show that we are willing and ready to help and that we can act quickly, responsibly and stand by our political and economic commitments. However, it is very important that European solidarity is not only blind, but supported by real results and action, because the economic and economic situation in our Member States is also not very satisfactory, and many citizens rightly feel that the European Union should first resolve the urgent economic problems within itself and only then help externally.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. - The European Commission's proposal to allocate an additional €1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is important and crucial in many eyes. Ukraine is a country of strategic importance for the European Union, but also for countries of the extreme same old continent, which are not members of the EU, for geopolitical reasons, and for the sake of fragile political stability and the currently extremely strengthened relationship with Russia. The European Union has felt the effects of the Ukrainian crisis both economically and socially. There is no doubt that Ukraine needs the necessary economic and social reforms in the form of mitigating the negative effects of the crisis and to stimulate comprehensive growth. I believe that this €1.8 billion is going towards the support of the European Union and its bodies, the launch of structural reforms and democratic processes to prevent the further deterioration of the long-standing economic recession and stagnation caused by various conflicts and occupations, and to pave the way for genuine change. I also highlight the fruitful effectiveness of a common and coordinated approach in delivering a holistic assistance plan that can, indirectly, be a catalyst for the mobilisation of additional funding. I believe that the macroeconomic financial assistance mechanism, which represents a remarkable european union response to similar crisis situations and is also available to other EU partners, can contribute to the stability of Europe's Eastern Neighbourhood and accelerate Ukraine's recovery process.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the decision to grant macro-financial assistance is of the utmost importance for political and economic reforms in Ukraine. Our relations with Ukraine are developing within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy and we must support the government's efforts on the reform path.  The military conflict, which has led to the violation of sovereignty and territorial integrity, is detrimental to the Ukrainian economy. Much of it was focused on Russia's annexed Crimea peninsula, as well as in the region held by the separatists Donetskaya and Luhansk. As a result, the country's economy has shrunk by more than 20% in the past year, and the direct budgetary costs of the conflict further worsen Ukraine's balance of payments and liquidity.  In this context, I consider the granting of financial assistance to be a fully timely measure, because the country's external financing needs are significantly greater than initially determined. For their part, the authorities in Ukraine must reaffirm their commitment to reforms in line with the framework provided for by the Association Agreement and present a clear action plan.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – Helping Ukraine in rebuilding its economy and providing advice regarding structural reforms is a very important and honourable task, since these solid building blocks are a necessity for a sustainable future for Ukraine. Unfortunately, our efforts to help Ukraine in the long term would be largely undermined if France were to provide Mistral warships to Russia. Right now, the French are waiting for an improvement in the conflict, like an effective ceasefire or at least a temporary stagnation in its perpetual escalation, in order to be able to deliver these warships to Russia. This is the wrong attitude towards this problem, since we have to keep in mind the bigger picture. Even if we make progress towards solving the conflict in Ukraine, we must remember this was not an isolated incident in Russia’s aggressive expansionism in the region. Unless regime change happens in Russia, there will never be a right time to provide military equipment to a country that does not respect the territorial integrity of its neighbours, and where opponents of the regime are murdered. Since France cannot sell these warships to Russia at any time in the near future, a different buyer for these ships has to be sought.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is voting time. Because of the delay, the oral explanations of vote do not take place immediately after the vote, but at the end of today's debate. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Mr President, after the emphatic discussion that I had with President Schulz – who told me that I should intervene now and not two hours ago – I call for this report to be referred back to committee on the basis of Rule 188(2). The reason is that, if you read the report, there are still doubts about a number of important issues – WikiLeaks documents and so on. There are also doubts about something that is especially important. When we dealt with the case of Mr Severin, we agreed to lift his immunity but on the condition that his capacity to exercise his mandate was not affected, that his personal freedom was not restricted. I would ask the Committee on Legal Affairs to take the same decision in the current case, and to reconsider this, so that Mr Uspaskich’s personal freedom is not restricted. I do not see why Mr Uspaskich should be treated in a less favourable way than Mr Severin, who was pursued for corruption, which is a much more serious matter. For that reason, I ask you to have a vote to refer this back to the committee.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, although Mr Verhofstadt is a political opponent, I strongly support his proposal. I served for more than ten years on the special committee, which was then called the Committee on Regulation, Verification of Powers and Immunities. There was, more than twenty years ago, in this Parliament, objective jurisprudence, due to one of our colleagues - Mr Donnez - which made it very clear that when there was a fumus persecutionis, a smell of political persecution, that the Member was being pursued by political opponents and for political reasons, his immunity had to be maintained. I think I have always observed this case law personally, even when it was a political adversary. I have observed with regret an evolution of the committee which tended to maintain the immunity, say, of mainstream parliamentarians and to lift it systematically, even for matters of political expression, for "politically incorrect" parliamentarians. I conclude, Mr. President. I would have liked Mr Verhofstadt to apply the same ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Uspaskich had a great opportunity to speak in his case. The Committee on Legal Affairs has been very careful, very careful in this matter, as it has done in other cases of immunity. We have dealt with this in detail – already in the last parliamentary term. The whole thing is a procedure that is now before the Court of Appeal, and we have once again dealt with this same case very carefully in the Committee on Legal Affairs. That is why the decision is absolutely ripe – and now. We have looked at this case really long and very closely and now is the time to vote on it. (Applause)

name: Eva KAILI
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I should like to move the following oral amendment so that paragraph 37 reads as follows: ‘Welcomes the swift implementation of country-by-country (CbC) reporting for banks as defined in the fourth amendment to the Capital Requirements Directive (CRD4); calls on the Commission to introduce as a next step mandatory CbC reporting for cross-border companies, excluding SMEs, in all sectors and in all the countries in which they operate, including non-cooperative jurisdictions and tax havens, through an immediate revision of the accounting directive, whilst ensuring that administrative burdens are minimised.’

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the recent terrorist attacks in Tunisia (2015/2633(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we discussed the situation in Tunisia to some extent in the margins the last time we discussed Libya in Strasbourg. I remember that, on that occasion, we said that Libya was definitely one of the main problems we have to deal with in our neighbourhood, and that this applies not only to European countries but also to Libya’s neighbouring countries, starting with Tunisia. And here we are, some weeks later, discussing that fragile situation which is even more evident after the attack which took place last week. Tunisia is a very special neighbour for us. First of all, it is a neighbour which demonstrates that democracy, freedom and inclusive politics can be the future for the region. I was very impressed by the words of a boy participating in the demonstrations just after the attack in Tunis, who said that what terrifies the terrorists is ‘us’ – referring to his generation of Tunisian people in that street. The best response we can give to the attack that took place, and to the fragility of Tunisia, is to support that boy, that girl, those Tunisians of all ages who were in the streets reacting to the attack – just as French citizens, together with others, reacted to the attack in January in Paris – all the Tunisians, especially the younger generation, who believe in a free, democratic, open future for the country. The day before the attack, we were here in Brussels, together with the Foreign Minister of Tunisia, for the Association Council between the European Union and Tunisia. We were doing two things. On the one hand, we were discussing, as we do among partners, the positive developments in the country in the last year – the adoption of a new constitution, legislative elections, presidential elections, a unity government – and also the elements that make Tunisia fragile still: its youth, which is highly educated but has very low employment rates and very poor employment experiences; the place in society for young people and for young girls in particular in Tunisia; the fact that some steps in the democratic process still need to be taken – I am thinking of the local elections due to take place later this year; the differences – the cleavages – between different parts of the country, in which different regions have huge differences of income, social conditions and economic conditions; a sense of disparity within the country (we were even discussing the possibility of promoting twinnings between some regions or cities in Tunisia and some regions or cities in the European Union); and also the security challenge for the country. The security challenge comes, first of all, from the fact that Tunisia is one of the countries, if not the country, in the region where the number of foreign fighters is highest, around 3 000; but it also comes from the situation in Libya and the issue of border control. But apart from discussing all these things, we were also doing something else with the Foreign Minister of Tunisia. We were signing cooperation agreements together to open up European Union programmes to Tunisians: those Tunisian young people, enterprises, students or researchers who are willing, or who aspire, to participate in European Union programmes in an open way, opening the way for strong cooperation. We also discussed our next high-level visit from the European Union after my own visit – I visited Tunisia the week after the new Government took office in February – and the fact that next Tuesday we will visit the country with President Tusk. The day after the attack I had a telephone conversation with the Prime Minister of Tunisia. We exchanged condolences – from my side for the Tunisian victims and for the attack on the heart of the country, and he expressed his condolences to me in the sense of the European Union, as many of the victims were Europeans. But he basically told me one thing: that they were doing all they could to react, to make sure that this attack did not interrupt their process, which was still fragile and difficult but which was on track, and that they needed to be supported by friends, and they saw the EU countries as their main friends. I passed this message to the European Council which was taking place on the same day, and which opened with a minute of silence. I shared with the Heads of State and Government the concrete elements of our effort to be a special friend to Tunisia in these difficult times, and our effort to increase cooperation. This is about four different levels of increasing cooperation: security cooperation, financial support, support for the economy with concrete, immediate measures, and regional cooperation focusing on Libya. Let me go quickly through these four issues, starting with security cooperation. Obviously security is at the heart of a democracy and of a democratic system, but the converse is also true. Security can be sustained only with a genuine democratic process respecting human rights and the rule of law, and we know that one strengthens the other. Democracy strengthens security and security strengthens democracy. That is why, from the European Union side, we are engaged in three different reviews in Tunisia: one on justice, one on border management and the third on security-sector reform. Actions on border management will start shortly, and a very ambitious security-sector reform programme, addressing counter terrorism, among other challenges, is now in its very final stage of preparation – this will include EUR 25 million. We are also working with our Tunisian partners to support the reform of their justice sector. We know that we need to do much more, especially at the present time. The EU counter-terrorism coordinator was in Tunis, at my request, just a few days before the attack, and started discussing with his counterparts areas of cooperation, including a counter-terrorism dialogue and a package of measures that will soon be finalised and, we hope, will be implemented in the coming months. It is important that in this process we keep the partnership on a completely equal level and that we discuss and decide everything with our Tunisian partners. However, we know that supporting Tunisia’s stability requires not only security. It means mainly – and I stressed this in my public messages as strongly as I could – supporting the economic and democratic transition. This is what will make Tunisia stronger. How do we do that? First, through financial assistance. Since 2011 the European Union has more than doubled the initial commitments to Tunisia. For last year alone – 2014 – nearly EUR 170 million was allocated to Tunisia, and micro—financial assistance of up to EUR 300 million in loans comes in addition to that. Financial allocations for 2015 have not yet been completely decided, but we are working with Commissioner Hahn to make sure that Tunisia gets what it needs and what it deserves, and that is also in our own interests. But beyond financial assistance, there are concrete measures – sometimes even creative measures – that we have to put in place to accompany Tunisia along its path of strengthening democracy and the economy. A true progressive integration of the Tunisian economy into the European internal market, supporting the economic model that was chosen by Tunisia and in the manner and pace suited to its own economy: this could be one element. The European Union is ready – and we started discussing this with the new Tunisian authorities last month – to start negotiations for a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement with Tunisia. It is probably also important to give a positive sign to investors, so that they can find ways of supporting economic recovery in the country. This will obviously bring results in the medium and long term, but we also have an urgent need to support Tunisia immediately. Earlier this year we adjusted our monthly import quotas on olive oil – something very small, but something very important for Tunisia – and we can do more in this respect. The Commission is also starting to work on Tunisia’s application to be associated with the Horizon 2020 research programme. These are only examples – and others will follow – of where we can make a difference completely and immediately. The fourth level of cooperation is, obviously, in relation to Libya. On one side there is the border issue, on the other side there is the bigger Libya issue that affects the situation in Tunisia. I expect some speakers will return to that, so maybe I will leave more for my replies in the end, but you know – and we discussed this in Strasbourg last time – that we are increasing the level of our commitment and of our engagement in diplomatic work. Just two days ago here in Brussels, I myself hosted a meeting of 34 mayors from various cities in Libya. Listening to them, I heard on the one side a desperation that only mayors can understand, facing their own people in very difficult situations. Most of those cities were bombed while we were meeting. But on the other side there was a strong, passionate, emotional feeling of needing to move forward and finding the political agreement that could allow Libya to restart. That meeting produced good results in terms of concrete cooperation and confidence-building measures, and also an appeal to the political track to produce a result. You know that a plan to establish a new political framework is currently being discussed, not only in Rabat but also in Tobruk, Tripoli and other cities, and I think – and it is also the view of our Tunisian friends – that this will be the only way to solve the Libyan crisis. Let me add one more thing before I finish, and this is about you, honourable Members, and Tunisia. Parliamentary cooperation is also an essential part of the support that Tunisia is looking for. It is a country where your engagement can have a huge impact. The two European Union electoral observation missions in 2011 and in 2014, and the European Parliament contribution to the ongoing EU project assisting the Tunisian parliament, were really significant for them, and also for us. I look forward to the establishment of the Joint Parliamentary Committee with Tunisia, which is provided for in the action plan for a privileged partnership. The European Parliament, by strengthening its links with the new parliament, can certainly play a key role in reinforcing Tunisian democracy. I think we all saw the images of Tunisian Members of Parliament singing their hymn inside the Parliament during the attack, just as they were working on an anti-terrorism law. Our debate today is also our way of standing together with them and saying to all Tunisians – not only the Members of Parliament but starting with them – and to the rest of the world and the region, that they will never be alone, and that if they turn towards us to look for friends, we will be there ready to support them. They will always find us ready.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I forgot to point out that there is no catch-the-eye procedure on this item other than the group spokesmen and that blue cards cannot be used. I would also ask you to stick strictly to speaking time. We are very late.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, immediately after the appalling attack on the Bardo Museum, the group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) condemned this act and, as I did a week ago on social media, I would like to express my condolences to the families and loved ones of the victims and to show our full solidarity with the Tunisian people in this ordeal. The attack on the Bardo Museum targeted the country in the region, which has made real efforts to turn the promises of the Arab Spring into reality. Beyond the innocent victims, the attack was therefore aimed at hitting the Tunisian democratic transition itself, a transition that is a political and institutional scenario unique in the Arab world. But make no mistake, the Tunis attack is not only an attack on our partner but also an attack on Europe.  First of all, it is obvious, because the majority of victims are European citizens. Secondly, because the security of the Mediterranean is also our security. Finally, because the attack on the Bardo Museum is an attack on our values: tolerance and fundamental freedoms. Daesh claimed responsibility for this attack, once again confronting us with the barbarity of an ideology built on a political interpretation of Islam and on the rejection of the other. The same barbarism and intolerance that struck Yemen last Friday. The same barbarism and intolerance that struck Christians in Pakistan, victims of suicide bombings, on 15 March. In the face of all this, we must more than ever stand firm in the defence of our values, fight together against terrorism and fanaticism, with our partners and, first and foremost, with Tunisia. We have supported the democratic transition of this country from the beginning and we must not abandon it in these critical times. There is a need for real international support and I look forward to hearing from the High Representative on all the dimensions of this cooperation, which absolutely needs to be strengthened. I would like to add that, in a few days, a delegation of our colleagues who are part of the delegation for relations with the Maghreb countries and the Arab Maghreb Union will visit Tunisia to exchange with our parliamentary colleagues.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I returned this morning from Tunis, where I had some institutional meetings, starting with the President of the Parliamentary Assembly, who confirmed to me that the main objective of the terrorist attack was the Tunisian Parliament. In the exchange of views I had with the various interlocutors, I sensed the awareness that Tunisia could be an ideal target for a terrorist attack. This country which initiated the Arab Spring is also the most advanced country on the road to democratic transition and the ability of the political forces to create, not without a lively dialectic, a modern Constitution and a unity government, after the elections a few months ago, can only be positively underlined.  For our part, we must be equally aware that Tunisia has been affected precisely because a successful outcome to this experiment would be a point of reference for the whole region and for the whole of Europe, because that would be the greatest demonstration that it is possible to secure a democratic and free future in an Arab country. This is not acceptable to terrorists, because their objective is chaos throughout the Mediterranean region. That is why we can only agree with what the President of the Republic of Tunisia said: terrorism is not just a problem for Tunisia, it concerns everyone. It is also because many European tourists were killed in the attack on the Bardo museum, and this has had a twofold consequence: on the one hand, the raising of the level of fear, which is already very high for the events in Libya, and, on the other, a negative impact on Tunisia's image with objective devastating consequences – I am thinking in particular of the economic revenues from tourism.  If this is clear to us, then we need a few words and many concrete actions. Today, not tomorrow! More than ever, Europe has a decisive role to play vis-à-vis Tunisia on two fronts. Firstly, we need political support for democratic institutions and forces by acting institutionally and civilly, in order to strengthen the antibodies capable of dealing with the increasingly pervasive threat of the Islamic State – and here, as the High Representative mentioned, there is, of course, our task, too, of the European Parliament. And then we need a substantial financial contribution, now, along the lines of what we gave Ukraine a few minutes ago in terms of financial assistance. This is the first test of the new neighbourhood policy, of its ability to be flexible and to identify priorities, and I have no doubt that for us, for socialists and democrats, Tunisia is today the priority.  Madam High Representative, I am aware of your sensitivity, but I would ask you to be involved in our request and to make possible as soon as possible, in addition to the things you have said, a political decision by the European Commission and the Council by giving a concrete follow-up to the Association Council that took place on 17 May, precisely in order to ensure that these events respond effectively to the problems we have in Tunisia today.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, firstly on behalf of the ECR I would like to extend my condolences and prayers to the families and the victims of the 18 March Bardo museum shooting in Tunis. Twenty-three people died in this brutal assault, where gunmen were randomly firing with automatic weapons at innocent visitors and tourists. Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the attack, and whether or not it is true that it was actually carried out by ISIS – we do not know – the attack shows the threat posed by Jihadist terrorists to the democracies of the world. Tunisia is a Muslim-majority country, and the lone success story of the Arab Spring. These terrorists do not seem to care who they kill: Muslims, Christians or Jews. They only care about one thing, and that is the destruction of those they view as an enemy of their utopic caliphate. These men are evil. They are a threat to everything this parliament and the EU stands for. It is our duty in this House and in the European Union to do everything we can in our power, both economically and in security terms, to help the fledgling democracy of Tunisia.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, as I augured in the debate on the situation in Libya, held at the previous plenary meeting, Tunisia's breakdown has already reached Tunisia.  I would like to remind you that the High Representative stated in the same debate that the situation in Libya and North Africa is a priority of the European Union together with that of Ukraine. However, this equal priority does not seem to be reflected ely in economic terms or in political terms. In particular, two-thirds of the funds of the European Neighbourhood Instrument go to the eastern region of Europe, with a population of just over 12 million, while the southern region, with a population of 22 million, is not given the same attention. This highlights the imbalance of priorities.  But the situation in the southern part of the Union is extreme. The European Neighbourhood Policy needs to be urgently revised to ensure in a balanced manner the Union's ongoing and in-depth commitment to its eastern and southern partners.  In the specific case of Tunisia, last week's terrorist attack, in addition to seeking to derail its fledgling democracy, has sought to harm its most important productive sector, tourism. We cannot forget that Tunisia is the only country where the democratic transition has been genuine: in no other Arab country is there an Islamist government that has won and lost power in free elections; there is no other State on the southern shore of the Mediterranean – the southern border of the European Union – other than today a religious or military autocracy, except Tunisia; and the Islamic State, which we are far from defeating, is knocking on your door. We must therefore meet this situation, we must help Tunisia with all the means at our disposal and initiate a comprehensive support plan, including loans, investments and security assistance over the coming years. We cannot afford a single more focus of tension and instability on Europe's southern border, we cannot afford to lose Tunisia.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, thank you, Mrs Mogherini, for coming back to this House. First, condemn and regret these terrible attacks in the name of sectarianism and religious fanaticism. Unfortunately we had had warnings in the impoverished south of the country, there had also been such attacks and we had not listened to them much. In her reaction, Madam High Representative, she was right to rush to refer to Libya, she is not right, because the threat of jihadist terrorism cannot be attacked country by country. This approach based on the idea that all the evils of the Middle East were the result of the existence of a handful of dictators has generated monsters such as the organization of the Islamic State. Because it must be said clearly and without any plugs that this terrorist organization is the daughter of interference policies. The United States preferred to fatten and strengthen the brutal Gulf monarchies in order to secure their geopolitical dominance, and some European governments, against their own interests, did an embarrassing follow-up. The Islamic State is now well-funded and well-armed by a rich rear, and it is growing stronger in the Mediterranean because many actors in this European Union actively contributed to destroying the structures of secular states. For the solution, we cannot forget the importance of regional actors; we cannot forget the importance of multinational institutions. But it should be emphasized that it is not time for unilateral interventions, neo-imperial adventures, or serving Atlantic interests that are less and less like our own.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The attack on the Bardo Museum in Tunis claimed the lives of at least 22 civilians. Meanwhile, the Islamic State has claimed to be involved in this heinous crime. Shortly after the attack, you, THE EU's foreign affairs representative, assured the Tunisian Government of its support, referring not only to security measures, but also to the economic and democratic development of the country, and have once again explained this in great detail here today. It is important that we in Europe show our solidarity with Tunisia at this difficult time. However, we must also translate our words into action and be prepared to provide adequate resources to support Tunisia more than we have done so far. Support must ensure that this attack does not become a setback for the country's transformation process, but that Tunisia can continue to develop into a democratic model of success in the region. Thousands of Tunisians have taken to the streets in the past week. During the protests, a central slogan of the Jasmine Revolution of 2011 was again used in a modified form. The shout "We are not afraid!" became "We are not afraid of terrorism!". Given the global threat posed by jihadists, this should be a central message not only for Tunisia, but for the entire region and also for Europe. "We are not afraid of terrorism!" should also be seen as a warning against hasty measures and overreactions. I see it as our task to support the Tunisians in making measures to protect against terrorism in line with human rights principles. It would therefore be very important for the EU to promote, in particular, the strengthening of institutions governed by the rule of law. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the World Social Forum now taking place in Tunis. The fact that it is taking place is also a concrete declaration of solidarity with Tunisian society.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, why has this tragedy struck only Tunisians, ladies and gentlemen? In recent months, I have visited Tunis three times to observe the smooth running of elections in the only country where the Arab Spring has really paid off. Today, when I think of the images of blood and death of the attack, I know that they will not succeed in erasing those of the moments I experienced: images tinged with enthusiasm, of this incredible commitment of the Tunisian people in preparing and organizing the elections. One word still resonates: choukran, thank you. Thank you for being with us, supporting and encouraging us as we regain our freedom of speech, vote and opinion as we strive for equitable social reform, as we begin to build a better future for our children. Everywhere, at polling stations and elsewhere in the country, I found hospitality, education and warmth. I also visited its museums, this wonderful Bardo and its collection of mosaics, which bear witness to three millennia of exchanges and relations between Europe and North Africa. Why Tunisia, then? Because some want to destroy its tourism and its economy, to stifle its democracy and the voice of young Tunisian citizens. To plunge the country into anarchy, defending positions of strength with the flames of violence. To make it seem, with terror, that there is no possible coexistence between Islam and democracy. And that interest is not just that of the terrorists, unfortunately. If we fall into the trap of the clash of civilizations or religions, this fallacious rhetoric will win. I believe in the words of the King of Jordan when he says that Muslims around the world will not allow terrorists to exploit their faith to commit intolerable barbarism. Nor should we allow them to exploit us. We need to redouble our efforts in a concrete way. It is only by cooperating and working together in the economic, political, security, social and cultural fields that we will overcome, always together, the culture of strength with the strength of culture. Yes, colleagues, we are all Tunisians.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, let us not confine ourselves to condolences, which I naturally share – many of the victims are my fellow countryman, unfortunately. Remember that ISIS does not fight with fathers or prayers, perhaps even in Latin, even in Arabic. Rather, Europe should immediately provide Tunisia with suitable means, military but also intelligence, and operate not only through the usual ugly figure of bureaucrats sent around Tunis, staying in five-star hotels without concluding anything concrete. The first of the goals is to seal the borders with Libya, to seal these borders to stop the uncontrolled start of Allah's warriors. And so I deplore the crocodile tears, as an Italian, of certain rulers who have done nothing to combat the phenomenon of foreign fighters and who, however, are in the front row in front of the cameras crying at the funerals of the poor victims. Something concrete must be done, this danger must be seriously combated and, of course, poor Tunisia must be helped. We all go on holiday to Tunisia!

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Vice-President of the Commission (VP/HR). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by responding to Mr Mas's report. Borghezio. The issue of border control between Tunisia and Libya was exactly one of the points we discussed with the Tunisian Foreign Minister the day before the attack on the Bard. And he said at that meeting that Tunisia has no interest and no intention of sealing its borders with Libya. I am used, with respect for a country, first and foremost to respecting the decisions of its authorities, especially when it is one of the countries that has experienced a successful democratic transition. So the first basis, the first principle of our support for Tunisia, must be respect for the autonomous decisions that the Tunisian authorities take and will take, because it is clear that the challenge is common.  It is also clear that these are not clashes of religions or civilisations, because the victims were together Europeans, not Europeans, Tunisians, Muslims, Christians and atheist, and it is also clear that the attack was both an attack on Europe and an attack on Tunisia. So here there is no confrontation between north and south of the Mediterranean: here there is a common, patient, difficult and concrete work to be done together between the two shores of the Mediterranean against violence and terrorism.  And it is a job that we cannot delude ourselves that can only be solved by means of security measures. Security measures, even immediate, must be taken. But we will only win the challenge – and this is what our Tunisian friends tell us – if we can really invest in the younger generation of Tunisia by offering jobs, by offering a place in society, by offering dignity, which was what young Tunisians were asking for by starting the revolution years ago: dignity! I believe that this is our task, that of respectfully supporting a path that is specific to Tunisia, with all the means we have, but with respect and dignity. There have been a number of speeches which have raised a number of specific points, and I will mention two of them. One concerns the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy. This was one of the points that we discussed with Tunisia just the day before the attack. This is the subject we will have on the agenda of a meeting in Barcelona on 13 April with our neighbours on the southern shore of the Mediterranean, as well as with our eastern partners later in May. The review of the European Neighbourhood Policy can be an exceptional tool for us and our partners, if we do not take it as a bureaucratic review, as an internal exercise; it can really be the time to think together, in that spirit of mutual respect, what tools can be most useful to us together, to face the challenges that today are different from those that were there ten years ago.  And in the South there is certainly the challenge of the stability of the region, there is the challenge of terrorism, there is the challenge of the absence or fragility of state institutions and there is the challenge of Libya, which is not just a Libyan challenge because, as some of you have said, the victims are all the same, and I agree. The victims are all the same: we were referring to other attacks that had killed other victims and on which we react less, I agree very much. The victims are all the same and they are all important and I would like to say a word today, here, also about the victims that are in other parts of the world, sometimes very close to Tunisia: I am thinking of Nigeria, I am thinking of what is happening in Yemen. This is not the subject of this evening, but we must be careful first of all not to apply double standards in our condemnations, in our reaction, and we must also be careful that regional crises do not stop – and here I would like to refer to the invitation made to me by one of you to call for answers, not unilateral but within the multilateral framework. Well, I take up this appeal. It is a work that we are doing on a daily basis and laboriously together with the United Nations, together with the Arab League, together with our regional partners. I believe that it is particularly important at this time for all actors, particularly in the region, to act responsi responsi responsily, not only in Libya but also on Yemen.  We need a regional framework that, together with the multilateral and international framework, together with the United Nations, together with the European Union, will be able not only to react but also to act by seeking sustainable solutions in the long term, because it is all too often the case that a way of 'solving', in many quotation marks, a crisis turns into a new crisis years later. Then we must be forward-looking and understand how, starting with Libya, but not only on Libya, we are able to prevent future crises and also prevent terrorism in the region. One last note I want to make is with respect to the allocation of the funds. Some people have referred to an unfair division: two thirds for the East and a third for the South. It is an unwritten rule but it is an unwritten rule in reverse: two thirds of the funds are normally allocated to the South, one third to the East. This is an issue that can clearly always be discussed, but I wanted to clarify this fact, which is the case at the moment, not the other way round.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The terrorist attack that struck The capital of Tunisia on 18 March reveals once again the barbarity of Islamists who attack the cultural heritage of ancient civilizations, which is part of the material heritage of all humanity. What could be more vile than to attack the remnants of extinct civilizations and those who come today to admire — or simply discover — what these civilizations have bequeathed to us? In the face of these barbarians, it is more urgent than ever to review our diplomacy and stop supporting regimes that, like those of Saudi Arabia or Qatar, are strongly suspected of maintaining Islamic terrorism.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. The terrorist attacks that hit Tunisia on 18 March are another attack on the European civilizational model. The attackers chose the Bardo Museum in Tunis, not only because it attracts thousands of Western tourists each year, but also because it is a veritable showcase of pre-Islamic Tunisian heritage. The jihadists, like their leaders at the head of the Islamic State, intend to carry out their own cultural revolution to clean up a history they consider blasphemous. In the face of this barbarity, it is time for the European Union to get rid of the oripeals of its idealism in order to take on the necessary realism. It was by participating in the programming of the destabilization of Africa that the European Union made the bed of terrorism: the collapse of Libya resulted in Islamist chaos, as the Tunisian head of state, Mr. Béji Caïd Essebsi, pointed out. How much longer, ladies and gentlemen, will you let your idealism be the humus of terrorism? It is time to take responsibility, to review our diplomacy with respect to certain countries suspected of financing terrorism. It's time to reconnect with history.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. I join all those who have offered condolences for the attacks on March 18 th in Tunis. In a region buffeted by war, political instability and suffering, Tunisia is still the only success of the Arab Spring. It is also essential that every effort be made to ensure that this country continues its path to democracy. If any attack on human lives should deserve our deepest repudiation, this tragedy must also be a strong call to action and a strengthened fight against fundamentalism of any kind.  The statements of the High Representative, which I am sure are echoed in this House, are therefore to be commendable. The European Union must not only maintain but strengthen its presence and support for Tunisia, in the fight against terrorism, in increasing security, in the consolidation of democratic regime and in economic and social development.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – Tunisia is the country from which the 'Arab Spring' started. It is the only country in the region where democratic values are visible: moderate Islamic political forces and many non-religious parties are working to sit down at the table, and citizens' rights, including those of women, are well regulated and respected compared to other Arab states.  The terrorist attack on the National Museum in Tunis is an attack on Western values. The European Union must work more closely with its partners to deal with terrorist threats. It is also important to mobilise all the necessary tools to fully support Tunisia in the fight against terrorism and in the reform of the security field. I strongly condemn this terrorist attack; at the political level, such heinous actions must not impinge on the process of strengthening democracy in Tunisia, after the approval in Parliament of the new Constitution.  Tunisia needs security help, in addition to economic and social support. At the same time, we have a duty to stand with it in its commitment to promoting peace and democracy. Such acts of violence must not discourage us, but rather unite us to deal with such threats.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. The recent terrorist attacks on the Bardo Museum in Tunis dealt a severe blow to a country that is a symbol of freedom and democracy and which took to the streets in the wake of the attacks, with determination, on fundamentalism and terrorism. Faced with these odious acts and in the light of the renewed climate of tension that is characterising the international scene, the European Union is called upon to contribute to the fight against terror with a global strategy that is able to combat violence by identifying its deepest roots. It is therefore necessary to increase security in the Mediterranean region, but above all to strengthen political, economic, social and cultural ties, with the aim of creating a vast area of in-depth Mediterranean cooperation. Only with a new commitment by the European Union to the Mediterranean region can there be greater security in Tunisia, the Maghreb and throughout the southern shore of the Mare Nostrum.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Writing. – It is now four years since the ruler Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali was overthrown, and for four years Tunisia has gradually built a democratic country. Only a few months have passed since the first free elections, in which a new progressive constitution was built. In this process, however, the armed jihadist movement has also experienced an upswing. The recent terrorist attack on the Tunisian National Museum bardo is a clear attack on the state's young and still unconsolidated democracy. We must now give Tunisia, as one of the most democratic Arab countries, the greatest possible support in the European Union. It is now necessary to speak out firmly against the atrocities and to prevent the spread of terror. A functioning democracy is one of the most effective means of fighting Islamist extremism and violence. However, we should also start with the backgrounds that are breeding ground for terror: the poor living conditions and the lack of prospects for the future of many young Tunisians, as well as the excessive violence from Libya. The Tunisian Government must now remain strong and prove that the attacks do not lead to greater tension between the Western and pro-democracy camps. Security and democracy are interdependent and security can only be achieved in the long term if we invest in the young generation in Tunisia.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. The terrorist threat has struck again. This appalling attack on the Bardo Museum in Tunis is an attack on Tunisia's democratic transition, but also on Europe and its values. More than ever, the European Union must step up its cooperation with its partners if it is to effectively combat the global terrorist threat and extinguish the hotbeds of jihadism. I therefore welcome the European Council's statement of 20 March that the European Union and its Member States will intensify their cooperation with Tunisia in order to counter this common terrorist threat, strengthen Tunisian democracy and participate in its socio-economic development.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. The attack in Tunisia was an incredible blow, in front of the door of the European house. But not only that: it is a targeted attack on the only case of real desire for democratisation in the region. This is mainly because of this, rather than geographical proximity, that we Europeans, the European Union, should feel involved.  The path taken by Tunisia after the Arab Spring is a model, where the Tunisian Islamic Party, Ennahda, participated in the creation of a secular Constitution, with a view to cooperation and marginalisation of extremist fringes. This path did not end with the blind violence that struck him last week: Tunisia is still a land full of hope. But it is also a land with very serious problems: the country's economy needs important help to reduce general unemployment and youth unemployment in particular. It needs a boost, which will enable us to accompany the commitment to the democratization of the institutions with a real hope of a better life for families.  Europe cannot look away: it is our duty to support the democratic path of states in difficulty, this is an opportunity to give concrete form to the values and ideals on which we have built our common home.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I condemn in the strongest possible terms the horrific terrorist attack at the museum in Tunisia and offer my condolences to the families of the 19 victims. It is an act that threatens the values of peace, tolerance and solidarity nurtured by the civilised world. In these circumstances, full support should be given to the authorities and people of Tunisia in their fight against terrorists and all forms of radicalism. The difficult economic situation does not contribute to democratic stability and institution building, and in this context the EU's role is key. It is important that the EU sends a clear message that Tunisians are not alone and that they have friends who are ready to help them. Members of the parliamentary delegation for Maghreb countries are the 'first among equals' who can help in this regard, expressing solidarity with the people of Tunisia. Also, an important component for Tunisia's democratic and economic development is investment in the education of young Tunisians, as they will be a force for economic recovery. By evenly redistributing EU funding, the European Neighbourhood Policy will contribute to peace and stability at its eastern and southern borders.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on - the oral question to the Commission on conditions of employment, including minimum wages in road transport by Marita Ulvskog on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (2015/2571(RSP)) (O-00 2015- B8-0106/2015) and – the Commission statement on the conformity of The German rules on the minimum wage applicable in the transport sector with EU law (2015/2620(RSP)).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: questioners. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr One of my strongest memories of last year's EU election campaign is a phone call from a priest in Sweden. She expressed her despair at the social distress that prevailed in the large parking lot outside her city. There are rows of trucks lined up, waiting for new runs. Meanwhile, the drivers live and live in their cars. They have difficulty with food and hygiene, make fires in the parking lots or warm themselves in small spirit kitchens in the Swedish winter cold. They have no salary, no collective bargaining agreement – just their waiting. This is unworthy. The haulage industry has major problems with unfair competition. From countries with lower wages and poorer conditions, permanent domestic traffic is operated in countries where higher wages and better conditions apply. People are forced to work in unacceptable conditions, while serious haulage companies are being knocked out. Most Member States have collectively negotiated or statutory minimum wages, including for the transport sector. Some Member States also apply them to, for example, foreign hauliers, in terms of minimum wages and administrative requirements, such as prior authorisation, when carrying out road transport abroad, at transit speed such as international transport or cabotage. I would therefore like to ask the Commission, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, the following questions: firstly, what regulations of European law and national law does the Commission consider to apply to lorry drivers and other workers providing services on the way through or in another Member State? As regards terms of employment and applicable law in transit or the territory of the host Member State? To what extent can domestic regulations apply to foreign transport activities? Question two: how does the Commission view such transport activities in terms of terms of employment and the law applicable to the employment relationship at the time of the provision of the service, including the Posting of Workers Directive and the Rome I Regulation? Question three: what measures does the Commission intend to take to protect the social rights of workers in the road transport sector? The EU's objective of achieving a liberalised internal market will never be realised unless the Commission also dares to recognise the problems, the very serious problems, caused by the EU regulatory framework. As the Commission prepares a major overhaul of Europe's transport rules, it can no longer turn a blind eye to the problems. Instead of further liberalisation, measures must therefore be taken to tackle social dumping and unfair competition. It will be crucial for the content of the European project, both in terms of regulatory framework and in terms of democratic content.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, socially responsible road transport services which are at the same time safe and efficient are the key pillar in the creation of a fairer and deeper internal transport market, a market shaped by people, for people and – that was my promise – one which respects workers’ rights and contributes to developing society and the economy in the EU. Each and every symptom of social unfairness and unfair competition must be combatted. However, prevention is the best means of redress. Let me stress that the Commission welcomes the introduction of minimum wages at national level. They are fully in line with the social policy commitment of this Commission. However, it goes without saying that national measures on a minimum wage applicable to the transport sector must be applied in a manner which is fully compatible with EU law, notably the Treaty principles on free movement of goods and freedom to provide services. This implies, inter alia, that the measures should be non-discriminatory, and that any restriction of such freedom should be justified having regard to the principle of proportionality. The Commission understands that the first questions to be raised in that respect concern the recently introduced scheme operated by Germany. The Commission is assessing thoroughly the German rules on minimum wages and their impact on the transport sector and on the proper functioning of the internal market, taking into account in particular the information provided recently by the German authorities’ response to the Commission’s inquiry. Therefore, I am not yet in a position at this stage of the procedure to provide precise answers to Parliament’s questions. The legal assessment is complex, as it involves basic EU Treaty principles, in particular in relation to the freedom just mentioned, but also several pieces of legislation, notably the Posting of Workers directive. In addition, the measures also need to be analysed in the context of regulations which liberalise the road transport market, Regulation nos 1072/2009 and 2073/2009. The Commission will decide on further steps based on the results of this comprehensive assessment, and will inform Parliament of its position as soon as possible. Mr President, honourable Members, let me turn to the third question and share with you the Commission’s vision for improving social and working conditions in transport, in particular road transport. The Commission is fully committed to promoting fair social standards and fair working and business conditions. These three elements are crucial to creating a sound framework for more and better jobs in the sector. It is also of the utmost importance that the current legislation at both EU and national level is fully and equally understood and applied across the EU. This concerns all stakeholders including Member States, shippers, drivers, freight forwarders and other operators active in transport. With a view to completing the existing framework in line, notably, with the aspects just mentioned, the Commission is currently considering new measures which could be presented in a ‘road package’ in 2016.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the If a lorry driver is travelling in another EU country, he must comply with the local road traffic regulations. No one in the whole of Europe is questioning this. The same must apply to minimum wages. Where Europe-wide rules are lacking, the Member States have the right to take matters into their own hands. This is clearly confirmed by the Posting of Workers Directive, the Rome I Regulation and also numerous ECJ rulings. We Social Democrats want equal pay for equal work in the same place in the transport sector, but also in all other sectors. Then there is the accusation that minimum wages would ruin companies. No, wrong! Companies are ruining businesses. Namely those who engage in wage and social dumping on the backs of workers and at the expense of responsible companies. This greed for profit is to blame for the fact that everything must also be controlled. This has nothing to do with bureaucracy, but it protects honest companies from fraudsters and workers from exploitation.  I have been in close contact with truck drivers for many years, with transport companies all over Europe. What I am experiencing is partly modern slavery. Drivers who drive criss-crossing Europe, stay in the trucks, meet their daily needs at rest stops, and are away from home for months. There were already wages of up to 300 euros a month. This must not be the common business model in Europe. That is why minimum wages must apply everywhere and for everyone, without exceptions, without loopholes. I hope that the Commission will endorse this view and send out a clear signal against social dumping, but also against ruinous undercutting competition, because that is also fair competition in Europe and the freedom of fair businesses.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mrs. Steinruck, you have a blue card from Mr. Chrysogonos. There are requests for more cards, but note that we are in considerable delay, so we will accept a single blue card per turn. We regret that this is the case; but if we didn't, we'd be eternalized. Do you accept the card? He won't accept the card.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: for the ECR Group. – The minimum wage is economic nonsense in itself because it affects the most vulnerable, those whose skills are worth less than the minimum wage. These employees are effectively prohibited from working. It is clearer than the sun that the minimum wage increases unemployment, especially if it is set as high as the German one. Germany may have forgotten that 10 years ago he was the sick man of Europe, but if Germany decides to damage its economy, it is its problem and its business. However, Germany is abusing the minimum wage to foreclosure its market: this is contrary to the single free market. The Minimum Wage Act is discriminatoryly set because it unfairly burdens only foreign carriers, not domestic carriers, who do not have these obligations, by over-administration. Moreover, diets must not be part of the minimum wage, which means that in the end a foreign carrier has to pay more than the German one – this is further discrimination. Such a practice is incorrect, especially from a country that has strong exports because it benefits from a weak euro at the expense of economically weaker countries. I therefore ask the European Commission to act decisively in this case to force Germany to limit its minimum wage only to working relationships subject to German law. This means in the case of transporters, let the hood be paid by the minimum wage, but not for transport, not for export and not for import.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: on the alde group. – I am very concerned about the effects that the German minimum wage law has on European employers, and in particular carriers. Each state is entitled to its own minimum wage law if it wants to, but it is not possible for the application of such a law to be contrary to EU principles. This is clearly about moving against the fundamental principles of the free market and the free movement of people and services. Unfortunately, the German measure fits into the current trend of increasing protectionism within the EU. What is particularly dangerous is that if Germany defends the application of the law in this form, a chain reaction in other countries can be expected. In addition to the financial burden, we cannot forget the huge increase in bureaucracy, which is contrary to the adopted European principle of smart regulation. In the 21st century in Europe, can we really require companies to send documentation by fax somewhere in Cologne or detailed work records of their employees kept only in German?  However, I see, in addition to the legal and technical aspects, that the German minimum wage is a fundamental political problem for Europe, a step backwards. Instead of further unification, an invisible barrier is being built between states in Europe. This, after all, belies the meaning of the EU's existence and the meaning of our work. This afternoon, in front of the Parliament building, I met representatives of Czech carriers who, together with carriers of other countries, are protesting against German law. The demonstrators asked me what information I had, how the situation was evolving. They're worried about survival, especially the little carriers. And what could I have told them? Nothing, Commissioner, nothing. After weeks of asking questions and waiting for the authorities responsible to comment, we still do not have a solution. You know, the worst uncertainty for any entrepreneur is, and for me, that uncertainty is unacceptable. This legal uncertainty has been going on for 3 months. So I ask, Commissioner, when will the final clear assessment really be? When will you have clear unequivocal answers for our carriers and employers? Please publish a German reply that you have had for more than 3 weeks? Are you prepared, if necessary, to start proceedings against Germany for compliance? Thank.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Commissioner, we are here facing a profound vice inherent in the current European construction which gives precedence to the right to competition over law and social progress. While a state - Germany - decides to create a minimum wage, neighbouring countries and the Commission have lobbied anti-socially to ensure that the minimum wage does not apply to truck drivers. This way of doing things condemns European employees to the least perpetual social. We must not accept such logic.  The Commission and our Parliament must support any initiative to enable upward social harmonisation: the implementation of a rising minimum wage in each country, a revision of the directive for seconded workers in the direction of equal treatment for all workers in the European Union. We have a responsibility to put social progress ahead of the right to compete.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: I would not want to be rude, but I ask the guests in the rostrum to refrain from making demonstrations either for or against the views or interventions of the lords and ladies and gentlemen, please.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What exactly do we need the European Union for? If you ask this question to European citizens today, many people say that the EU is a project of neoliberalism, untamed competition and, above all, in the interests of banks and large companies. Social rights have been eclipsed by the pursuit of profit and profit maximisation. The debate on minimum wages in the transport sector that we are having today is a critical point to show that the EU is much more than that. It is precisely the dispute over the issue of minimum wages that makes one thing very clear: that we still have a long way to go in ensuring social rights and fair working conditions for all EU citizens. Indeed, the debate highlights the imbalance between a European integrated internal market, where services can be provided across the EU, and the lack of Europe-wide minimum social standards that ensure fair working conditions for all citizens. It is precisely for this reason that the European Commission should use this debate as an opportunity to finally make sustainable proposals on how to guarantee common minimum social standards in the transport sector and beyond. We, as representatives of the citizens of Europe, should work with trade unions and civil society to make a social and just Europe a reality.

So you're right about a fairer market. And the rules, when do we make them for this fairer market? Because either we start to give answers that have their own certainty or we always come to talk about the same things, and then when it comes to giving concrete answers, I think of the gentlemen who are up there, who I imagine are the category and those directly concerned, we can also ask them not to applaud, but dear my dears we must protect them, so when we decide to regulate a market and give certain and precise rules we can also say that they must not applaud, but the interests that must be respected are theirs.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Mrs Agea, do not cause unnecessary situations and, in any event, respect the presidency's decision.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – On 1 January this year, Germany introduced a statutory minimum wage, applicable to every worker working in Germany. The country where I come from, the Netherlands, has a large transport sector and more than 45% of Dutch freight transport goes to or through Germany.  For the Netherlands, the problem is not so much in the level of the minimum wage. However, the problems are in the huge administrative ballast, the extra costs involved and the fact that competitors from lower-wage countries will compensate elsewhere for the hours worked in Germany. Mr President, in a Union of sovereign states, Germany is free to introduce such legislation. My party also wants this freedom for the Netherlands, if it is needed. However, we would like to urge our eastern neighbours to tackle the negative effects of this legislation, so that the Dutch transport sector is not disproportionately disadvantaged and the Dutch driver does not have to foot the bill.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Mr President, the minimum wage is an economic measure that each Member State is free to apply. It is a measure that applies to citizens of that State or to citizens working in that State with individual employment contracts. Under no circumstances may it apply to workers employed by a company external to the Member State, in the field of services, for example, in particular road transport. The obligation of companies to pay drivers for international transport at least the minimum wage applied in Germany during the period of running in Germany clearly violates the rules of the single market, the services directive. The obligation of companies to keep separate accounts and make them available to the German authorities is a complete requirement outside any national or European legislation. Such a measure constitutes a dangerous precedent, already other Member States have announced their intention to apply similar measures that will create great problems in the single market in the European Union. I add the new rules, in addition to European regulations, imposed by other Member States on drivers, as well as the outlier fines provided for by the legislation of those states, including Germany. I think it is obvious that these measures can be considered protectionist measures. I call on the Commission to continue the infringement procedure and to reach an outcome as soon as possible in order to limit the losses suffered by carriers in a significant number of Member States, including Romania.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Mr President, this new German law, the so—called MiLoG, has been applied on a territorial scale and is contrary to certain EU laws. First of all, it is against Article 56 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Secondly, it is against Article 8 of the Rome I Regulation. Thirdly, it is against Article 1 of Directive 96/71/EC concerning the posting of workers and it is against Article 9 of Regulation No 1072/2009 on common access to the international road haulage market. Truck and bus drivers perform international carriage operations on German territory only on a temporary basis, so they are not workers posted in Germany. These drivers remain employed by their own original employers, and international travel is a core feature of the work they conduct. I would therefore expect you, Commissioner, not to promise us new laws; I would expect you to execute the laws which already exist. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. "Today, together with Mr Liberadzki, I stood out in the rain in front of the building where employers from five countries stood and protested against the current rules. Here is the petition that we have received, which has been sent to us MEPs. I'm going to send it to you, all of you. Do you agree with me, The Congressman, that we would like to see higher wages for our employees, for our drivers? But this solution, the German solution, will bring unemployment to current workers in several countries rather than higher wages. Because in Hungary, only 40,000 to 50,000 people's jobs can be affected. They won't have higher wages, they'll have less work.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". – Yes, I agree that they may lose their jobs, but one more brief explanation. It is not true that they earn 300 euros, as we have heard. The driver's wage, e.g. Polish, consists of three factors: the fixed wage – and this fixed wage is in the order of 500-600 euros per month, the variable elements – and that is 400-600 euros per month and the so-called daily allowance – 45 euros per day for each day of stay abroad. And that is a total of almost 8 euros 50 cents.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Here, My Colleague Liberadzki presented the provisions of the Treaties, directives against which the new rules on the minimum wage in Germany simply conflict, even with the principle of freedom to provide services and the free movement of goods, as well as the directive on posted workers, as clearly defined in the Treaty of Lisbon.  I think that we here today should ask everyone here, Commissioner, to get a very clear position from the European Commission, also in the context of the response that has been sent to the European Commission in recent weeks. So that we have a clear situation. In my opinion, the minimum wage rules in Germany are violating all possible EU treaties and directives, and we should maintain this as soon as possible.  And, dear country, there is one more thing that is very important in this context. After all, in most Member States the right to a minimum rate of pay is protected by national law, so it is in no way acceptable for one Member State, in this case Germany, to impose its wage conditions on other Member States. Take note of this as well. That is why the role of the European Commission is crucial here. I hope that a clear position will soon be sent to the European Parliament as to whether these provisions are in force, and we here in the European Parliament will monitor this matter so that these bad rules are simply suspended as soon as possible.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work she has done. Normally I am very proud of our German thoroughness. But in this case, the German government has gone far beyond the mark with its obsession with detail. It is indeed the case that I am not at all against minimum wages as such. The Commissioner said this: every country can decide for itself, that is national sovereignty – perfectly okay. In this case, however, it is the first time – we are not the first country to have a minimum wage law, many others have already had it – that the transport sector, including the transit sector, has been described in such detail, until then – as my colleague has said – that faxes should be sent in advance to German to the German Government, the German authorities, when exactly which company is on German soil for how long. , and that you should make sure that you pay the German minimum wage. I believe that this goes well beyond the target, and it is also against European law. The examination is not yet complete, as you said. But how can we be in favour of the internal market, where we have different living conditions in different countries, and, of course, different wage levels? That's just the way it is! We certainly do not want lorry drivers to be treated badly. There is also a lot in the wrong. That is exactly what I admit. But I believe that , as Mr Ujhelyi has also said, this also applies to the petition and the demonstration – this is the wrong way to remedy this. We really need to do something different in order to create better conditions for lorry drivers. In fact, I believe that Germany has opened a barrel with it. This is the first time that logistics and transport have been included – a European policy. Now France has followed suit. France now wants to do the same. If other countries join, what should a freight forwarder do, please, who travel through five different countries? In Poland the wage is relatively low, at 1.95 euros or a bit more, in Luxembourg 11.10 euros, in France 9.61 euros, in Germany 8.50 euros. How can this be dispersed, and who is to control it? In this case, I believe that this is clearly about the objective of making people better, and absolutely against Europe and against the internal market. I do not think we can tolerate that at all. Finally, I also fear that small and medium-sized enterprises, which we always want to protect, will now have to give up and lose jobs. That is not Europe's will either! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ismail ERTUG
