text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, I would like to thank the I deliberately drew a blue card because Mrs Meissner said that France would now follow suit. My question would be whether this is indeed the case, Mrs Meissner said. Because the French Republic had exactly this law until 2010. It has repealed this and is now considering reintroducing it. There is a fundamental difference between what is actually a fact and what Mrs Meissner has described. I would therefore like to ask her whether she is aware of this.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Perhaps we should check why France withdrew this. That is precisely because it has violated EU law as it was. I repeat: that is precisely the danger. If we start now in Germany and follow France, how can a freight forwarder from Eastern Europe, who pays a lower wage, because there are also other living conditions, different living costs, be able to keep up? This would mean that only the German and French companies can survive, because they can pay for it and the others cannot. That is not European! We want jobs to be everywhere and for people to make their way. That is where we have to start.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, single markets often become a tool for devaluing working conditions. The transport market, which is so important for economic and social development, is a fragile market that is being precarious for unfair practices, such as the relocation of companies to countries with low operating costs. The regulations we have, or do not serve or legitimize social dumping; the principle of freedom of choice in employment contracts, set out in the Rome I Regulation, is a falsehood: the worker can never choose his working conditions against the employer. The European Union must favour, upwards without lowering, harmonisation of living and working conditions: a minimum wage cannot mean the 'lower minimum wage' in some countries of the Union. And we must promote the economic balance between the different countries of the European Union, because this is, in the end, the ultimate cause of these inequalities and differences, and not impose, as has been done, on other countries the working conditions of the countries with the lowest conditions.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the presence of many European transport trade unionists, who are here in our Chamber and listening to us. Social dumping is a hellish spiral that pits employees against each other and favours large companies over small businesses.  We are talking today in the transport sector about savage competition on labour costs because, precisely, employees are particularly mobile in this sector. Dentressangle in the road transport sector, Ryanair in the air transport sector: these companies are not playing the game. In the maritime transport sector, it is the same: a new form of modern slavery is developing, every day, in this respect, with the exploitation of unreported employees. Commissioner, everyone in this Chamber agrees that we have a real problem with social dumping in transport. Yes, let's do it! Let us create a European labour inspection agency to monitor and punish unscrupulous employers. Let's put together a blacklist of these companies. Let us put in place minimum standards for working conditions and wages. This is precisely an opportunity to introduce the minimum wage throughout Europe. As for transport, it is true that we need to move faster: strengthening the rules of coasting in the road transport sector, clarifying, in particular, the problem of national flags in the maritime transport sector. German and French legislation has recently evolved so that every truck driver is paid the minimum wage during, in particular, his passage through the territory. There is no question of waiting for each state to put in place its own legislation. It is up to Europe to take responsibility and provide a common response. If we do not now mobilise against social dumping in this sector, this poison can put an end to our project, the European project. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, I would like to ask the distinguished MEP, when she is already talking about the need to equalize the salaries of those who transport goods, whether she thinks that perhaps the salaries of all doctors in the European Union should be equal because they are surgeons, they are treating us, they care about us, so maybe all doctors should have the same salary, which might be more important than if those who did the hard work of transporting goods had it.  We live in a different Europe, we have different wages, different standards. I'm not talking about social dumping, it's a problem of different standards.

name: Karima DELLI
text: "blue card" answer. "Mr. Member, my sentence was very clear. I said, "This is an opportunity to set up the minimum wage all over Europe." Regardless of the sector: the minimum wage should cover all sectors. This is the social Europe we are waiting for: for the same work, the same salary everywhere in Europe!

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I have something that none of you, my fellow Members, have here, namely 30 years of experience of sitting behind the wheel of a lorry. I know exactly what the problems are, I know why they have arisen, and I see the situation getting worse. In Sweden, the market is flooded with cars driving for compensation that is far below the limit of what a Swedish company can do. The cars are manned by drivers who can have as low compensation as 500 euros a month. That is what you, ladies and gentlemen, have in per diem for two days! You even have more in per diem than they have in the month. What is happening is scandalous – and everything is happening under the protection of the EU cabotage regulation, which is riddled with loopholes. What is happening on our roads is simply not decent. Are minimum wages perhaps a way to go? I don't know, but Swedish companies are going bankrupt on assembly lines. Drivers are made redundant, tax money is lost. Fair competition is not feared, but that situation does not exist now. Then you hear the defense that the drivers of foreign cars have a salary that is quite ok compared to what they earn in their home country. What good is that? They are not in their home country. They have completely different cost of living. Now the question is what the Commission intends to do to put this problem in order. Some call it protectionism and nationalism when trying to protect their country's businesses and employees. I call it morality and decency when we demand fair conditions on our roads and workplaces. Social dumping must be stopped. What are the Commission's proposals to achieve this? It must still be some damn order in the transport sector!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, I too share the concerns expressed by this question. Especially in the area of European road transport we have many examples of exploitation of workers and complete circumvention of their labour rights. Unfortunately, however, the problem is not limited to that. We have complaints where employers are pressuring drivers to work long hours of gruelling driving exceeding human endurance limits. There is also no second driver, as provided for in long road trips, both in freight vehicles and in tourist buses.  This situation poses an increased risk of road accidents.  The way in which the Common Market has been structured gives opportunities to those who do not care about labour rights and allows labour exploitation. In order to stop these phenomena, therefore, we need radical solutions, which will demonstrate European solidarity in practice. We must therefore move towards a fair policy, both in pay and working conditions throughout the Union. This will combat such phenomena and we will find ourselves one step closer to a Europe of peoples and nations and not to a Europe of speculators and exploiters.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: I must tell you that I warmly welcome the arrival of the German minimum wage. I believe that it is important for a social Europe that all the Member States of the European Union should be given a minimum wage. These minimum wages will differ, but they will grow together in the long run - and I know it will take too long for many. But if we all have a minimum wage, then at least we know what we are talking about. The second point. Like Mr Marinescu, I have problems with the maintenance of the German minimum wage for transit traffic. I think that you are making things unnecessarily complex and that this involves an extraordinary amount of administrative rules. I am also curious to see what the European Commission's procedure entails in this area and will teach us. Let's talk about the domestic cabotage in Germany. I assume that the German minimum wage will be paid for transport in Germany by non-German companies. This is another step towards a fairer playing field. Again, I know that things are too slow for some, but a socially and competitive Europe must do so. Then there are the other problems in the sector. Also in the Netherlands we have parking spaces where at weekends 50, 60, 70, mainly Eastern European drivers cook their potty, do their need. That is a distressing social problem. I hope, Mrs Bulc, that you will pay attention to this in the road transport package, because workers in Europe have the right to a fair wage and fair social services. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – How do you explain the imposition of this measure on small and medium-sized enterprises, first of all, which are not able to finance? The truth is that I think that this measure was tailored to the very great German companies and, apparently, the Dutch ones.  Does the member do not believe that this measure was designed to benefit only German companies and bankrupt their foreign counterparts? Don't you believe this is nothing more than a protectionist measure?

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: "blue card" answer. – The answer is clear. Small and medium-sized enterprises also have to pay minimum social conditions. If that is not possible, then the company is probably not viable. It cannot be the case that small and medium-sized enterprises have to survive on EUR 50 an hour. Then we get to the heart of that social Europe. Think of our constituents, too. Support for Europe is currently decreasing and the social paragraph - Mr Juncker said in his introductory speech - will need more attention.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: – Commissioner, I appeal to you and ask whether it is legitimate that the national laws of one country in the transport sector can be imposed on other countries? On what basis? Whether they distort fair competition and whether we do so will not lead to precedents, not only in the field of transport but also in other areas of economic activity. Market fragmentation and unfair competition actually pose a very serious risk to the carriers of eastern European countries, including my native Lithuania. Because they will certainly not be able to compete with the requirements imposed by Germany. Therefore, the worst option can happen, our carriers will go bankrupt. Workers will lose their jobs, lose their income. Finally, in this whole situation, we must take into account the workers themselves and their rights. They are actually doing hard work and must therefore be properly paid and socially protected. Mr Commissioner, I appeal to you once again. The Commission, working together with the Member States, must take the necessary measures in the transport sector to ensure that workers have adequate social guarantees.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: – Mr President, I am very concerned to see the principle of subsidiarity properly upheld. We must respect the competence of Member States and their freedom to set their own minimum wages and address their own social policy issues as they see fit. Under no circumstances should this debate be used as an opportunity to call for an EU-wide solution or an EU framework on minimum wages. These are exclusively the preserve of the Member State and should be addressed at Member State level. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, must defend freedom to provide services and the free movement of goods. This is key to the proper functioning of the single market. The new rules in Germany require prenotification and extra record-keeping, and I think such conditions have brought in additional burdens and administrative requirements which are of grave concern to small businesses. I sympathise with these concerns but it is crucial that we are very clear as to what we are asking the Commission to do and what things the Commission has the competence to do. Interfering in minimum wages is not one of them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: the blue card. – I would like to ask a respected colleague how do you think this decision is not directly related to the protection of your market?

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: blue-card answer. – My concern is that we should maintain the single market – and indeed we still have not completed the single market – which is important, but it is equally important, and possibly more so, that the rights and responsibilities of Member States and the subsidiarity principle be recognised by Europe. I am very concerned that Europe is trying to do more and more. We listened to the Commissioner say we must do the things that we can do better together, but not get involved in detail. My view is that social policy should be the prerogative of the Member States.

name: Ulla TØRNÆS
text: – Mr President, I would like to underline the fact that Germany is, of course, fully within its rights in adopting a minimum wage. The minimum wage itself is not the problem. The problem is that with the minimum wage come piles of bureaucracy which are creating a wall around Germany for foreign workers, and this is not in compliance with the Single Market Act. I do not understand how Germany can decide what the wage should be in different countries. According to the Treaty, Germany does not have the competence to do this. Some people are claiming that the German application of the minimum wage is one of the most serious attacks on the single market since the adoption of the Single Market Act. These protectionist measures create barriers all the way down through Europe. This is very serious and very worrying. It is the Commission’s responsibility to protect the single market. From what I have heard so far, I am not convinced that the Commission is fulfilling its responsibilities in this regard. Having said that, I notice Commissioner Bulc stated that national implementation of the various laws should comply with the different aspects of the EU legislation. Therefore, I have a very simple question to the Commission: will the Commissioner give this House a guarantee today that it will do whatever it takes to protect a smoothly functioning European single market? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". More than twenty countries in the European Union have a minimum wage. And all are for equal pay for equal work in the same workplace. They don't want differentiation. That is why this must be respected. I am glad that Germany, as the 23rd country, finally has a minimum wage. And that has to be taken into account. And abuse is on the increase, social dumping is on the increase! What do we get from this if, for example.B, in Lithuania or Latvia, only lorry drivers who come from Belarus are soon there because they have social dumping? That does not bring Europe together, it divides us. That is why we need equal pay for equal work in the same workplace.

name: Ulla TØRNÆS
text: blue-card answer. – Coming from a country where the social partners actually do the collective bargaining, I am not against a minimum wage, but it is up to the partners to decide what the level should be. I do not think Germany can decide what the level for Danish workers working in Germany should be. As I see it, this is not an issue that Germany can decide and, from my understanding of the European legal framework, Germany does not have the competence to decide on things like that.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Despite the EU's many achievements in building the single market, Germany's new minimum wage law goes against it.  This is particularly noteworthy nowadays, when we are trying to move the economy around by improving the investment environment, and we are building new administrative barriers instead of breaking down barriers. I am personally glad that German workers have finally been given the right to the minimum wage. However, I am afraid that the German Government has used this to gain a competitive advantage and to fundamentally undermine the free movement of services in the internal market.  The application of the German government's proposal in its entirety would be the fault of the liquidation of Czech car transporters. In addition to the considerable financial burden, the implementation of the law also includes a significant administrative burden, which also does not help the free movement of services in the internal market and also applies only to foreign carriers.  The application of this legislation will lead to a deepening of a two-speed Europe and is actually a partial blockage of the labour market. In this respect, we are asking for a clear statement from the European Commission, which should consider whether it will be in the tow of the German Government or whether it will actually represent the interests of all member states and promote European law and the pillars on which the EU is built, including, for example, minimum social standards for workers across Europe or even opening a debate on the Eu-wide minimum wage.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe of good intentions forgets to protect its citizens and businesses, and in order to achieve its objectives it tramples on rights and rules. The single market has considerable advantages, but at the same time we have to overcome so many problems due to the economic and wage differences that exist in different countries and which turn into a distortion of competition. In Italy too, as in Germany, road haulage companies are arriving from Eastern European countries which, thanks to lower labour costs guaranteed by their own states, charge lower prices and therefore unfair competition with Italian or German companies, which are becoming increasingly impoverished and forced to close down.  So what can we do to guarantee both the Single European Market and workers' rights? As a 5-Star Movement, in Italy we have proposed to give minimum social guarantees to citizens and workers with the income of citizenship, and we also share a minimum income of work. In order to reduce the gap with other countries, we must now adopt rules in Europe that take account of where companies actually do their jobs and that protect fair and fair competition. We need clear rules, based on reciprocity. It is not by bringing the companies of the individual Member States to their knees that we will be able to build this Europe.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Road freight transport is the main artery of the European economy. 75% of all transports in the EU are by road. In Germany, employees there receive a minimum wage of EUR 8.50 per hour. Frankly, not to everyone's delight, but concerns also arise from small and medium-sized enterprises: documentation obligations mean greater bureaucratic burdens. But on the other hand, we need fairness in pay. We need to prevent social dumping. We also need protection from those companies that treat their employees honestly. There has been a lot of criticism, especially here. We do not want to have any new walls in Germany. We've had enough of one. The German Government has acted. It has suspended the minimum wage for pure transit journeys through our country for lorries, stopped checks and suspended fines. But when trucks drive through Germany and are loaded and unloaded there, then – as with cabotage – the minimum wage is to be paid. Commissioner, you have promised to review the complicated regulations. Agree! We all need legal certainty while maintaining the principle of subsidiarity. I recommend that we proceed with great care and analyse the full range of impacts on individual sectors and Member States. Distortions of competition to the detriment of workers and to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises must be prevented. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The definition of 'social dumping' has been repeatedly found in this Chamber. I have not met such a definition anywhere in economics, and I have not met an entrepreneur who would provide his services below the costs he incurs. I would like to ask you about the definition of 'social dumping'.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. The most important thing of all is that people feel that they are being paid fairly. There are several ways to do this. As you pointed out, we in Germany, too, now have a minimum wage system that not everyone can accept. The essential thing is that people feel that they have done a job and are being rewarded for it, and that the situation described by colleagues does not prevail, in which people feel nothing more than exploitation. This must be prevented, but we have strong social partners, including here in Germany, with a good social partner tradition. If we can achieve this, we will achieve common ground. Make sure that you also have strong social partners in other Member States of the European Union! Then we will reach the consensus that is necessary in many areas.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, social dumping practices are impoverishing workers and undermining the European project. They must be fought firmly. The internal market and competitiveness cannot be used as a pretext to call into question the improvement of working conditions in all countries and I welcome the German government's decision to introduce a minimum wage for cabotage. This is not a question of defending a particular country, but of defending an idea and a conviction. In December, the European Parliament had already shown its determination by refusing to vote on an act that did not include illegal cabotage practices as serious offences. It is time today for the European Commission to take a serious look at the protection of social rights in transport. Finally, I would like to point out that the application of a minimum wage to coasting operations, which are clearly covered by the Detached Workers Directive, is fully compatible with European law. Road transport companies must comply with the remuneration conditions of the countries where they carry out coasting operations. In France, there is a minimum wage and the government's initiatives will ensure that European legislation is respected.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: Mr President! For the Danish People's Party, there is no doubt as to what the core of this problem is. At the heart of this problem is for us the right to national self-determination. For us, it is a very clear national issue what the different pay and working conditions should be, how to organise a welfare state, and it is not something that the European Union should not interfere directly or indirectly with. The right to organise your national labour market also includes the right to ensure that everyone plays by the rules if you want to be a labourer in another Member State. That is why we believe, in principle, that germans have the right to introduce the minimum wage. It is always debatable whether the control mechanisms are the right ones, but we also have the right to have such control mechanisms, and there is no doubt in my mind that respecting the sovereign rights that nation states should have in cooperation is at the heart of sensible European cooperation.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, because of the very special nature of international road transport, which is different from whether it is transit or coasting, the risky attachment to the seconded workers directive or the Rome I regulation, which is often random, has many negative consequences. Firstly, a great mess for the work environment of international truck drivers, who are either shamefully exploited or have their jobs destroyed, since the national channels have lost thousands of jobs as drivers. Secondly, in response to these facts, the taking of measures by the Member States, and this is the subject of today, which can have serious consequences for the functioning of the single market itself. Thirdly, the uncertainty in which the institutions find themselves on the attitude to be adopted, which is, Commissioner, your case today. I therefore strongly call on the Commission to address this problem and to adopt a specific legal framework for international road transport workers, allowing both to defend their rights and to ensure the proper functioning of this sector, which is so important to the Union. It should be remembered that 72% of goods within the Union are transported by road: it is therefore an essential tool of the market. Current uncertainties and approximations can no longer be tolerated.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission is at the foot of the wall: we are debating an eminently European subject, namely road transport. Without undermining SMEs that, as we know, are creating jobs across Europe, we now need several clarifications. The first is the distinction between transit and coasting activities. It is extremely important that you are clear on this subject. The second point is the link between the work we have done on the Detached Workers Directive and the organisation of the work of road hauliers today. We really need a very clear clarification on this subject, a legal framework, as some of my colleagues have said, because we cannot allow ourselves to be drawn down the slope of social dumping and unfair competition between companies. From the debate I am hearing here tonight, I understand that we are going far beyond that. We are in a debate that is no longer a European debate: we have returned to national debates, in which everyone is defending their piece of bacon. Yes, we need the Commission to be a social commission, as Jean-Claude Juncker has said and promised us. Also, you need to take a step forward and be firm in this area.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Mr President! I very much agree with what has just been said. However, now that almost all Western countries have taken measures to improve conditions in the transport sector, then there could be something wrong with the rules that work at European level. Not a single country knows how to manage according to the rules. What is a carbotage drive? What is a mailbox company? And so on, and so on. No one can answer that. So perhaps it was time for the Commission to come up with an idea of how to create common rules that can be administered in such a way that we have fair competition between countries. There is no doubt in my mind that the intention of European law is that if you want to do business in another country and you want to be a worker in another country, then you have to work under the conditions that apply in that country. It is indisputable. It is in the Treaty. But let us have some common rules that can be administered after, so that we have a fair transport industry again.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for your Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking We have heard many times in this House the slogans of European solidarity and peana in honour of European integration. We boast about how much we have achieved in building a common market and rebuke the examples of violations of economic freedoms, which are, after all, the foundation of the European Union. But when it comes to a specific case of a breach of EU law by a Member State, we have to wait for the European Commission to react.  The minimum wage regulations introduced by the German Government are undoubtedly the result of legitimate reasons: we all agree that decent pay for the work done is indisputable. However, the scope of these rules and the inclusion of transport workers from other countries, rather than helping to protect workers' rights, harms it. They affect the freedom to provide services and directly affect transport undertakings, m.in. from Polish, but not only, which will result not in increases, but exemptions. The adoption of these rules is an attack against free competition and market position, which, thanks to good organization and solid work, have developed themselves – Polish also – carriers in Europe.  Um gut verstanden zu werden, besonders von unseren deutschen Freunden, sage ich es auf Deutsch: Ich rufe die Kommission auf, schnellstens das neue deutsche Gesetz für vertragswidrig zu erklären. Es muss ein eindeutiges Signal gegeben werden für andere Mitgliedstaaten, dass die Vertragswidrigkeiten von der Kommission nicht akzeptiert werden können.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today, instead of talking about rational solutions in line with the overarching provisions of the Treaties, we are basing our debate on the undefined concept of social dumping, which is a pretext for introducing protectionist rules that breach the fundamental principle of freedom to provide services and provide for disproportionately high penalties and administrative burdens for carriers of other countries in any situation: transit, international transport or cabotage.  I would point out that a competitive advantage m.in. on lower labour costs, but also on organisational efficiency and labour productivity cannot be equated with social dumping. We know that lower labour costs are m.in differences in the levels of economic development of individual countries, and are also due to differences in social security systems, the amount of contributions paid by companies. Therefore, social dumping cannot be talked about, as no company can afford to do business below cost.  Today, none of us questions the right of any Member State to introduce a minimum wage in our country. The problem, however, is the scope of the rules on this wage for persons employed in other Member States and its compatibility with the freedom to provide services in the internal market. In view of the chaos and legal uncertainty created by the recent German legislation, today we are demanding a clear and clear answer from the European Commission: to what extent should Germany's national law on the minimum wage be applied to foreign transport carriers, without conflicting with European Union law and the national law of the other Member States.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: – The debate on the application of the German Minimum Wage Act does not only have an aspect of its compliance with EU law, the legal uncertainties of carriers that have been exposed since 1 January this year, and complicated administrative burdens. All this needs to be resolved very soon, Commissioner. In this respect, I, too, call for a swift response to clarify the situation of carriers in compliance with European law. But the context of the debate is deeper and longer-term. Some call it social dumping, someone competitive based on lower costs, especially wages. There are huge differences in the EU's neighbouring countries in the existence of the internal market and the freedom to provide services. For example, the set minimum wage in Germany is four times higher than in the Czech Republic and is even twice as high as the Czech average wage. The current situation in the transport sector has only demonstrated this problem in its entireas.  Whatever the European Commission's decision, this contradiction will not disappear from Europe.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – I join colleagues who strongly criticise the Decision of the German authorities on the minimum wage. If this system only applies to German carriers, it would, of course, be germany's business. Unfortunately, this dramatically impacts on entrepreneurs in other countries, who are either forced to break domestic laws or face hefty penalty fines from the German authorities. I am very concerned that, according to the available calculations, this may be winding down for many, especially small firms. The EU is founded on the fundamental principles of the free movement of people, goods and services between Member States. However, here we see a clear violation of this principle and we do not want to witness a series of counter-measures and a de facto classic trade war between EU Member States. I therefore call on the German Government to immediately repeal these measures, to amend them and to the Commission to resolve this problem as a matter of speed.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, the issue we are discussing here on the minimum wage is part of a wider discussion on what are indeed the real obstacles to the development of a barrier-free road market and, of course, which has serious consequences mainly for peripheral countries, as is the case, not only but also of Portugal, and we must not forget that these issues affect economic growth and , ultimately, they also end up affecting export growth. I believe that legal clarity for carriers is imperative, but also a simplification of the demanding regulatory framework. We have two fundamental questions here. On the one hand, the lack of effective control over cabotage operations and, on the other hand, differences in the application of certain provisions, such as the prohibition of regular weekly rest on board vehicles, as is the case in France and Belgium. We therefore need to review the establishment requirements, avoiding the transfer of activities to other Member States, with the deliberate end of tax evasion and labour taxation. The Commissioner has spoken here of fair working conditions and I think it is very good that she has done so, because I think it is important to safeguard the social and labour situation of European workers in this regard, especially while respecting the principle of subsidiarity. I will therefore end by ascating whether it is really willing, and when, to initiate an effective reform of the road transport market in the Union, so that all companies can compete on an equal footing and for their workers to have access to a level playing field not only but also in countries such as Portugal.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, my briefing note from my excellent assistant says in capital letters ‘COMPLEX ISSUE’, and the Commissioner, when she opened the debate, said the legal assessment is complex. You would think from listening to the debate tonight that this was a complex issue – but it is not complex at all. This is an incredibly simple issue. We are asked to believe that unless this measure is contested the haulage industry in north-eastern Europe will collapse under the weight of the costs. But Comrade Liberadzki said in passing that actually the average effective wage for truck drivers in Poland is EUR 8.5 per hour, the cost of these vehicles is EUR 100 000-plus, the diesel costs thousands of pounds and the tolls are hundreds of euros, so the notion that this cost can cripple these industries is ridiculous. The Posting of Workers Directive is clear: you pay the rate for the job in the country where you are doing business.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: (ECR). – Why should we artificially turn German companies into monopolists? The minimum rates of pay in transport must be consistent with the legitimate payment of salaries in each Member State of the European Union. If the employers of truck drivers from the poorest country in Europe - Bulgaria have an obligation to pay minimum rates according to French or German standard, then this would be murderous for the Bulgarian transport industry.  Centralised wage setting is absolutely unworkable among countries in the European Union because of huge differences in the standard of pay. It is in the interest of national economies to set minimum rates by national laws and not to subject the payment of transit workers to centralised regulations by the European Commission. I recall, Commissioner, the fundamental rule of the European Union is the free movement of goods and people.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I agree with the concept of a minimum wage. I think it is very important, and I am glad that Germany has introduced such a scheme. However, different states have different rates and the cost of the minimum wage in Germany is different to that in Ireland, different to that in the Czech Republic, different to that in Bulgaria. In individual states we have different approaches to wage levels, and indeed to taxation, and the cost of living can vary. I do know – and I do understand – there has been unfair treatment of workers, exploitation of workers, and that should not happen, but we cannot have one country setting itself up as judge and jury in this whole area. I would urge the Commission to do something about this, because in the absence of a policy in this area we get the kind of situation we are discussing now. It is important that this void be filled and it needs to be addressed. My main concern in this whole issue is that I have been contacted by Irish road haulage operators who are concerned at the level of bureaucracy, the level of red tape, that it will involve for them. It will certainly add to their costs. It will discourage them from crossing Germany. They will maybe seek alternative routes, increasing their costs again and ultimately increasing the cost to the consumer. I think it is important that we have a moratorium while we address this situation, which ultimately has to be decided on an EU—wide basis. I do not think we can have one country dictating how we operate in this area.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I believe that this debate is indeed complex.  It also shows, in essence, that this is the result of the different standards within the European Union. I believe that this is the essence of the debate. We must also be honest among ourselves and address it in this way. Lower wages lead to lower costs for entrepreneurs. Lower costs for entrepreneurs ultimately also means lower offer prices when it comes to getting a contract. This is, of course, a clear competitive advantage for countries that have lower standards. I am also surprised by those who say that the German minimum wage is higher and would not apply to others. But the same entrepreneurs from these countries ultimately set their offers or prices according to german, French or Italian prices, but no one complains about them. When it comes to wages, yes, but if the entrepreneurs collect the money, then no.  That is why I will give you an example from my own country. I am a representative of the East Bavarian region in Germany. I am on the border with the Czech Republic. What do German companies do? And that is why the German FDP's criticism comes from being driven by the lobby. These companies outsource their businesses, 50 km further east. They form a letterbox company there with employees who are ultimately Czech citizens, possibly have other nationalities, to their low standards. But the work – and that is what it is all about – is ultimately done in another state, such as .B in Germany. Now we can take a different view. However, we must be honest, and we must ultimately also ask the Commission to actually get a European approach to the definition. What is cabotage? Above all, what is transit traffic? And above all – I have not heard this today – what is cross-border transport? That is also crucial. What about trucks that drive .B from Prague to Munich, unload and immediately drive back? We need to define these points in more detail. Then we can also reach a compromise. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: the blue card. – I have known Mr Izmail for a long time since the last term of office, and this question is really pointing out today that there are many unresolved issues within the European Union itself. This is not the most fundamental issue today in terms of social dumping. When we joined the European Union, we had to open up our markets. And everyone was well aware of the different economic situation, the different tax system, and so there is a different minimum wage. He exists in Lithuania too. But the talk is that Germany is actually trying to compete for carriers from other countries by introducing this law so that they can take it. And does it not seem to you, my colleague, that, however, as you said, it is necessary to clarify that our European Union does not actually fall apart with the basic principles, trust in each other.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear Zigmantas, that's right what you say. However, it is part of honesty, which is why I say this: we must resolve this at European level. The problem would be solved, for example, if we finally oblige companies that pass on orders from their country of residence to pay this minimum wage. Then the problem would be solved. Incidentally, we are not talking about work in Lithuania or Romania or Hungary. We are talking about work taking place on the territory of the state, which has raised a minimum wage. I understand, of course, that this erodes the competitive advantage in terms of price. In fact, however, there is nothing wrong with the fact that, in the end, this Member State also raises its minimum wage. I know that the subject is complex. But we have to stick to it.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The solutions introduced by Germany hit the transport industry in Poland and other central and eastern European countries, threaten the development of our companies and mean the elimination of jobs. This must be said very clearly and loudly. They set a dangerous precedent, because if we allow such rules to be in force today, they can be introduced tomorrow in other industries and in other countries, by other countries of the European Union. There will be a new era of protectionism, and this means the end of free trade, the free market, economic freedoms and the free movement of labour in the European Union. The foundations of the European Union will then be shattered.  In Poland, polish transport companies have built their position on the European market for years, many companies have not withstood this rivalry. We competed with carriers from other countries, building a modern transport fleet. Today, almost 39% of all cargo exports from Polish were delivered to Germany. We cannot allow this effort to be ruined by a single administrative decision. We demand respect for European Union law and the free market and demand clear rules. And let us not allow Germany, under the pretext of caring for the working conditions of drivers in other countries, to actually eliminate competition for its own transport companies. That's what protectionism means!

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Since 1 January 2015, a statutory minimum wage of EUR 8.50 has been in place in Germany. The fact that not everyone in Germany was pleased with the introduction of this minimum wage, especially parts of the middle class, has also penetrated as far as Brussels. It is not essentially a question of EUR 8.50 – that is not the problem – but of the bureaucracy that is involved. The EUR 8.50 also applies to the transport industry and should also apply to transit through Germany. The displeasure and uncertainty in other Member States about the German regulation are there, as we have heard today. The fact that something seems to be wrong with the law is shown by the frantic reaction of the German Minister of Labour. Although it initially ruled out changes, it suspended the minimum wage for transit-only journeys until further notice when brussels began its examination. For example, our neighbours – especially from Eastern Europe – do not have to send their drivers' operational plans to German customs. Here, Brussels has indirectly reduced red tape. I think it is right that the Commission should now take a closer look at this German bureaucratic monster. The Commission has today stated that the procedure is still ongoing and is under further investigation. I can only recommend to Mrs Nahles that this examination be used as an opportunity to revise the Minimum Wage Act, in particular the many documentation requirements relating to salaries must be reduced. Finally, with this law, we must not allow ourselves to distort competition within Europe and must not create new obstacles in the internal market.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Look, there are a number of requests, there are blue cards which, unfortunately, we will not be able to attend because, I repeat, we have accumulated more than half an hour of delay, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, we have already given the floor to those who previously used it, which is why, in this case, we cannot give them the floor.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. The issue we are dealing with today is not a purely national problem. Nor is it a question of introducing a minimum wage in a particular Member State. Nor is it a question of the level of the minimum wage. Although wage policy falls under the principle of subsidiarity, the minimum wage is a European matter. It touches on areas such as competition, social dumping, the internal market and freedom of movement. And that is where the problem lies: national circumstances, subsidiarity and yet a European matter. That is why the Commission must take a clear position on this issue. I am in favour of a statutory minimum wage and Regret that in some Member States there is still none or that it has not been sufficiently implemented in some Member States. Social dumping in the field of road transport has reached alarming proportions. There is legislation, and this has been mentioned several times: the Posting of Workers Directive, Rome I, Directive 1071 of 2009. But this is circumvented or not controlled. In addition, many Member States are now taking their own measures and interpreting the rules as they see it. That is why, Commissioner, you were not able to convince me in your speech. But it may be too early. That's why I'm eagerly awaiting this whole package. My question to the Commissioner is: what is the Commission's plan to deal with this critical situation, and what are any measures or plans in this regard?

name: Anne SANDER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the issue we are dealing with this evening is of paramount importance for the future of European road transport and, more generally, for our vision of a social Europe. Currently, as you know, international truck drivers can load and unload their trucks in a passing country for seven days before arriving in their destination country. This is called cabotage. However, these truck drivers are not entitled to the same minimum wage or social protection as their colleagues in the country they cross. However, the activity is very similar and is well conducted in the same territory. In my country, France, the most caboté country in Europe, French truck drivers are therefore directly competing, on their national market, by other European truck drivers, which has led France to lose 21,000 jobs in fifteen years. We will soon vote on two million euros in aid for the licensed truck drivers of the carrier Mory Ducros. There really needs a European solution to fill the existing legal vacuum. I think we need to redefine the rules of cabotage and create a specific regime for highly mobile workers. Yes to mobility and competition, but not to a mad race for social dumping.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Many believe that the issue of the minimum wage is a dispute between the principle of subsidiarity in the Member States and the principle of a single market for the provision of services. At the same time, the single market has never been about the identity and the overall levelling of wages, because there are and will be wage differences between Member States.  Make no mistake, it is far from us that we would be opposed to the sovereign right of a Member State to set a minimum wage, but we already expect it to do so without jeoping the fundamental values of the European Union. We are talking about a narrower area, road transport. To put an issue in a social robe, which at the same time poses a serious financial and administrative burden, is not a fair attitude for transport companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises. And at the time, we did not mention the amount of penalties for infringements of the national rules imposed, which are so high that they can destroy smaller businesses in a single blow, while the development and strengthening of SMEs is the generally defined EU objective. There is a need for a swift and decisive stand by the European Commission, because this is the only way to put an end to this debate and at the same time prevent the single European market from gradually deteriorating to a pre-1992 level. Let the Commission do what its core task is, be the 100th edi of the founding treaties and our values.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – The law adopted by Germany is not compatible with economic logic or with the fundamental principles of the functioning of the Internal Market of the European Union. This has been talked about here all night. This is not just one country's intervention in the social policy and labour issues of other countries. Such laws are supposedly a fight against social dumping, but in reality it is a means of shutting down national transport companies and eliminating competition, especially for carriers from eastern and central European countries. And this will create additional social tensions in those countries. Russia already imposes restrictions on carriers, especially from neighbouring countries of the European Union. Carriers affected by this restriction have made considerable efforts to refocus transport from east to west in order to preserve their businesses and jobs, so it is incomprehensible how the Member States of the European Union themselves are introducing burdensome measures for carriers from other countries during such a difficult period. This undermines confidence in the principle of a single market, solidarity and free competition.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the situation in the European Union as a result of the economic crisis is 'bringing it up'. The countries of the European region have always supported the minimum wage and the protection of their transport work through cabotage. Germany has always been in favour of market opening, in favour of the Bolkenstein Directive, against cabotage and against the introduction of a minimum wage.  But now that the carriers of the countries of the European region are taking advantage of the internal market, Germany, under the pretext of applying the minimum wage, is erecting walls of protectionism. It is trying to put the small transport undertakings of the Member States of the European region out of transport. In order to remove these contradictions, a minimum average European wage must be introduced, unfair practices must be stopped, social dumping must be stopped and workers' rights protected.  So as the carriers of the poor countries clash with the carriers of the rich countries, "something is wrong in the Kingdom of Denmark", where the banking industry finally continues to rule.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, as I understand that you will give your word to practically every group, I was the first to answer, that's true, but my colleague José Faria asks me that he speak, so I would kindly ask you to speak José Faria instead of the ALDE group, not me, because I can see that we will not both get the word.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we must be clear that what we are discussing here is not only a social or economic issue, nor exclusively limited to the transport sector. It is, first of all, a question of European integration. It is a question of European integration because we are in the presence of a measure contrary to European law.  Throughout the process of building the internal market, there has always been a concern to observe the principle of mutual recognition of national laws with a view to establishing fundamental freedoms. In this context, this measure can only represent a setback. It also infringes what is a recognised principle of freedom of movement, i.e. the application of only one labour regime to workers in transit in the Union and, more specifically, a minimum remuneration scheme. Our obligation is to contribute to an integrated European policy in promoting the European internal market and not the other way around. The European Union has never failed to review the freedom of movement of persons, which occupies the most fundamental basis of the European project. I end by saying that we will not owe this measure if the German State commits to pay the wage gap that this measure will entail for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I regret that the European Parliament is discussing a very serious issue this evening, such as the minimum wage for work, in a disparaging way. We focus the debate only on the minimum wage for road transport workers in one country, and we forget the general problem of guaranteeing work of all kinds in each Member State. And we are dealing with it mainly from the point of view of competition rules, rather than the needs and lives of people.  If the European Union wanted to be consistent with the principles of the protection of fundamental rights, in accordance with Article 2 of its founding Treaty, then it should be established as a general principle that no one in any country is allowed to be paid a salary below the minimum standard of decent living.  On the contrary, however, the Union's policies in place lead to wage reductions below these levels, particularly in the Member States, in the name of falsified competitiveness. Change course before it's too late.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: " I think that this question has already been clarified and studied from all sides. And I think that, on the one hand, we must make it very clear to ourselves that there are huge differences in Europe and we need to make a sufficiently clear plan to reduce those differences as soon as possible, to mitigate them. On the other hand, I believe that, in this case, it must withdraw its right, to restore its rights, to send a clear signal to Germany that Germany has exceeded its mandate and That Germany must immediately suspend the application to other countries, apply them only to that country. And then we will have time to figure out and anticipate the system and then run it.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you very much for your very straightforward comments. I have heard them and I will ensure that they are taken into account by the Commission in its current assessment process, as well as its further work on enhancing the clarity and consistency of applicable social and market rules, in particular as part of the road package. By doing so, we will take a more comprehensive approach, which many of you have called for. I would like to underline that the establishment of national minimum pay rates is a positive development. But of course the national measures, while protecting workers, must respect EU law so as to preserve the proper functioning of the internal market with all the benefits it brings across Europe. We shall also draw lessons from this experience. The Commission will continue to monitor ongoing developments. It reserves the right to intervene against unilateral measures that unduly restrict fundamental freedoms such as the free movement of goods, workers and services. In the pursuit of constant improvement, we will also be looking into the most appropriate measures to create efficient, safe and socially responsible road transport services, with people at the heart of EU transport policy. Finally, I would like to stress one more time that the Commission will inform Parliament of the outcome of its assessment of the compatibility of the German measures with EU law as soon as possible, but please understand that we need to follow EU procedures and that takes time. I assure you, however, that the Commission will continue to act as a guardian of the EU Treaty and EU law. I will see you again as soon as possible on this topic.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to say that there are more than 30% of women in this Chamber, and you gave a catch the eye vote to 7 men. I, as a woman, feel discriminated against.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The sensitivity of my fellow Members is thus understandable in the late evening, we all feel that we are at a disadvantage when we sit there. Unfortunately, Madam President, the election is not done according to this, but the first of the political groups has been given the opportunity to comment in order. I know that it is very difficult to get used to this, but the timeframe available is limited in this regard, but I will forward Mrs Member's observation to the Bureau.  This concludes the joint debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The social dumping that is taking place in the transport sector (as in the construction sector) is unsustainable. Companies and their employees are engaged in a race to the bottom at the expense of employees, regardless of their origin. Free movement of services is a pillar of our Union, but it will undoubtedly be jeopardy if we do not address social malpractice. Some of these situations are the result of outright fraud, ghost companies or false self-employed persons. They should be more effective in addressing Member States by strengthening their social inspection services.  However, other situations have to do with the large wage differentials in Europe. Member States on minimum wage are now shooting in their own way because transport firms from other Member States should not respect that minimum. That's untenable. That is why we understand the German measure. The European Commission must come forward with proposals to rectify this. Firstly, in the interests of lorry drivers, many of whom are being exploited today. The current situation in the transport sector is unworthy of Europe and demand a strong answer. It is the only way to make our internal market work fully in the future.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: The German minimum wage law, which came into force in January 2015, presents us with a dilemma of enormous political importance. On the one hand, fighting to ensure a minimum wage for all workers is a challenge that our political family has always been the bearer of; On the other hand, unfortunately, this right, as formulated, conceals a prohibitionist and closing-down will on the part of Germany. It is, in fact, contrary to the principle enshrined in the Treaty establishing the European Union, which guarantees the free movement of goods. Indeed, while I can agree with the substantive principle that the life of every worker should be dignified, the way in which Germany applies this law is to be considered incorrect. Requesting the faxing of documentation attesting to one's job position and salary, translated into German months before transport, creates new burdens for businesses but above all for small hauliers who are unable to bear these costs. That is why I believe that the Commission must take timely measures to ensure that the principles of the Union are not undermined.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – The German proposal sounds extremely nice, but the truth is that this measure is also being introduced to restrict access by foreign companies in Germany. Under the rules adopted by Berlin, all workers, even those passing through Germany, must receive €8.5 an hour. In this way, Bulgarian transport carriers will be obliged to pay similar salaries plus postings. This makes them uncompetitive and they will simply give up working in Germany. Germany's idea to restrict carriers from Bulgaria, Poland, Lithuania and other European countries aims to benefit German carriers. One day, the big Member States talk to us about free market and competition, and the next day in their national laws they adopt exactly the opposite measures. By the way, France also applies this approach and tries to discriminate against carriers from small countries. France, on the other hand, is trying to introduce rules to oblige drivers to sleep in a hotel, which disrupts their route and makes transportation more expensive. The purpose of all these supposedly minor measures is to restrict small countries. It's a kind of protectionism. However, when applied by Germany and France, it is supposedly legal, and if we decide to do so, we will be subject to sanctions. That's what we're fighting against this double standard.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The impact of the new law on the minimum wage in Germany, which is to apply unexpectedly on a Union-wide scale, is being debated. In my opinion, such an understanding of German law is contrary to European Union law, above all the principle of the free movement of persons, goods and services. This debate has not only legal but also social aspects. Carriers from other countries will have virtually two options, both unfavourable: either they will break German law and pay drivers so far at country of origin rates, which threatens to result in high penalties, or they will pay at German rates, which could even lead to the bankruptcy of some companies and the loss of jobs by hundreds of drivers in Europe.  Companies cannot afford to do business below cost. The differences in the economic levels of each country are obvious and will not be equal in a few years. It is therefore not possible to 'level' the rates at the expense of others, which is de facto intended to eliminate cheaper competition from the market. We demand a clear and swift response from the EC as to the extent that Germany's national law on the minimum wage can or should not be applied to foreign transport carriers?

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. – With the adoption of the minimum wage in Germany, the discussion on the application of the new legislation to foreign lorry drivers who only cross Germany began. However, such a rule is not in line with existing EU law. The European Commission was right to launch a pilot procedure – the preliminary stage of an infringement procedure – against the Federal Government. The minimum wage in transit traffic was subsequently suspended. It is important that we find a European solution here and avoid over-regulation. We cannot require European hauliers to pay different wages in each Member State on a journey from Lisbon to Warsaw. However, in the case of journeys which take place only within the Federal Republic or when the cargo is unloaded in Germany, a level playing field must apply to all operators. Irrespective of the location of a forwarding agent, the minimum wage for work within Germany must be paid on a pro rata basis in these cases. Only in this way can we ensure fair competition.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am deeply concerned about the actions of some countries and the attempt to include in the Law on the minimum wage for foreign workers operating transport services on their territory. I believe that this action is contrary to one of the fundamental principles of the Union, which is the principle of the free movement of services, which is a pillar of the single market. Drivers from countries such as m.in. Poland are competitive on the European market not only because their labour costs are lower, but also because of good work organisation and productivity, which is by no means a manifestation of 'social dumping'.  Of course, drivers, like all other workers, have labour law. I would like to draw attention to the fact that a number of rules have been laid down in all Member States concerning driving, working and rest time or the use of tachographs, which are intended m.in to protect workers' social protection. These rules are largely harmonised and, of course, must be respected by everyone. The possible application of the minimum wage would, in my view, not only be incompatible with the principle of freedom to provide services, but would also result in many losses for businesses and workers in a sector of 5 million people. I therefore hope that the Commission will quickly settle any legal doubts relating to these provisions.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – My big question is: is the European customs union worth its 50th birthday in 2018, or will it be sent into retirement, ending one of the EU's most important achievements? Why am I asking you this? If higher costs resulting from different minimum wages in different countries are to be incorporated into the price of services, then the question is legitimate: to what extent would this be 'theoretically' different from the fact that tariffs are being imposeed on goods made in another EU Member State, saying that the cost of producing the product is higher domestically, so that the difference could be made by the production company in order to ensure that the competitiveness of domestic SMEs (similar to higher minimum wage undertakings) is not embated and that competition in this respect is 'evenly competitive'. I look forward to the Commission's position on whether the consequences of this minimum wage scheme will be the same as if duties were being paid by individual Member States, for similar reasons, in order to preserve their own competitiveness? This has to stop right here, right now.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I do not agree with the arguments raised during the discussions, alluding to the use of social dumping by workers and companies from central and eastern European countries in particular. A competitive advantage which entails lower labour costs resulting from differences in the levels of economic development of countries cannot be treated on an equal footing with social dumping. Polish workers, not only those from the transport sector, by providing services at lower prices, but not below cost, contribute to the development of economies also of those countries in whose territory they provide services.  No one questions the right of Member States to introduce a minimum wage – many countries, including Poland, have introduced it a long time ago – but it must not strike at the freedoms that underpin European integration. The provisions of the TOU must be complied with and the national law laid down must not conflict with them. It is therefore important for the Commission to rule as soon as possible on the compatibility of interpretations of German and European law.  The application of the territorial principle by Germany, the enforcement of German minimum wage rates under incomparable remuneration schemes, the translation of all relevant documents, the new and unclear administrative burden of transport operations carried out on German territory of whatever nature (transit, international transport, cabotage) affect the principles of integration and the European internal market, restrict the freedom to provide services, challenging the essence of the functioning of the EU.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: Writing. – The Law on the Minimum Wage in Germany is problematic and that is why it has sparked a passionate debate at European level. It has a direct impact on the principle of free movement of services and restores national protectionism. It significantly restricts Slovak forwarding companies. The situation is serious and I consider it to be at conflict with the principle of a free market and the free movement of goods in the EU. This principle is part of the EU's fundamental freedoms. That is why I will support the idea of abolishing the scope of this road transport law in Germany.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – The internationalization of the economy is a tough limit for the left of each State: policies for expanding demand and public services, increasing wages or improving working conditions, are at risk because of the ease with which capital moves its factories and deposits where taxation is more lax and the exploitation of workers is more lax and greater. As a result, the fight against tax or labour dumping increasingly requires negotiations and decisions at European level. But the current EU insists not only on replicating the logic of the market, but even on accelerating the breakdown of the conquests of the labour movement in each state. Thus, instead of clearly defending the introduction of a minimum wage in transport, the Commission remains ambiguous about the interpretation of its own directives, delaying a decision which would necessarily validate its legality. Instead of helping to regulate a sector severely affected by the liberalisation of services and lax implementation of labour regulations, the Commission is unable to come out of its defence, delving into the deep crisis of the European project.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: in writing. – In recent years, both the Commission and the European Parliament have been calling, wherever possible, to reduce the administrative burden on businesses, so as not to put further obstacles to their economic activity and to make full use of the potential of the single market, which is mainly based on the free movement of persons, goods and goods. Road transport brings together a majority part of freight transport in the European Union and is the main element of that internal market. Therefore, it is necessary to remove the remaining technical and legal barriers. We do not believe that there is social dumping in countries where purchasing power is simply lower. If there are illegal practices, they will have to be controlled, but it doesn't make much sense for a minimum wage rule to try to match countries with such different per capita incomes. The European Commission should act quickly and clearly in a matter which clearly transcends national borders and goes beyond the principle of subsidiarity, as well as being a regulatory precedent with clear consequences.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 1. Why is the EC unequivocally not answering whether the minimum wage rules in Germany are compatible or not in line with EU rules and treaties?  2. In my view, they are incompatible not only with EU law, but also with its guiding principle of a common competitive market. Instead of creating, they destroy jobs.  3. A competitive advantage m.in on lower labour costs but also organisational efficiency and productivity cannot be equated with 'social dumping'.  4. Each Member State shall have a different minimum wage, other components of the wage and other costs, on what basis the German legislation is to apply to economic operators from other countries. Not to mention that these rules increase administrative and bureaucratic burdens and can give rise to a multi-thousand and disproportionate penalty payment, and constitute a barrier to the freedom to provide services in international transport.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – The Minimum Wage Institute in each state is a measure that the Social Democrats can only support. On the other hand, it is unacceptable for this to interfere with the laws of other countries governing the level of the minimum wage. On the one hand, it is understandable that Germany should require sufficient financial security for persons — employees who move within their territory. Germany, on the other hand, thus interferes with the laws of other countries, which has other effects, such as the difficulty of wage accounting (reporting of business trips, monitoring of border crossing times). This complicates employment relationships (and thus wage entitlements) between employees and employers established in another country. In particular, germany's move is discriminatory vis-à-vis the new Member States, it presents unequal conditions where operators from those States are unable to cover the costs incurred by the measure and can therefore be pushed out of the German market. In any case, the situation requires a comprehensive solution. That is why the Commission must continue to act in order to avoid violating the European Treaties.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – The German Minimum Wage Act is against the principle of the single market. It also goes against the EU principle of the free movement of services. This regulation negatively affects businesses in 16 EU Member States, and if it can remain so, it could have a domino effect, effectively destroying the single market. Today, a German truck driver works at an hourly rate of €8.50. A Slovak gets €2.50 for the same job. It would be nice, of course, if Slovak workers were also paid German salaries, although we would be there, but if we think realisticly at all, we can see that the real aim of the German provision is to help German workers. Slovak entrepreneurs simply lose their competitiveness under these conditions, which in black and white means job instaffing. The European Commission, as the 1st edi of EU law, is obliged to ensure that member states' legislation does not go against the EU acquis. I trust the hanging horse's foot will get caught in the Commission's sieve.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Since 1 January 2015, a minimum wage has been introduced on German territory. In Poland, this will affect the fate of 26,000 companies employed, providing services in international transport 145 thousand cars. These companies, taking care of the quality of services and working conditions of drivers, take out loans for the purchase of modern cars. The number of new cars registered in Poland in 2012, mainly German, French, Scandinavian and Italian production, amounted to as much as 14 000. It will also result in losses for car factories produced in EU countries bought by Polish companies.  The regulations conflict with European Union law and, in particular, do not take into account Article 45 OF the EU HEREA on the free movement of workers. Nor do they take account of the ruling of the Court of Justice of the EU in Luxembourg (18 September 2014; C-549/13), which concluded: 'In a situation such as that at issue in the main proceedings, in which the tenderer intends to perform a public contract using only employees employed by a subcontractor established in a Member State other than that to which the contracting authority belongs, Article 56 TFEU precedes the application of the rules of the Member State to which that contracting authority belongs, requiring that subcontractor to pay those employees the minimum wage laid down by those provisions'.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – The recent imposition by Germany of a minimum wage for freight transporters from other Member States is just another in a recent row of economic protectionist measures in Europe disguised as social ones. What is worrying is that, even in this House, we are hearing more and more calls against so-called social dumping from the East. We should be careful not to misuse economic terms: dumping means exporting a product to another country at a price either below the price charged on its home market or below its cost of production. This is clearly not the case at hand. The reality is that, despite EU efforts, there still are strong disparities between Member States in terms of economic development, wages and production costs, just as there are differences in terms of financial backgrounds, technological development, access to finance and so on. Forcing companies in other Member States to artificially increase their costs, and placing on them burdensome administrative requirements, is not the way to make the EU a competitive player on the global market. If it really intends to be one, it should not be afraid of competition.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – From 1 January 2015, Germany requires foreign carriers carrying goods or passengers in Germany proof that they provide their drivers with a minimum payment of EUR 8.5 gross per hour. Such a measure is positive from the point of view of preventing social dumping in road transport and slovenian transport operators fulfil it, but at the same time such a unilateral measure undermines the principle of the free movement of services. We cannot solve one problem in the EU by creating a new one. Above all, these are restrictions on the EU's internal market and Germany's domination of competition, which is being hampered in this way. The introduction of a minimum wage in Germany for lorry drivers is logical and acceptable, but they cannot also demand this from other Member States which have completely different standards and salaries. Administrative barriers need to be reduced, but not at the expense of protecting workers who are too often exploited and underpaying them for their work. The imbalance between the integration of the single market and the provision of unsuadised services, on the one hand, and the lack of uniform social standards, on the other hand, is unacceptable and we cannot let these problems arise in the EU. The European Commission should set minimum standards for working conditions at EU level and also provide for fair pay in the transport sector.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – The abovementioned German law sets a minimum of EUR 8.50 per hour for workers working in Germany.
