This means that employers must submit registration documents in advance to the German authorities, which may entail additional costs and administrative burdens. However, I must say that I welcome the steps towards an increase in the minimum wage and a single European minimum wage. In addition, of course, the impact of the law on other Member States and the legality of the law must be examined, which the European Commission is doing. I ask whether the European Commission is projecting a reduction in the number of jobs as a effect of the measure. Are they examining whether workers' wages or employers' burdens are actually increasing? I also ask what studies do you take into account when developing the Commission's position?

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – German legislation sets a precedent because it imposes wages on employees of other countries. It is essential to uphold the principles of free movement in our common European market and not to build barriers between the east and west of the EU. I call on the European Commission to act immediately in this case.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. – Today's debate on employment conditions, including minimum wage rates in the transport sector, is touching on the very important issue for most European countries and their priorities in the field of services. This is particularly important for countries where road transport services are an important part of the economy. This is the case in Lithuania, where transport services account for 10 percent of the country's GDP. The interests of countries such as mine must therefore be taken into account in the preparation of Union decisions on this issue. Recent pointless German regulations, which also command minimum wages for carriers from other countries, have fuelled the European crisis in the transport industry. It is unacceptable for the legislation of one country to oblige entrepreneurs from other countries not to engage in economic activity in the territory of that country. After all, using a car transit in some country is not the same as a statement of work by drivers in that country. The German regulations have gone too far in this case, prompting disturbances in the Union's internal market and the limited freedom of movement of products. It seems that the best solution would be if the European Commission introduced an old and verified 'country of origin' principle with regard to transport service and international transport providers. In this way, we will avoid discrimination between companies and workers from the new Member States, for which transport services through transit through third countries are an important part of their economy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – I support the minimum wage as a social and economic principle throughout the European Union. This discussion, however, is not about the minimum wage, but about the application of the principle of subsidiarity in European legislation and the principle of competitiveness in the EU economy. If we respect these fundamental principles for the unitary development of the European Union, I believe that we can pay more attention to the scope of the minimum wage in the Western states and to how the imposition of these rules affects the economies of the East.  The transport sector in Central and Eastern Europe is populated with SMEs providing jobs, SMEs helping to develop a growing economy. If these SMEs are prevented from working by imposing rules that they cannot comply with, then the responsibility for losing a considerable number of jobs on whose shoulders does it fall?  I believe in the principle of regulating the minimum wage on the economy in all economic sectors, but I do not believe that these measures should adversely affect the free movement of goods in the EU and in no way adversely affect the maintenance of the competitiveness of companies in countries such as Romania. I want to create an economic environment and a harmonised market under the principles and European legislation that we have all committed to respect.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – Mr President! The free movement of goods, services and people is the main pillar of the EU. I find it worrying that this principle is now being combated in several European countries by erecting artificial border fences. Technically up-to-date equipment and qualified professional drivers ensure safe movement of goods also on wheels across Europe. It is therefore important that the working conditions are fair and, for example, that drivers' rest periods are maintained. On the other hand, it makes no sense to apply each country's own working conditions in drive-through traffic. Wage levels vary between neighbouring countries. The application of each country's working conditions, even in drive-through traffic, also entails an unreasonable administrative burden on hauliers and creates obstacles to free movement. There are still a number of obstacles in the area of transport before we can talk about an open and functioning internal market. Attention has been paid to the connecting pathways of Europe and their development. However, even a good road network will be of no use if it is made more difficult to use by building barriers to the path of free movement.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – The Minimum Wage Act in force in Germany of 1 January 2015 has raised a number of concerns about its compliance with EU law, in particular internal market provisions and the Posting of Workers Directive. The introduction of a minimum wage of EUR 8.50 for every hour worked in Germany is a kind of protectionist measure that leads to a number of negative consequences: additional administrative costs for transport carriers, increased transport costs in order to search for alternative routes, and higher prices for the end user.  The new provisions are particularly unfavourable for small and medium-sized international carriers. According to data from the International Union for Road Transport (IRU), the implementation of the law is related to an increase in their administrative costs by an average of EUR 65 000 per year, which can force a large part of them to leave the sector. Bulgarian carriers are particularly worried about the expected significant additional administrative burden that the new law will impose on foreign transport operators, as well as the lack of clarity on its practical implementation and the danger of imposing severe financial penalties.  I therefore welcome the commission's detailed examination of German law and the moratorium imposed by the German Government on its application to transit services carried out by foreign carriers.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. – The four freedoms that the internal market allows us – the free movement of goods, people, services and capital – are, in my view, one of the greatest and undoubtedly the most visible achievements of European integration. Therefore, the national law of any of the Member States must not restrict these freedoms. Not only would we then face discrimination against members of other EU countries, but we could also be the cause of their financial difficulties or complete bankruptcy. The legislation currently being introduced by Germany and seriously considered by other EU countries is therefore contrary to the four freedoms guaranteed by the EU to its citizens in certain sectors, namely transport. So let us look for a solution that does not jeopardise the functioning of the common market and thus does not harm the legal interests of businesses from other Member States.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Germany's adoption of a minimum wage in the transport sector has a fundamental impact on the functioning of transport companies in Europe, including Poland. We must bear in mind that lower labour costs are mainly due to differences in the level of development of individual EU countries. Entrepreneurs, taking advantage of this advantage, contribute to the economic development of their countries and the creation of hundreds of thousands of jobs in them.  In my opinion, the decisions of the German Government can lead to the collapse of many carriers, causing colossal financial and social problems. An important argument against the adoption of a minimum wage of EUR 8.5 per hour is the contradiction of that decision with EU standards, in particular the Directive on the posting of workers in the context of the provision of services. The principle of the freedom to provide services as a basis for the internal market has been infringed. The different types of transport services provided are not taken into account, thereby taking decisions away from the facts.  I therefore ask the European Commission to examine as a matter of urgency the compatibility of the German Minimum Wage Act with EU law. It is not clear to what extent eu Member State law on the minimum wage should apply to foreign transport carriers so that it does not conflict with EU law and the law of other Member States. Quickly perform this analysis to protect thousands of carriers from bankruptcy.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on "International Roma Day – Anti-Gypsyism in Europe and EU Recognition of Roma Genocide during World War II" (2015/2615 (RSP)).

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is a privilege to address this session today, and today we are discussing an issue that goes to the heart of European values, of who we are and what we stand for. So, as we prepare to celebrate International Roma Day on 8 April, it is opportune to reflect on the situation of Europe’s largest ethnic minority, on their circumstances, and on progress made and the challenges ahead. Not only is it opportune, but it is also necessary because Europe’s success in improving the situation of Roma communities is a measure of our ability to promote integration and tackle social exclusion everywhere. That is why four years ago the Council established the EU Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies. This Framework invited Member States to come forward with strategies to promote Roma inclusion in four key areas – education, employment, healthcare and housing. And just over a year ago, on 9 December 2013, the Council added fresh impetus to this drive by adopting a recommendation on effective Roma integration measures. There has been progress. Member States have stepped up their efforts and are taking action. The European Parliament has been very instrumental, by keeping the topic on the agenda, by assisting with ideas and discussion, as well as by reminding the Council and its Member States of the need to further progress on the issue. But this is a long road and major challenges remain. It is regrettable that in 2015 many Roma still live in conditions that are simply unacceptable. They still face deep poverty and social marginalisation. Many lack basic access to housing and healthcare. The unemployment rate is above the EU average, and Roma children are less likely to finish school. According to the EU Fundamental Rights Agency, as many as 54% of Roma still experience discrimination when looking for employment. Too often, Roma are the victims of prejudice, intolerance and social exclusion. Joint EU and national level action is helping, but genuine progress, the sort that will help not just future generations of Roma but also this generation, requires something much more fundamental than what is in place today: a change in public attitudes towards Roma communities. That is far easier said than done. There are three concrete steps that we can take to improve public awareness and understanding, all of which are included in the Council’s recommendation of December 2013. First, tackling prejudice and discrimination head on. This is a no-brainer and true for every group facing intolerance. We must take effective measures to combat anti-Gypsyism, negative rhetoric and hate speech. We must fight against racist and stigmatising language. Second, raising public awareness about Roma people. As we all know, intolerance is a common product of misunderstanding. So improving understanding of Roma communities, not just of the problems they face, but also of their history and rich culture, has to be part of the solution. Roma culture is an inherent part of the cultural diversity of the European Union. How aware, for example, are ordinary Europeans of the Roma genocide during the Second World War? Fostering public awareness of Roma history and culture, especially the traumatic and tragic events of the Second World War, is one of the most powerful ways in which we can support social cohesion and fight exclusion. This learning must start in our schools and universities and be nurtured across our societies. That also includes the media, which has a vital role to play. Third, and perhaps most urgently, we need to empower the Roma community, to give them a real platform to speak out for themselves, and to actively engage in public life as full EU citizens. These steps are key strands of the Council’s recommendation of December 2013. I note with great pleasure that they are also important issues for Parliament. Being a politician myself, I am convinced that parliamentarians play a significant role in shaping society’s attitude. The European Parliament plays a particularly important role in promoting tolerance. With International Roma Day almost upon us, we must celebrate the contribution made by Roma to Europe’s cultural and historical tapestry, and we must redouble our commitment to tackling the social and economic challenges they face. We all need to work hand-in-hand towards full eradication of discrimination, towards raising public awareness and empowering Roma communities. Only then can we really make progress on this pressing agenda. I will conclude by paraphrasing a famous advertisement. Let us strive towards the Union, which helps people help themselves!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members of Parliament, thank you for giving me a chance to speak to you today on a subject which is often overlooked. On 2 August 1944 almost 3 000 elderly people, women and children – the remaining Sinti and Roma of the so-called Zigeunerlager in the Nazi concentration camp of Auschwitz-Birkenau – were murdered in the gas chambers. The atrocities against Roma and Sinti during the Second World War must not be forgotten. This debate is a very small acknowledgement of a terrible debt. A moral debt to the Roma and Sinti people, wiped off the face of the earth during the Second World War, and wiped from our memories after the Second World War. Commemorating the Roma and Sinti victims is our duty. And we have to remain vigilant. Extremists are becoming more visible and their audience bigger. Hate speech is getting louder, hate crime more frequent. Europe’s old demons are attempting a comeback. We must confront them. Fifteen years ago we put in place anti-discrimination directives, yet Roma are still victims of discrimination. We have legislation in place combating racism and xenophobia, yet Roma are still victims of racism and xenophobia. I agree that anti-Gypsyism, as a specific form of racism, must be of serious concern to all of us. A lot has been done at national and European level over the past few years to foster the integration of Roma. In particular, the adoption of the EU Framework for National Roma Integration Strategies in 2011 initiated a change in Roma integration policies in the Member States. But although we have put in place comprehensive integration strategies and made funding available, and despite our efforts to promote diversity and to highlight the benefits of Roma integration, Roma are still victims of economic and social exclusion and we still see very few real improvements on the ground. We need consistency and coherence in our action. The Commission monitors Member States’ compliance with the Racial Equality Directive, which prohibits discrimination on grounds of racial or ethnic origin in a number of specific fields, including education. The Commission is ready to take action whenever Member States are found to be in breach of their duties under the directive. Deeply rooted stereotypes and prejudices link Roma to criminality, anti-social behaviour or benefit dependency. But how can we dismantle such stereotypes and prejudices? First, by applying the principle of equality before the law. Roma are EU citizens, and as such they should enjoy the same rights and have the same duties as the rest of us. Second, by ensuring equal opportunities. This is the fundamental objective behind our action – to build societies which offer equal opportunities to all, including to Roma. The 2013 Council recommendation on Roma integration requests that Member States implement measures to combat discrimination and anti-Gypsyism. To be effective, fighting discrimination should be mainstreamed into all policies, including on education, employment and access to services. It starts with basic education. Roma children must not be segregated. Teaching Roma children from socially excluded communities to read, count and write is necessary, but it is not sufficient to create that special feeling of belonging to a society. I expect the Member States to raise awareness about the benefits of Roma integration, both in Roma communities and among the general public. They could address the inclusion problems that Roma face in public curricula and teaching materials. We will carefully monitor these aspects in the Member States’ reports about their implementation measures at the end of this year. There are policies and legal and financial tools in place, both at national and EU level. We need to work on their combined enforcement in order to achieve sustainable results. We need to join forces and assume our roles and responsibilities in this process. We need to ensure that the solutions are discussed and implemented at local level, since this is where the exclusion takes place. This is, at least, what I take as the main message from last week’s European Platform for Roma Inclusion meeting. Another outcome is the importance of building trust among stakeholders in Roma integration at national level. Therefore, national Roma platforms should be set up, and we will work on this together with the National Roma Contact Points. Europe’s tragic past serves as a reminder of our duties and responsibilities towards the future. I believe our debate today will raise greater awareness and send a strong signal against anti-Gypsyism and all forms of racism.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – The upcoming International Roma Day gives us the opportunity to learn more about the social situation and culture of the Roma. In Hungary, the official day of remembrance is the International Day of Remembrance of the Roma Holocaust on 2 August. To this day, very few people know about the Roma Holocaust, porrajmos, despite the fact that it has claimed the lives of 500,000 Roma and Sysans. The Roma genocide is a crime against all humanity, for which there is no explanation. The legacy of this is carried by all of us here, whether in our country, in wider Europe, or anywhere in the world.  I would like to recall that, Hungary 2011 European Presidency of the European Parliament, the Member States adopted the European Roma strategy, also mentioned by the Secretary of State. Its main objective is to help roma catch up and improve their living conditions. To this end, the Hungarian National Social Inclusion Strategy is looking for comprehensive and effective solutions. I stress that you are looking for and supporting him, but let us be aware that it is necessary to make up for a centuries-old backlog. From crèches to universities, it seeks to help the integration of the cumulatively disadvantaged, including Roma youth. Hungary, my country, has started to work, yet its Roma policy is being unjustly attacked by many. Sometimes we feel like the surgeon who, because of his work, is considered the cause of the disease itself. Change takes time, long decades of hard work. This trip can't be saved. And, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that everyone does their homework primarily at home, in their own country.  The social inclusion of the Roma is not only one of the most important strategic challenges, but also one of the most promising opportunities for Europe. Thank you very much for your attention!

name: Soraya POST
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. – Madam President and Commissioner Jourová, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his excellent work. The situation of Roma within the EU Member States is, as it is today, under all criticism. Every day we violate fundamental human rights and the fundamental values of the European Union. Tens of millions of people live daily in great exclusion, in all areas. Discrimination, hate crimes and poverty are the effects of anti-Gypsyism. This is based solely on Roma ethnicity. Anti-Gypsyism, anti-Gypsyism, which targets the Roma, has been doing so in fact since the early 15th century. It is time to take a strong political stance in this very pressing situation. We should be ashamed of ythemselves. It is not ok that today, in a modern society because of ethnicity, people still cannot have a vision of their future, but only have a daily survival strategy. A first step in the fight against anti-Gypsyism is that we in this elected Chamber vote with common voice in favour of a resolution on the recognition of 2 August as a day of remembrance for the Holocaust of the Roma. This day is already being noticed by the Roma community. Zigeunernacht – between 2 and 3 August Auschwitz/Birkenau was emptied of the remaining Roma. At 9.00 a.m. on the morning of 2 August, the list looked as follows: 2 987 people. At 9:00 a.m. on August 3, it was 0. Witnesses say that the smell and stench of the crematorium never wanted to end. During the Nuremberg trials, roma were not mentioned. No Roma could testify. This year we celebrate 70 years of the liberation of the Auschwitz/Birkenau concentration camps. I think it is high time to recognise the Roma on 2 August. It is of great symbolic value to Europe's Roma, but also to democracy itself. It is about recognising history and aiming for a future built on europe's fundamental values. I would like to point out that this resolution has no political colour. It is an obligation for all of us who stand for democratic values to vote in favour of this resolution in April.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, Jasenovac is another Nazi camp where a large roma pogrom was carried out, and we should therefore speak clearly about the genocide that was committed in World War II. Unfortunately prejudice, discrimination, intolerance and racism still exist today.  I want to share here my experience as the man who led Istria for 12 years. I have excellent experience with Roma and we managed to integrate roma very much especially in the city of Pula. What did we do? First, we always mark World International Roma Day very publicly and very openly. Secondly, as far as education is concerned, we made kindergartens for small Roma children, where I once took them titus tangerines from Brijuni, which were a symbol of a gift once in the former Yugoslavia. Third, we organized their sports societies. Fourth, we've done a lot for their microeconomics. Fifth, we have a special radio show in which roma regularly participate. Sixth, they participate in all events where they nurture their cultural identity. We still have a lot to say, but I like to talk about positive examples. This is, like, something positive.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Although I note that you can discuss this within the group, you have the word.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". " Jokes aside, let's get down to business. Dear colleague, you have spoken of the experience in your community with the Roma, I would like to know how these initiatives have been funded and by the way, it is also understood that the European Commission should also fund other initiatives of this kind such as those you have just spoken about.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - It is definitely clear that the European Commission can also participate in the financing of these activities and I know that there are programmes where the European Commission also finances various activities. However, about these concrete things that I talked about, from education to cultural, sports and other events, radio shows, microeconomics. These were mostly local sources of the city of Pula, that is, the Istrian region that I led, and I think that local activity is crucial for the good integration of Roma. Our great efforts here and discussions about it are necessary, but local action is crucial.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Roma and Sinti are a real and authentic European people, who have lived almost in every corner of this continent for many centuries, speak several European languages and would have the historic right to regard Europe as their own home, at least as much as the other peoples. Yet this people of 12 million people – more than Belgians, Portuguese or Swedes – is discriminated against, persecuted and not recognised as a minority in many nations, including Italy. I find it absurd that, 70 years after the genocide of the Roma and Sinti, Europe still has to discuss and has not yet set up a day in memory of the victims of this crime. Even today, the Roma still live in an intolerable situation in Europe, with a life expectancy of just over 60 years, high infant mortality and unemployment in some regions of more than 90%.  In addition, they are the subject of increasing attacks which do not arouse the same indignation as other forms of racism and often go unpunished. Against this impunity, democratic forces should act in a concrete way and not just with statements of principle. We, the Members from other Europe, together with our Roma candidate Dijana Pavlović, have prepared a complaint against a Member of this Parliament, Mr Dijana Pavlović. Good morning of the Northern League, which will speak after me, which had used hitler's expression 'scum of society' towards the Roma people during a television broadcast. We must do this every day, enforce the laws we have set ourselves, combat this shame of anti-Gypsyism.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The final step in a genocide is considered to be denying it. It is therefore important that we now speak clearly about what has been too greatly reduced for a long time, that is to say, the genocide of Roma during the Second World War. It was the same time, the same war, the same administration, the same way into the gas chambers – whether you were rum, Jew, gay, disabled, etc. The Holocaust is about all the victims in nazi extermination camps. As a people without their own state, the Roma are more or less present in all our countries. They are citizens like us and part of our societies, but they were not allowed to speak for themselves at that time or now. Roma's most fundamental rights are still being violated in many European countries. They are discriminated against and persecuted. The majority society speaks of Roma and Roma. We think we know what's best for them, and we dictate their terms. We continue to divide people into categories on the basis of ethnicity, sexual orientation, etc.  The fact that in 2015, 70 years after the end of the Second World War, we continue to treat Roma as second-class citizens is not acceptable.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am the one who is described as a European racist. I am thinking of the title of this debate, 'Gypsy phobia' – but what is phobia? It's used in psychiatry to say it's an unjustified fear. So I ask: is it an unjustified fear when there are Roma and Gypsies stealing everywhere? Of course, not everyone is the same, we would miss something else, but a large part of them are taken to stealth, they are led to use children to go and steal – this is also said by law enforcement – they are led to make sure that children do not go to school by their will but only to go and steal.  So, excuse me, do roma and gypsy day on 2 August and the other 364 days what do we do about those who have been robbed? At the end are the rights of the child: go and see what they do with their children! So if there is a right to the child, there is also the right, in this authoritative forum, for me, to say the right to fuck of all those who think that there is no problem! The problem exists, let us not be hypocrites! Action must be taken. The past has passed, everyone has their own rights and duties. The duties are not to steal and the rights are to send their children to school and to work in a quiet and serene way!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, let me draw attention at the beginning of my speech to mr Buonan's speech, which does not really spare you his racist and discriminatory statements against the Roma population, and I would like you to make this request to the Presidency of the European Parliament.  To the point of alone. Ladies and gentlemen, Roma are Europeans like us, like you, Mr Buonanna, like me. It is a minority that has 9 million but is not represented in the European Parliament. There are a lot of Italians here, but how many Roma are there?  These are precisely the issues where we discriminate against roma on the basis that they are different. To say about the Roma that everyone is stealing, that everyone is doing iniquities, is a primitivism that right-wing radicals are embalming, and it is the latent racism that we are undermining European credibility and the inability to integrate the Roma.  Ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to talk about something else entirely. I wanted to support and thank the Commissioner for really starting to address this issue. I wanted to talk about social housing and how things are improving significantly in Europe. The Czech Republic is often criticized. Madam President, I made a technical point at the beginning, I would like to finish my speech only briefly.  I want to say that we do not criticise states that have a problem with the Roma issue, and whether we try to show examples of good practice, that can help the Roma.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – I am proud that my political group is leading the fight against discrimination against the Roma and is working towards their equal integration into European society. And I am sad that, even in our institution, in our hall of democracy and respect for human rights, there are Members who spread hate speech that express anti-Roma, racist views. It is my and our duty to stop these colleagues every day, and today it is once again a public opportunity for all these colleagues and others who think of the Roma as inferioable people, as well as ourselves, how they would feel if they were born roma. If we were to have our kids locked up in a psychiatric facility because he's a Roma. If we were to automatically send us to classes for the less intelligent, to special schools, because we would be Roma. If we were beaten for belonging to their minority, or if we were denied a decent funeral. These shames happen today, in the 21st century in Europe. The Roma are our largest ethnic minority and their situation has deteriorated significantly in the economic crisis. The future for them and for us is education.  The Roma must be educated, but we must also learn. We have to discard stereotypes. Let's also start using a different diction. Let us not ask what we can do for the Roma in Europe. We have to ask ourselves what, and above all, how we can do it with them. More attention should also be paid to young Roma and their organisations. Through systematic cooperation, by creating the possibility of occupying more influential positions, and by omnisoning hate speech, we will be able to take measures that will ensure a decent, proud and just life for the Roma, this century, even systematically killing a minority. This, rather than ethnicity, is what rome most painfully distinguishes from its fellow citizens.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, 70 years after the atrocities of the Nazi regime, the topic of the recognition of genocide is once again on the agenda in this institution.  Today, the Roma are the largest ethnic minority in the European Union and at the same time are the most marginalised community. Unfortunately, much of this community continues to suffer discrimination and social exclusion, as well as being subject to racist attacks. And this is happening within the European Union, the steadier of freedom and human rights. That is why we must recognise this barbaric act of The Second World War and share the suffering of the Roma as a historical lesson that should not be repeated.  Tens of thousands of Roma are killed in death camps and our children should know about the sad events of the past, because this is the best lesson for fighting discrimination. We must continue to protect minorities in the path of their integration. This is part of our political responsibility because freedom and equality are at the heart of the Value System of the European Union.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, the Roma are one of the largest ethnic groups in the EU, and International Roma Day is without doubt an important opportunity to recognise the historic and persistent discrimination against them in Europe. Roma suffered hugely during the Holocaust, and were systematically persecuted, deported and killed. It is vital we recognise the suffering they endured and distance ourselves from the sickening comments we heard here this evening, which were nothing short of hate speech. Today Roma continue to suffer discrimination in many ways, including in education, healthcare and housing, and in ignorance from MEPs in this Chamber. It is vital that all citizens have fair and equal access to provisions which are, after all, human rights. In Ireland, in some instances, the Roma community has been subjected to racism and violent threats. In 2009, Loyalist elements disgracefully intimidated, threatened and eventually forced Roma families out of their homes in South Belfast. Sinn Féin condemns these attacks in the strongest terms, and we continue to defend the rights of the Roma community in Ireland, in Europe and elsewhere.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the More than half a million Roma and Sinti were estimated to have been killed by the racist reign of terror of the German National Socialists. In Ausschwitz alone, more than 23,000 Roma and Sinti were murdered in gas chambers. During the dissolution of the so-called gypsy camp in Ausschwitz-Birkenau, on the night of 2 to 3 August 1944, 2 897 Roma and Sinti, mostly women, children and the elderly, were killed. That is why the victims of the Roma and Sinti genocide have been remembered for years on 2 August. It is long overdue for this Day of Remembrance to become more widely known. We fully support the call for recognition of 2 August as the European Day of Remembrance of the Genocide of Roma and Sinti. And remembering this crime means that, even today, we must take decisive action against all forms of racism and actively combat the existing discrimination and exclusion of Roma and Sinti wherever it occurs. Also in this House!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, parliament is concerned today about the Roma is not surprising. Since 2010, the European Union has been increasing communications, recommendations and regulations to force Member States to achieve Roma integration. This includes enabling Roma to find jobs and housing, and their children to attend school. At the same time, the European Union has spent billions of euros on Roma. For example, the European Social Fund provided EUR 13.3 billion between 2007 and 2013 to finance Roma integration. All of these efforts have largely failed. In France, for example, the Andatu programme, in the Rhône department, is presented as a success. However, it cost 2,600,000 euros over three years and served roma only to obtain residence permits and to receive the income of active solidarity, without being able to integrate them into the labour market or into French society. Let us be realistic, it would be better to change policy and put pressure on Romania and Bulgaria to treat their Roma with dignity instead of trying to integrate them elsewhere, even when they do not want to.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Allow me to join this debate on the genocide of the Roma and Sinti during The Second World War.  The more we learn about the new facts about this dark side of European history, the more true the thesis is that it is indeed a forgotten Holocaust. I would like to underlin that we cannot yet incorporate violence against the Roma into the concept of genocide. Therefore, at the level of the United Nations or the European institutions, we must extend the meaning of this concept accordingly in the future. However, the fact is that it was a mass crime, ethnic cleansing, which involved around 600,000 Roma during World War II, including women and children.  It is usually said that the perpetrators of this genocide were only Nazis. The fact is that in the 1930s Stalin also had roma families from Leningrad to Moldova. The fascists also had concentration camps for the Roma in Italy.  Well, they killed a few hundred Roma in my country, too. It is important that most of them were killed by partisans who were led by the Communist Revolutionary Movement. The rest were added by Nazi and fascist authorities. Let me finish. Only totalitarian regimes and forces, all in turn, carried out genocide against the Roma. Today's generations must remain committed to remembering these victims and ensuring that these and other atrocities of our semi-previous history will never happen again.

name: Damian DRĂGHICI
text: – Madam President, I am a Roma myself. Europe’s largest ethnic minority inside the EU comprises the youngest and fastest—growing demographic segment of the population. For example, by 2020, young Roma will make up one third of the new entrants to the workforce in Hungary and in Bulgaria. Europe cannot afford another lost generation. This is a matter of human rights and basic values and it is vital to peace and cohesion in society across Europe. Europe cannot afford to ignore the fast growing anti-Gypsy policy within its boundaries. Europe, while adjusting and reinventing its own instruments for a participatory democracy, can no longer be silent in the light of the human rights violations that most European citizens of Roma origin are facing in their daily existence. Racism against Roma is racism too and cannot – and should not – be tolerated any longer. Racism and intolerance became rooted in European societies as the economic crisis deepened societal cleavages and created the premise for strengthening extremism against poor, deprived, socially—excluded European citizens, often ethnic Roma. As we can see even here with our colleague, Mr Buonanno, racism is no longer limited to the fringes of society. It is present even here in the European Parliament. What upsets me, as a Roma, is that I am well enough educated not to discriminate myself. I feel sorry for him.  Legal means alone do not seem sufficient to counter trends and to counter discrimination. More needs to be done. Anti-Gypsyism, as Commissioner Jourová said – and I congratulate her – is one of the most acute problems facing Europe today. It has for far too long been a widely—accepted policy at state stakeholders’ level, and this has to stop. Therefore, in the interests of fully participatory democracy, I, as a Roma, pledge myself in favour of acknowledging and assuming, through our internal European Parliament political mechanism, the existence of anti-Gypsy rhetoric.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, it is important to have this day of commemoration of the genocide of the Roma people in World War II, but in this case we have learned little from the horrors of the past: persecution of the Roma people continues, today, within the borders of the European Union. In 2007, Mr Franco Frattini, then Vice-President of the European Commission, said: "What needs to be done is simple: go to a nomadic camp in Rome and ask them, "Can you tell me where you live?" If they answer that they don't know, take them and send them to Romania." And as Juan de Dios Ramírez Heredia, President of the Spanish Romani Union, said at the time: ""Cogedlos" brings us the memory of the saddest history in Europe." Take them," the dictators have always said; "take them," the Nazis said, taking us to the concentration camps and then to the gas chambers." And little has changed the situation since 2007, except that the wave of racism and xenophobia has also been added to social democracy. The now French Prime Minister, Manuel Valls, is known for trying to expel a fifteen-year-old girl while hiking, and also, here in this Parliament, we also have sitting on a far right that keeps shouting 'take them'.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – The history of genocide must not be repeated. We need to create a Europe that allows everyone to help themselves. Therefore, of course, all forms of discrimination and exclusion must be combated. As has been said many times today, the Roma are the largest ethnic community in Europe, which, of course, has its own culture, its own customs and perhaps sometimes its own perception of freedom. However, they have exactly the same rights and obligations as all other Europeans.  Therefore, of course, it is also necessary to provide appropriate financial incentives and resources for integration policy, for a policy of cooperation and, in fact, for such a policy, which will also enable the Roma to live as we want for ourselves. Unfortunately, of course, we are living in a time of increasing intolerance, and preventive action must therefore also be strengthened, and there, of course, there is also a call to the Commission, not only on Roma Day, but also on other days of the year.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: "Perhaps it would be worth asking the Gypsy people who they consider their greatest enemies today, the main anti-Gypsy ones. I have done this in my travels to Hungary, and responsible Gypsy people have told me that their main enemies are those who have an essential interest in the roma being left in misery and aid dependency. Who are they? Well, politicians in the first place. Politicians who go out during the campaign and buy a packet of pasta, beer or other for the votes of gypsies in a miserable situation.  The other such group is corrupt Gypsy leaders. Those who "steal" huge amounts of money, in fashionable terms, referring to various projects, programmes, the misery of the Gypsies, and the wretched part of the Gypsies, is the one who sees no benefit from them.  The third such group is loan sharks, who very often, and most often, are criminals belonging to the Gypsy community who also take advantage of the misery of the Gypsies, and it would be a real disaster for them if the Gypsies were to be raised, because then they would have to make a living from decent work, similar to the girl traffickers and run-ins. It would also be worth focusing on these groups when it comes to protecting and lifting the Gypsies.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The Roma Holocaust has absorbed more than 500,000 lives. In nazi death camps, Roma were mass murdered, starved, gassed. Today they lie in nameless graves, in unknown places, without flowers, without wreaths, without honors given by the authorities and by survivors. The recognition of the Roma Holocaust is our moral duty, the first duty that we should do as Parliament, and an important step in building a Roma identity and building new relations between Roma and non-Roma.  Polish Sejm declared the extermination of the Roma in 2011, establishing 2 August as the Day of Remembrance of the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti. Every year, official celebrations take place at Auschwitz-Birkenau, a Nazi concentration camp where 5,000 Roma were murdered, 3,000 of them in one night during the liquidation of the gypsy camp. They are organized by Roma organizations with the participation of state authorities. Polish the government's Roma programme in millions of zlotys is one of the best in Europe, but it is far from sufficient, because the Roma are still living in really high poverty, there is a high level of unemployment and homelessness, and this is all coupled with inadequate education, sometimes statelessness, and a vicious circle of poverty and discrimination is being created, which we must necessarily stop.  I believe that the key to these better actions is education, both roma and adult children, as well as cooperation with Roma assistants and people who will build bridges between the Roma community and the non-Roma community.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – The Roma community is the largest ethnic minority in Europe with 10 million people. Their daily lives are systematically made difficult by discrimination, xenophobia and stigmatisation. It is clear that this is not just a problem for Eastern European countries, but of the European Union as a whole. A sad but telling example arose three months ago, when the mayor of a suburb of Paris refused to have a deceased Roma baby buried in his municipality.  A number of political measures and initiatives have been taken in recent years, including at European level. Aimed at housing, education and care, these measures aimed to improve the lives of Roma in Europe. Unfortunately, that didn't happen. The situation of Roma is still woefully bad in all EU Member States today. This will continue as long as discrimination and exclusion are not addressed. There is no need for new working groups, strategies or large conferences. It is high time to take action. The mentality and prejudice towards Roma must be addressed. In addition, Member States should be addressed to their policies towards minorities and respect for fundamental rights. The segregation of Roma is unacceptable. The European community of values is based on fundamental rights, human dignity, equality and the rights of minorities. It is high time to make these words come true for the 10 million Roma in Europe.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – The persecution of the Roma ethnic group after 1938 also concerns the territory of the Czech Republic. Of the more than 6,000 Roma, only a few hundred survived on the territory of the Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia.  Today, there are up to 200,000 Roma living in the Czech Republic who subscribe to this ethnic group. Whatever the exact numbers, it should be said that the situation of Roma in the Czech Republic is not improving much. It is reported that up to half of Roma are unemployed and the situation is particularly alarming among the young population, with between 60% and 70% unemployed among young people aged 15 to 25. This is, of course, mainly due to low education. Of course, the Czech Government is responding to this situation. It adopted a strategy of measures for Roma integration for the years 2014 to 2020, which mainly concern education, employment and also housing.  Although very slowly, after all, it must be said that the situation especially in the field of education is getting better. This is evidenced by the many activities of our schools and non-profit sector, as well as regular monitoring. Measures by the Czech Government, which wants to introduce a compulsory pre-school year of education, are also aimed precisely at promoting the involvement of children from Roma communities.  In this context, I would like to emphasise a very beautiful film called Way Out, which talks about the current Roma community. If we want to do something up-to-date, let us give it space within the European Film Prize.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, nothing in the world would have stopped asking for the floor in a debate, in this European Parliament, which reflects on the International Day of the Gypsy People and which pays tribute to the victims of the Holocaust against Roma in World War II, which also existed. And then I make him proud because the Socialist Group had among its ranks the first Gypsy Member of this Parliament, Juan de Dios Ramírez Heredia, and now counts between its ranks two distinguished and honourable members, Soraya Post and our colleague Damian Dr. Dghici. But I also make it proud that the Socialist Group maintains an indelible commitment to discrimination, equal rights and opportunities, and also to the stigmatisation of any population, even a minority, in European society. And that is why I demand that this Parliament monitor national strategies against discrimination against the Roma people, including in a country like mine, Spain, which blasona from an experience of success in integrating the Roma community and which, however, still in the Castilian language makes the stereotype against Roma pervivious in a set of sayings and even jokes. Extremely demanding against stigmatisation and above all against hate speech, deploring that in this Parliament we have had to hear manifestations of this negative stigmatisation of hate-laden Roma by representatives of the far right who shame this Parliament.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – I am pleased that the European Parliament is dealing with this important subject, and I am irely sorry that this debate, like the previous debate on anti-Semitism, takes place at such a late hour and in an almost empty room. We are talking about The Roma in Europe, who face constant discrimination in their daily lives, in all aspects of daily life: education, employment, health. Our primary task as Members of Parliament, I think, is to create a framework within which our fellow Roma citizens consider themselves to be full members of society. Our task is to encourage and ask them to participate in social and political life. I think it is important to set up the European Roma Institute, which can help to keep in touch between the Roma and non-Roma populations.  Finally, I consider it essential to classify 2 August as an official day of remembrance, because this terrible remembrance, this terrible act, is weighing on the consciences of all of us, and I am deeply ashamed that the Hungarian authorities were also involved in this terrible event at the time. We must draw attention to the fact that hatred, discrimination and racism are still present today. We have just witnessed how MEPs can speak. I think it's a disgrace to all of us, and we have to fight it with all our might.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – I think that tolerance and acceptance of otherness are very often lacking in Europe. One of the most discriminated groups is gypsies. There is no question that there is still strong anti-Gypsyism in the Member States, not only in the eastern part of Europe, but also in Western societies. Think of the official actions against the Roma, the repatriation. It is therefore very important to see that the Roma issue is not only an internal matter for some Member States, but also a European matter. Only through a joint effort can we achieve results in this area.  I come from a Member State, Romania, which has a large Roma population, and I am convinced that we should first and foremost look at this issue as a social problem. If we help these communities to connect with the labour market by reducing the level of early school leaving, then anti-Gypsyism will also be significantly reduced. Of course, this does not go from one year to the next, it can only be the result of conscious and long-term activity.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – I would like to start by saying that I come from Slovakia, namely the city of Košice, which is known as the centre of the Roma minority, the famous Luník 9 is probably known to everyone. Despite the negative reports, which are often and not objectively published, I would also like to point out positive examples that show that cooperation with the Roma community is gradually improving at every level. Romathan Theatre is successfully working in the city and is the only one of its kind in Slovakia, a Roma media centre, a private primary school and a gymnasium with a focus on teaching The Roma language and Roma realms. More recently, the 'We take it into our own hands' project, which aimed to present young Roma, has proved very good in many schools. Last year, I was honoured to be able to invite Roma community workers and Roma journalists to visit the European Parliament in Strasbourg, who subsequently filmed a document on the European Parliament and on the work of us MEPs, which they then presented in Roma communities, for which I would like to thank them very much, and I think that this is also the way of breaking down barriers.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in 2011 the European Parliament took the historic decision and recognised the genocide of the Roma by the Nazi regime and its collaborators, since they regarded the Roma as racially inferior.  Today's debate not only highlights the genocide of thousands of Roma by Nazi troops. It brings to our memories the mass executions of thousands of Greek patriots, in the hundreds of holocausts in the martyr villages of Greece. It brings to our memories the thousands of Greeks murdered in nazi concentration camps, Auschwitz, Dachau and elsewhere.  It reminds us all how timely it is to claim German reparations from Greece and to implement the court order that vindicates the victims of Distomos. Seventy years after the end of the Second World War, the fight for German reparations continues.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, in 1928, years before the Roma genocide, one of the greatest Spanish poets, Federico García Lorca, published the Gypsy Romancero. He made gypsies visible in positive for literature, visible and worthy, reflecting their fragile humanity. More "Garcías Lorcas" is needed, and debates are needed other than invisible hours, because we have to make up for it. Gypsies are still rejected. Today too, even to bury a ten-month-old baby — Maria Francesca – on 4 January 2015, in France, in Champlan, it was impossible to bury her there and they had to bury her elsewhere. Look, in García Lorca's Romance of the Moon, there is talk of the death of a gypsy child in these verses: "The moon goes through the sky / with a child in hand. / Inside the forge weep, shouting, the gypsies. / Air the candle, candle. / The air is watching her." I pray for Maria Francesca's soul and ours, because we have heard today things that, of course, incite hatred.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – I would like to talk about humanity. The word Roma means man. Humanity means understanding that every human life has the same, that is, absolute value and dignity. Recognising the genocide of the Roma is an act of sensibility, the redislation of humanity where our fathers and grandfathers have lost it. We are their descendants and heirs, so it is up to us to ask for forgiveness on their behalf. Humanity is proximity, it is the ability to touch, empathize, shake hands, hug. If, seventy years after the end of the Second World War, we are once again concerned about the increase in resistance to the Roma in Europe, this means that there is still little humanity in us. Let us ask the Roma for forgiveness for the evil of which we are heirs and find together with them a path of humanity.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I esteem this exclusive privilege to be allowed to speak twice here today. Thank you for the opportunity to participate in today’s debate. These discussions are always very inspiring for me, with the flow of – mostly – good ideas which we use in our work. I would like to react quickly to what Ms Záborská said about humanity. This is very much what I feel in my heart, and we must be strong in combating the increasing intolerance we now have in Europe. We had a discussion about this last week with Vice-President Timmermans. We are planning a big conference for October this year, where we want to gather together with all important stakeholders in the European Union to discuss how to combat not only anti-Gypsyism but also anti-Semitism and other forms and signals of increasing intolerance in Europe. I would like to add something regarding the Commission policy: I would like to call the policy we want to have a practical policy. We do not need big new legislation, new committees, big glossy conferences. We already have legislation in place, so what we need is stronger enforcement of the existing legislation and very precise insistence on observing the law. This is our main principle: that we are all equal before the law. This is something we need to use in the Member States, in everyday policy and everyday action. We are now assessing the national strategies which we collected from the Member States. I appreciate the Hungarian input, because I know it was the idea of Hungary in 2011 to start to work on the national strategies, which enable us to look at new methods and the new instruments we are going to use in the Member States and to help best practices to be shared by all. So, for instance, I spoke to the Deputy Minister in the Romanian Government who presented to me the new policy the Government wants to start in Romania to help not only Roma citizens but all those who are in need, people suffering from poverty, to overcome these problems. I asked them, please, to implement this as soon as possible, and then in one year’s time I would like them to share their experience with others. It is part of the role of the Commission to help ensure that best practices are transferred and to coordinate these actions. In the newly—submitted national strategies we see a lot of innovation, a lot of good ideas, a lot of effort to get rid of the things that do not work, and not to waste time, energy and money, and a really big effort to solve the problems. I hope the strategies will be as good when put into practice as they look on paper. In all the strategies we see ways of combating unemployment and poverty, ways to increase education and access to services, including housing – very practical things. A last comment regarding financing. You said here that well—targeted funding is necessary. It is not only the European Social Fund which should be used in the most practical and effective way. In this respect the Commission – and I personally, because I was very active for four years in EU funding – are helping to share best practices and to share information on what works and what has been funded from the European Social Fund. But there are also governments financing projects and programmes for Roma integration and combating poverty, because most of these programmes concern not only Roma citizens but also all those who suffer from poverty. Here we see increasing interest from governments in using their resources to help the situation. A last comment regarding the NGOs. I very much appreciate the work of NGOs and activists working on the ground because they are doing the right work and the proper work to help the situation. I am convinced that if we find a way to introduce multiannual financing of these NGOs – which, in fact, work in place of the state doing the work which the public sector should otherwise do – they should have more stable financing. This would, in turn, save time and energy for the real work, as they would not be spent chasing money to survive. I apologise for taking so long but the debate was very inspiring and I felt I wanted to add these practical points.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, I have followed the debate with great interest and I will reiterate that politicians play a great role in shaping public opinion. They can do good but they can also cause a lot of damage. This is why I fully share the opinion that there is no room for hate speech in parliamentary chambers. Many of you have made the suggestion that there should be a commemoration date of the Roma genocide. I must say that the Council has not yet taken a position on this subject. At the same time, I find it symbolic that we are having a discussion on the possibility of a memorial day to commemorate the Roma genocide on the day when my country, Latvia, commemorates victims of the Soviet totalitarian regime. Without prejudice to the Council’s eventual position on the matter, as a representative of a country whose people suffered a great deal from totalitarian regimes, I understand the historical, political and educational value of having such a date. Irrespective of when we celebrate International Roma Day or when exactly we commemorate victims of the genocide, there is an urgent need to address the poverty, marginalisation and discrimination faced by Roma communities. As part of the EU and national action, we have a duty to ourselves, to our values and of course to Roma, to tackle public misunderstanding, raise awareness and fight intolerance because, as we look back, so too must we look forward to ending stigmatisation, to properly integrating Roma – and indeed all minorities – into European society and to showing that every European has a place in Europe. It has been a pleasure to have this dialogue with you on this really vital issue.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Thank you very much, Madam Secretary. Indeed, it is our job to shape public opinion, and it is our responsibility. Therefore, there is no use for any kind of hate speech, and it has no place in Parliament. However, it is important not only to talk, but also to make sure that the situation improves. The debate is over. A vote will take place at the second meeting in April. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – I believe that, in order to live in a modern society based on such European values as human dignity, one needs to address and understand history and the evolution of human moral behaviour. For this reason we should be prepared to recognise and accept past atrocities committed on the European continent. Therefore, I would like to encourage the honourable Members to recognise the memorial day for the Roma genocide during the WWII period, in which the Nazi regime conducted mass killings of Roma people on racial grounds. However, certain discriminatory or xenophobic practices against the Roma community persist in a number of EU countries to this day. These practices often arise from prejudices and stereotypes which generate hatred and divide societies. Therefore, it is absolutely essential to obtain the equal treatment of such minorities. We should rethink how their social inclusion within national communities could be enhanced. I believe, first of all, that we should address the socioeconomic aspect and provide every opportunity to the Roma minority to have access to vocational training and state education, and we should stop the dissemination of biased information building a negative image of the Roma community.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – In recent years, the issue of the Roma minority has become a priority topic both in public debate simens and on the European political agenda. Roma are one of the largest ethnic minorities in the European Union, with statistics indicating the existence of about 12 million Roma living in different Member States, often in harsh living conditions.  Although important legislative and institutional progress has been made during this time, the reality shows that there is still work to be done in the process of social inclusion of Roma communities. Discrimination, poverty, social exclusion, lack of education and access to basic healthcare are just a few problems that the Roma community faces and that we must continue to fight for.  The European Union has developed a legislative framework aimed at increasing the social integration of marginalised groups, combating racism and racial discrimination, within the framework of general strategic visions such as the Europe 2020 Strategy, the European Platform for Roma Inclusion, the European Framework for Roma National Integration Strategies – 2020. I believe that the promotion of policies for the social inclusion of minorities, through initiatives and actions to combat poverty, must be on the list of priorities of the European agenda.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – International Roma Day has been celebrated since the first International Roma World Congress in 1971. This is an opportunity to pause for a moment and review the situation of the Roma. When I look around, unfortunately, I see that the Roma are still not full citizens of my country. The life expectancy of the Roma in my country is 10-15 years shorter than that of their majority counterparts. Their housing conditions in many ghettoes are comparable to those of those in the Third World, with poverty constantly increasing and their breakout potential diminishing. Since the regime change, the number of Roma who have been forced out of the primary labour market has increased, and even though the unemployed have been begging for humiliating public work that does not provide a real livelihood for years, they often do not have access to it. In Hungary, almost 2/3 of Roma children are studying in segregated educational institutions. The Minister responsible advocated for a school maintainer who was also found to be discriminatory by the court, and the court's decision was answered by a change in the law. While EU and national funds for development are allocated by a political body whose pro-government leader is now unable to account for the spending of nearly EUR 2 million. There is also the Responsibility of the Union for this: despite many excellent plans and resources spent, there has been no discernible change. However, it is safe to say that the situation of the groups with the worst advocacy skills is the best indicator of what the future of Europe will bring.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. – The Roma people are Europe’s largest ethnic minority. Of an estimated 10-12 million in the whole of Europe, some six million live in the EU, most of them EU citizens. Despite the fact that EU countries have banned discrimination against Roma people, many Roma in the EU are victims of prejudice and social exclusion involving housing, education, access to healthcare and employment. Education is a key element for equality, social inclusion and integration. Every child has a right to equal opportunities for education. However, as many as 50% of Roma children in Europe fail to complete primary education. The EU must ensure the right to basic education for Roma children, with particular emphasis on improving access to early childhood educational opportunities and transition to quality primary education. It is our responsibility to promote integration and tackle the social exclusion of Roma people. We cannot forget that almost 3 000 Roma men, women, and children were murdered in the gas chambers on the night of 2-3 August 1944, when the Germans liquidated the Zigeunerlager at Auschwitz-Birkenau. Therefore, it is essential to recognise the Roma genocide and establish a European memorial day to commemorate its victims.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. – Roma are the largest ethnic minority group in Europe. Today many Roma are living in very poor conditions, have lost their jobs and housing and are finding it difficult to support themselves and their families. They are often facing racism, discrimination and social exclusion. In order to integrate Roma people into European societies we must recognise them, learn about them and teach our children their history. That is the key to understanding and overcoming hatred and racism. The killing of Roma during WWII, a process called Porrajmos, can be considered one of the largest mass killing in history. This cannot be forgotten. I therefore support the idea of having a European Memorial Day of the Genocide of the Roma.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. International Roma Day is an essential event to better combat prejudice and denounce the discrimination and persecution that Roma still too often suffer. The European Roma Inclusion Strategy adopted in 2011 remains under-implemented in the Member States. As a result, Roma still do not have access to the same care as other European citizens. Roma children are less educated, and even receive apprenticeships in some states normally for children with disabilities. In addition, Roma often live in unacceptable hygiene and safety conditions, while discrimination in hiring persists. The European Union's Roma inclusion strategy must be pursued and amplified. For this, the European Commission has a responsibility to be more vigilant about its effective application by states, and to apply sanctions when necessary. The inclusion of Roma is an issue for this minority but also a challenge for Europe. A challenge to the scourge of populism. A challenge for the European idea, because the Roma are the heart of our Europe. This Europe that rhymes with diversity and multiculturalism.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – During World War II, the Roma community was the target of what can be called the "forgotten holocaust". The Roma were persecuted, captured, subjected to forced labour and murdered in Germany, the occupied territories and the countries that cooperated with the Nazi regime.  Despite all the atrocities committed against the Roma community, it was not until 1982 that the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany recognized the persecution and genocide of the Roma. Thirty years after the war, many of the victims did not live long enough to receive recognition and restitution for the crimes they were targeted for. Unfortunately, there was not even the justice possible for tens of thousands of human beings.  The establishment of the day in memory of the Genocide of the Roma during World War II is a gesture that has long been vital to restore some justice and restore dignity to the Roma community.  I fully support the initiative and hope that it will be a first of many steps in building a different narrative towards Rome and in recognizing its integral role in European and global culture, historical, present and future.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. It was on 8 April 1971 that the Roma, who represent the first minority in the European Union, chose, despite a still difficult situation, the symbols of their community as well as their flag and anthem. It is estimated that between 7 and 9 million Roma live in Europe. Many are still victims of gypsy xenophobia. And it can only be countered by recognising their history, their culture, and their contribution to European heritage. Through ignorance or received ideas, they are still victims to varying degrees of racism and discrimination. Today, the extent of the Roma genocide is not sufficiently recognized by a wide public, and some are unaware of its existence. The situation experienced by Roma in Europe leads everyone to question the necessary respect for human rights, and this in all the countries of origin of the Roma populations where they are constantly discriminated against and rejected. European policy is yet to be built in this area!

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. "Catching up and lifting gypsies is a shared responsibility of all of us. But how do we live with that responsibility? Looking at Brussels and Strasbourg, we sometimes get off the subject: we organise some buffet conferences, decide on new studies and order background analyses, and then set up billions more for programmes. But I would venture, with a few exceptions, we have little information on their end-use.  Just one example: in Hungary, the National Roma Municipality, which until recently was run by a Fidesz MEMBER of Parliament, recently launched an investigation after it was revealed that the 600 million forints of funds received from the European Union were spent on luxury offices and cars instead of creating jobs. For years, the Gypsy municipal system in Hungary has been surrounded by corruption, inefficiency and money-stealing. It is a bottomless hole in which european taxpayers' money is poured in, and the Gypsies at the end of the line do not profit from it. It is untenable that we do not have sufficient control over these uses of resources, that we do not call for effectiveness. It is scandalous that pro-government politicians invade and steal the self-organization of the Gypsies.  A few days ago, I hosted the Gypsy mayor of The Village of Cherdi in Brussels, who, on his own, through specific and sometimes radical programmes, almost completely eradicated unemployment and crime in his village. It is necessary to learn from him and to support people like him who want to do something, not to put money into corrupt systems that further exacerbate the cause of gypsies.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Claude ROLIN
text: Madam President, at the inauguration of the new European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker and Marianne Thyssen highlighted the crucial role of social dialogue.  This dialogue is essential, but we must recognise that it is not doing well today, particularly with regard to inter-professional social dialogue. The recent thirtieth anniversary of the launch of the social dialogue in Val Duchesse was the occasion of a high-level conference which, through its success, demonstrated the commitment of many actors to this dialogue but above all their expectation of a new beginning.  The European Commission is right to want to relaunch this dialogue, which depends on the will of the social partners but also on the energy that the Commission will use to define a method to accompany them. This approach should enable them to find the path of agreements that engage them concretely, both at the sectoral and inter-professional level.  This dynamic is essential. It will be credible if the Commission builds on these agreements by giving them the weight and place they deserve. I am convinced that this is a challenge that we must face, and so is the very future of the European project.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Madam President, in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs yesterday we talked about the GBP 42 million of Commission pre—financing that is not being taken up by the UK Government and used in the UK and, on Monday, Labour MPs went to meet Commissioner Crețu and talk to her about the GBP 718 million of EU structural fund money that is not being taken up by the UK Government and used in the UK for the social and economic purposes for which it was intended. Earlier this afternoon in this Chamber we voted on measures under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as we often do, providing billions of euros of assistance to get people back into work across the EU, but not in the UK, which has never made an application. The message to the Tory Government of the UK is clear: it is our people who are suffering the consequences of your obscurantist isolationism.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in accordance with Article 7 of Regulation No 472 of 2013, the Member States of the Union subject to a Memorandum shall carry out a full audit of their public finances in order to assess the reasons for excessive levels of debt and to identify any irregularity.  As Greece has broken down economically and socially, due to the memorandums that set debt at 175% of GDP, we call today, on the day of our national anniversary of 25 March, on the Greek government, taking advantage of Regulation 472 of 2013, to carry out an immediate debt audit and to write off the shameful debt.  After all, as Mr President-in-Point pointed out, Juncker, Greece's over-indebtedness is due to illegal actions by the European Union's supervisory authorities, who, although they knew that Greece was over-borrowed, in breach of the Maastricht Treaty, turned a blind eye to continuing the seamless export of German and French products and industrial equipment to Greece.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, 20 years has passed since the celebrated Arafat-Rabin handshake on the White House lawn, 20 years since the establishment of the Palestinian National Authority, and 20 years since the formal start of the Palestinian-Israeli peace process. Yet it was clear from my third visit to Palestine, and my third refusal into Gaza last week, that this year marks 20 years of shattered hopes and unfulfilled obligations. In the run-up to the Israeli elections Netanyahu exposed the 20-year pretence that he was a genuine partner for peace when he stated that there would never be a Palestinian state. A hard-hitting EU report warns that Jerusalem has reached a dangerous boiling point of polarisation and violence. Jerusalem is more divided today than at any time since Israeli occupation began in 1967. The report calls for tougher European sanctions against Israel. Without doubt the EU needs to impose such sanctions.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to express my support to the families and friends of the victims of the terrible plane crash that has shocked us. Ladies and gentlemen, the report of the European Network for Linguistic Equality on Discrimination in Spain is blunt. In the Spanish State, those speakers of co-official languages, such as Catalan or Valencian, as we call it, Galician, Basque, Aragonese or Asturian, are violated by their fundamental rights in a way incompatible with a democracy. The report lists hundreds of cases that reach aberrant limits, such as denying medical care or beating people for speaking these co-official languages. Most of these attacks are caused by agents of the Spanish Administration, including security forces, who act with impunity. The Spanish authorities consent to this violation of human rights, because living in their own language is a fundamental right that every European state should ensure. If we tolerate governments like Spanish allowing such practices, we become complicit. This report will soon reach the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and, there, will shame all Europeans who feel Democrats.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are four MUOS ground stations around the world. One of these is located in Europe and exactly in Niscemi, Sicily. The presence of MUOS in Sicily is an example of how the will of the citizens and the rule of law disappear when they come up against the imperialist arrogance of the American colonizer, because that is what it is all about.  MUOS serves only and exclusively the American War.
