No one wants it, neither in Sicily nor in Italy, it harms health and the environment, and an Italian court has said so, despite the fact that the government thinks that the citizens who have appealed were not entitled to do so, and it is a sensitive military objective, but a foreign one, on Sicilian territory. No Sicilian wants it, you can ask it one by one, and if Europe were a community it would side with those citizens who daily fight for their health and the environment and would defend them against this foreign military installation on our territory.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, since 2003, when the European Neighbourhood Policy was designed, there have been many major changes in Europe's neighbourhood. There is instability everywhere, a large number of illegal immigrants are moving to the countries of the European Union, we have illegal trade activities and the threat of terrorism. All of this creates threats to Europe's security and must be dealt with in an appropriate manner.  The neighbourhood policy must not be based solely on economic benefit. It must be based on the principles and values of the European Union. We must help these countries so that they do not export their problems to Europe. But the most serious thing to do is not to get involved in their internal differences and, above all, in their civil disputes. Consider what happened to Ukraine, Libya and especially Syria, where we created the monster of ISIS that is in danger and threatening to eat Frankenstein.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Unfortunately, I must remind again in the European Parliament that the rights of children, the rights of the Czech Michalák siblings, are still not protected and enforced.  After more than 3 months of waiting, I received a reply from the Norwegian Ministry of Children, Equality and Social Inclusion to a letter in which I appealed to Minister Horne against the removal of children by the Norwegian authorities. In the letter, the Norwegian Ministry states that it cannot intervene in the case and refers to the Law on the Welfare of the Child. This would be no bad thing if the authorities actually led their actions to the welfare of the child and also to preserve family ties. Unfortunately, this is the opposite process. The actions of the Norwegian authorities are incomprehensible to me, because in the case where the law gives much different possibilities of adjustment, the authorities will choose the worst for the children, i.e. the removal of children and the entrustment of foster parents, to complete strangers.  In this respect, I appreciate the activity of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Czech Republic, which is trying to help the family and make amends. In view of the fact that this is not an isolated excess towards citizens of EU member states, I have interpelled the EU High Representative in writing and asked her to push for the rights of children. I'm waiting for her answer.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, please listen to this data: EUR 500 million invested in the construction of an underwater gas warehouse off the coast of Castellón in eastern Spain; EUR 1 350 million in compensation to the concessionaire for the haltion of the project – which we will pay all consumers for thirty years on the electricity bill; more than 500 earthquakes recorded in the area for one month as a result of gas injections. This is the data; and the facts are that the Government of Spain approved compensation by Decree-Law, for more than 1.35 billion euros, for a facility that never became operational; and that compensation was paid with unprecedented haste in forty days without justifying eer urgency or amount.  That is why we ask the Commission to investigate whether this compensation is subject to law.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Many of you who know the history of the Czech Republic will probably not be surprised that we are a nation that is very cautious when it comes to staying, albeit short-term, foreign troops on our territory or moving it. We hoped that our so-called NATO allies would understand and respect the historical wounds on the soul of the Czech nation. In this respect, the US should remember the strong resistance of the Czech public against the possibility of building an American radar on Czech territory. This defiance has now partially spilled over into an American column of 120 vehicles and 520 soldiers, which will pass through the Territory of the Czech Republic in the coming days. I would like to inform the European institutions that some citizens and public representatives do not believe that such demonstrations of military power calm an already tense atmosphere.  I hope that hot heads that do not take part in creating a peaceful atmosphere and disrupt peaceful silence with demonstration troop movements will soon calm down. Our aim should be a diplomatic solution to the crisis, not an escalation of the crisis. The EU should not stand by to see two great powers showing off the size of their armies, escalating tensions in Eastern Europe. We do not want to see examples of foreign power and military power, we demand that armies remain in their states.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Italian online newspaper Quotidiano Nazionale has committed an outrageous violation of the freedom of religion and the rights of millions of Christians who believe in the sacramentality of confession – Catholics, Orthodox and others. Catholic priests who administered the sacrament of confession in good faith were recorded. Respect for the inviolability of confession has always been part of all the civilised laws of European countries, and on the other hand, violation and disrespect for the sacrament of confession, eavesdropping, has been the name of totalitarian states and violent violence. If we tolerate this practice, we will reconcile the rights of millions of people, and unfortunately let us point out one thing: in times of today's crisis of religion, people who benefit from confession, even though there are many in Europe, are very often minorities in individual European countries. We will reconcile the rights of millions of people who want to live their spiritual lives peacefully, violating trust in the most personal act. The response to this scandal will be a measure of respect for Christian life and for the rights of these people. I call for a swift response from the authorities of the Italian Republic.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Billions of public funds are being turned around in the area of public procurement, and I think that particular attention should be given to this subject.  Some equate public procurement with corruption, but I think everything else is important in public procurement, not just the lowest price, because how the right to healthy food and a healthy environment can compete with the lowest price. Of course, it cannot, and in some way, also de-double the quality of life of people who are subjected or who enjoy, in quotes, to the fruits of public procurement. In schools, kindergartens buy food at the lowest price, where cheaper, less quality food is purchased, and this can of course have a significant impact on the health and quality of our children's lives.  I therefore, of course, call on the Commission to take the necessary measures in this area, in accordance with the new directives.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: " I would like to invite my fellow Members to a very important programme. From 1:00 next Tuesday there will be a public hearing where hungarian victims of bank fraud and infringements will speak, the victims of so-called "foreign currency lenders", also known as Swiss franc-based loans, to put it this way.  A lot of people ask when they see the poster, "But this problem has already been solved in Hungary, isn't it?". After all, these fraudulent loans based on swiss francs have been converted into the national currency. Yes, but not at the exchange rate at the time of admission, which may have been around 160 HUF, but at the current market rate of 260 HUF. So it's not true that the problem has been solved, people are still being suicidal, tragedies are coming.  I ask you to come and find a solution to this problem affecting millions of people in Europe, because not only in Hungary, but also in Croatia, Romania, Poland, there is such a rough construction.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, the recent statements by the Russian Ambassador in Copenhagen that all countries participating in the NATO anti-missile system will be targets of Russia are extremely serious statements, which must not go unnoticed by the European Commission, but, on the contrary, must be a major concern at the level of this institution. The European Commission cannot wait for the US to always take the first step and react to the aggression of the representatives of the Russian administration, especially since these statements directly target member countries of the European Union and NATO, such as Romania and Poland. The safety of citizens, peace and stability of the whole of Europe are systematically jeopardised both by declarations and by concrete actions from Russia. That is why I believe that a joint effort by the European Union and the US is needed in the face of Russia's attitude, so that it understands that peace and security in the region are inviolable and the answer otherwise will be appropriate.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: – Media pluralism and freedom of the media are one of the most important common core values of the European Community and the European Union. In recent years, a number of Hungarian Members, the Tavares report and various European institutions have pointed out that these core values have been compromised in Hungary. The independence and freedom of the media are not guaranteed as in other European countries. In the time since then, the government has taken certain steps, but it must now be said that there are no longer guarantees of political independence in the civil service. There is no television with public service functions in Hungary, and the distribution of radio frequencies is also extremely one-sided. I must say that this is not a Hungarian matter, it is a question of the fundamental values of the European Union, and that is why it is the fundamental task of the European Parliament to draw attention to the damage to these freedoms.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, a few months ago, the graphic comedian known as 'El Roto' published a vignette reading: 'Young people should be encouraged to leave the country, unless they intend to change it.' Hundreds of thousands of young and not-so-young people in recent years have been forced into exile because in the Spanish state they are denied the future. They are expelled and then then, when they are already away, they are prevented from voting.  In 2011, the People's Party and the Socialist Party changed electoral law and now Spanish citizens residing abroad have to beg for the vote in order to participate in the elections, a whole process with a thousand difficulties that practically prevents them from exercising their right to vote. In fact, in the last European elections only 4.5% of the census of residents abroad and in Andalusia voted only 3.8%, which calls into question the legitimacy of the electoral result. It's perfect: first they kick them out and then they won't let them vote. Perfect for some to continue to be inpoltronated in their seats serving those who have led us to the current situation of unemployment and exile. But whether they want to or not, and even though thousands of young people are denied a vote, we're going to change this country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – In my contribution, I want to return to the topic of the Czech Republic as a Czech MEP, namely the topic of consumer rights protection in the field of telecommunications services.  I have already informed once that the Electronic Communications Act has been adopted in the Czech Republic, which according to most lawyers is contrary to the content of the Universal Service Directive and significantly shortens consumer rights in relation to important, influential and economically strong operators.  I have sent a question on this matter to the Commission and I was very pleased that the Commission does not take this matter lightly, that it notes that it is pursuing the case, and that the Commission has contacted the Czech Republic for clarification and to ensure that the Czech legislation complies with EU law. I would like to ask and call on the Commission to continue to monitor this issue and, if there is a show of inconsistency, to take all steps to remedy this, in my opinion, discriminatory Czech legislation.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I would like to bring to this House what has been the impact of the crisis on the fundamental rights of Spaniards, after the three years of government of the People's Party. The assessment I am going to make corresponds to the conclusions of a work published by this Parliament. The study reads: "The many austerity measures taken in Spain, with cuts in social, educational and health budgets, have led to a worrying increase in family poverty, negatively impacting fundamental rights. In education, the reforms adopted have led to a great inequality of the Spanish education system; public health has ceased to be universal and free; pensions acknowledge that there is already a reduction in the amount of pensions with the consequent reduction in purchasing power'. The report concludes by saying that the austerity measures taken by the Rajoy government have led to growing inequality in Spain.  The first response of the public to these harsh policies is in the results obtained by the People's Party in my region, Andalusia, last Sunday, losing 14% of the vote, in the face of the victory of the Socialist Party, which has pursued another policy in defence of fundamental rights.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: – Yesterday, the Subcommittee on Defence and Security (SEDE) discussed the militarisation of Crimea and the security situation one year after Crimea's illegal annexation of Russia. Refat Chubarov, president of The Mejlis of the Crimean Tatars, also spoke at the debate. He stressed that Russia's mere compliance with the Minsk agreements cannot be a reason to stop sanctions against the Russian Federation.  We must not lose sight here, ladies and gentlemen, that the territorial robbery of Crimea, which is part of the sovereign state of Ukraine, is a serious violation of international law. I spoke at yesterday's discussion and informed the SEDE subcommittee that a convoy of the US army would pass through my country, the Czech Republic, on the way from the Baltics to Germany in the coming days. I consider this demonstration of military readiness for defence to be of the utmost importance. That is why, in the SEDE, I proposed that the international community demonstrate its readiness for defence in Ukraine and the waters of the Black Sea as another step in the pressure on Russia following the application of sanctions.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Madam President, in Syria the toll is dramatic and we have a country in ruins, with over 220,000 dead, and thousands of civilians and children among the victims. The number of refugees stands at around 4 million, while the number of displaced people stands at 7.6 million.  And while the humanitarian crisis in Syria is deepening, insufficient and effective initiatives have been taken by the European Union to resolve it. It must finally be understood to all that humanity's greatest enemy is ISIS.  Is it time to come to terms with Iran and the Syrian regime to bring about some stability? The ultimate goal of all of us must be to end this situation in order to stop the civilian population suffering.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: – Economic pressure and a one-sided policy of equal representation of women and men in the European Union labour market lead many women to postpone pregnancy until after the 30th. However, with the older age of the mother, the likelihood of the appearance of Down syndrome also increases. These women and unborn children deserve more than prenatal diagnosis from society and, if found positively, offer a free abortion. On Saturday, March 21, we commemorated the world day of Down syndrome. Funding for research into this genetic disorder should be a priority of Horizon 2020.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, an entire region of southern Italy, Puglia, is on its knees by an epidemic that is destroying its olive groves. It is currently identified in the bacterium of Xylella nuisance the primary cause of olive disease, but there is no certainty that the bacterium is the real and only responsible, still needing a phase of study that I hope as quickly and punctually as possible.  The epidemic seems to have been defined too hastily and the eradication of olive groves itself proposed by Commissioner Andriukaitis could only be justified with the certainty that it is the only possible remedy. What is undoubtedly true is the very serious damage inflicted on the apulian regional economy, with the threat hanging over more than 23 000 hectares of olive groves and the threat of an entire sector, which sees a production drop of up to 40% possible. I call on the Commission to intervene immediately with the provision of compensatory measures for farmers by establishing adequate compensation for the possible felling of plants and to invest more in research, the only real remedy capable of definitively eradicating this cancer for Apulian agriculture and beyond.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – A month ago, the Supreme Court of the Republic of Slovenia abolished the controversial report of the Commission on The Prevention of Corruption, which in 2013 served as a tool for the removal of the otherwise successful centre-right government of Janez Janše.  The fall of the government has stalled urgent reforms, particularly privatisation.  The court's decision comes after two years of justice, but the economic, social and political consequences remain. It is particularly concerned about the poor functioning of Slovenian justice, which therefore enjoys the lowest level of trust among citizens compared to other Member States. Let me just remind you of the infamous Patria process. I call on the European Commission to draw up as soon as possible a sixth-hearted action in the area of justice, which will allow external systemic control of the functioning of the courts in the Member States. Only then can citizens, especially from transition countries, expect improvements.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – There are indications that the European Union imports €6 billion worth of agricultural land from illegal deforestation of tropical forests, which are often the livelihood of local communities. The savage destruction of forests for the productive purposes of palm oil, soy, beef and beef from cattle is an absolutely criminal act, with serious environmental and social consequences. It can also be inferred that these imports subject European farmers to unfair competition. The European institutions and their citizens should be alerted to these indications and, if confirmed, compensation of the injured parties and a refund of environmental services to indigenous communities should be made.  I also draw attention to the fact that the deforestation process, where corruption and violence are involved, calls into question climate stability and leads to the loss of biodiversity and these are issues with which the European Union is formally committed to its strategy of sustainable development, global warming mitigation and the fight against biodiversity loss.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, a serious political crisis is under way in Bucharest. It's like the one in the summer of 2012. The Senate has decided to violate the Constitution. "We don't care about her!" said one of the upper house members. It was a vote to lift the immunity of a former minister, Dan Sova. He is accused by anti-corruption prosecutors of complicity in abuse of office. More than half of the senators present voted to lift immunity, but the President of the Senate and the Prime Minister, a close friend of Sova, decided to consider the vote as a negative. The Constitution and several decisions of the Constitutional Court are thus violated. Basic common sense is despised. People took to the streets in Bucharest and shouted: "Parliament is criminal!". I demand, here, the resignation of Prime Minister Ponta! The only solution is to hold early elections.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I'm closing the agenda.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 ('Radio and television programming and broadcasting activities')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece.  This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  This application comes from Greece and concerns the field of electronic media. This sector has been particularly affected by the crisis. Many electronic media workers were made redundant during the crisis due to declining advertising revenues. For this reason, the Greek authorities requested additional funding of 5.04 million for the retraining and reintegration of 928 redundant workers from companies in the Region of Attica.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report, which approves the application EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting, from Greece for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Greece's needs in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Attica Broadcasting, which operates in the publishing sector. The Greek economy is in deep recession for the sixth year in a row, since 2008. Greece's GDP fell by 25.7%, government consumption by 21%, private consumption by 32.3% and unemployment increased by 20.6%. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 to 928 redundant workers. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training, and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Although opposed to the hypocritical system of the "Globalization Adjustment Fund", I voted in favour of this report to help the 928 employees affected by the closure of 16 broadcasting companies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal because the greek authorities' application meets the eligibility criteria laid down by the EAGF Regulation. Redundancies are in the radio and television programming and broadcasting sector of the Attica region that is linked to the global economic and financial crisis. In total, there are 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 ('Radio and television programming and broadcasting activities')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30), in Greece. At the moment, the Attica region is the highest number of unemployed among the twelve Greek regions; And also because the application is made will be for vocational guidance, training, recycling and vocational training, specialized training and education, job search and training and mobility subsidies, and all eligible laid-off workers will participate in the measures financed by the EGF.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This request, which concerns Greece and more specifically Attica, the region most affected by unemployment in Greece (26.3%), proposes the mobilization of commitments (5.046 million euros) to help the broadcasting sector in Greece, following the dismissal of 928 people in 16 companies in the broadcasting sector.  The causes mentioned are the fall in the purchasing power of households which has led to a collapse in demand and the deterioration of credit conditions.  The aid consists of grants for reorientation and vocational training, or unemployment benefits.  However, these causes are only the result of the dramatic squeeze on domestic demand and fiscal austerity in force in Greece, under the pretext of fiscal consolidation and the reduction of the external deficit.  As this aid is essential to the economic recovery of this Greek region, I have decided to vote for it.  Even if the Globalization Adjustment Fund is a back-and-forth to the problems created by the austerity policy and the opening to the four winds of globalization, it seems essential to provide financial assistance to these sectors currently threatened by the crisis.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to support 928 Greek workers in 16 companies in the programming and transmission sector. I think we should support this funding, which supports a region, Attica, which is greece's highest unemployment rate. The EGF remains an excellent tool for supporting companies and workers affected by the crisis, but it needs to simplify the bureaucratic process for its activation, so that it can have a positive impact on citizens' lives, especially in this time of crisis.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs.  However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the European Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 5 046 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 928 workers who have lost their jobs in sixteen companies operating in the field of radio and television programming and broadcasting activities in Greece's Attica region as a result of the economic and financial crisis that plagues the Hellenic country and which , on the one hand, has significantly limited the costs associated with day-to-day information, despite its importance, and, on the other hand, has drastically restricted loans to companies and individuals as a result of the lack of liquidity of Greek banks. The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants for the creation of new companies and promotion of entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Attica region, which already hosts the largest number of unemployed among the twelve Greek regions, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the granting of financial support from the European Globalisation Fund to 928 staff, For greek redundancies, attika broadcasting during the reporting period from 12 June to 12 September 2014. severely limiting, regardless of its importance, the cost of daily information. At the same time, the lack of cash in Greek banks has led to a drastic reduction in the issuance of loans to businesses and individuals. The harmonised package of personalised services to be co-financed consists of vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training services, an autonomous subsidy, a job search allowance and a training allowance and a mobility allowance.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The establishment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has so far proved to be a very important tool for workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. In my experience, the grants awarded so far have helped the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour market. The Greek Government's request complies with the requirements set out in the establishment of the Fund, which is why I supported its adoption.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed decision to allocate funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) of more than €5 million to 16 companies from the Greek region of Attica, who are active in the field of radio and television and have been forced to forgive because of the deterioration of the economic situation. The EGF will thus provide assistance to 928 workers who lost their jobs in 2014. For laid-off workers will thus be made available to measures such as vocational guidance, training (re- vocational and specialised training), education and job search, training and mobility allowances. Self-employment grants will be allocated €1.8 million, €1.536 million for various training forms and €1.152 million will be allocated to training allowances. The 120 workers will be provided with mobility benefits to help them move to the place where they will be offered a new job. The Attica region is at its worst position among the 12 Greek regions in terms of the unemployment rate, with the highest number of unemployed people already living in Greece. This kind of assistance from the EU budget is therefore much needed. I hope that Slovenia will also start to make more intensive use of EGF funding, thus enabling re-employment for individuals who have lost their jobs in the past.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒Since Greece has submitted a justified and complete application for a financial contribution from the EGF following the dismissal of 928 workers in 16 NUTS 2-level companies in the Atici region, I support this Decision.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This request from Greece for the intervention of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund comes after 928 people were laid off in 16 companies operating in the programming and broadcasting sector. The work of the Committee on Budgets indicates "that layoffs in the distribution sector of the Attica region are linked to the global financial and economic crisis which, on the one hand, has reduced household disposable income, which has led to a very sharp fall in purchasing power and, on the other hand, has greatly reduced lending to businesses and individuals due to the cash flow difficulties of Greek banks". They further note that "these redundancies are expected to have a very large negative impact in the Attica region, which already has the largest number of unemployed in Greece". I therefore voted in favour of the intervention of the fund to the tune of EUR 5,046,000.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, since I maintain it is very important to deploy the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to help Greek citizens who have lost their jobs.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Attica region is an area that until the beginning of the crisis has provided many jobs but, due to the crisis, the number of unemployed has increased significantly, with Attica being among the first regions with the most unemployed in Greece today.  The amount of EUR 5 046 000 for the 928 workers can be useful for the relaunch of the area in terms of labour. This situation has been reached because, in economic crisis, banks were no longer able to provide loans as a result of insufficient liquidity. This has created a vicious circle, which prevents and makes it difficult for both workers and the system to work. I support this report because any support for those who have the strength, strength and willingness to work is welcome for both the affected area and the Union as a whole.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure in support of employment and workers who are victims of globalisation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to greece's application for financial assistance under the EGF following 928 redundancies at 16 companies operating in programming and transmission activities.  The Greek economy is going through a severe recession: according to data from ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, Greek GDP has fallen by 25.7 percentage points since 2008, public consumption by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment has risen by 20.6 percentage points. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from the EGF because of the lack of support from local and national institutions, which submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 958 workers of 16 enterprises operating in the programming and broadcasting sector in the Greek region of Attica. This is a particularly important issue for me, as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local BOSE factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Fund will be made in this instance, but adequate support for the workers in retraining and up—skilling must be provided in any case. The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as justification for making workers redundant.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The current mobilisation of the EGF is once again taking place in Attica, the Greek region with the highest unemployment rate. The demand for mobilisation is based on the redundancy of 928 workers from 16 companies operating in the field of audiovisual programming and transmission. This is the sector's first EGF application, and the request was requested by the beneficiaries themselves at the Greek Ministry of Labour. This is a particularly positive note, not least because it has allowed personalised intervention services to be identified since the redundancies took place in 16 different companies.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will provide some relief to 928 employees who have been affected by the closure of 16 television companies. As everyone knows, Greece has been in an intense recession since 2008; according to ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, greece's GDP has fallen by 25.7 points since 2008.  This situation, we know, is the consequence of the financial crisis, a crisis caused by a savage globalization, creature of unbridled ultra-liberalism. The Greek people who are suffering from austerity, mass redundancies, decommissioning for six years now, deserves to receive meagre compensation from this European Union which, on the other hand, is so often complicit in its economic and budgetary persecution.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the beginning of 2015, this is the third application for access to the Globalisation Adjustment Fund on which the European Parliament is giving its opinion. It is a clear sign of the difficulties that all the countries of the Union are experiencing and which now affect almost all sectors of activity directly or indirectly affected by this long economic and financial crisis. The Greek company Attica Broadcasting, like many others in its country, has suffered from the severe recession that has affected Greece for the sixth year in a row. Despite the efforts and new business plans, the company has registered an redundancy of 928 people. I voted in favour of Greece's request to the European Commission, which was also welcomed by the Council's Budget Committee, to mobilise EUR 5 046 000 to deal with the effects of the crisis and, above all, to support the many workers who are now unemployed.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure we have examined refers, compared to the 2015 budget framework, to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 for Greece. It concerns the redundancies of 928 workers. The request is based on the relocation of at least 500 workers over nine months to companies operating in the same economic sector defined at the level of the NACE Rev. 2 divisions. It should be said that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. According to data cited by the Greek authorities, the state economy is going through a severe recession. In addition, it is reported that the severe recession has been going on for several years now and that public consumption has fallen by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 points, while unemployment has risen by 20.6 points. Two main factors would appear to be the causes of the redundancies: the fall in family income due to the sharp rise in unemployment and the significant reduction in credit to individuals and businesses. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Greece because I believe that this appropriation can compensate for the costs and benefits that can result from structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. I believe that the 928 redundancies at 16 companies operating in planning and transmission activities in the Attica region are an indirect consequence of these changes in the patterns of trade, since the global economic and financial crisis on the one hand has led to a decrease in disposable income to households and, consequently, a collapse in purchasing power and the need to establish spending priorities by severely limiting the purchase of information despite its importance and , on the other hand, has reduced lending to businesses and individuals due to a lack of liquidity at Greek banks.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on mobilising EUR 5,046,000 for Greece with the aim of supporting the 928 workers made redundant in 16 companies linked to radio and television programming.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting for the following reasons. This fund offers support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade or because of the economic and financial crisis.  The Greek authorities, well before the decision to use the EGF, opted for the creation of personalised services for workers by dealing directly with the representatives of the workers (there are 928 redundancies, spread over 16 different companies operating in the same field, however, due to the economic crisis). This latest evidence is very important given that, as the report shows, redundancies will have a negative impact on Attica, which, it should be pointed out, already holds the sad record in the percentage of unemployed in Greece.  In conclusion, there seem to be all the requirements for access to the Fund which, in the present case, result in job losses as a result of the economic crisis and considerable economic damage to the regional economy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ 928 personnel from 16 enterprises working in the programming and broadcasting sector have been made redundant. Such redundancies are linked to the global financial and economic crisis. The European Globalisation Fund measures recommended will seek the reintegration of redundant workers into employment through occupational guidance, training, retraining and job search. I have thus voted in favour of this report.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the proposal to allocate EGF funds to the 16 companies involved in the broadcasting sector in order to protect the 928 workers made redundant. Indeed, at a time of serious economic crisis and in a country such as Greece, the granting of financial aid is the only instrument that can prevent further company closures and job losses, further aggravating the social emergency situation, which in some respects could be considered a humanitarian emergency.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 ('Radio and television programming and broadcasting activities')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece.  This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This application refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece. It concerns 928 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014. The events giving rise to the redundancies at Attica Broadcasting, according to the Greek authorities, were mainly two: (1) the decrease of available household income ― due to the increase in the tax burden, decreasing salaries and rising unemployment ― resulting in the need to prioritise spending while limiting significantly the cost of everyday information; and (2) the drastic reduction of loans to enterprises and individuals due to the lack of cash in the Greek banks. As this action will provide a second chance to workers who have been unfairly affected by changes beyond their control, I voted in favour of the application.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament is once again being called upon to cope with the effects of the crisis of recent years and the structural changes caused by globalisation. We are voting in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the three requests on the agenda in this plenary.  The mobilisation of the EGF, launched in 2007, has already supported more than 120 000 workers and is a key instrument of intra-European solidarity with the primary objective of reintegration into working life of the workers concerned. Other procedures for requesting the mobilisation of the EGF are already in progress and there will also be personal support for them, with a view to the full and concrete implementation of the European Union's social policies.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 928 employees in 16 companies in the broadcasting sector, Greece has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find a job or start their own businesses.  The aid provided amounts to EUR 5,046,000 and covers 60% of the cost of the projects that will be offered to these employees. Since Greece's request corresponds to the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Since 2008, Greece has been experiencing an unprecedented financial and fiscal crisis. In this context, goods and services that are not essential are particularly affected by the decline in household consumption. This is particularly the case in the broadcasting sector. I supported the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) in order to help nearly 1,000 sacked employees in 16 companies in this sector who found themselves in a situation of social fragility. With the co-financing of the EGF, these employees will be able to benefit from a range of personalized services such as career guidance, training, retraining and mobility.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Greek economy is experiencing a severe recession for the sixth year in a row. According to data from ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, Greek GDP has fallen by 25.7 percentage points since 2008, public consumption by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment has risen by 20.6 percentage points.  I supported the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund because it will allow the reintegration into the labour market of the 928 workers made redundant at Attica Broadcasting, a Greek company affected by major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece. The request was sent to the Commission on 4 September 2014. The Commission found that the application complies with the requirements laid down in Article 4(1)(b) of Regulation (EC) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 for the use of the EGF. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led mainly to the redundancies: 1. an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment reduced household disposable income, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and, despite their importance, a significant reduction in the amount spent on everyday information; 2. The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, retraining, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because, although I disagree with the way the funds are managed, this report concerns Greece.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece. The request was sent to the Commission on 4 September 2014. The Commission found that the application complies with the requirements laid down in Article 4(1)(b) of Regulation (EC) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 for the use of the EGF. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led mainly to the redundancies: 1. an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment reduced household disposable income, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and, despite their importance, a significant reduction in the amount spent on everyday information; 2. The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, retraining, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers.  In the case of Attica Broadcasting, and considering that the application meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, the aid package which I voted for is composed of vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training and subsidies for self-employment, job search and mobility, with a view to improving the employability of all workers. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union. According to data transmitted by the Greek authorities, the Greek economy is in a deep recession for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013). According to ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, since 2008, Greek GDP has decreased by 25.7 percentage points, public consumption by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment has increased by 20.6 percentage points. This support concerns 928 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support for redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Greek authorities have submitted an application for redundancies in 16 companies operating in radio and television programming activities in the Attica region, corresponding to a financial contribution of more than EUR 5 million. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted positively, because it is above all, even if the absolute free-trade policy of the European Union is at the root of the difficulties of European companies, to support a company in difficulty, its managers and its employees.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to Greek workers in Attica Broadcasting, who have been affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has also affected the labour market in Greece to a significant extent. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide the necessary and necessary support for workers affected by major structural changes in the world trade sector. On 3 February 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal to mobilise the Fund in favour of Greece. EUR 5 046 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to be used for the reintegration of 928 staff. The Greek economy is in deep recession for the sixth year in a row. The funds in question from the Fund are intended to re-engage unemployed workers in the form of job counselling, profiling and vocational training.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting the fund EUR 5 046 000 for the 928 redundancies in 16 companies in the Attica region, which is the region with the highest unemployment rate in Greece.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although I disagree with the way EGF funds are managed and some companies are treasured by retraining new skills of the dismissed with little money going for the benefit of the unemployed, I am voting in favour of the EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting application because it concerns Greeks.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I am entirely against the use of these funds since they do not respect the principle of subsidiarity as social welfare is firmly a Member State competency. Additionally, I do not believe that this represents any value for money and it is a waste of resources.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece. The request was sent to the Commission on 4 September 2014. The Commission found that the application complies with the requirements laid down in Article 4(1)(b) of Regulation (EC) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 for the use of the EGF. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led mainly to the redundancies: (1) an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment reduced household disposable income, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and, despite their importance, a significant reduction in the amount spent on everyday information; (2) The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, retraining, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it gives the green light to the mobilisation of the EGF to make a financial contribution of EUR 5 046 000 in response to Greece's request for the 120 redundancies made by sixteen companies operating in the radio and television programming and broadcasting activities sector in Greece.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is the Duty of the European Union, at times like these, to stand shoulder to shoulder with Greek families and to do everything possible to help as many people in need. For these reasons, I voted in favour of Greece's request to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I voted with conviction for Mr Kyrtsos' report mobilising concrete help for the workers of Attica Broadcasting, in response to the request made by the Greek Government.  Greece has been hit far too hard by the employment and economic crisis of the last five years. The hope is that these measures, in addition to being an instrument of professional reintegration as provided for in the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, can finally be seen as a gesture of openness and sensitivity on the part of Europe. The redundancies of Attica Broadcasting workers will have a further negative impact on a region which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece. I therefore hope that the release of funding will be able to put an immediate palliative and introduce measures that restore confidence and skills for the workers concerned.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the reports on the proposals for decisions of the EP and of the Council on the mobilisation of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contributions of EUR 5 046 000 and EUR 3 746 700 for the information sector in Greece.  Dramatic events, such as that of Attica Broadcasting, with the redundancy of 928 workers by 16 television companies, or the case of Attica Publishing, with the redundancy of 705 workers employed in 46 companies in the advertising sector, require commitment and solidarity.  The two events have common origins, the economic crisis, and common responses: closures and mass redundancies.  The fall in family income and purchasing power and the cut in business credit have bent Greece, opening up serious scenarios for territories such as the Attica region, one of the poorest in the country, and leading to the renunciation of services such as information, which are considered superfluous. This is all the more serious in view of the closure of the public broadcaster RTF at the behest of the Troika, and the democratic vulnus due to the lack of a plural information system. The financing under the EGF of personalised retraining and vocational training services, subsidies for entrepreneurship and start-ups is therefore very necessary from the point of view of European solidarity.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on resource mobilization for adaptation to a globalized space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 928 workers from 16 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support the provision of additional assistance to workers suffering from major structural changes in world trade patterns. The UK has never made an application under this Fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, because the purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In this case, 928 people had lost their jobs as a consequence of globalisation.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece. The request was sent to the Commission on 4 September 2014. The Commission found that the application complies with the requirements laid down in Article 4(1)(b) of Regulation (EC) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 17 December 2013 for the use of the EGF. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led mainly to the redundancies: (1) an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment reduced household disposable income, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and, despite their importance, a significant reduction in the amount spent on everyday information; (2) The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, retraining, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on resource mobilization for adaptation to a globalized space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 928 workers from 16 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. In assessing the application submitted, I consider that it should be granted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a Decision by parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of 928 redundanct Greek workers in the Attica region because the situation in Greece is extremely difficult and the recession that has hit the Greek economy has been going on for more than six years. In such cases, it is important to provide adequate assistance and support as quickly and efficiently as possible to mitigate the consequences of global structural changes.  The Attica region is greece's highest unemployment region, and the economic situation will be further exacerbated by these layoffs. Therefore, I consider that EGF financial assistance is of utmost importance in order to reintegrate workers into the labour market as soon as possible and to stimulate the growth of entrepreneurship, while also demonstrating the solidarity of the European Union.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Greece following redundancies in 16 companies specialising in radio and television programming and broadcasting. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I also welcome the adoption of this aid amounting to EUR 5,046,000.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that additional support should be given to workers who are suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade and who should be supported with a view to their reintegration into the labour market, especially if they have been made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, as is the case with Attica Broadcasting workers.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The application was submitted to the European Commission on 4 September 2014. Greece applied for assistance from the EGF after 705 staff were made redundant during the period 12.9.2013-12.6.2014. Support is provided in the form of career guidance and career planning assistance, support for business start-ups and start-up sanitising, training, training and higher education programmes, training grants and income support. I support this assistance for the redundant workers in Greece and I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made by Attica Broadcasting. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Attica Broadcasting was a large employer in the Attica Region of Greece, and the 928 redundancies which have resulted from its closure have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy, which was already struggling with large-scale unemployment. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected by helping them re-enter the labour market.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. As I had already had the opportunity to do so in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the Krystos report to mobilise the European Mobilisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) with regard to 928 sacked employees of the Greek company Attica Broadcasting. The EUR 5,046,000 allocated under the EGF will finance a global project of EUR 8,410,000, which includes professional support services, vocational training, specific entrepreneurship advice and business start-up support.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Krystos report to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the 928 sacked employees of the Greek broadcasting company Attica Broadcasting. Greek media companies lost almost half of their main source of revenue between 2009 and 2013 when many advertisers withdrew. In this context, and for the first time in the mass media sector, the EUR 5.04 million mobilised under the EGF will finance numerous aids to professional support and training with the aim of reintegrating sacked employees into the world of work.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Greek authorities submitted the request for financial contribution from the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) with reference EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting, following 928 redundancies in 16 companies in the programming and broadcasting sector. In addition, I would like to point out that this is the first request for aid to the EGF from this sector. Most of the funds requested are earmarked to support the creation of enterprises in the form of self-employment grants and training measures, including vocational training and training grants. I therefore believe that measures to support vocational guidance, training and self-employment should take into account the emerging opportunities that new media on the web can offer these workers. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Greek economy is having a hard time recovering from the effects of a crisis that has been going on there for 6 years. During this period, more precisely since 2008, there has been a 25.7% drop in GDP, and the Commission's forecasts show that growth in 2014 is only 1%. Since 2008, thousands of companies have ceased operations and their workers have ended up on the stock exchange. Unemployment increased by 20.6% during the crisis. Greek authorities have applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of 5m euros to help 928 redundanst workers. The requested amount would be used to co-finance a project to help laid-off workers of 16 companies in the mass media sector. The aid package consists of a personalised career guidance service, training and self-employment subsidies to reintegrate workers into the labour market. I support the demand for mobilisation of the EGF, as Greece, along with Spain and Portugal, is a member of the European Union with the highest continuously rising unemployment rate and personal consumption figures at times of crisis are worrying. Analyses from 2012 show that 23% of Greek citizens live below the poverty threshold, so personal consumption fell by 32.3% at the time of the crisis.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the approved rules of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, the application qualifies for assistance in the form of a financial contribution. Greece has been in a deep recession since 2008. The region to which the aid is directed has the largest share of unemployed compared to other regions in Greece. The redundancies of 928 staff in 2014 exacerbated this situation in the region. The aid granted is earmarked for the adoption of active labour market measures and the reintegration of redundant workers into the labour force.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Greek authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to the affected workers on 28 November 2014 , long before the decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ By way of an explanation of my vote, I considered this an appropriate cause for the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece. This question concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 relating to 928 redundancies at 16 companies operating in NACE, a company in the "Programming and Transmission Activities" sector.  The mobilisation of the EGF will make it possible to co-finance key measures such as individual assistance in finding a new job, training and retraining courses and the promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The profound transformation of the international trading system, attributable to the advance of globalisation and the economic and financial crisis, has led Greece towards dramatic economic and social conditions.  According to data cited by the Greek authorities, the country's economy is still going through an intense recession. I have chosen to support the Kyrtsos report, which supports the mobilisation of the EGF in support of 928 workers made redundant at Attica Broadcasting, because I believe it is necessary for the European Union, on the basis of the principle of solidarity, not to miss an opportunity to help Member States in difficulty.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. I voted in favour of supporting the proposal to mobilisation the amount of EUR 5 046 000 for Greece, in order to support the 928 people who were dismissed in a total of 16 companies, as a result of the crisis at national and international level.  I am confident that this support can actually facilitate the reintegration into the labour market of the workers concerned.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In view of the decline in household disposable income as a result of the increased tax burden, falling salaries and rising unemployment, as well as the drastic reduction in lending to companies and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks, there have been numerous redundancies of workers. These workers who have become unemployed must be supported in their reintegration into the labour market, which is why this application has also received my positive vote.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting support to the Attica region of Greece, where 16 different companies in the publishing sector lost their jobs during the nine months of the reporting period as a result of the economic crisis. In order to address emerging social problems as quickly as possible and taking into account the labour market situation in the affected area, support shall be given to the professional reorientation, training and measures of redundant workers promoting entrepreneurship, self-employment and job creation. Support shall be granted from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Greece has been hit hard by the austerity of previous governments, loyal companions of the infamous troika and its "structural reforms". The request concerns the 1,000 employees of local television stations in the Attica region. Indeed, public spending in mass media fell by 57% between 2008 and 2012. Since coming to power, Syriza has already introduced a bill to rehire employees of the public television channel ERT. Methods surely more effective than the proposals for self-entrepreneurship and forced relocation contained in this report. However, I abstain so as not to deprive Greek workers of this fund.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now appropriate to give this aid to Greece, which has submitted the EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica broadcasting application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 (radio and television programming activities) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS 2 (EL 30) region of Greece.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools in the EU’s arsenal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 928 workers in the broadcasting sector in Greece due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In Greece, 928 workers were made redundant in 16 different companies in the field of television programming and broadcasting activities. We are voting in favour of allocating EGF funds in the form of subsidies for self-employment and vocational training measures to support business start-ups.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an important institution of solidarity within the Union; an active employment policy instrument that shares the burden of returning to the labour market between the worker, the Member State concerned and the Union, and its results help both the worker who is able to re-enter the labour market, the Member State that is forced to deal with unemployment and the Union which is aiming to increase employment. The two applications submitted by Greece require assistance for a personalised service for the reintegration into the labour market of 705 workers to be laid off in 46 broadcasting and publishing companies in the attic region. According to the Commission's position, the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the Regulation and the provision of the service started well before the granting of the assistance. On the basis of all this, I found the application worthy of support.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  This report refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 from the EGF in favour of Greece. It concerns 928 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.
