These redundancies occurred due to the reduction in household disposable income and increased unemployment, which resulted in a huge drop in purchasing power and the need to set priorities in terms of expenditure, significantly limiting the amounts devoted to daily information, as happened with Attica Broadcasting. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed consists of vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training and subsidies for independent work, job search, training and mobility.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This request, which concerns Greece and more specifically Attica, the region most affected by unemployment in Greece (26.3%), proposes the mobilization of commitments (5.046 million euros) to help the broadcasting sector in Greece, following the dismissal of 928 people in 16 companies in the broadcasting sector.  The causes mentioned are the fall in the purchasing power of households, which has led to a collapse in demand, and the deterioration of credit conditions.  However, these causes are only the result of the dramatic squeeze on domestic demand and fiscal austerity in force in Greece, under the pretext of fiscal consolidation and the reduction of the external deficit.  The aid consists of grants for reorientation and vocational training, or unemployment benefits. In order not to penalize more of the dismissed people I voted for this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to activate the Fund to the tune of 5 million euros to support the reclassification of nearly 1,000 employees laid off by 16 Companies in Attica. In Greece, GDP has fallen by almost 25% since the beginning of the crisis, while the unemployment rate has risen by 20 points. The Mobilization of the Fund is once again a testament to the European Union's solidarity with the Greek citizens hardest hit by the economic crisis.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers of the company Attica Broadcasting, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade.  On the basis of the data cited by the Greek authorities, the redundancies were caused by the fall in household disposable income due to the increase in the tax burden, the fall in wages (both in the public and private sectors) and the increase in unemployment, which caused a collapse in purchasing power and the need to establish spending priorities by severely limiting the cost of daily information.  The coordinated package of personalised services to be cofinanced will be directed mainly towards vocational guidance, training and retraining actions and allowances for job search and mobility will be provided. We are therefore sure that these European incentives will be a valuable aid for the reintegration of these workers.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  This application, the third in the context of the 2015 budget, relates to the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Greece totalling EUR 5 046 000. Specifically, it concerns 928 redundancies at 16 companies operating in the programming and transmission activities during the reference period between 12 September 2013 and 12 June 2014. In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the Kyrtsos report because I believe that workers, victims of the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the advancement of globalisation, must have full support from the European Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: request egf/2014/018, GR/Attica Broadcasting as special rapporteur of the S&D Group for the EGF. The application is well documented and complies with the requirements of the European Commission in this area.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. •The financial crisis has led Greek households to significantly rebalance their spending priorities. Many households had to forego goods of daily use, such as television or newspaper subscriptions, which were not considered essential for everyday use. This is a 60% drop in sales. Advertising spending in the Greek mass media has fallen by half. Broadcasting service providers should receive EUR 5.04 million in EGF assistance. I consider support in this case to be very important and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 5 046 000 from the EGF to Greece, as it will help 928 people who became unemployed as a result of redundancy. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. With the EGF Fund, we can re-mobilise these people in the labour market.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  The support provided by this fund is vital during the economic and social recovery. During this period, it is essential that the EU show solidarity with redundant workers.  It is necessary to grant support as 928 redundancies in the broadcasting sector have had a particularly negative impact on the Attica region. It should be noted that the region already has the highest unemployment rate in Greece compared to the other 12 regions.  Undoubtedly, the support provided will help redundant workers to find new jobs as soon as possible and to reintegrate into the labour market. The MOBILF fund must be mobilised as soon as possible, as the redundancies are directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis, which has reduced household disposable income and led to a sharp reduction in purchasing power, and a drastic reduction in the issuance of loans to businesses and individuals due to a lack of cash for Greek banks.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the global economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, adopted at the conciliation meeting on 17 July 2008, and in compliance with the IAEA of 2 December 2013 with regard to the adoption of decisions mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF);  I am pleased that all workers have been offered vocational guidance, consisting of various traineeships, which will provide them with individual and personalised advice as well as plans for reintegration into the world of work, and I welcome the decision annexed to this resolution. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support this request submitted by the Greek authorities for the EGF's financial contribution, which follows the dismissal of workers in 16 companies operating in the programming and television sectors in the Attica region of Greece.  With the Greek economy in deep recession for years and already in a deep recession for the sixth year in a row, the government has taken unpopular measures to repay foreign debt, such as raising tax revenues, rationalising public spending and reducing the wages of public service workers. This has led to a decline in personal consumption and a decrease in purchasing power. I therefore support this requirement concerning the care of 928 workers from 16 companies, who propose to mobilise the EGF by EUR 5 046 000, representing 60 % of the total cost of the proposed measures in order to ensure a contribution to their application.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the approval of EUR 5 046 000 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations in order to partially finance losses incurred by redundancies in 16 companies operating under Section 60 of the NACE Rev classification. 2 (broadcast). Member States need to show solidarity with each other when necessary, and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. At the same time, Union financial assistance to redundanst workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible. The Greek authorities applied to EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting for a financial contribution from the EGF, following the redundancies of 928 workers in 16 broadcasting companies. According to greek authorities, the economy has been in a deep recession in the last six years (2008-2013), and according to ELSTAT, the Greek statistics body, since 2008 Greece's GDP has shrunk by 25.7 percentage points; public spending by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment increased by 20.6 percentage points. The layoffs are expected to have an extremely negative impact on the Attic region, which has the highest number of unemployed in Greece overall, compared to 12 other regions. I therefore support Rapporteur Georgios Kyrtsos' report on the mobilisation of EUR 5,046,000, which represents 60% of the total cost, as the aim is to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 As has traditionally been the case with the approval of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I must state that, in the vast majority of cases, these funds are heading to the so-called old Member States. Even today, this is the case, and the ratio is even three cases to none. It is also interesting that today we approve two cases where funds from the Fund go to Greece. Despite these reservations, I supported the report, but I still believe that the situation described will change.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in NACE Rev. 2 division 60 (Radio and television programming activities) in the Attica region during the period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.  According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is clear, on the one hand, that the redundancies in question are linked to the global economic and financial crisis, as household disposable income has decreased, resulting in a huge fall in purchasing power and the need to set priorities in terms of expenditure , significantly limiting the amounts devoted to daily information and drastically reducing loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks, and, on the other hand, that redundancies will have very negative repercussions for the Attica region, which already has the largest number of unemployed in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 5 046 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 928 workers who have lost their jobs in sixteen companies operating in the field of radio and television programming and broadcasting activities in Greece's Attica region as a result of the economic and financial crisis that plagues the Hellenic country and which , on the one hand, has significantly limited the costs associated with day-to-day information, despite its importance, and, on the other hand, has drastically restricted loans to companies and individuals as a result of the lack of liquidity of Greek banks. The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants for the creation of new companies and promotion of entrepreneurship. While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Attica region, which already hosts the largest number of unemployed among the twelve Greek regions, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help the 928 workers laid off by Attica Broadcasting. It is no secret that Greece is probably the European country that suffers the most from the financial and economic crisis that Europe is going through. Both public and private consumption fell drastically (by 21 and 32.3 percentage points respectively between 2008 and 2013). As is often the case in these cases, this decline was mainly felt in expenditures deemed non-essential, such as magazine and newspaper purchases, in which Attica Broadcasting is active. In view of these elements, it seems to me normal and important to vote in favour of the mobilization of the Fund, for a sum of EUR 5,046,000.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a financial aid mechanism that aims to support workers who are victims of relocations in the globalised context in which we live. Greece has submitted an application for the EGF's financial contribution to address the 928 redundancies that have occurred in 16 audiovisual-related companies in the Attica region. Note that this is the first application in this sector. Since the dismissal of this number of workers will have negative effects on this Greek region, which has the highest unemployment rate in all 12 regions, I consider this proposal to provide a financial contribution to Greece in the amount of €5 046 000, especially given that most of these funds will be channelled into supporting the creation of businesses and investing in vocational training.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I welcome the european Union's efforts to help our fellow citizens who are particularly suffering as a result of the global crisis. This application will help 928 people operating in 16 Greek companies, a country in great need of help at the moment.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because it calls for the mobilisation of the European Adjustment Fund to the sum of around EUR 5 million to cover 928 redundancies in 16 companies located in Greece carrying out programming and transmission activities.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Written. \u2012 Greece's application for unemployment effects resulting from the shutdown of 46 companies engaged in programme activities and mass media in the Attica region complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The application concerns 705 unemployed persons. The report shows that labour reductions have a very significant impact in the Attica region, which is already the worst unemployment area in Greece. The authorities took active steps to help and mobilise the unemployed well in advance of the EU Commission's decision to recommend the granting of a grant from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The report also shows that all those who have become unemployed have become or are about to be subject to activation measures. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 ('Radio and television programming and broadcasting activities')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece.  This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) on Greece's application for financial assistance following redundancies and terminations of activity in 16 companies operating in Division 60 ("Programming and transmission activities"). I believe that this contribution can be a valuable aid to these 928 workers who are now out of work and who will receive timely assistance for relocation thanks, for example, to adequate training, recognition of skills acquired throughout their careers and effective vocational guidance service.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant due to the global financial and economic crisis. It refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 046 000 from the EGF and concerns 928 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – The Attica region of Greece is among those with the highest unemployment. That is why the Government of Greece has requested a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Fund for 928 workers in 16 companies who have worked in the production and broadcasting of programmes and have been made redundant as a result of business cuts. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed by the European Globalisation Fund for 60% includes professional advice, education, retraining and training, self-employment subsidies, job application allowance, training allowance and work travel allowance. The Greek authorities must respect the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination when drawing on these funds, and the funds must be used to support individual workers and not to restructure companies or sectors. I supported Greece's request.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  The application for a financial contribution submitted by Greece to help the Region of Attica, where 928 redundancies in 16 companies has been made redundant, fulfils the eligibility criteria. The redundancies in the radio and television sector in the Attica region are the result of a global financial and economic crisis that has reduced household disposable incomes, resulting in a decline in purchasing power and a fall in household costs associated with daily information. In addition, the lack of money in Greek banks has led to a reduction in the volume of loans to businesses and individuals.  The redundancies have serious consequences for the Region of Attica, where the number of unemployed was already at its highest in Greece before the layoffs in the sector. As the co-financed services package covers the following important areas: vocational guidance and training, self-employment assistance and job-search allowances, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support 928 employees of Attica Broadcasting, a group of companies operating in the programming and transmission sector in the Attica region of Greece.  The redundancies are due to the global financial and economic crisis which, by reducing the disposable income of Greek households and their purchasing power, has led to the need to reduce expenditure on non-essential services, such as daily information through subscriptions to television services. The redundancies of Attica Broadcasting will have a huge negative impact on the Attica region, which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece compared with the other 12 regions. The eur 5 046 000 aid provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to co-finance a package of personalised vocational guidance, vocational training, specialised training and education services, employment search allowances and, for a number of selected workers, a contribution to enable them to start their own businesses in order to promote entrepreneurship.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Greece has applied to EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 928 workers in 16 companies operating under Section 60 of the NACE Rev. 2 (broadcast) in the NUTS 2 (EL 30) Attica Broadcasting region of Greece. I welcome the fact that all laid-off eligible workers are expected to participate in measures for which support comes from the EGF and, in accordance with the provision, Greece is entitled to a financial contribution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - As the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up precisely to support redundanst workers and the self-employed affected by major globalisation-driven economic changes, I agree with the report and welcome the decision to adopt Greece's application. In fact, Greece applied for EGF funding following the redundancies of 928 workers in as many as 16 companies in the Atici region, which already has the highest number of unemployed in total compared to other regions in Greece. It is positive to point out that even before the decision to approve the EGF funds was taken, Greece took the necessary steps to help and professionally target workers, and this means will facilitate this, it is also very good that a significant amount of funds will be directed towards supporting start-ups in the form of incentives for self-employment. I support the steps already taken and I hope that such active measures will lead to permanent, long-term employment, which is an important factor in the recovery of each economy.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because, as I have long stated, the redistribution of money to help the 'victims of globalisation' ultimately amplifies precisely the problems to be addressed. If the European Union wants employees not to suffer as a result of 'globalisation', it should itself review its policies that reduce the competitiveness of EU firms, especially its absurdly strict climate targets.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds for Attica broadcasting - Greece following the redundancy of 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in the radio and television business. The redundancies in the radio and television sector in the Attica region are linked to the global financial and economic crisis, which, on the one hand, has reduced disposable household incomes and, on the other hand, drastically reduced the volume of loans to businesses and individuals due to a lack of money in Greek banks. I also voted in favour of the resolution because the workers come from the Region of Attica, where most unemployed people live compared to the rest of the Greek regions.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support, because it concerns Greek unemployed, the disagreement that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or dismissed and not to some companies that will be rewarded to train them. In Greece we have an unemployment problem and not a lack of knowledge, skills and degrees for the unemployed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted to mobilize the Fund to support these workers. The aim of this assistance is to reorient workers professionally and train workers who are victims of restructuring and redundancies within their companies. This Fund is the symbol of a Europe that can be more united. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. The broadcasting sector in the region of Attica faced 928 redundancies in 16 different enterprises. It is the first time the EGF has been mobilised in support of the programming and broadcasting sector. The region of Attica is the region with the largest number of unemployed people in Greece and it is of utmost importance to co-fund the coordinated package of personalised services for the workers. This fund will be used to develop appropriate training to reintegrate these workers into the job market, and in certain cases will support the movement of people who find another job somewhere else in Greece. Most of the funding will be used to support business start-ups. I believe it will mark a path to durable and long-term employment in the region.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on mobilizing resources for adaptation to a globalised space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 928 workers from 16 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because the European Union has legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support for workers who suffer the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns or global economic and financial crisis, and to assist their reintegration into the labour market. I hope that the workers of this Greek company may have a better future.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European globalisation adjustment funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies who are sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultra-liberal policies applied within this European Union which is unable to defend either the peoples who make up it or the companies that make it work.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes, especially relevant in peripheral regions such as Greece.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) requested by Greece in order to support 928 workers made redundant from 16 broadcasting companies. This sector has been hard hit by the global financial and economic crisis, which has forced households to drastically reduce consumption in non-essential goods and services, especially in those european regions most in difficulty, such as the Attica region, which has the highest level of unemployment in greece.  Although I am absolutely convinced that the Greek situation urgently requires a complete review of current economic policies and the renegotiation of financial agreements with european partners, I believe that the EGF is nevertheless a concrete instrument for stemming, at least in part, the very serious economic and social emergency that is the first to affect workers. Thanks to this aid, which amounts to more than EUR 5 million, Europe will help to co-finance a package of vocational guidance and training services, job-seeking allowances and contributions for the start-up of new businesses.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 928 redundancies in 16 companies operating in division 60 ('Radio and television programming and broadcasting activities')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece.  This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Due to the global financial and economic crisis that has profoundly affected the Greek economy, Greece has requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of workers in the media sector, in this case 928 workers in 16 programming and broadcasting companies. In this context, media companies have had a decline in revenues, as spending on advertising, one of their basic sources of revenue, fell dramatically by about 57%.  The redundancies covered by this EGF application are concentrated in Attica, a region with an unemployment rate of 28% and where there are few job vacancies compared to the high number of jobseekers. As a result, more than 70% of the unemployed have been out of the labour market for more than 12 months. The measures co-financed by the EGF have helped workers find new jobs by providing them with training, entrepreneurship-specific advice, contributions to business opening. All workers made redundant are eligible to participate in the measures. While reasting this support, we reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of neoliberal policies which have once again led to this outcome.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In view of the decline in household disposable income as a result of the increased tax burden, falling salaries and rising unemployment, as well as the drastic reduction in lending to companies and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks, there have been numerous redundancies of workers. These workers who have become unemployed must be supported in their reintegration into the labour market, which is why this application has also received my positive vote.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece has requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of workers in the media sector, in this case 928 workers in 16 programming and broadcasting companies. These job losses were the result of the global financial and economic crisis that deeply affected the Greek economy. During the years 2009-2012, companies operating in the media sectors closed their activities or reduced their staff. In this context, media companies have had a decline in revenues, as spending on advertising, one of their basic sources of revenue, has fallen sharply. All redundancies covered by this EGF application are concentrated in Attica, a region with an unemployment rate of 28% and where there are few job vacancies compared to the high number of jobseekers. As a result, more than 70% of the unemployed have been out of the labour market for more than 12 months. We agree that this aid is rapidly mobilising to support those who are primarily targeted by the consequences of the liberalisation of world trade, and further reaffirm our criticism of the lack of measures to halt the course of the neoliberal policies that have once again led to this outcome.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds in the event of redundancies in the Greek region of Attica Broadcasting, as the dismissal of 928 redundancies in 16 different companies was linked to the global financial and economic crisis, which has left households with a shift in essential goods and reduced purchasing power for radio and television services. I also voted in favour of the report because redundancies are having a bad impact on this region, where most of the unemployed already live in Greece, and because the report allows the EGF to co-finance job search, vocational guidance, training, education, mobility and the creation of its own businesses. By providing funds to viable business initiatives, the Fund will promote entrepreneurship, which should also lead to the creation of additional jobs.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 705 redundancies made in 46 companies operating in division 58 ('Edition')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers suffering the effects of Globalisation It is good that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers and to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market. I believe that the Union's financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible.  This application comes from Greece and concerns the publishing industry. The media sector has been particularly affected by the crisis. Many print workers were made redundant during the crisis due to declining advertising revenues. For this reason, the Greek authorities requested additional funding of 3.75 million for the retraining and reintegration of 705 redundant workers from companies in the Region of Attica.  I am therefore voting in favour of the report, which approves the application EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Broadcasting publishing activities, from Greece for the mobilisation of funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to mobilise the EGF for Greece's needs in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Attica Publishing operating in the broadcasting sector. The Greek economy is in deep recession for the sixth year in a row, since 2008. Greece's GDP fell by 25.7%, government consumption by 21%, private consumption by 32.3% and unemployment increased by 20.6%. The EGF is intended to provide a total amount of EUR 3 746 700 to 705 redundant workers. The package of services tailored to them will include guidance and counselling, skills assessment, retraining, vocational training and advice on entrepreneurship.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Although opposed to the hypocritical system of the "Globalization Adjustment Fund", I voted in favour of this report, which provides for compensation to the 705 employees of Attica's 46 Greek companies operating in the editorial sector.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I believe that the mobilization of these funds for the Greek sector of editing should be particularly noteworthy because they will help to resolve an extremely serious and complex situation with an active, intense and positive participation of the beneficiaries. The funded support measures are almost personalized, built on demand thanks to the involvement of the people who will receive it. There are all sorts of measures and especially those that will support self-priming actions, something that is much needed in the Greek economy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This request for the mobilization of the Globalization Adjustment Fund concerns the publishing sector in Greece, which is facing the dismissal of 705 people in 46 companies in the Attica region. The amount of the commitment appropriations amounts to 3,746,700 euros, consisting mainly of aid for reorientation and vocational training, or grants to independent activity (self-entrepreneur) and the creation of businesses.  The reasons for demand and the causes are the same as for the broadcasting sector, namely the decline in household disposable income and the tightening of business credit linked to the difficult situation of the Greek banking system. But this has been largely fuelled by the austerity policies demanded by Brussels. However, as this aid is essential to the survival of this sector in Greece, I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF worth EUR 3 746 700 in favour of 705 employees made redundant in Greece in the publishing sector. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an indispensable instrument for remedying the malfunctioning of the internal market, but I would also like to stress here that its activation process must be speeded up in order to support our citizens more strongly.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of this report. I therefore do so to provide workers in the cases in question with financial support for retraining and/or other measures to find new jobs. However, I would like to stress that the high level of unemployment in europe could be effectively combated if the austerity policies of the Commission and the governments of the Member States have long been pursued could be stopped. Creating new jobs in Europe requires a new economic policy with massive public and environmentally friendly investments. Public investment is needed in schools, health and social care, but also in infrastructure, rail, public transport, energy-efficient housing and sustainable energy systems.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 3 746 700 from the Globalization Adjustment Fund for 705 workers who have lost their jobs in 46 companies operating in the edition sector in Greece's Attica region as a result of the economic and financial crisis that plagues the Hellenic country , which has reduced household disposable income causing a huge drop in purchasing power and the need to set spending priorities, reducing the availability of products not considered to be of first need for everyday life, such as magazines and newspapers, as well as drastically reducing lending to businesses and individuals. The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants for the promotion of entrepreneurship.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the unemployment drama in the Attica region, which already hosts the largest number of unemployed among the twelve Greek regions, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the granting of financial support from the European Globalisation Fund to 705 staff, For greek redundancies, Attika Publishing was two of the main events that led to the reduction in household disposable income during the reporting period from 12 June to 12 September 2014. severely limiting, regardless of its importance, the cost of daily information. At the same time, the lack of cash in Greek banks has led to a drastic reduction in the issuance of loans to businesses and individuals. The harmonised package of personalised services to be co-financed consists of vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training services, an autonomous subsidy, a job search allowance and a training allowance and a mobility allowance.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 In using the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it is important to improve workers' chances of employment through personalised training and recognition of their previous professional experience. Further training can be expected to be tailored not only to the needs of the redundant workers, to their individual ideas, but also to the actual business environment.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted IN FAVOUR of the proposed report or decision to allocate funds from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) of more than €3,746,700 to 46 companies from the Greek region of Attica, who are active in the publishing sector and have been forced to lay off as a result of the worsening economic situation. The EGF will thus provide assistance to 705 workers who lost their jobs in 2014. The redundancy will thus be allocated €1.2 million in the form of self-employment grants, €1.104 million for vocational guidance and training. €828,000 will be allocated to training allowances and the rest will be allocated to job search and mobility allowances. Up to 80 workers will be able to receive up to €15,000 in aid of setting up their own businesses, and 80 workers will be eligible for mobility benefits, which will help them move to the place where they will be offered a new job, the Atica region is at its worst position among the 12 Greek regions, with the number of unemployed people in Greece already living in it. This kind of assistance from the EU budget is therefore much needed. I hope that Slovenia will also start to make more intensive use of EGF funding, thus enabling them to regain employment for individuals who have lost their jobs in the past.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Since the Greek application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I support the financial assistance of 705 redundancy workers in 46 Greek companies.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. The report by Lefteris Christoforou, presented in the Committee on Budgets, favours the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 3,746,700. The publishing sector in Greece is facing serious difficulties. Forty-six companies made 705 redundancies. The Committee on Budgets welcomes the fact that "the Greek authorities, anxious to provide rapid assistance to workers, decided to launch the implementation of personalised services for the workers concerned on 28 November 2014, without waiting for the decision to grant EGF support for the proposed coordinated package". For example, "measures for career guidance, training and vocational training, self-employment assistance and job search, training and mobility allowances" are planned. These are carried out "in consultation with the representatives of the intended beneficiaries". I voted for the intervention of the fund.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: per iscritto. ‒ I voted yes because the mobilisation of the EGF is fundamental to support the redundant workers in Greece.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Attica region of Greece is a productive area in terms of media activities but the crisis, as in other areas, has managed to set in. So it is that, as in the case of Attica Broadcasting, redundancies took place. The economic problems in this sector were caused by the decrease in incomes, which led to a decrease in the number of people who wanted to buy newspapers and magazines, these being the materials produced by companies affected by economic problems in the Attica region. Thus, the lack of demand led to the dismissal of 705 people. I voted in favour of this report because the granting of EUR 3 746 700 would provide substantial support to workers in the Attila region, a region compromised by the crisis. People could more easily reintegrate into the labour market through training courses and thus the area could be relaunched economically through those working there.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. I support employment and workers who are victims of globalisation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (the EGF, set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade) which refers to greece's application in relation to redundancies in 46 publishing companies in the Attica region. These redundancies in the publishing sector of the Attica region are linked to the global economic and financial crisis which, in addition to eroding the income available to households, has drastically reduced lending to companies due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks. The link between redundancies and major changes in the world economic structure due to globalisation is therefore clear. I therefore voted in favour of this measure. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from the EGF because of the lack of support from local and national institutions that submitted only 14 requests in total between 2007 and 2014.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report is concerned with the re-integration into the labour market of an estimated 705 workers of 46 enterprises operating in the publishing sector in the Greek region of Attica. This is a particularly important issue for me as only recently in my own constituency and my home town of Carrickmacross, 140 workers were made redundant from our local BOSE factory. This has had a devastating effect on the workers, their families and the wider community. We do not yet know if an application for funding from the European Globalisation Fund will be made in this instance, but adequate support for workers in retraining and up—skilling must be provided in any case. The Fund plays a vital role in ameliorating what is a very distressing situation for workers who have found their whole livelihoods placed into disarray. In what is often a very harrowing situation, it is important to focus on the positive and constructive options which are available. However, I would like to add a general qualification that no government should use this fund as justification for making workers redundant.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 At the root of the current mobilisation of the EGF are 705 redundancies in 46 publishing companies in the Attica region of Greece, which – in a particularly difficult general state situation – already has the highest number of unemployed than in the other regions. The crisis, felt very strong in the country, has deeply eroded household income, leading to a sharp decline in purchasing power, accompanied by a major brake on banks to lend to citizens and businesses. It is easy to understand how a sector such as publishing, which is also central to all democratic societies, is heavily penalised by such a context.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for compensation to 705 employees of 46 Greek Attica companies operating in the editorial sector. While unemployment in Greece has increased by 20.6% since 2008, the WEF must be able to help a state in which, as the report states, the global economic and financial crisis has led to a decline in household disposable income, resulting in a sharp fall in purchasing power and the need to prioritize spending. Logically, the publishing sector suffers because the Greeks, hit by the austerity imposed by the troika, no longer consume or much less cultural and literary products. Fighting the austerity imposed by the IMF and the European Union, I am therefore in favour of this endowment of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece's difficult economic conditions are very evident. The recession for the sixth year in a row has eroded the income of a large part of the population, with the consequent and inevitable reduction in purchasing power.  The economic constraints in which Greek households find themselves have helped to give priority to those goods deemed necessary, thus reducing the consumption of other products, such as those related to the publishing sector.  The crisis at Attica Publishing stems from this situation and unfortunately involved 705 people and 46 companies. I voted in favour of Greece's request to the European Commission, which was also welcomed by the Council's Budget Committee, to mobilise a sum of EUR 3 746 700 from the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2015, with the hope that there will soon be an economic recovery at European level.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure we have examined refers, compared to the 2015 budget framework, to the mobilisation of the EGF for a total amount of EUR 3 746 700 for Greece. It covers 705 redundancies. The request is based on the relocation of at least 500 workers over nine months to companies operating in the same economic sector defined at the level of the NACE Rev. 2 divisions. It should be said that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. According to data cited by the Greek authorities, the state economy is going through a severe recession. Moreover, the severe recession has been going on for several years now and public consumption has fallen by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 23.3 points, while unemployment has risen by 20.6 points. Two main factors would appear to be the causes of the redundancies: the fall in family income due to the sharp rise in unemployment and the significant reduction in credit to individuals and businesses. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF in favour of Greece because I believe it may represent an adjustment of the structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. I believe that the 705 redundancies in 46 publishing companies in the Attica region are an indirect consequence of these changes, since the global economic and financial crisis, which is particularly affecting Greece, has eroded the income available to households, leading to a sharp decline in purchasing power and the need to put expenditure in order of priority , cutting what is considered not essential to daily life, such as magazines and newspapers. I am particularly pleased with the fact that all eligible redundant workers have been offered a vocational guidance service which includes various stages and which will provide each individual with personalised advice and a plan for reintegration into the world of work.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established in 2006 to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major changes in the structure of international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market. From 1 May 2009, the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been extended to include support for workers made redundant as a direct result of the economic, financial and social crisis. At a time when Europe is in the face of a financial, economic and social crisis, with unemployment being one of the main consequences, the European Union should use all means at its service to react, in particular, to the support to be provided to people who have been left without a job. I therefore supported this report on the mobilisation of EUR 3,746,700 in favour of Greece with the aim of supporting the 705 workers made redundant in 46 companies operating in the area of the edition.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the application for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Publishing activities for the following reasons. The EGF is the instrument promoted by the European Union to provide support for redundant workers as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation. A necessary condition for the protection of the Fund to be applied is that these redundancies have a significant negative impact on the regional or local economy.  In the present case, there are 705 workers made redundant as a result of the economic crisis, from 46 different companies operating in the same sector in the Attica region, which currently has the highest unemployment rate in greece.   It should also be pointed out that the services provided by the Greek authorities to these workers, despite the fact that they have been the result of an enormous effort, have not been able to solve the problem definitively because it is very complex.  All the requirements for access to the EGF seem to have been met, which, in the present case, result in job losses due to the economic crisis (of countless workers) and considerable economic damage to the regional economy.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The report states that 705 workers from 46 enterprises working in the publishing sector have been made redundant due to the global financial and economic crisis. Redundant workers will participate in the co-founded personalised services which will include support for start-ups, occupational guidance, training measures, including vocational training and training allowances, as well as a job search and mobility allowance. I have thus voted in favour of this report, which seeks to redress the situation by increasing the employability of workers to reintegrate them into the workforce.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of mobilising the EGF Fund in order to safeguard the 705 redundant workers of the 46 companies engaged in the publishing sector. At present, it is only through the granting of this aid that it is possible to protect employment in an area of the Greek country hard hit by the crisis.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 705 redundancies made in 46 companies operating in division 58 ('Edition')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This application concerns 705 redundancies from Greek company Attica Publishing in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014. The events giving rise to the redundancies, according to the Greek authorities, were mainly two: (1) the decrease of available household income ― due to the increase in the tax burden, decreasing salaries and rising unemployment ― resulting in the need to prioritise spending while limiting significantly the cost of everyday information; and (2) the drastic reduction of loans to enterprises and individuals due to the lack of cash in the Greek banks. As this action will provide a second chance to workers who have been unfairly affected by changes beyond their control, I voted in favour of the application.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 705 employees in 46 companies in the publishing sector, Greece has asked the European Union to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to support people who have lost their jobs and to help them find a job or start their own businesses. The aid granted is 3,746,700 euros and covers 60% of the cost of the projects that will be offered to these employees. Given that Greece's request meets the EGF's mobilization criteria, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to help Greece, which is facing significant redundancies in the publishing sector. The publishing sector, which does not represent basic goods for consumers, has suffered particularly from the Greek recession. This translates into a 60% drop in publishing sales for the period 2009-2013 and a significant number of layoffs. The granting of this fund will promote the reintegration into the labour market of 705 workers, with the aim of supporting a revival of growth in this country.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece, in order to support the reintegration into the market of 705 workers made redundant due to the global economic and financial crisis. According to the Greek authorities, there are two main events that caused the redundancies: the erosion of the income available to households, which has led to a sharp decline in purchasing power and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led to the redundancies mainly: 1. an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment reduced household disposable income, resulting in a sharp decline in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and abandonment of products that they do not consider essential in everyday life; 2. The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals. Sales by businesses in the sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) fell by 60% in the period 2009-2013 due to weakened demand for their products. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because, although I disagree with the way the funds are managed, this report concerns Greece.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The current Hungarian Government has so far hardly initiated the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In particular, it has tried and sought to resolve the loss of certain jobs and its negative effects. As a result of the government's successful economic policies, there is currently an increase in jobs in Hungary, not a decrease. Despite our objections, the European Union is treating the European tobacco sector quite harshly. Tobacco grown in Europe for centuries provides a livelihood for 80,000 farmers and employs 350,000 seasonal workers a year, most of them in the poor regions of Bulgaria, Spain, Greece, Italy, Poland, Hungary and Romania. It is known that European production differs from that of large exporting countries in the developing world in that, although in smaller quantities, it is of higher quality, more stable and more traceable. The latter properties contribute to alleviating the public health consequences of smoking. Despite the Opinion of the European Parliament during the reform of the CAP, the Commission has achieved a complete end to EU support for tobacco production from 2015. European tobacco production under controlled conditions will be significantly reduced, thus significantly increased imports of less controlled tobacco products produced outside the EU and illegal imports. Due to these measures and effects, there is a significant risk that many jobs will be lost in the tobacco sector. In response to my written question on this subject, the Commission only sees the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as feasible.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. I voted in favour of this report because it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to local economies hard hit by company closures. I regret that the government has not taken advantage of this fund in Wales.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument that supports workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns and aims to assist redundant workers. In the case of Attica publishing activities, and considering that the application meets the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, the aid package which I voted for is composed of vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training and subsidies for self-employment, job search and mobility, with a view to improving the employability of all workers. This support should be complementary to the company's responsibility under national law and not to be overtaken by other types of financial support by the Union. According to data transmitted by the Greek authorities, the Greek economy is in a deep recession for the sixth consecutive year (2008-2013). According to ELSTAT, the Greek statistical authority, since 2008, Greek GDP has decreased by 25.7 percentage points, public consumption by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment has increased by 20.6 percentage points. This support relates to 705 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EGF was created to provide additional support to redundant workers following major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation or the financial crisis and to help them find new jobs. Redundant workers are offered measures such as support for business creation, job search assistance, vocational guidance and various types of training. In most cases, national authorities have already begun to take steps to get their costs reimbursed by the EU when their applications are approved. The Greek authorities have submitted an application for redundancies in 46 companies operating in editing activities in the Attica region, which provides for a financial contribution of EUR 3 746 700. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted positively, because it is above all, even if the absolute free-trade policy of the European Union is at the root of the difficulties of European companies, to support a company in difficulty, its managers and its employees.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this request to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide additional support to Greek workers at Attica Publishing who have been affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis has also affected the labour market in Greece to a significant extent. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide the necessary and necessary support for workers affected by major structural changes in the world trade sector. On 3 February 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal to mobilise the Fund in favour of Greece. EUR 3 746 700 from the Resources of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to be used for the reintegration of 705 staff. The Greek economy is in deep recession for the sixth year in a row. The funds in question from the Fund are intended to re-engage unemployed workers in the form of job counselling, profiling and vocational training.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of granting the fund EUR 3 746 700 for 705 redundancies in 46 publishing companies in the Attica region, which is the region with the highest unemployment rate in Greece.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although I disagree with the way EGF funds are managed, and some companies are treasured by retraining young people with little money going for the benefit of the unemployed, I am voting in favour of the EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Publishing activities application because it concerns Greeks.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led to the redundancies mainly: (1) an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and abandonment of products which they do not consider essential in everyday life; (2) The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals.  Sales by businesses in the sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) fell by 60% in the period 2009-2013 due to weakened demand for their products. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because its approval will mobilize the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund of EUR 3 746 700 for the 80 redundancies made in forty-six companies operating in the edition sector in Attica, Greece. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to laid-off workers as a result of major structural changes in global trade patterns caused by globalisation or the financial crisis and to help them find new jobs.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a duty on the part of the European Union at times like these to stand by Greek families and do everything possible to help as many people in need. For these reasons, I voted in favour of Greece's request to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, budgetary cooperation and sound financial management.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I voted with conviction for Mr Christoforou's report mobilising concrete aid for workers at Attica Publishing Activities, in response to the request made by the Greek Government.  Greece has been hit far too hard by the employment and economic crisis of the last five years; the hope is that these measures, in addition to being an instrument of reintegration into employment as provided for in the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, can finally be seen as a gesture of openness and sensitivity on the part of Europe.  The redundancies of Attica Publishing workers will have a further negative impact on a region which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece. I therefore hope that the release of funding will be able to put an immediate palliative and introduce measures that restore confidence and skills for the workers concerned.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on resource mobilization for adaptation to a globalized space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 705 workers from 46 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to offer assistance in Greece following 928 redundancies across 16 enterprises. The funding shall contribute to the costs of measures for the reintegration of 120 redundant workers into employment. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-funded covers three main areas: redeployment, training and promotion of entrepreneurship (including support for enterprise creation and collective projects). The UK has never made an application under this Fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, because the purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. In this case of the publishing sector in the Attica region, 705 people have lost their jobs. These redundancies are expected to have huge negative impacts on the Attica region, which already has the largest number of all the unemployed people in Greece as compared to the other 12 regions. Therefore, the publishing activities sector has been the subject of an application for financial support under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 On 3 February 2015, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis. According to the Greek authorities, the following events led to the redundancies mainly: (1) an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries (which affected both private and public sector employees) and an increase in unemployment, resulting in a sharp reduction in purchasing power and consumers' choice of expenditure and abandonment of products which they do not consider essential in everyday life; (2) The liquidity problems of Greek banks have dramatically reduced the sources of credit available to businesses and individuals.  Sales by businesses in the sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) fell by 60% in the period 2009-2013 due to weakened demand for their products. The coordinated package of personalised services to be co-financed includes career guidance, training, vocational training, self-employment support, job search support, training and mobility support. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on resource mobilization for adaptation to a globalized space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 705 workers from 46 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in global trade patterns. In assessing the application submitted, I consider that it should be granted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a Decision of parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of 'Attica Publishing' as the EGF's financial contribution directly assists the economic situation of greece's Attica region, which is affected by the adverse impact of the 705 redundance workers.  The global financial and economic crisis has had a negative impact on the publishing sector and has further jeopardised the already difficult economic situation and unemployment rate of the region. In this context, I support the guidance provided to redundancy workers and tailored training and recognition programmes. It is important to create a stable and positive atmosphere that would be an incentive for job creation and for the growth of the economy, as pursued by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. I also believe that action is needed as quickly and efficiently as possible.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on the european Globalisation Adjustment Fund's request for the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund introduced by Greece for redundancies in 46 publishing companies. The Fund was created to promote the reintegration into the labour market of workers who are victims of changes in the structure of international trade resulting from globalization, or the financial crisis. I also welcome the adoption of this aid, amounting to EUR 3,746,700.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that additional support should be given to workers suffering the consequences of major structural changes in the shape of world trade and supported for their reintegration into the labour market if they have been made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, as is the case with Attica Publishing activities .

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The application was submitted to the European Commission on 4 September 2014. Greece made this request for assistance from the EGF after 928 staff were made redundant during the period 12.9.2013-12.6.2014. Support is provided in the form of career guidance and career planning assistance, support for business start-ups and start-up sanitising, training, training and higher education programmes, training grants and income support. I support this assistance for the redundant workers in Greece and I am therefore voting in favour of this motion.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support the application for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund made for Attica Publishing activities. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns. Attica Publishing activities were a major employer in the Attica region of Greece, and the 705 redundancies which have resulted from its closure have had a significant adverse impact on the local economy, which was already struggling with large-scale unemployment. I therefore voted in favour of this report as it is a means by which the EU can give valuable help to the local economy and support the workers affected by helping them re-enter the labour market.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the Fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers into the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: In writing. As I had already had the opportunity to do so in the Parliamentary Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of the Christoforou report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) with regard to 705 former employees of the Greek company Attica Edition. The adoption of this report demonstrates the European Union's ability to respond effectively to the challenges and challenges posed by globalisation. In fact, 705 sacked employees operating in the publishing sector will benefit from an egR of 3,746,700 euros to finance projects such as training or guidance. The plan, worth a total of 6,244,500 euros, will also enable these former publishing workers to adapt their skills and know-how to new market needs so that they can quickly find a job.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Christoforou report, which foresees the mobilization of more than 3.7 million euros under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), in favour of sacked employees of the Greek company Attica Edition. Between 2009 and 2013, the Greek press lost nearly 60% of its subscribers due to the global economic and financial crisis. Thanks to the EGF and a plan totalling EUR 6,244,500, more than 700 employees will benefit from reintegration measures such as job search assistance, career guidance and various types of training.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'Globalisation is inevitable and goes hand in hand with the opening of new markets, with international competition, with economic growth and with job creation. The flip side of this is job losses in less competitive sectors. The N-VA delegation in the European Parliament understands the objectives of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), but also pays attention to the taxpayer who pays the bill. Moreover, social policy should be primarily a competence of the Member States. A European transfer union is not a panacea to tackle unemployment.
