In particular, structural reforms are needed to re-establish economic growth. The MEPs of the N-VA have therefore abstained on this dossier.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Greek authorities submitted the request for financial contribution from the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) with reference EGF/2014/018 GR/Attica Broadcasting, following 928 redundancies in 16 companies in the programming and broadcasting sector. In addition, I would like to point out that this is the first request for aid to the EGF from this sector. On the other hand, most of the funds requested are earmarked to support the creation of enterprises in the form of self-employment grants and training measures, including vocational training and training grants. I voted in favour of this proposal, as I believe that measures to support vocational guidance, training and self-employment should take into account the emerging opportunities that new media on the web can offer these workers. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created to help former employees find a new job, education or self-employment, who have lost their jobs as a result of globalisation and the financial and economic crisis. Greek authorities have applied for a 3.7m-euro mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help former employees of 46 companies in the Attica publishing sector. Greece's deep crisis, which has been going on for 6 years, is the reason for the layoffs of large numbers of workers and the closure of thousands of businesses from all sectors. The publishing sector saw a 60 per cent drop in sales between 2009 and 2013, as the reduction in wages resulting in reduced personal consumption only makes citizens spend on basic needs. The package planned to be co-financed by the EGF is intended to target assistance for 705 redundant workers who meet the conditions. Among them are as many as 576 people in the 30-54 age group.  I support this demand to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, as the number of unemployed in Greece increased fourfold and grew continuously during the crisis, with the Attica region contributing 43% to Greece's GDP and having a major impact on the entire Greek economy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The aid in the form of a financial contribution is aimed at providing support to 705 employees made redundant from their work in the field of loading activities. It is important that the beneficiary, when using EFG assistance, use the funds provided as a matter of priority to support permanent jobs that will help Greece on the way out of the economic recession. It is also important that the auditing and control bodies check on an ongoing basis the fulfilment of the conditions for the aid granted and its actual use.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; in accordance with point 13 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 2 December 2013 between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission on budgetary discipline, cooperation in budgetary matters and sound financial management, since the Greek authorities decided to launch the implementation of personalised services to affected workers on 28 November 2014 , long before the decision on EGF support for the proposed coordinated package.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ By way of an explanation of my vote, I considered this an appropriate cause for mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it necessary to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as a support for the reintegration into the labour market of 705 workers made redundant in 46 companies operating in the "publishing activities" sector. The aid granted today is a good active one aimed at reintegrating workers. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report on the request for the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Greece.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The consequences of changes in world trade have negatively impacted the Greek economy, which has already been the victim of a significant fall in domestic demand for some years. It is necessary for the European Union to intervene in support of the country and its inhabitants, so that the burden of economic depression can finally diminish.   That is why I thought it appropriate to express my agreement with the Christoforou report, which supports the mobilisation of the EGF, to the benefit of 705 workers made redundant at Attica Publishing.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for mobilizing the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support 705 other laid-off workers in Greece, as the companies in which they worked, mainly related to publications, saw their sales reduced by 60% in 2009-2013, due to falling demand for their products. Through the EUR 3 746 700 provided by the EU in this case, we want to help these workers find new employment opportunities to overcome the difficult economic situation in their families and in the country in general.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I also voted in favour of this motion, as workers made redundant as a result of the far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns or in the global financial and economic crisis must be supported in their reintegration into the labour market. The decline in demand for products in this sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) in the period 2009-2013 led to a 60% decline in sales. We need to consider measures to strengthen this sector again.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting support to the Attica region of Greece, which has the highest unemployment rate in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. The ongoing global financial and economic crisis, with the sacking of 46 companies from the publishing sector, has raised a number of social problems that need to be addressed without delay. Support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will therefore be used to promote business start-ups, vocational reorientation, training measures, unemployment benefits and mobility benefits.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Greece has been hit hard by the austerity of previous governments, loyal companions of the infamous troika and its "structural reforms". Household consumption fell by more than 32 percentage points, while unemployment increased by 20.6 percentage points. The Greek people had to survive above all, and the annual subscriptions and the purchase of the daily press were severely affected. Newspapers experienced a 60% reduction in sales, putting some 40 companies in the Attica region at risk. This globalization fund helps some 700 licensees in these companies. I denounce these funds for aid to globalization, a real tool to encourage shareholders and states to adhere to the social irresponsibility of capitalism. I abstain on this particular case in order to support the possibilities of rehiring these employees and relaunching a quality press thanks to Syriza's regional and national policy.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. There is an increasing number of companies relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices, which are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights. The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment.  The EGF has been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now appropriate to give this aid to Greece which submitted the EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica publishing activities application to a financial contribution from the EGF, following 705 redundancies in 46 companies operating in division 58 (editing activities) of NACE Rev. 2 in the Attica region of level 2 NUTS (EL 30) in Greece.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the key tools in the EU’s arsenal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions to mobilise EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 705 workers in the publishing sector in Greece due to the global financial and economic crisis.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the publishing sector in Greece (Attica region), 705 workers from 46 different publishing companies were made redundant. Support will be provided in the form of job search and vocational guidance allowances, training allowances and job search and mobility allowances.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  The redundancies in Greece occurred due to a reduction in household disposable income and increased unemployment, which resulted in a huge drop in purchasing power and the need to set spending priorities, significantly limiting the amounts devoted to daily information, as happened with Attica Publishing Activities. It should be noted that companies in this sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) recorded a 60% reduction in sales in the period 2009-2013. To that end, I am in favour of mobilising a total amount of EUR 3 746 700 from the EGF in favour of Greece, which concerns 705 redundancies in the reference period from 12 September 2013 to 12 June 2014.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This request relates to the publishing sector in Greece, which is facing the dismissal of 705 people in 46 companies in the Attica region.  The amount of the commitment appropriations amounts to 3,746,700 euros, consisting mainly of aid for reorientation and vocational training, or grants to independent activity (self-entrepreneur) and the creation of businesses. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide assistance to workers suffering the consequences of the crisis in a given sector, or the changes in the economic structures of Member States caused by globalisation and free trade.  Although this Fund is a step in the right direction to deal with the problems created by the austerity policy and the opening up to the four winds of globalization, it seems essential to provide financial assistance to these sectors currently threatened by the crisis. I have therefore spoken in favour of this aid.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim is to activate the Fund to the tune of 3.7 million euros to support the reclassification of 705 employees laid off by 46 Attica companies. In Greece, GDP has fallen by almost 25% since the beginning of the crisis, while at the same time the unemployment rate has increased by 20 points. The Mobilization of the Fund is once again a testament to the European Union's solidarity with the Greek citizens hardest hit by the economic crisis.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the call for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece, in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers from Attica Publishing, who have been made redundant as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade.  According to the data cited by the Greek authorities, the redundancies were directly caused by the erosion of the income available to households – due to the increase in the tax burden, the fall in wages (of both public and private employees) and rising unemployment – which led to a sharp decline in purchasing power and the need to put expenditure in order of priority , cutting what is considered not essential to daily life. Due to the fall in demand, companies in the sector in question (newspapers, magazines, etc.) experienced a 60% decrease in sales for the period 2009-2013.  The coordinated package of personalised services to be cofinanced will be directed mainly towards vocational guidance, training, grants for self-employment, employment and mobility grants. We are therefore sure that these European incentives will be a valuable aid for the reintegration of these workers.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the economic and financial crisis and market imbalances attributable to the advancement of globalisation. On 3 February 2015, the European Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Greece. This application, the eighth in the 2015 budget, calls for the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 3 746 700 in favour of 705 redundancies at 46 companies operating in the publishing activities between 12 September 2013 and 12 June 2014.  In the light of the above, I voted in favour of the Christoforou report because I believe that workers should benefit from the broadest support from the European Union. This appropriation, which will finance actions aimed at enhancing the professional skills of these workers, will help to offer them new employment opportunities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund: the request of EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Publishing activities as the special rapporteur of the S&D Group for the EGF. The application is well documented and complies with the requirements of the European Commission in this area.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Greek authorities submitted the application EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Publishing activities on 4 September 2014. The application concerns 705 workers made redundant at 46 companies. These companies were active in the NACE-Rev. Division 58 (publishing) in the NUTS 2 region of Attica (EL30). The reasons for this were the consequences of the economic crisis. In order to give prospects to those who are made redundant, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up, which has EUR 500 million available annually. I am voting in favour of this report because support is very important and it is an important signal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution to allocate EUR 3 746 700 from the EGF to Greece, which will allow 705 people who have become unemployed as a result of redundancy. Unemployment in the European Union increased dramatically as a result of the economic crisis. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF, we can re-engage these people in the labour market.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 Mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is necessary and necessary to prevent some of the extremely negative consequences that may result from such a large scale of redundancies in 46 different companies in the publishing sector.  In view of this, I support the proposal to provide financial support to Greece for active labour market measures, since the redundancies of 705 workers from companies in the publishing sector in the Attica region are directly linked to the global financial and economic crisis. It is essential that all eligible redundant workers are given the right access to measures supported by the EGF adapted to individual needs. Only sufficient and effective support will help these workers to return to the labour market. In order to mitigate the negative consequences and improve the negative situation, redundant workers must be provided with measures to promote employment and provide vocational guidance and retraining opportunities that will lead to a return to the labour market as early as possible.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the global economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market; that Union financial support for redundant workers should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible, in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, adopted at the conciliation meeting on 17 July 2008, and in compliance with the IAEA of 2 December 2013 with regard to the adoption of decisions mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF); For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Due to economic and financial problems in the Attica region related to the global and economic crisis, I support this requirement concerning the care of 705 workers who are technologically redundant in 46 companies.  The EGF should be mobilised with EUR 3 746 700 representing 60 % of the total cost of the proposed measures in order to ensure a financial contribution for their application. Furthermore, I note that these redundancies will have an extremely unfavourable impact on the Attica region, which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. I welcome the fact that all laid-off eligible workers have been offered career guidance in several stages, which will provide them with individual, personalised counselling and help draw up plans for their re-employment.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Since the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-in-the-world trade flows, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 546/2009(3) or the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the approval of EUR 3 746 700 in commitment appropriations and payment appropriations in order to partially finance redundancy losses in 46 companies operating under Section 58 of the NACE Rev classification. 2 (publishing activities). Member States need to show solidarity towards each other when necessary, and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. At the same time, Union financial assistance to redundanst workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible. Greece has applied for a financial contribution from the EGF for the redundancies of 705 workers in 46 companies operating in the publishing sector in the Attica region of Greece. According to the Greek authorities, the main causes of the redundancies are the reduction of household disposable income due to the increase in tax burden, lower wages and rising unemployment, which has led to a large drop in purchasing power and the need to prioritise consumption and eject products that are not essential for everyday life, and a drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals due to a lack of cash in Greek banks. The layoffs are also thought to have an extremely unfavourable impact on the Attica region, which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. Therefore, I support rapporteur Lefteris Christoforou's report on the mobilisation of EUR 3,746,700, which represents 60% of the total cost, as the aim is to assist redundant workers in training and retraining for new jobs.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece submitted an application to obtain a financial contribution from the EGF, following 705 redundancies in 46 companies operating in nace rev. 2 division 58 (Editing activities) in the Attica region, during the period between 12 September 2013 and 12 June 2014. According to the Commission, this application complies with the eligibility criteria laid down in the EGF Regulation, and it is clear, on the one hand, that redundancies in the editing sector in the Attica region are linked to the global economic and financial crisis which has reduced household disposable income, resulting in a huge fall in purchasing power and the need to set priorities in terms of expenditure , with the daily abandonment of magazines and newspapers, as well as drastically reduced loans to businesses and individuals due to the lack of liquidity of Greek banks, and, on the other hand, that redundancies will have very negative repercussions for the Attica region, which already has the largest number of unemployed in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 3 746 700 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 705 workers who have lost their jobs in 46 companies operating in the edition sector in Greece's Attica region as a result of the economic and financial crisis that plagues the Hellenic country , which has reduced household disposable income, causing a huge drop in purchasing power and the need to set spending priorities, reducing the availability of products not considered to be of first need for everyday life, such as magazines and newspapers, as well as drastically reducing lending to businesses and individuals. The personalized services to be financed from the FEAG include vocational guidance, training, recycling and job search activities, as well as grants for the promotion of entrepreneurship.  While these aids alone are unable to alleviate the drama of unemployment in the Attica region, which already hosts the largest number of unemployed among the twelve Greek regions, they do constitute good assistance and training for the reintegration of workers affected.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Attica Publishing, a Greek publishing company, has laid off 705 workers. The socio-economic situation in Greece has been complicated since the economic and financial crisis. In 2012, 23% of Greeks were living below the poverty line, and in 2014, three out of four workers or employees reported that their income level had decreased from the previous year due to wage cuts. As a result, many people have reduced their spending on non-basic products such as magazines and newspapers. I did not hesitate for a second to vote in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This decision will help Greece and these 705 workers with a contribution of 3,746,700 euros.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 As in the previous proposal, Greece has submitted another application to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to mitigate the effects of the dismissal of 705 workers in 46 companies operating in the audiovisual sector, in the editing component, also in the Attica region. Since the criteria for allocating this fund are met and because it is a similar situation to greece's previous application for the audiovisual industry, I also voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, the European Parliament has approved the request from Greece that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help 705 people made redundant in 46 companies. With this, the European Parliament is continuing its action on behalf of its fellow citizens.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because it calls for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the sum of around THREE million and seven hundred thousand euros to cope with 705 redundancies in 46 companies carrying out editorial activities in Greece.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Written. \u2012 Greece's application for unemployment effects resulting from the shutdown of 16 companies engaged in programme activities and mass media in the Attica region complies with the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The application concerns 928 unemployed persons. The report shows that labour reductions have a very significant impact in the Attica region, which is already the worst unemployment area in Greece. The authorities took active steps to help and mobilise the unemployed well in advance of the EU Commission's decision to recommend the granting of a grant from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The report also shows that all those who have become unemployed have become or are about to be subject to activation measures. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 705 redundancies made in 46 companies operating in division 58 ('Edition')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of mobilising the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) on Greece's application for financial assistance following redundancies in 46 companies operating in Division 58 ("Publishing Activities"). As a result of the economic crisis, the communications sector has been hit hard, and in this case there are 705 workers made redundant. That is why I think it is important to give my support.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece. A total amount of EUR 3 746 700 from the EGF will be used to support the reintegration into the labour market of 705 workers made redundant from Attica Publishing activities. The UK has never made an application under this Fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I supported the Greek Government's request to make a contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. In the Attica region, the reduction in the availability of household incomes resulted in an increase in the tax burden, a reduction in salaries and an increase in unemployment, resulting in a sharp fall in purchasing power, the winding-up of businesses in the newspaper and magazine publishing sector. The contribution of EUR 3 746 700 granted relates to 705 workers who are granted a start-up allowance, a labour mobility allowance, professional advice, vocational training and training. The proposed measures will only be granted to workers and will not be used to restructure companies or sectors.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  The application for a financial contribution submitted by Greece to help the Atika region, where 705 redundancies in 46 companies have been made redundant, fulfils the eligibility criteria. The layoffs in the publishing sector in the Attica region are the result of a global financial and economic crisis that has reduced household disposable incomes, which has reduced purchasing power and has shifted household spending to emergency products where newspapers and magazines do not belong. In addition, the lack of money in Greek banks has led to a reduction in the volume of loans to businesses and individuals.  The redundancies have serious consequences for the Region of Attica, where the number of unemployed was already at its highest in Greece before the layoffs in the sector. As the co-financed services package covers the following important areas: vocational guidance and training, self-employment assistance and job search, training and mobility allowances, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in order to support 705 employees of Attica Publishing, a group of publishing companies in the Attica region of Greece.  The redundancies are due to the global financial and economic crisis, which, by reducing the disposable income of Greek households and their purchasing power, has led to the need to reduce expenditure on non-essential services, such as daily information through subscriptions to magazines and newspapers. In view of the fall in demand for their products, the companies in the sector in question (such as newspapers and magazines) suffered a 60% decrease in sales in the period 2009-2013.The redundancies of Attica Publishing will have a negative impact on the Attica region, which already has the highest number of unemployed in Greece compared to the other 12 regions. The aid of EUR 3 746 700 provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to co-finance a package of personalised services aimed in particular at supporting the creation of new businesses through job-seeking allowances, but also includes vocational guidance, training measures, including vocational training, as well as job search allowances and mobility.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Greece has applied to EGF/2014/015 GR/Attica Publishing activities for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 705 workers in 46 companies operating under Section 58 of the NACE Rev. 2 (Publishing activities) in the NUTS 2 Attica region (EL 30) in Greece. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I welcome the fact that all laid-off eligible workers are expected to participate in measures for which support comes from the EGF and, in accordance with the provision, Greece is entitled to a financial contribution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I welcome the fact that the Greek authorities have decided to start providing services that will be adapted to workers before the EGF funds are approved. Redundancies as a result of the pervasive crisis have also caused spending cuts as well as redundancies in the publishing sectors, as non-essential expenditure is first eliminated. I welcome the fact that laid-off workers at Attica will participate in EGF grants. It is important to introduce tailor-made training programmes with recognition of the capabilities and skills adopted by the worker during his career. I welcome the fact that workers will be offered personalised advice on future employment. I would like to stress that those measures that encourage long-term employment should be co-financed. For all of the above reasons, I support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal as I do not consider it beneficial. The logic presented in the text of the proposal is also interesting. The redundancies in the publishing sector are said to be linked to the financial and economic crisis, mainly due to lower household disposable incomes and the subsequent change in priorities in the expenditure of these households. However, with similar consideration, the European Union could justify compensating for virtually any redundancies. However, as in other cases, this is only about subsidising at the expense of others, which only leads to a deepening of the problems mentioned.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds for Attica publishing activities - Greece after the redundancies of 705 redundancies in 46 publishing companies. The application fulfils the eligibility criteria and Greece is therefore eligible for a financial contribution. I also voted in favour of the resolution because all eligible redundant workers have been offered a multi-tiered career guidance, providing them with individual and tailored advice and plans for reintegration into the labour market.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support, because it concerns Greek unemployed, the disagreement that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or dismissed and not to some companies that will be rewarded to train them. In Greece we have an unemployment problem and not a lack of knowledge, skills and degrees for the unemployed.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted to mobilize the Fund to support these workers. The aim of this assistance is to reorient workers professionally and to train workers who are victims of restructuring and redundancies in their companies. This Fund represents the symbol of a Europe that can be more united. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. The publishing sector in the region of Attica suffered from the economic crisis and the decrease in the available household income, and 46 enterprises faced a total of 705 redundancies. It is the second time the EGF has supported the publishing sector. The region of Attica is the region with the largest number of unemployed people in Greece and it is of utmost importance to co-fund the coordinated package of personalised services for the workers. This funding will be used to develop appropriate training to reintegrate these workers into the job market, and in certain cases will support the movement of people who find another job somewhere else in Greece. Part of the funding will be granted to 80 selected workers who will set up their own businesses. I believe it will mark a path to durable and long-term employment in the region.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on mobilizing resources for adaptation to a globalised space. The report deals with a labour market reintegration item of 705 workers from 46 companies in the Greek Attica region.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ The lay-offs in the publishing sector in the region of Attica are related to the global economic and financial crisis, which reduced households’ disposable income and caused a huge drop in purchasing power, creating a need to establish spending priorities. It is feared that the dismissals in question could have enormous negative effects on the region of Attica, which already has the highest number of unemployed of the 12 Greek regions. I gave my approval to this report because the package of personalised services to be cofinanced mainly supports entrepreneurship, via grants for self-employment, career counselling, and training measures, including vocational training. It will be a positive means of creating new opportunities for the people affected.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European globalisation adjustment funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies who are sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultra-liberal policies applied within this European Union which is unable to defend either the peoples who make up it or the companies that make it work.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilization of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalization on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes, especially relevant in peripheral regions such as Greece.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I supported the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in favour of Greece, in order to assist the 705 redundancies of Attica Publishing, a group of companies in the Attica region, operating in the publishing sector, which has suffered a 60% drop in sales since 2009.  As in the case of Attica Broadcasting, the subject of another EGF intervention in favour of the Attica region, the redundancies are linked to the global financial and economic crisis which, involving a drastic reduction in disposable income, has forced families to cut spending on non-essential products, such as magazines and newspapers. With a contribution of EUR 3 746 700, redundant workers will be able to benefit from a package of personalised vocational guidance services and support for the creation of new businesses through job search allowances.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilization of 705 redundancies made in 46 companies operating in division 58 ('Edition')(4) of NACE Rev. 2 in the NUTS level 2(5) region of the Attica region (EL 30) in Greece. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Greece, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. In Greece, media business activity has been a trend of steady decline in recent years: the turnover of media companies in publishing has decreased by more than 40% over the last three years (2010-2013), resulting in layoffs.  As a result of this crisis, Greece has requested assistance from the EGF to assist in the dismissal of 705 workers in 46 publishing companies.  This region, which concentrates almost half of Greece's GDP, has already been hit hard by the negative consequences of the crisis. All redundancies covered by EGF applications are concentrated in Attica, a region with an unemployment rate of 28% and where there are few job vacancies, with more than 70% of the unemployed out of the labour market for more than 12 months.  The measures co-financed by the EGF aim to help workers find new jobs by providing them with active career guidance, vocational training and entrepreneurship-specific advice. In fact, this fund only represents limited immediate support for workers, nothing to address the consequences of the continued liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal policies continuously followed by the EU.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I also voted in favour of this motion, as workers made redundant as a result of the far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns or in the global financial and economic crisis must be supported in their reintegration into the labour market. The decline in demand for products in this sector (newspapers, magazines, etc.) in the period 2009-2013 led to a 60% decline in sales. We need to consider measures to strengthen this sector again.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece requested assistance from the EGF following the dismissal of 705 workers in 46 publishing companies.  Turnover in media companies has been trending steady in recent years: the turnover rate of media companies in the publishing sector has decreased by more than 40% over the last three years (2010-2013), resulting in redundancies. During the years 2009-2012, companies operating in the media sectors had closed their activities or reduced their staff. These layoffs have overwhelmed a region that has already been hit hard by the negative consequences of the crisis. All redundancies covered by EGF applications are concentrated in Attica, a region with an unemployment rate of 28% and where there are few job vacancies, with more than 70% of the unemployed out of the labour market for more than 12 months. The crisis in Attica affects the entire Greek economy, as the region contributes 43% of Greek GDP. In fact, this Fund only represents limited immediate support for workers, a palliative, which does nothing to address the consequences of the continued liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal policies continuously followed by the EU.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds for the publishing sector in the Greek region of Attica (Attica Publishing activites) because the dismissal of 705 redundancies in 46 different publishing companies was linked to the global financial and economic crisis, which led to a shift in household spending towards emergency products and a significant decline in purchasing power in the field of less urgent products. , such as magazines and newspapers, and because, compared to the 12 remaining Greek regions, the largest number of all unemployed in Greece lives. It is good that EGF funding is used to reintegrate workers made redundant into the labour market through vocational guidance, training, mobility support and support for start-ups in the form of subsidies for self-employment. I voted in favour of the report because it emphasises that only active labour market measures leading to permanent and long-term employment can be co-financed with assistance from the EGF, while stressing that workers' training must also be adapted to the actual business environment.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of ALDE Portuguese MEP Antonio Marinho e Pinto. Since the same MEP concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The charge against Mr Marinho e Pinto clearly has nothing to do with his role as an MEP but with his former role as president of the Portuguese bar. In addition, the alleged acts do not relate to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties. In addition, Mr. Marinho himself asks for the lifting of his immunity. So I voted in favour of it.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting the parliamentary immunity of MP Marinho e Pinto, who himself wishes to be able to answer the accusations against him of defamation of former officials of the Portuguese bar during his time as president of that body.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The Member of Parliament himself wants his parliamentary immunity lifted, so I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I was present in the Chamber during the vote on the Chrysognos report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of this Member's immunity in the light of the request made to this effect by the judge of the District Court of Coimbra, and that the accusations made against him do not relate to opinions expressed or votes issued by Members of the European Parliament in the exercise of their duties and that there is no suspicion that parliamentary work will be attempted to impede legal action they actually started before it took its seat in the European Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because it has led the European Parliament to waive the immunity of a Portuguese Member of the European Parliament, António Marinho e Pinto. Parliament has ruled against the immunity of that member on the grounds that he was sued when he has not yet exercised his powers in the European Parliament and is accused of defaming former employees of the Portuguese Bar Association while being President of the Portuguese Bar Association. Furtherwise, the Parliament's decision states that there is no suspicion that there has been an attempt to obstruct the parliamentary work of António Marinho e Pinto through the case, so that there are no legal obstacles to waiving immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the revocation. The case concerns an alleged defamation between members of the Bar Association in Portugal. The Member is the party on whom the charge is imposed. I do not believe that the facts are linked to parliamentary activity or, in any case, referable to cases of protection with immunities provided for in the Rules of Procedure.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of António Marinho e Pinto, who is a Portuguese MEP.  By waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the rules on immunity (Rule 7 of its Rules of Procedure and Protocol No 7 to the TFEU) to these cases. When it finds that defamatory statements are made that have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive immunity, so that court proceedings in the national Member State can be brought or continue. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr António Marinho and Mr Pinto was requested by the judge of the District Court of Coimbra in relation to a possible judicial proceeding for an alleged crime. Since the accusations clearly have no relation to the office of Member, but result from his previous role as President of the Portuguese Bar Association, I voted in favour of waiving immunity.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I have decided to vote in favour of the request to lift the parliamentary immunity of Antonio Marinho e Pinto. Accused of defaming former officials of the Portuguese bar, Antonio Marinho e Pinto himself has called for the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, as the facts alleged against him in Portugal have nothing to do with opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. Moreover, there is no indication that the proceedings against Antonio Marinho e Pinto are inspired by the intention to interfere with the MP's political activity.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the European Parliament's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of António Marinho and Pinto, transmitted on 8 October 2014 by Dr Rodrigo Pereira da Costa, Judge at the District Court of Coimbra.  Having examined the documents, it decided to ask the Parliamentary Assembly to waive immunity, considering that the charges clearly have no relation to the office of Member of the European Parliament of António Marinho and Pinto, but result from his previous role as President of the Portuguese Bar Association; There is also no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis, and this case actually began before António Marinho and Pinto took office in the European Parliament. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of the measure

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. In the case in question the charges are manifestly unrelated to the position of the Member as a Member of the European Parliament and arise from his former position as President of the Portuguese Bar Association. The alleged actions do not relate to opinions expressed or votes cast by the Member of the European Parliament in the performance of his duties within the meaning of Article 8 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of ALDE Portuguese MEP Antonio Marinho e Pinto. Since the same MEP concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favor of the request for waiver of the immunity of the Deputy concerned, in accordance with the will expressed by himself and allowing to follow up the judicial proceedings that takes place in the Judicial Court of the District of Coimbra.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The Portuguese authorities submitted a request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Marinho and Pinto, accused of having criticized, as a bastion of the Portuguese Bar Association, an earlier decision of the disciplinary body of the Order itself that had acquitted a former leader. The disciplinary proceedings had been brought due to a complaint by a judge against a former OAP bastionary, and he was eventually acquitted.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted to lift parliamentary immunity because he himself was requesting it.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am against parliamentary privileges and in particular parliamentary immunity, because everyone is equal in the face of the law. I am therefore voting in favour of the request for the waiver of António Marinho e Pinto's immunity.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour since the case does not concern the member's activity and the Member accepts the suspension of his immunity.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour since the case does not concern the member's activity and the Member accepts the suspension of his immunity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Antonio Marinh e Pinto's immunity, as this allows Mr Marinh e Punta to prove in court the true thoroughness of the charge of alleged defamation by former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association. However, I consider it necessary to ensure that an MEP can work smoothly in the European Parliament.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Mr Antonio Marinho e Pinto is calling for the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, so I have decided to vote in support, considering that this decision concerns only him. This Member wishes to have the opportunity to defend himself before the courts of his country, and only a lifting of parliamentary immunity allows him to do so. Nevertheless, I would like to express concern about the substance of the case. Mr Marinho e Pinto is facing an accusation which seems to me to be both unfair and unfounded and which I consider to be contrary to the principle of free expression, a right that is increasingly restricted in the countries of the Union.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the request to lift the parliamentary immunity of MP Antonio Marinho e Pinto.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The committee responsible voted unanimously to waive the immunity of Mr Antonio Marinho e Pinto, who is accused of defamation of former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association. Since the offence alleged to Mr Marinho e Pinto took place before his election to the European Parliament, his parliamentary activity is not to be hindered by the procedure. That is why I am voting in favour of this motion.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour because this Member of Parliament asked himself to lift his immunity in order to defend himself in the courts of his country. But, on the merits, the prosecution seems abusive because it retains a very restrictive conception of freedom of expression.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the request for the waiver of the immunity of António Marinho e Pinto, following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Union.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of António Marinho and Pinto.  The Member must continue to enjoy immunity, as a guarantor I will continue to vote against these reports. Immunity is a guarantee for the independence of the European Parliament as an institution and not for the personal benefit of its members.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The judge of the District Court of Coimbra requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of António Marinho and Pinto, Member of the European Parliament, in relation to a judicial proceeding relating to an alleged offence of defamation against former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association.  Given that the charges against António Marinho and Pinto have no connection with the exercise of his mandate as an MEP, I have decided to support the report signed by Mr Chrysogonos, which calls for his immunity to be waived.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In his capacity as President of the Portuguese Bar Association, Antonio Marinho e Pinto is accused of defamation of former civil servants. Although the procedure was initiated before he took office in the European Parliament, this may affect the parliamentary activity of Antonio Marinho e Pinto. As a result, I agreed with the request for the waiver of immunity.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the immunity of Mr Marinho e Pinto, Portuguese ALDE MEMBER of Parliament. While sticking in Portugal he called the minister of justice a "silly cockroach". He's being sued for defamation. Since Mr Marinho e Pinto does not object to the lifting of his immunity, I am voting in for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. A judge in the coimbra district court requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament, António Marinho and Pinto, in the context of a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence.  António Marinho e Pinto is accused of the crime of defamation of former employees of the Portuguese Bar Association. Since the charges are not manifestly related to the functions of António Marinho and Pinto as a Member of the European Parliament and derive from his previous position as Bastonário of the Portuguese Bar Association, I therefore voted in favour of the waiver of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. Mr Marinho e Pinto himself has asked for the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, so there is no reason to object.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the waiver of immunity relates to charges which are not directly related to the activity of a Member of the European Parliament, since they relate to a position previously held by the person concerned. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of this report which aims to lift immunity.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Member concerned by this request to waive parliamentary immunity being himself in favour of this request, I voted in favour.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to approve the report on the request to lift the immunity of António Marinho e Pinto.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request for waiver of the immunity of António Marinho e Pinto because of the pending case in Portugal.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Judge of the District Court of Coimbra has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of António Marinho and Pinto, Member of the European Parliament, in relation to possible judicial proceedings in relation to an alleged crime and whereas, under Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union, Members of the European Parliament benefit, on national territory, from the , the immunities accorded to members of their country's parliament; that, under Article 157(2) and (3) of the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic, no Member may, for the duration of the parliamentary term, be prosecuted, arrested, detained or otherwise deprived of his liberty without the prior authorisation of this House; that António Marinho and Pinto are accused of defamation against former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association and that the charges clearly have no relation to the position of Member of the European Parliament of António Marinho and Pinto, but result from his previous role as President of the Portuguese Bar Association; For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although the prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EEA. Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but concerns his function as President of the Portuguese Bar Association, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political damage to the Member Concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Pinto became a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported Representative Kostas Chrysogonos' report on the request to lift the immunity of Representative Antonio Marinh e Pinto. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of MEP Antonio Marinh e Pinta, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution brought with the intention of causing political damage to a Member because it was initiated before becoming a Member of the European Parliament. Since the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with the performance of Antonio Marinh e Pinta's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I agree with the unanimous decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The judge of the coimbra district court, Dr. Rodrigo Pereira da Costa, requested the waiver of the immunity of António Marinho and Pinto, on October 8, 2014, in connection with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offense, being charged with the crime of defamation of former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the accusations stem from his previous position as Bastonário of the Portuguese Bar Association, so they do not concern opinions or votes expressed in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In view of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision which lifts the immunity of António Marinho and Pinto.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of this Member's immunity in the light of the request made to this effect by the judge of the District Court of Coimbra, and that the accusations made against him do not relate to opinions expressed or votes issued by Members of the European Parliament in the exercise of their duties and that there is no suspicion that parliamentary work will be attempted to impede legal action they actually started before it took its seat in the European Parliament.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of the immunity of Mr Antonio Marinho e Pinto, so that the Portuguese justice system could do its job, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged offence has no direct or obvious link to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. The proceedings are not intended to damage the political career of the Member concerned, but concern his former activity, when Mr Marinho e Pinto was president of the Portuguese bar.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP António Marinho e Pinto, requested by the Judge of the Court of the District of Coimbra, on 8 October 2014, and deals with a possible legal action relating to an alleged offence committed by the Member of the European Parliament, at a time prior to his current duties, in which he has been accused of a defamation of former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association.  In view of the fact that the accusation is not related to the exercise of the current European mandate, resulting before his previous position as Bastonário of that professional order, and since he himself has already publicly assumed that he does not wish to use the prerogative granted by Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, I voted in favour of this report on the waiver of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of ALDE Portuguese MEP Antonio Marinho e Pinto. Since the same MEP concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The Socialists & Democrats Group voted in favour of the request for waiver of the immunity of António Marinho e Pinto. The charges are manifestly unrelated to the position of António Marinho e Pinto as a Member of the European Parliament and arise from his former position as President of the Portuguese Bar Association.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's decision to lift the immunity of Antóni Marinh e Pinto, which was forwarded on 8 October 2014 by Dr Rodrigo Pereira da Costa, judge at the Coimbra District Court (Ref. 6076/12.0TDLSB), and published in plenary on 12 November 2014. A judge at the District Court in Coimbra has applied for the waiver of mep Antóni Marinh e Pinto's parliamentary immunity in connection with possible legal proceedings for the alleged offence. The alleged acts are not related to the expression of an opinion or the vote of members of the European Parliament in the performance of their duties within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ Since october 8, 2014  Dr Rodrigo Pereira da Costa, judge at the District Court of Coimbra, forwarded a request to the European Parliament requesting the lifting of mep Antóni Marinh e Pinto's immunity in relation to the defamation charge against former officials of the Portuguese Bar Association, I support the European Parliament's decision to lift the immunity of a fellow MEP because I consider it in the spirit of the European Union to show respect and good faith towards all legislative and legal institutions , and I believe that in this way we also show confidence in the judicial systems of the Member States.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted in favour as the case does not concern the Member's activity and the Member accepts the suspension of his immunity.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The delegation spoke in support of the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Antonio Marinho e Pinto at the request of the Member. He is accused of defaming former officials of the Portuguese bar.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of the impunity of Mr António Marinho, as a common practice in these cases.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of ALDE Portuguese MP Antonio Marinho e Pinto. Since the same Member concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 António Marinho e Pinto is accused of the defamation of former employees of the Portuguese Bar Association. The accusations are not manifestly related to the functions of António Marinho and Pinto as a Member of the European Parliament. They result from their previous position as Bastonário of the Portuguese Bar Association. Since the alleged actions do not concern opinions or votes expressed in the performance of the duties of member of the European Parliament and there is no suspicion of any attempt to obstruct parliamentary work by António Marinho and Pinto, we support the waiver of the immunity of António Marinho and Pinto.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. In his capacity as President of the Portuguese Bar Association, Antonio Marinho e Pinto is accused of defamation of former civil servants. Although the procedure was initiated before he took office in the European Parliament, this may affect the parliamentary activity of Antonio Marinho e Pinto. As a result, I agreed with the request for the waiver of immunity.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law. .

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Croatian ALDE MP Ivan Jakovcic. Since the same Member concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Ivan Jakovčić, who is a Croatian ALDE MEP. By waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the rules on immunity (Rule 7 of its Rules of Procedure and Protocol No 7 to the TFEU) to these cases. When it finds that defamatory statements are made that have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive immunity so that court proceedings in the national Member State can be brought or continue. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Although the allegedly defamatory comments attributed to Mr Jakov-i- relate to a case dating back to a time before his mandate as an MEP, these were made when Mr Jakovic was already serving as an MEP. Parliamentary immunity does not allow Members to be prosecuted for opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. This lifting of parliamentary immunity is therefore an offence to freedom of expression. So I voted against her.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of The parliamentary immunity of Mr Ivan Jakov-i- because I consider it an infringement of a parliamentarian's freedom of expression: he is accused of remarks he allegedly made in July 2014 during an interview with croatian broadcaster HRT.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this request to waive parliamentary immunity because it is an attack on freedom of expression.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I was present in the Chamber during the vote on the Zwiefka report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of this Member's parliamentary immunity in view of the view that the accusations made against him in his country of origin relate to allegedly defamatory statements made when he was already a Member of the European Parliament but which are not directly or obviously related to the exercise of the functions of Member of Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because it has allowed the European Parliament to waive the immunity of Ivan Jakovčić, a Croatian MEP. Parliament has decided to waive the immunity of that member on a defamation, private charge against him in a case brought against him for facts that have happened when he has not yet exercised his mandate in the European Parliament. Parliament's decision also states that there is no suspicion that there has been an attempt to obstruct Ivan Jakovčić's parliamentary work through the case, so there are no legal obstacles to waiving immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. The rapporteur does not consider that the facts in question are linked to parliamentary activity or, in any case, referable to cases of protection with immunities provided for in the Rules of Procedure.  This is alleged defamation (the MP had commented on an accusation made by a private individual to the local authorities of the Istrian province of which he had been governor), but the episode seems small.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Ivan Jakovčić, who is a Croatian ALDE MEP. By waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the rules on immunity (Rule 7 of its Rules of Procedure and Protocol No 7 to the TFEU) to these cases. When it finds that defamatory statements are made that have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive immunity, so that court proceedings in the national Member State can be brought or continue. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 A private applicant's lawyer has asked for The immunity of Ivan Jakovčić to be waived in the context of a trial concerning an alleged offence of defamation. Since the statements relate to an issue which dates back to a period prior to that of the parliamentary term of office, the waiver of immunity does not encounter any obstacles.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. Because I am resolutely and unconditionally committed to the principle of freedom of expression, I could only vote against this request to lift Ivan Jakov's parliamentary immunity. Indeed, this Member is being prosecuted for defamation offences, on the pretext that he gave in the press freely his opinion on a Croatian entrepreneur. If a public man can no longer express himself freely — whether his words are derogatory or not — in the face of the globalist fringe of employers, let me be told all the major declarations of intent of the European Parliament in its resolutions on human rights and freedom of expression. A new hypocrisy of the European institutions that I had to denounce.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the European Parliament's reasons for the request to waive ivan Jakovčić's immunity of 23 October 2014. The President announced that, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, he had received a letter from the lawyer of Georg List, a major international entrepreneur.  Having examined the documents, the Commission decided to ask the Parliamentary Assembly to waive immunity, given that the accusations of defamation clearly have no relation to Ivan Jakovčić's position as a Member of the European Parliament, but result from his previous role as governor of the Istrian province; There is also no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Parliamentary immunity is not a Member’s personal privilege but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament as a whole and of its Members. The case in question does not have a direct and obvious connection with the Member’s performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament nor does it constitute an opinion expressed or a vote cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament for the purposes of Article 8 of Protocol No 7. I have thus voted in favour of the report to waive the immunity of the Member.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of Croatian ALDE MP Ivan Jakovcic. Since the same Member concerned is in favour of suspension, I voted in favour.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The lawyer of a private complainant has requested the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of a Member of the European Parliament, Ivan Jakovčić, for alleged defamation. Ivan Jakovčić was a Member of the European Parliament at the time of the interview. However, the alleged statements concern an issue dating back to a time when he did not yet hold that office and do not have a direct and clear link with the exercise of the duties of Member of the European Parliament by Ivan Jakovčić, nor do they constitute an opinion or vote cast in the performance of his duties as a member of the European Parliament.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of parliamentary immunity, because it is above all a question of defending freedom of expression.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am against parliamentary privileges and in particular parliamentary immunity, because everyone is equal in the face of the law. I am therefore voting in favour of the request for the waiver of Ivan Jakovčic's parliamentary immunity.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that although Ivan Jakovcic was a Member at the time the events took place, these facts are not related to his activity as a Member of the European Parliament, so there is no problem in the revocation of immunity.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. We understand that although Ivan Jakovcic was a MEMBER of the EP at the time the events took place, these facts are not related to his activity as an MEP, so there is no problem in revoking immunity

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift my immunity because it is the only way that allows me to confront those who accuse me soon in court. It is important that the truth is fully investigated and determined, and parliamentary immunity is not a priority but a truth.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Over the years, the demand for the lifting of parliamentary immunity has become a means of opposing their political opponents and thus avoiding substantive debate. Against the background of suspicion of corruption, Ivan Jakov-i, considered innocent until his guilt is proven, allegedly claimed, against one of his accusers, who is also a real estate developer: "I do not pronounce on idiots". In addition to the weakness of the insult, I can only object to Mr Jakov-i-a being prosecuted for these remarks, considering that this would be contrary to freedom of expression. I also regret that this concept is frequently manipulated to serve as political low views. I therefore voted against this request to waive parliamentary immunity.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In the legal interpretation of the European Court of Justice, statements which may be regarded as excessive, annoying or offensive are no longer covered by parliamentary immunity if they are not directly and manifestly related to the exercise of parliamentary office. As far as the nature and content of the statement by Mr Ivan Jakovic is concerned, it is not directly related to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In particular, the facts show that, although the statement in question was made when Mr Jakovic was already a Member of the European Parliament, it relates to a matter which dates back to a time when he was not the holder of that office. That is why I agree with the request to waive the immunity of Ivan Jakovsic.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against it because the defamation grievance against this Member seems unconvincing. For the benefit of the doubt.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Against. Although Mr. Jakov-i's comments towards Mr. List may appear to be disrespectful, they are not sufficient to accept a request to waive his parliamentary immunity. This is in the name of freedom of expression.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of Ivan Jakovčić's parliamentary immunity following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of requesting the waiver of Ivan Jakovčić's immunity.  As a guarantor, I remain convinced that he should continue to enjoy immunity.
