The main company is active in the NACE Rev 2 Division 33 ("Repair and installation of machinery and equipment"). The redundancies of the companies concerned are mainly carried out in the Irish NUTS 2 region 4 Southern and Eastern (IE 02). I welcome this motion, as I consider it important that the EU should send out an important signal, especially in times of crisis, by making sensible investments to combat unemployment, and I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to allocate EUR 2 490 758 from the EGF to Ireland, as it will allow us to help the 424 people who became unemployed in The Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd, a Company based in Ireland. Unemployment is one of the most painful problems in the European Union. As a result of structural changes and globalisation, many companies have had to lay off a large number of workers or close their doors. With the EGF Fund, we can re-engage these people in the labour market.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for granting aid to Ireland. It should be noted that redundancies have a particularly serious negative impact on local and regional economies.  Thus, although the country does not meet the requirements laid down in the Regulation, it must be exempted from the intervention criteria laid down by the EGF in the light of the current situation and the reasons given, it must be exempted from the intervention criteria laid down in the EGF.  It should be noted that workers in this sector have very specific skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult for workers to find new jobs easily. Egf support for workers in the repair and installation sector of machinery and equipment who have lost their jobs will help the most disadvantaged to return to the labour market. In particular, they will be offered employment promotion measures and opportunities for career guidance and retraining. In this context, the implementation of the measures envisaged will help to reduce the negative impact on Southern and Eastern Ireland, where a significant number of disadvantaged people live and live in poverty.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. Having regard to the fact that the Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows or the global economic and financial crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market; that Ireland has applied for EGF/2014/016 IE/Lufthansa Technik for a financial contribution from the EGF following a total of 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland; whereas the application does not meet the eligibility criteria laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of the EGF Regulation and is based on the provision relating to exceptional circumstances referred to in Article 4(2) of that Regulation;  it is agreed with the Commission that the exceptional circumstances put in place by the Irish authorities, namely that redundancies have a serious impact on employment and the local and regional economy, justify a derogation from the intervention criteria under Article 4(2) of the EGF Regulation and that, therefore, Ireland is entitled to a financial contribution under that Regulation. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I support the Irish authorities' request to the EGF for a financial contribution following redundancies from Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland, relating to 424 workers and a sum of EUR 2 490 758 representing 60% of the total cost of the proposed measures to ensure a financial contribution to their application. Redundancies in the company will have an extremely negative impact on southern and eastern Ireland, and these areas are extremely disadvantaged. I point out that workers from this sector have very specific skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult for these workers to search for new employment, in particular workers close to retirement (around 20% of workers). I welcome the fact that, in agreement with the targeted beneficiaries, their representatives and trade unions, a harmonised package of services tailored to their needs has been developed.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ Given that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who ceased their activity due to major structural changes in globalisation-inducements in globalisation, due to the protracted global financial and economic crisis mentioned in Regulation (EC) No 1001/2013; 546/2009(3) or due to the new global financial and economic crisis and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, I support the proposal to mobilise EUR 2 490 758 for the application submitted by Ireland in order to partially address the financial consequences resulting from the redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two of its suppliers in Ireland. Member States need to show solidarity towards each other when necessary, and I am pleased that they have shown this today in this example.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in international trade and to help them reintegrate into the labour market, i.e. to find a new job. At the same time, union financial assistance to redundanst workers should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible. Ireland applied to EGF/2014/016 IE/Lufthansa Technik for a financial contribution from the EGF following the redundancies of 424 workers at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two of its suppliers in Ireland. Although the application does not meet certain eligibility criteria, due to the serious impact on employment and regional economies, it falls into the category of exceptional circumstances, allowing for the use of EGF funds. Redundancies in the company will have an extremely negative impact on southern and eastern Ireland, and these areas are at an extremely disadvantage. At the same time, workers from the "Repair and Installation of Machinery and Equipment" sector possess very specific skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult for these workers to search for new employment. I therefore support rapporteur Victor Negrescu's report on the mobilisation of EUR 2 490 758, which aims to assist redundante workers in training for new jobs.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Ireland submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF following 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its supplier companies during the period from 1 March 2014 to 30 June 2014. According to the Commission, the exceptional circumstances presented by the Irish authorities justify a derogation from the intervention criteria of the EGF Regulation, and it appears, on the one hand, that redundancies in the 'repair, maintenance and installation of machinery and equipment' in the southern and eastern regions of Ireland are linked to major structural changes in world trade standards due to globalisation , since the closure of ltai is the result of a profound change in trade in goods and services in the Union, which has changed the global location of aircraft production, and, on the other hand, that these redundancies are expected to have a major negative impact on the already heavily disadvantaged southern and eastern regions of Ireland, as shown by certain socio-economic indicators , such as the low level of education and professional qualifications. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of Ireland.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report to approve the mobilisation of EUR 2 490 758 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 424 workers who have lost their jobs at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two of their suppliers in Ireland who were engaged in the repair and installation of machinery and equipment. These layoffs have resulted from profound structural changes in the patterns of international trade caused by globalisation, as a result of a major transformation of EU trade in goods and services due to a technological change in the production of aircraft and next-generation components, from a reorientation towards practices of producing larger aircraft components , and a change in the location of global aircraft production, highlighting the tendency of U.S. and Western European airlines to ship their large-capacity aircraft to China for heavy maintenance. The customized services to be financed from the EGF include training and recycling activities that provide good assistance for the reintegration of the workers concerned.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund as requested by Ireland to help the 450 workers laid off by Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two of its suppliers. Lufthansa Technik's Irish subsidiary, which is active in aircraft repair and maintenance, has experienced financial difficulties following the arrival on the market of a new generation of aircraft increasingly manufactured and maintained in Asia. Given the many closures in this sector in Ireland, it seems important to help these workers to help them train and thus find a job.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The sector of repair, maintenance and installation of machinery and equipment, as well as the production of aircraft in Europe has been suffering the effects of globalization with the relocation of this type of services to China and Southeast Asia. In the present case, the parent company Lufthansa Technik took the decision to base its Airbus A330/340 MRO operations on a subsidiary company located in the Philippines. This has led to the dismissal of 250 workers in a very sensitive sector which has had very negative repercussions in the southern and eastern regions of Ireland, where the level of education and lack of professional qualifications are an unavoidable reality. In view of the above, I am therefore in favour of mobilising this fund, amounting to €2 490 758, in favour of Ireland, since it fulfils the exceptional circumstances laid down in Article 4(2) of the EGF Regulation.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Ireland has asked the European Union for help in overcoming the economic crisis that has blocked the activity of a company for which the 149 redundancies have become a problem. I therefore voted in favour of this report in order to ensure that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can help a European company.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of the call for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the sum of around EUR 2.500 million for EUR 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland and two of its suppliers due to relocation to Asia. The Irish authorities point to a fall in total employment in the sector of around 52%.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Written. \u2012 Ireland's application for unemployment effects of a company engaged in aeroplane mechanics follows the criteria of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund by way of derogation. The application concerns a total of 424 unemployed persons. Ireland's application has benefited from the derogation provided for in Article 4(1)(a), which allows support from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, even where fewer than 500 workers are affected by direct unemployment effects, but have very significant effects on regional unemployment. The report also shows that the unemployed have a low level of education and a high proportion of subsidised housing. It is also very difficult for these workers to continue to be placed in the labour market because they have special expertise that is not needed in other sectors. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation following a total of 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Ireland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of the human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilising the EGF (European Globalisation Adjustment Fund) on Ireland's application for financial assistance due to 424 redundancies in Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland. I hope that the coordinated package of personalised services co-financed by the EGF will contribute to the reintegration into working life of these workers who, having some very specific skills that are difficult to exploit in other sectors, are in danger of encountering even more difficulties in finding a new job.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of an application made by Ireland. A total amount of EUR 2 490 758 from the EGF will go towards supporting the reintegration into the labour market of 149 workers made redundant from Lufthansa Technik. The UK has never made an application under this Fund. UK workers therefore receive none of this support.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I supported the motion for a resolution to provide Ireland with a contribution of EUR 2 490 758 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This contribution is granted at the request of the Irish Government following the redundancies of 424 workers from Lufthansa Technik. The dismissal of these workers has a significant negative impact on the southern and eastern Ireland region. This aid will be used to co-finance active labour market measures leading to permanent and long-term employment, while respecting the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination. Redundant workers will be provided with professional advice and assistance in career planning, support their independent business and retraining.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is an instrument whereby the European Union provides additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  Although ireland's application for a financial contribution submitted by Ireland for aid to Lufthansa Technik in which 424 redundancies were made out does not meet certain eligibility criteria for the aid, it falls within the category of exceptional circumstances permitting the mobilisation of the EGF due to the serious impact on employment and the regional economy. The company's layoffs were the result of major structural changes in global trade flows due to globalisation, and the company's closure was the result of changes in trade with eu goods resulting from the technological transition to the production of new generation aircraft and their components and affecting the market fundamentals of the company's core business model. The redundancies have had a serious negative impact on the Southern and Eastern Ireland region, which is characterised by significant local deprivation and poverty, and the redundancy workforce there has specific skills that are difficult to use in other sectors. As the co-financed services package covers three important areas: career advice and career planning, training and further education, and assistance for businesses and the self-employed, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this report in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of 450 workers made redundant as a result of globalisation at the Irish subsidiary of Lufthansa Technik, a company operating in the field of maintenance and repair of air carriers and components.  Lufthansa Technik had to close the Irish site when its business model proved to be no longer valid as a result of a number of factors, such as the choice of customers to turn to operators active in the production of new generation aircraft and components, the switch to larger-scale methods in the production of aircraft components and finally the geographical transfer of world aircraft production to Asia. With the recent closure of similar companies in Ireland, redundant workers in this sector are finding it very difficult to relocate, having very specific skills that are difficult to exploit in other sectors.  The aid of EUR 2 490 758 provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund will help to co-finance a package of personalised services, such as vocational guidance and career planning, training and refresher programmes, higher education programmes, support for the creation of businesses and self-employment and income support.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund offers funding to those who lose their jobs in collective redundancies as a result of globalisation trends. The funds are intended for retraining or to help start a business. It is important that these funds are used efficiently, so that this aid really directs towards those who need it most.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution as Ireland has applied to EGF/2014/016 IE/Lufthansa Technik for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies of 424 workers at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two of its suppliers in Ireland. As the application meets the eligibility criteria set out in the EGF Regulation, I welcome the fact that all laid-off eligible workers are expected to participate in measures for which support comes from the EGF and, in accordance with the provision, Ireland is entitled to a financial contribution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – The closure of Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd, resulting from a major change in trade in goods and services in the Union due to a technological shift in production, has resulted in the dismissal of a large number of workers who possess very specific skills difficult to apply in other sectors. This created a negative impact on eastern and southern Ireland, which was already at a disadvantage before, judging by socioeconomic indicators. They show that there are low levels of education, poverty and a large number of social housing beneficiaries in the area, and it is this area that has been affected by a series of layoffs within the same sector over the past few years. For these reasons, I support the report and the decision to allocate EGF funds, and I welcome ireland's initiative, which has decided that a harmonised package of services, co-financed by the EGF, will be used for professional orientation and support in career planning, the implementation of training and secondary education programmes and the contribution to the cost of the course not only in redundant workers, but also the target group of up to 200 young people under 25 who are not necessarily from the sector. I see this as positive and active measures directed towards the target groups to make concrete progress not only for the sectors affected, but also for the economy in general.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the proposal. The main reason for granting this contribution should again be 'major structural changes in world trade patterns caused by globalisation'. Of course, the existence of these changes cannot be denied. However, the negative impact of these changes on employment in the EU is also to a large extent also the result of many harmful EU policies and, paradoxically, of redistribution in this and a number of other EU programmes.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I supported the resolution on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds for Lufthansa Technik - Ireland due to the redundancies of a total of 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd and two suppliers in Ireland. Redundancies in the repair and installation sector of machinery and equipment in Ireland are linked to major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation. I also voted in favour of the resolution because of the fact that the workforce in this sector has some very specific skills and skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult for workers to find new employment.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The money from the Adjustment Fund should be given primarily to the dismissed, and not to reintegration or retraining companies. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted to mobilize the fund to support these workers. The aim of this assistance is to reorient workers professionally and train workers who are victims of restructuring and redundancies in their companies. This Fund represents the symbol of a Europe that can be more united. It should be noted, however, that, with regard to all of these aids, it is always a question of allegoing the damage of unbridled liberalism, which must now be replaced by targeted and massive public investment initiatives.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I think it is important to provide European industries with financial support when they have to undergo structural changes which put at risk the economic and social sustainability of a region. The shift in aircraft component production practices encouraged Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland to relocate their activities to the Philippines and led to 424 redundancies in southern and eastern Ireland. This case did not match all the eligibility criteria of the EGF Regulation but fits the exceptional circumstances provision as the redundancies have had a serious impact on employment in the region, with unemployment reaching 23%. This fund will be used to develop appropriate tools to reintegrate these workers, as well as 200 young people not in employment, education or training, into the job market. The tools include individual job search assistance, training and promotion of entrepreneurship. I believe it will mark a path to durable and long-term employment in the region.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report on mobilizing resources for adaptation to a globalised space. The report deals with a item for the reintegration into the labour market of 250 workers in Ireland and the economic benefits that this budgetary mobilisation will have for the region.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The delegation systematically votes on the "European globalisation adjustment funds" because they are programmes to support employees of companies who are sometimes forced to lay off under the pressure of market deregulation, the consequences of the disastrous ultra-liberal policies applied within this European Union which is unable to defend either the peoples who make up it or the companies that make it work.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote has been in favour of this report, as have the other reports that in this plenary session have called for the mobilisation of an essential fund for mitigating the impact of globalisation on the functioning of local economies and the future of regions affected by deind industrialization processes and, in this case, as it is a peripheral region of the euro affected by the crisis such as Ireland , makes more sense.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) in order to support 450 workers made redundant at the Irish subsidiary of Lufthansa Technik, a company operating in the field of aircraft and components maintenance and repair, which is under great threat from international competition, especially in Asia.  The aid, which amounts to around EUR 2 500 000, will help to co-finance a package of tailor-made vocational guidance and retraining services, as well as support for the creation of businesses and self-employment. I believe that this is a fundamental instrument for restoring hope in the future to highly sectorally specialized workers who find it very difficult to relocate to other sectors.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation following a total of 424 redundancies at Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland Ltd (LTAI) and two of its suppliers in Ireland. This mobilisation of funds is due to the disastrous consequences of the internationalisation of productive sectors in the EU.  These funds are not able to solve the problems of these workers in the context of unemployment in Ireland, but at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. 'Lufthansa Technik' was dismembered from the main group in 1994. In 1999, Lufthansa Technik took full ownership of Aer Lingus which in 1980 created "Airmotive Ireland", aircraft maintenance and repair and overhaul in Dublin. A profound change in trade in goods and services in the Union, mainly due to globalisation and relocations, has impacted the business models underlying Lufthansa Technik, leading to the closure of Lufthansa Technik Ireland. This is the tenth transfer proposal for the mobilisation of the EGF, transmitted to the budgetary authority so far in 2015. This time, this is Ireland's application to the European Globalisation Fund to support 149 workers, a group of 424 workers made redundant from Lufthansa Technik, in their reintegration into the labour market.  Once again, the regions with the highest unemployment rates are those that are hit again with the consequences of deregulation and liberalisation of world trade and neoliberal EU policies.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland (LTAI) was closed due to the serious shift in the trade in goods and services in the Union, a shift in the general practice of the manufacture of aircraft components and a geographical shift in global aircraft production. As a result, many workers have been made redundant. These workers who have become unemployed as a a body as a a cost of structural change must, of course, receive support, which is why I voted positively in favour of this motion.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 A profound change in trade in goods and services in the European Union, resulting from a technological change in the production of new generation aircraft and their components, added to the global relocation of aircraft production, the fact that western European and US carriers have the habit of sending their large aircraft to China, in order to carry out the heavy maintenance there, and the relocation of the parent company Lufthansa Technik, which decided to base its Airbus A330/340 MRO operations on the Lufthansa Subsidiary Technik Philipines in the Philippines, impacted on the fundamental aspects of the market and the business model underlying Lufthansa Technik, leading to the closure of Lufthansa Technik Irland. This is the 10th transfer proposal for the mobilisation of the EFSI forwarded to the budgetary authority so far in 2015. This time it is Ireland's application to the European Globalisation Fund to support 149 workers, from a group of 424 workers made redundant from Lufthansa Technik. In addition to the many redundancies in companies in this sector over the last few years, it is even more difficult for these workers, with very specific skills in this sector, to find a new job.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Lufthansa Technik Airmotive Ireland (LTAI) because the dismissal of 424 workers at this company and from two of its suppliers in Ireland and the closure of LTAI are linked to major structural changes in global trade flows due to globalisation. The redundancies in the repair and installation sector of machinery and equipment in southern and eastern Ireland are largely due to the transition to the production of a new generation of aircraft and changes in the locations of global aircraft production. Western European and American carriers are sending some planes to China for major maintenance work, and even Lufthansa has decided to carry out work on one type of Airbus in the Philippines. In this sector, workers have specific skills and skills that are difficult to use in other sectors, making it difficult to find new employment. In some areas where LTAI workers live, the unemployment rate is around 23%, low levels of education and lack of professional qualifications are common, and significant local deprivation and poverty are also shown. Ireland will offer aid co-financed by the EGF to 250 beneficiaries and 200 under-25s who are not in employment, education or training (NEETs).

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Viktor Uspaskich. Given that the MEP belongs to the Russophone minority, a minority often discriminated against by today's Baltic governments, there are doubts that this is not political persecution. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The case concerning Viktor Uspaskich seems unclear. He is reportedly charged with several criminal offences, but doubts remain about the charges against him. Moreover, Viktor Uspaskich being a Russian-speaking Lithuanian, given the current situation vis-à-vis Russia, this accusation may well constitute a fumus persecutionis. However, when a "smell of political persecution" is discernible, according to which the Member is being pursued by political opponents or for political reasons, parliamentary immunity must be maintained. I therefore voted against the lifting of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity because, according to WikiLeaks documents, it appears to be a case of fumus persecutionis. Wouldn't the Russian origins of this Lithuanian MP have anything to do with the judicial persecution of which the accused claims to be a victim?

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I have obviously objected to this report, which smells of political persecution and is thereby aimed at restricting the personal freedom of the Member concerned.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I was present in the Chamber during the vote on the Regner report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the arrest on 12 July 2013 as guilty by the Vilnius Regional Court and sentenced to a four-year prison sentence for the offences charged to him, that no convincing evidence has been provided of fumus persecutionis and that the offences against him are unrelated with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. On Monday, 23 March, in a public session, Jean-Marie Cavada, Vice-President of the Committee on Legal Affairs, was surprised by the haste on this issue and that the conclusions of the legal services are not expected. Mr Verhofstadt, a former Belgian prime minister, caused a plenary session incident on Wednesday. Bruno Gollnisch rightly recalled the necessary respect for the basic principles of defence rights. I therefore voted against the lifting of Mr Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the revocation. The criminal proceedings in question, in their content, coincide with the procedure where by which the European Parliament decided as early as 2010 to waive viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity; The MEMBER was sentenced at first instance to 4 years' sentence for alleged irregularities in the financing of the party he chaired. The case is awaiting the second degree and the EP is being asked to give its opinion, not even as a result of new evidence brought by the accused, but which, according to the rapporteur, do not seem to change the substance of the decision already taken.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The accusations against my colleague Viktor Uspaskich do not concern an opinion expressed in the exercise of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. However, during the committee's consideration, there were very dubious points as to its actual responsibility in this matter and about a possible fumus persecutionis.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. Fumus persecutionis in this case! Under false pretenses, the European Parliament is calling for the lifting of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity. This Member is, in fact, the only wrong of being a Russian-speaking Lithuanian. The witch hunt began in UERSS. In the war that the European Union is waging against Russia on behalf of the Americans, all blows seem permissible. As a supporter of peace in Ukraine, of the principle of reality in the face of ideology and, above all, of the principle of presumption of innocence, I could only vote against this report.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the European Parliament's reasons for the request to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. On 15 September 2014, the President announced, pursuant to Rule 9(1) of the Rules of Procedure, that he had received a letter from the Public Prosecutor's Office of the Republic of Lithuania requesting the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.  Having examined the documents, the committee decided to ask the Parliamentary Assembly to waive immunity, considering that the accusations clearly have no relation to Viktor Uspaskich's position as a Member of the European Parliament, but are imputed to his position as party chairman. At the time, he was charged with organizing a criminal association to commit various crimes by operating illegally and circumventing the obligation to supervise the correctness of funding to the party of which he was chairman. In fact, fictitious accounts were used to hide revenue and expenditure. In general terms, he would have repeatedly inedeted the instruction to omit to register or officially declare several commercial and financial transactions. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ In the light of the fact that a decision on the same matter has already been taken and a further decision on it has become necessary only because of the re-election of the Member to the European Parliament, and on the basis of the foregoing and of the available documents, it was concluded that there are no grounds for refusing to waive the parliamentary immunity of the Member again. I thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Viktor Uspaskich. Given that the MEP belongs to the Russophone minority, a minority often discriminated against by today's Baltic governments, there are doubts that this is not political persecution. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because I am against parliamentary privileges and, in particular, parliamentary immunity.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The Regional Court of Vílnius has delivered a judgment, which has not yet become final, against European Parliament Member Viktor Uspaskich, who is currently pending before the Lithuanian Court of Appeal. The accusations made against Viktor Uspaskich do not relate to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as an MEP.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against the lifting of parliamentary immunity, because there are doubts about the charges against this Member of the European Parliament, who could above all be the victim of political persecution.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am against parliamentary privileges and in particular parliamentary immunity, because everyone is equal in the face of the law. I am therefore voting in favour of Viktor Uspaskich's request for immunity to be waived.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote to suspend Viktor Uspaskich's immunity. We do this taking into account the situation in the Baltic countries and the circumstances of the arrest. The circumstances, as well as the accusations made to Viktor Uspaskich are all very serious and require the closest scrutiny possible. However, we understand that abstention reinforces the idea that a more thorough investigation has to be carried out, and that both accusations and circumstances need to be watched more closely before granting this suspension.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Viktor Uspaskich. I strongly support the view that Parliament should not take the role of a court and should trust the Lithuanian national courts. I believe that political immunity cannot be a safeguard to prevent Members of the European Parliament from taking responsibility in their Member State when they are found in the act of committing an offence.  I support the report given by the committee claiming that Mr Uspaskich was afforded the right to a fair hearing at every possible level. The main motive for the procedure of waiving immunity that was presented by the rapporteur Ms Regner was the fact that the definition of the offences giving rise to the charges has always remained the same. Moreover, by the decision to waive Mr Uspaskich’s immunity the European Parliament has one more time approved believing in Lithuania as a democratic country ensuring the rule of law, and respecting human rights.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote to suspend Viktor Uspaskich's immunity. We do this taking into account the situation in the Baltic countries and the circumstances of the arrest. The circumstances, as well as the accusations made to Viktor Uspaskich are all very serious and require the closest scrutiny possible. However, we understand that abstention reinforces the idea that a more thorough investigation has to be carried out, and that both accusations and circumstances need to be watched more closely before granting this suspension.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the Proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the application for the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity on the basis that there are still doubts and a lack of clarification on a number of important issues in the report submitted. In addition, this way prevents Mr. Uspaskich from performing normal parliamentary duties and limits his personal freedom. I believe that the waiver of parliamentary immunity must be based on concrete facts and thorough analysis.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This request to waive Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity appears to be politically motivated, considering that Mr Uspaskich is a Russian-speaking Lithuanian. In the geopolitical context that we know, doubt is not allowed. However, he lives on many parliamentarians on this matter, since the lifting of immunity was only voted by a very small majority. The lifting of parliamentary immunity must remain only an ultimate tool, when the facts and evidence are overwhelming, in order to allow justice to be exercised and expressed. It must not in any way become hostage to low political considerations or personal or state interests. In this case, this Member, according to many, would represent a definite embarrassment for the foreign policy of the European Union since he is not aligned with the Atlanticist positions advocated by the European Union. That is why I voted against lifting parliamentary immunity.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against it because the request is officially motivated by the fact that this Member would have kept a double accounting in the management of his political party. But, like many other Members, I am convinced that the real reason is political persecution, because he belongs to a persecuted Russian-speaking minority in his country, Lithuania. Proof that the doubt was legitimate, the debate in plenary session was heated, and the lifting of his immunity was finally voted on by a narrow majority. Small consolation for this congressman who will go straight to prison.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Against. We can seriously express doubts about the strength of the charges against Mr. Uspaskich. Indeed, we did not have in our possession any formal evidence of the offences for which he would have been guilty. In view of these questions, I am voting against the lifting of Mr Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against because I consider the case of Mr Uspaskich to be politically fabricated and biased. On this point, I agree with the leader of the Liberal faction that there are grounds for handing back the Uspaskich case to the JURI Committee without yet depriving him of immunity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity, following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am against the request to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. In my opinion, you must continue to enjoy immunity. As a guarantor, I will always vote against these requests for revocation. Parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of the Member, but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament, as an institution, and of its Members.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Vilnius District Court has opened criminal proceedings, which are still ongoing, against Viktor Uspaskich. The latter is accused of having committed certain offences punishable under the Lithuanian Criminal Code.  Although Viktor Uspaskich was acquitted of some of the charges, he was sentenced, with a sentence not yet final, to 4 years in prison to be served in a prison.  In view of the fact that the accusations against Mr Uspaskich have no connection with the performance of his parliamentary duties, I have decided to support the Regner report, which supports the withdrawal of his immunity.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. After the first request for the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity, it turned out that this was not a politically motivated persecution. Since there is no suspicion of political persecution and due to the fact that there is no credible evidence of the existence of a so-called "fumus persecutionis", there is no reason to refuse to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. I therefore approved this request.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request concerns the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, Lithuanian MEMBER of the ALDE. Viktor Uspaskich is being prosecuted for illegally financing his political party, the Lithuanian Labour Party. The procedure followed by the Lithuanian justice system still raises some questions, including the fact that the search took place even while the accused was at his mother's funeral. It should be noted that Viktor Uspaskich is Russian-speaking, a minority often discriminated disproportionate by the current Baltic governments. In view of these doubts about the proper functioning of the Lithuanian justice system, and the person concerned denouncing a relentlessness against his freedom of expression, I vote against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. This request is made by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece who requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of a possible conviction for an alleged offence. A Vilnius Regional Court has handed down a judgment, which has not yet been finalised, against European Parliament Member Viktor Uspaskich. The accusations made against Viktor Uspaskich do not relate to opinions or votes cast in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament and therefore Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply. I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of his parliamentary immunity.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The request for waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity was transmitted in July 2014 by the Lithuanian authorities. Since the accusations made against the Member do not relate to his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I am in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this lifting of parliamentary immunity because it all has a smell of political persecution which is intended to restrict the personal freedom of the Member concerned.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to approve the report on the request to lift Viktor Uspaskich's immunity in accordance with the decision adopted in the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the request for waiver of Mr Uspaskich's immunity because he is in a pending case in Lithuania.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the charges against Viktor Uspaskich are not linked to opinions or votes cast in the exercise of his mandate as a Member of the European Parliament and therefore Article 8 of the Protocol does not apply; that, pursuant to Article 9 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members shall enjoy on national territory the immunities accorded to members of their country's Parliament for the duration of sessions of the European Parliament; that immunity may not be invoked in the event of a flagrant crime and may not prejudice the right of the European Parliament to waive the immunity of one of its Members; that under Article 62 of the Constitution of the Republic of Lithuania a member of the National Parliament (Seimas) without the approval of the Seimas may not be subject to criminal proceedings, detention measures or other restrictions on freedom; it is decided to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich, instructing its President to forward this decision and the report of his competent committee immediately to the competent authorities of the Republic of Lithuania. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation because, although prosecution is not related to the opinion expressed or the vote to serve as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the EIA, it is not related to the opinion expressed or to vote in the performance of its duties as a Member of the European Parliament within the meaning of Article 8 of the Protocol No. 7 on the privileges and immunies of the European Union, and the alleged offence is clearly not in any relation to the performance of his or her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but concerning his former function in Lithuania, there is no reason to assume that the prosecution was initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned (fumus persecutionis) because it was initiated before Mr Uspaskich became a Member of the European Parliament. In addition, the Committee on Legal Affairs is also not tasked with reviewing the judicial systems of the Member States individually in the framework of the immunity decision-making process.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported MP Evelyne Regner's report on the request to lift the immunity of Representative Viktor Uspaskich. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of Representative Viktor Uspaskich, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution initiated with the intention of causing political harm to the Representative, and that it was the same procedure that, after a non-final judgment of the regional court in Vilna, is now before the Court of Appeal of Lithuania (and the European Parliament has already decided in 2010 to lift Viktor Uspaskich's immunity).  Since the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with the performance of Viktor Uspaskich's duties as a Member of the European Parliament, I agree with the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the waiver of immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 In proceedings pending before the Court of Appeal of the Republic of Lithuania, the Lithuanian judicial authorities forwarded to the European Parliament on 21 July 2014 an application for waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity for falsifying accounting. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the evidence presented by the Member for the existence of "fumus persecutionis" was not convincing and, moreover, the unlawful acts of which Viktor Uspaskich is accused have nothing to do with opinions or votes expressed, or with any other activity, as a Member of the European Parliament. In view of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision which lifts viktor uspaskic's immunity.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending this Member's immunity in view of the arrest on 12 July 2013 being convicted by the Vilnius Regional Court and sentenced to a four-year prison sentence for the offences against him and that no convincing evidence has been provided of fumus persecutionis and that the offences against him are unrelated with his activity as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Viktor Uspaskich's immunity, so that the Lithuanian justice system could continue its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged offence has no direct or obvious link to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. The prosecutions are not intended to prejudice the political career of the Member concerned, but are related to irregular accounting under national procedures.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the European Parliament's mandate is the responsibility of the European Parliament and can only be called into question at last instance.  In the present case, the Lithuanian Attorney General received instructions from the Lithuanian Court of Appeal to request the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Viktor Uspaskich, with a view to complying with the sentence of 4 years of effective imprisonment, handed down by the Vilnius Regional Court on 12 July 2013, for various offences of the Lithuanian Penal Code, mainly related to party funding. Since the decision was appealed, which is why the procedure was suspended and Vicktor Uspaskich was re-elected as a Member of the European Parliament, there was a need to examine a new request for the waiver of his parliamentary immunity.  Considering that this request concerns alleged illegal acts which relate to the commission of tax offences relating to the financing of the party to which he presided and there is no reason to consider that we are dealing with criminal proceedings motivated by political reasons, I believe that it is necessary to withdraw his parliamentary immunity.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of MEP Viktor Uspaskich's parliamentary immunity. Given that the MEP belongs to the Russophone minority, a minority often discriminated against by today's Baltic governments, there are doubts that this is not political persecution. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with the Socialist and Democrats Group to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. The charges against Viktor Uspaskich do not relate to an opinion expressed or vote cast by him in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament so Article 8 of the Protocol is therefore not applicable.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. I support the Report on the Application for waiver of Immunity for Viktor Uspaskich because a non-final judgment was issued against him at the regional court in Vilna and now the same proceedings are being brought before the Lithuanian Court of Appeal. Since the charges against Viktor Uspas are not related to his work as a Member of the European Parliament, article 8 of the European Convention on The Hague does not apply to him. protocol on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ According to the ruling of the regional court in Vilna on 12 July 2013 condemning Viktor Uspaskich for the offences of improper conduct of accounting, and in addition to the European Parliament's decision of 7 September 2010 that lifted the immunity of members, I support the decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs not to protect viktor Uspaskich's immunity and privileges again. Given that the new facts to prove that he is a victim of the fumus persecutionis process, which he provided in his letter on 24 October 2014, do not have the power of evidence or are relevant, there is no legal reason for Parliament not to remain on the previously adopted decision lifting immunity.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on the suspension of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity. We do this taking into account the situation in the Baltic countries and the circumstances of the arrest. The circumstances, as well as the accusations made to Viktor Uspaskich are all very serious and require the closest scrutiny possible. However, we understand that abstention reinforces the idea that a more thorough investigation has to be carried out, and that both accusations and circumstances need to be watched more closely before granting this suspension.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The case of Mr Uspaskich, whose parliamentary immunity is requested to be lifted, seems to have the appearance of a political trial. The charges against him are questionable. It should also be noted that Mr Uspaskich is a Russian-speaking Lithuanian. The National Front delegation expressed itself AGAINST the lifting of its parliamentary immunity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of suspending the impunity of MEP Viktor Uspaskich as a common practice in these cases.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of MEP Viktor Uspaskich. Given that the MEP belongs to the Russophone minority, a minority often discriminated against by today's Baltic governments, there are doubts that this is not political persecution. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This case, rocambolesco, has been going on in this Parliament for a long time, involving several cases that interconnect, making the situation complex. Again, it was not possible to establish any sufficient relationship between the new elements, in fact presented, and the case brought against Viktor Uspaskich for falsifying accounting. We believe that no convincing evidence has been presented of the existence of 'fumus persecutionis' and that the unlawful acts of which Viktor Uspaskich is accused have nothing to do with his activities as a Member of the European Parliament. We believe that it is up to the Committee on Legal Affairs to examine this case better in order to better substantiate this Parliament's decision.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. After the first request for the waiver of Viktor Uspaskich's immunity, it turned out that this was not a politically motivated persecution. Since there is no suspicion of political persecution and due to the fact that there is no credible evidence of the existence of a so-called "fumus persecutionis", there is no reason to refuse to waive the immunity of Viktor Uspaskich. I therefore approved this request.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of former MEP Gabriele Albertini. Given that the matter on which he is to be judged has nothing to do with his role while he was an MEP, I voted in favour.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Gabriele Albertini, a former MEP, had expressed an allegedly defamatory opinion during her term of office. His comments relate to opinions he allegedly expressed during his tenure as an MEP, in order to determine whether the conduct of Alfredo Robledo, a prosecutor who opened an investigation into facts involving the municipality of Milan and relating to the functions of the mayor, constituted a breach of professional ethics and therefore should be subject to disciplinary proceedings. Gabriele Albertini's comments do not show anything scandalous. Parliamentary immunity does not allow Members to be prosecuted for opinions expressed in the performance of their duties. In addition, the prosecutor, himself accused of abusing his duties to settle a personal matter, was suspended. It seems to be a personal dispute here. I therefore voted against Gabriele Albertini's request for non-defence of privileges and immunities, as it is an offence to freedom of expression.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Gabriele Albertini, a former Member of the European Parliament, has asked for the defence of her parliamentary immunity in a criminal proceeding pending before an Italian court. I voted against this report, which denies it when the facts alleged are, in my view, freedom of expression, since Mr Albertini has given his opinion on justice in Lombardy.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it is a case that touches on the essential principle of freedom of expression. This report recommends not defending immunity.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not underccouring Gabrielle Albertini's immunity from the claim in view of the new information provided not establishing the direct and manifest relationship between the views by which an Italian court opened investigative measures and the exercise of parliamentary functions. The conclusion reached twice by Parliament that Gabriele Albertini did not exercise his duties as a Member of the European Parliament in making the declarations in question must therefore be ratified, which is why his immunity was lifted.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because it decides that the European Parliament decides not to defend the immunity of gabriele Albertini, an Italian MEP. Parliament thus held that the supporting documents submitted by Mr Albertini did not show a link between the statements made by him and his duties as a Member of the European Parliament, but also because the fumus persecutionis doctrine, i.e. sufficiently serious and clear suspicions that the proceedings were brought with a view to undermining the political reputation of the Member concerned, cannot be applied in this case, since, at present, Mr. Albertini does not hold the position of Member of the European Parliament.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am opposed to the pro-decision against Members for their views.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report related to the waiver of parliamentary immunity of Gabriele Albertini, who is an Italian ex-MEP of the EPP Group. By waiving an immunity defence, Parliament does not formulate any opinion on the probability of guilt or not of the MEP in question. It only looks at applying the rules on immunity (Rule 7 of its Rules of Procedure and Protocol No 7 to the TFEU) to these cases. When it finds that defamatory statements are made that have no direct and obvious connection to the performance of their duties as an MEP, then it decides to waive immunity, so that court proceedings in the national Member State can be brought or continue. On this basis, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Justice of the European Union has ruled that a declaration made by a Member outside the classrooms of the European Parliament may constitute an opinion expressed in the performance of his parliamentary duties in accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, giving importance to the nature and content of the declaration.  However, the link between the opinion expressed by the Member and the parliamentary functions must be direct and must be clearly established. Since the statements referred to were made by Gabriele Albertini as Mayor, I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Andrzej Duda.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. Another attack by the European Parliament on freedom of expression.  Mr. Albertini only gave his opinion on the state of the judicial system in Lombardy and was accused of defamation for expressing doubts about the integrity and professional ethics of the prosecutor Alfredo Robledo, who was investigating facts involving the municipality of Milan and relating to the duties of mayor that Mr. Albertini held in 2005. I do not see why, having used his right to free expression and free opinion, Mr Albertini should lose his parliamentary immunity and his privileges as a Member of Parliament. So I voted against this report.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The text under discussion sets out the European Parliament's reasons for Gabriele Albertini's request for the defence of immunity.  Among the lines of the documentation you can note the reason for this request: with a w.D. on October 12, 2012, Gabriele Albertini was invited to appear before the Court of Brescia by Alfredo Robledo regarding the statements made by Gabriele Albertini in an initial interview published by the newspaper "Il Sole 24 Ore" on October 26, 2011 and in a second interview published by the newspaper "Corriere della Sera" on February 19, 2012. These statements offended the good repute of the magistrate who was leading the investigation at the time.  The statements related to the office of Mayor of Albertini, not to his position as a Member of the European Parliament. Furthermore, there is no reason to suppose that there is a fumus persecutionis. The committee therefore decided not to defend the immunity of Gabriele Albertini. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The determining criterion for the enjoyment of immunity under Article 8 of Protocol No 7 is evidence of a direct and obvious link between the opinions in question and the performance of parliamentary duties. No evidence of such a link has been provided in the case in point. I have thus voted in favour of the report.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the parliamentary immunity of former MEP Gabriele Albertini. Given that the matter on which he is to be judged has nothing to do with his role while he was an MEP, I voted in favour.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I am therefore opposed to parliamentary privileges and in particular to parliamentary immunity. Everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 A former Member of the European Parliament, Gabriele Albertini, requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before an Italian Court for the allegedly defamatory nature of the views expressed by Gabriele Albertini in a written question to the Italian Minister of Justice, with a view to determining whether the conduct of Alfredo Robledo, a prosecutor who opened an investigation into facts involving the municipality of Milan and related to the functions of Gabriele Albertini , in his capacity as Mayor of that city in 2005, constituted a violation of professional ethics, which could therefore be subject to disciplinary proceedings. Parliament took the view that the facts of the case, and in accordance with Gabriele Albertini's oral explanation to the Committee on Legal Affairs, indicate that the statements made do not have a direct and obvious link with the performance of Gabriele Albertini's duties as a Member of the European Parliament and therefore decided not to defend Gabriele Albertini's immunity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted against the request for non-defence of privileges, because I consider it primarily a matter of defending freedom of expression.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against Gabriele Albertini's application for defence of the privileges and immunities. I am against parliamentary privileges and, in particular, parliamentary immunity, because everyone is equal in the face of the law.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report. Gabriele Albertini is a former EP member of the EPP. We understand that the Minister of Justice is tried for defamation, that they are confirmed and that he was not acting as an MEP; therefore there is no problem in revoking immunity.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on Gabriele Albertini's request for protection of privileges and immunity confirming previous decisions not to protect his immunity and privileges. In that case, there is no evidence of a direct and obvious link between the opinion expressed and the performance of parliamentary duties which would allow the use of immunity in accordance with Article 8 of the Regulation. protocol on the privileges and immunies of the European Union.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Gabriele Albertini is accused of defaming a prosecutor by accusing him of using brutal and arbitrary methods contrary to democratic principles. Mr. Albertini appears to be the subject of a political cabal after his statements against his accuser, prosecutor Alfredo Robledo. Indeed, the prosecutor had heard a case of "amendments without content" over a period of more than seven years, only to conclude that everyone would be acquitted. There is therefore a personal dispute between the two men and it seems that this request to waive parliamentary immunity is politically motivated in order to damage Mr Albertini's image. All the more so since his comments were not scandalous and fall under the most basic freedom of expression. Finally, the prosecutor was eventually suspended from office after this new case, which supports Mr. Albertini's comments that the prosecutor is abusing his duties to settle a personal matter. So I voted against it.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. It is Parliament's practice that the level of absolute immunity cannot cover all aspects of legal proceedings. The case law of the European Court of Justice is not entirely clear here. However, the recommendation of the committee responsible provides a clear and scientific and careful consideration as to why immunity should not be protected in this case. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against it because he is a grievance of this Member of Parliament for defaming a prosecutor by accusing him of using brutal and arbitrary methods. But the prosecutor was subsequently suspended from office, a sign that the MP's charge may have been well founded.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I vote in defence of Gabriele Albertini's privileges and immunities, in the name of defending freedom of expression.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the waiver of Gabriele Albertini's parliamentary immunity following the positive recommendation of the Committee on Legal Affairs of the European Parliament.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am not in favour of the report on not defending the immunity and privileges of Gabriele Albertini and not following up his request for a review concerning the civil proceedings against him.  I am convinced, as a guarantor, that the existence of immunity serves an important purpose; That is why I shall always vote against such reports. This is an important prerequisite which must remain as a basis for similar cases. Freedom of expression must be and must remain protected in order to allow the proper performance of duties.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. Gabriele Albertini expressed allegedly defamatic views in a written question to the Italian Minister of Justice during his time as mayor. Since there is no evidence of a direct and unequivocal link between the statements in question and the exercise of the parliamentary mandate, I agreed with this request.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The request concerns the defence of the parliamentary immunity of a former Italian MEP: Gabriele Albertini. In 2010, when he was mayor of Milan and the subject of investigations, he said that the prosecutor of the Republic of Milan had "gestapist methods". He has since reiterated his remarks by targeting all Italian courts and prosecutors. Considering that the new case had nothing to do with his position as a Member of Parliament and that he was not in office at the time, the report proposes the lifting of his immunity. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties. This request is made by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Supreme Court of Justice of Greece who requested the waiver of the immunity of Theodoros Zagorakis, a Member of the European Parliament, in the context of a possible conviction for an alleged offence. A former Member of the European Parliament, Gabriele Albertini, requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before an Italian Court, and who, moreover, requested the review of the request for the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the civil action pending before the same Court. It has been proven twice that the actions taken by Gabriele Albertini were not directly related to her activity as a Member of the European Parliament. I therefore voted in favour of the lifting of your parliamentary immunity

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on the basis of decisions taken earlier, in particular in May 2013 and February 2014, does not advocate the maintenance of the immunity and privileges of a former Member of Parliament, since it considers that the person concerned was not acting in the performance of his duties as a Member.  I'm in favor of approving it.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. I voted against this report. It is a text that weakens freedom of expression and advocates not to defend immunity.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to approve the report on Gabriele Albertini's request for the protection of the privileges and immunity of the privileges and immunity in accordance with the decision adopted in the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas a former Member of the European Parliament, Gabriele Albertini, has called for the defence of his parliamentary immunity in criminal proceedings pending before an Italian court; that Gabriele Albertini has also requested a review of his request for the defence of immunity in civil proceedings pending before the same court; that the request to defend immunity concerns the alleged defamatory opinions expressed by Gabriele Albertini in a complaint presented to minister Guardasigilli italiano, on 22 October 2012, aimed at ascertaining whether in the activity of Alfredo Robledo, the prosecutor who had launched an investigation relating to facts dating back to 2005 in which the City of Milan was involved and concerning the functions of mayor of that city exercised by Gabriele Albertini , disciplinaryly recensorable conduct from the point of view of professional ethics; it is confirmed, respectively, that it does not defend the immunity and privileges of Gabriele Albertini and that it does not follow up its request for a review of the civil proceedings against him; it is decided, on the same grounds, not to defend the privileges and immunities of Gabriele Albertini in the criminal proceedings against him. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I respect the rapporteur's recommendation regarding the retention of immunity to my colleague Albertini. The current case, in any event, was brought because of the opinion expressed by the Member and, in that context, the key criterion for the possibility of using immunity in accordance with Article 8 of that Protocol is evidence of a direct and obvious link between the opinions at issue and the performance of parliamentary duties.  Also, since the doctrine of fumus persecutionis — i.e. sufficiently serious and accurate suspicions that the case has been referred to the court with the intention of causing political harm to the member concerned — applies only to cases of immunity covered by Article 9(1) of the EEA). protocol, i.e. judicial proceedings relating to offences which do not belong to those offences committed by expressed opinions or votes cast pursuant to Article 8, paragraph 6 of that Protocol and in view of the fact that Mr Albertini is a former Member of the European Parliament , Article 9 no longer applies to this case.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported MEP Andrzej Duda's report on a request to protect the privileges and immunity of former MEP Gabriele Albertini. Parliamentary immunity is a remedy that protects the smooth functioning of Members and thus constitutes a necessary means of protecting parliament's independence. In order to be credible, it is important that parliamentary immunity is solely an instrument of protection against politically motivated persecution. In the case of Representative Gabriele Albertini, the Committee on Legal Affairs found that it was not a prosecution brought with the intention of causing political damage to a Member. The case was brought because of an opinion expressed by a Member but in this context a key criterion for the possibility of using immunity must be evidence of a direct and obvious link between the opinions expressed and the performance of parliamentary duties. Evidence of such a link in this case has not been provided, which Parliament has already stated twice before. Given that it has been established for the third time that the initiated proceedings have nothing to do with gabriele albertini's performance as an MEP, I agree with the Decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs which does not protect privileges and immunity, as the remedy for the protection of citizens' representatives at EU level must not place Members above the law.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. A former Member of the European Parliament, Gabriele Albertini, requested the defence of his parliamentary immunity on 16 September 2014 in the context of the criminal proceedings pending before the Court of Brescia (Italy) and, moreover, requested a review of the request for the defence of his parliamentary immunity in the context of the civil action pending before the same Court. According to the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, the supporting documents submitted by Gabriele Albertini did not make clear the relationship between her statements and her duties as a Member of the European Parliament, and when making the statements in question, she was not acting in the performance of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In the opinion of that report, I voted in favour of this Decision, which maintains the decisions of 21 May 2013 and 24 February 2014 of the European Parliament, not to defend gabriele albertini's immunity and privileges and not to follow up on her request for review with regard to the civil action brought against him.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing.
