I voted in favour of not underccouring Gabrielle Albertini's immunity from the claim in view of the new information provided not establishing the direct and manifest relationship between the views by which an Italian court opened investigative measures and the exercise of parliamentary functions. The conclusion reached twice by Parliament to the conclusion that Gabriele Albertini did not exercise his duties as a Member of the European Parliament in making the declarations in question must therefore be ratified, which is why his immunity was lifted.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Gabriele Albertini's immunity, so that the Italian justice system could do its job, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, considering that the alleged offence has no direct or obvious link to the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament. The proceedings relate to statements made by Mr Albertini when he was an MEP, but are not part of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 With regard to the request for the defence of privileges and immunities made by Mr Albertini, which has been reviewed, I agree with the coherent argumentative line of the Committee on Legal Affairs to reject that claim. As is evidenced, the facts do not subdue any of the legal provisions of the Protocol and the Rules of Procedure in this regard and there is no direct and obvious causal link between the statements made by it and its performance in the exercise of the duties of a Member of the European Parliament.  As such, I consider it undefensible to accept his claim to defend his privileges and immunities.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the former MEP's parliamentary immunity from PE Gabriele Albertini. Given that the matter on which he is to be tried has nothing to do with his role while he was a MEP, I voted in favour.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the request for defence of the privileges and immunities of Gabriele Albertini. The case arises from opinions expressed by the Member. The determining criterion for the enjoyment of immunity under Article 8 of the Protocol is evidence of a direct and obvious link between the opinions in question and the performance of parliamentary duties. A direct and obvious link has not been provided and the Parliament has previously endorsed that Mr Albertini was not acting in the performance of his duties as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Former MEP Gabriele Albertini has applied for protection of his parliamentary immunity in relation to criminal proceedings and civil proceedings before an Italian court. Proceedings are being conducted in relation to Mr Albertini's alleged defamatory views and statements about Alfredo Robledo, the prosecutor who launched the investigation into a case involving the municipality of the city of Milan and to which Albertini himself associated himself.  Since Mr Albertini did not make the statements at issue as a Member of the European Parliament, I supported the committee's position not to protect Gabriele Albertini's privileges and immunity in relation to the criminal proceedings brought against him.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I agree with the Decision of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which decides not to protect Gabriele Albertini's privileges and immunity with regard to the criminal proceedings brought against him.  It is known that as early as 21 May 2013 and 24 February 2014, The European Parliament decided to lift Gabriel Albertini's immunity and privileges because of defamatory views expressed by Mr Albertini towards prosecutor Alfred Robledo in an Italian newspaper. Since, even on the basis of the documents subsequently submitted by Mr Albertini, it is not possible to dispel doubts, I consider it right to stand by Parliament's previous decision and not to grant Albertini's request for reconsideration concerning the civil proceedings brought against him.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 MEPs should be held to account in court when the need to investigate their activities is required, in accordance with existing legal procedures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report. Gabriele Albertini is a former EP member of the PPE Group. We understand that the Minister of Justice is tried for defamation, that they are confirmed and that he was not acting as an MEP; therefore there is no problem in revoking immunity.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of lifting immunity, considering that the charges have no relation to the development of their parliamentary activity.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The report calls for the suspension of the former MEP's parliamentary immunity from PE Gabriele Albertini. Given that the matter on which he is to be tried has nothing to do with his role while he was a MEP, I voted in favour.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence request relates to the allegedly defamatory nature of the views expressed by Gabriele Albertini in a written question to the Italian Minister for Justice on 22 October 2012. The request for review relates to a summons, lodged against Gabriele Albertini at the Court of Milan by Alfredo Robledo, relating to allegedly defamatory statements made by Gabriele Albertini in a first interview published by the Italian newspaper. There is no evidence in the present case that Gabriele Albertini, in making the statements in question, was not acting in the performance of her duties as a Member of the European Parliament. In this sense, gabriele Albertini's immunity and privileges are not defensible with regard to the civil action brought against him.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Gabriele Albertini expressed allegedly defamatic views in a written question to the Italian Minister of Justice during his time as mayor. Since there is no evidence of a direct and unequivocal link between the statements in question and the exercise of the parliamentary mandate, I agreed with this request.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. ‒ We will support the requests for waiver of immunities as in these reports. We are in favour of legal equality, the principle under which all people are subject to the same laws of justice – the fact that everyone must be treated equally under the law.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I will only briefly justify my vote on ukraine's macroeconomic assistance.  I very much welcomed the fact that, in addition to the political assistance to Ukraine that we declare here in Parliament's deliberations, we have today also adopted specific macro-financial support in the form of EUR 1.8 billion as a medium-term loan. I believe that if we want Ukraine to go down the path of democratisation, the development of the rule of law and the market economy in the long term, it is necessary to support this country not only politically but also economically. It is necessary to get this country back on its feet, just as America helped Western Europe after World War II. That is why I supported this proposal, and I hope that we will also consider other forms of support in the future. This support must be linked to the terms of further reforms in Ukraine, so that the money that will be given to Ukraine as loans does not end up in the pockets of the oligarchs, but really helped the country.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Zoltán Balczó and my colleague and friend were very concerned about how to vote on this issue. After all, we were in an even more difficult situation than most of our fellow Members, because we had to vote as Hungarians on whether the European Union should give support and financial support to the Ukrainian Government, which we know is not in the best interests of hungarians in Carpathia in particular. At the same time, as Hungarians, we also know that Hungarians in Transcarpathia are going through inhumane suffering. On the one hand, because of so-called military obligations, this is not their war, yet their sons must be sacrificed to their husbands.  On the other hand, due to inhumane social conditions and poverty, we are practically at the stage where there are African third-world income conditions. We used to say about Africa and the so-called developing countries, that people have to make a life out of one euro a day. Now there are salaries and pensions – around EUR 30 a month – something needs to be done about this.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ukraine needs the union's support. However, the financial support that parliament has now voted for is not for the real, real purpose. It will be spent entirely on the IMF's reform programme. At the same time, there is a social crisis in Ukraine. This would be the main focus of EU aid. These amendments were voted down by a majority.  Stabilising Ukraine would require peace first and foremost. The ceasefire is important, the end of the bloodshed, but it does not bring lasting peace. True peace and stability should take into account the fair interests of all parties involved, including the right of indigenous peoples to self-determination.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will serve as support and impetus to Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process, accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Macro-financial assistance is an exceptional tool in reaction to the crises that the EU makes available to its partner countries with serious payment problems. This report proposes to provide Ukraine with financial support of EUR 1.8 billion, taking into account that this is in addition to the funds previously given to them by both the EU and the IMF or the World Bank. Since this aid is conditional on respect for certain requirements such as the implementation of structural reforms in the economic field (privatizations, deregulations) as in the political sphere, I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. –    It is clear that Ukraine is facing a deteriorating humanitarian crisis and it is widely recognised that ongoing conflict there has caused this situation to become progressively worse. In this context it is disappointing that the Commission proposal does not include a proposal for a political agreement for a peaceful resolution of the conflict. Furthermore, the Macro-Financial Assistance of EUR 1.8 billion proposed by the Commission is tied to austerity through Macro-economic adjustments and structural ‘reform’.  The proposal does not say how such structural ‘reform’ will improve the economy of Ukraine, or how it will impact on its people, as it currently endures a conflict that has seen approximately 1.2 million of its citizens internally displaced. Sinn Féin welcomes efforts to assist Ukraine in dealing with its humanitarian situation. Indeed I voted in favour of amendments improving the Commission proposal. However, given that the proposal is fundamentally based on a flawed austerity model, which I believe will not improve the humanitarian situation for the people of Ukraine, I abstained on the overall legislative resolution.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Commission's proposal on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, as I consider it our duty to help Ukraine financially cope with the deep recession, the sharp devaluation of its currency and the depletion of its foreign exchange reserves. At the same time, the Ukrainian Government has pledged to proceed with the necessary reforms contained in the Association Agreement with the European Union aimed at strengthening the rule of law and the multi-party parliamentary system as well as ensuring respect for human rights.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This macro-financial assistance in the form of a EUR 1.8 billion loan is subject to political and financial conditions. It is justified by the european neighbourhood policy and the European neighbourhood policy, which aim at opening up markets and liberalising the National Front. These imposed conditions constitute a real interference in Ukraine's policy and run counter to its sovereignty. In addition, the purpose of these funds and how they will be used is uncertain. While it is essential to ensure peaceful relations with neighbouring states, as well as fundamental freedoms and the proper management of allocated funds, under no circumstances should financial aid be provided in return for economic and financial transformations that meet the ambitions of the European Union and oppose Ukraine's interests. So I voted against the text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I supported most of the amendments, which sought to introduce checks and balances to any financial assistance to Ukraine. I do not believe that British taxpayers’ money should be spent on providing assistance to Ukraine, or on an interventionist foreign policy, particularly in such a complex area. Therefore, I felt it necessary to vote against the final resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to allocate EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine. A medium-term loan to help the country deal with the economic downturn. This macro-financial assistance would complement the support provided by other donors under the economic programme financed by the International Monetary Fund. Ukraine's economy is facing a severe crisis caused by long-term structural problems and exacerbated by the armed conflict with Russia. Macro-financial assistance is the EU's exceptional crisis response mechanism, which is open to EU partner countries facing major balance of payments problems. This assistance should also lead to a gradual recovery of confidence and support the reforms undertaken in the country, while implementing a policy framework to be agreed with the Ukrainian authorities.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I voted against this report from a Lithuanian Member of Parliament who, like too many Members of the Baltics, seems above all to revive the cold war against Russia. Apart from the fact that the required counterparties are a right of interference which I dispute with the European Union, I do not believe that it is responsible for paying 1.8 billion "macro-financial aid" to a country plunged into a terrible civil war... that the United States and the European Union have otherwise provoked at least encouraged. Do the Commission and Parliament once again want to throw oil on the fire and take the risk of financing Ukraine's armament when the fragile Minsk 2 agreements have just been signed? The priority is to ensure Kiev's willingness to respect the Minsk agreements in order to find the path to peace.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. Europe is only credible when, as in this case, it is consequential. Ukraine faces an exceptional situation, perhaps never seen before in the European framework. Its internal problems of poor governance, corruption and instability are joined by external aggression, Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea, and the economic and financial losses caused by that state of laved war and occupation. Ukraine is also outside international debt markets. I also believe in the two effects that this initiative can have. Encourage new donors and promote other "creative" financial pathways, as the report says, to stimulate good governance, the fight against fraud and corruption.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I objected to this report. At a time when Ukraine is in the grip of economic chaos, the European Union is considering coming to its rescue. But above all, it must be remembered that it is precisely the European Union, which, through a zealous Atlanticism, has helped to throw oil on the fire by supporting the real coup d'état that took place in Ukraine. The result is clear, the union's unconditional Russophobia, driven by a grime misunderstanding of the geography of a country cut in half, has led to economic disaster: rampant inflation (28.5%), deep recession, probability of default close to 100%, central bank's key rate at 30%, despite joint imf and EU aid. The Commission, with the approval of Parliament, has decided to grant 1.8 billion euros to Ukraine, and this, quickly, while at the same time it refuses for the moment any new aid to Tsipras's Greece...

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the Landsbergis report analysing macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. This European Union finds itself generous and out of pocket to provide EUR 1.8 billion in the form of a loan; It is a pity that when it comes to supporting our businesses that are closing because of the crisis, helping our citizens without a job, supporting Italy in the immigration emergency or in the fight against terrorism, Europe disappears.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. Ukraine is in a deep crisis and is in dire need of rapid financial support in order not to completely collapse.  At the same time, I would like to stress that, unfortunately, several positive amendments by the GUE/NGL Group were voted down in plenary. The amendments underlined that the reform agenda in Ukraine could not only be about economic structural reforms, but must also have a social dimension that ensures the basic needs of its citizens. In addition, amendments by the GUE/NGL linked the importance of seeking a peaceful solution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine were linked to the issue of financial assistance. Let me state that it is in clear violation of international law that Russia has annexed Crimea. For this there are no excuses or extenuating circumstances, but violence and war will not resolve this conflict. The UN has stressed the need for a de-escalation of threats and a de-escalation of political language in order to create an environment in which a political process can be started to resolve the conflict. I therefore believe that the European Union should have taken advantage of this opportunity to link financial support to a consistent effort for a peaceful solution.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supports the Commission's proposal to allocate EUR 1.8 billion to the European Union. EU support to Ukraine for a more sustainable balance of payments. The ability of the Ukrainian authorities to carry out the necessary reforms in the country is greatly hampered by armed conflict in the East, the increasing restrictions on trade imposed by Russia and the escalation of the dispute between the two parties over natural gas. The conflict in the East and the crisis of confidence have led to a sharp depreciation of export revenues in the local currency and the loss of international reserves. At present, Ukraine does not have access to international debt markets and this is unlikely to change in the near future. As a result, there has been a significant additional shortage of external financing. The EU's assistance will thus help Ukraine to overcome the economic and social difficulties caused by the country and the region. It will promote structural reforms to increase sustainable economic growth and improve public finance management.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Due to Ukraine's protracted economic and structural problems, I believe that it has submitted an informed request to the Commission for EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance. For the sake of European orientation, Ukraine is in a serious domestic political crisis, a difficult economic situation and, foreign policy, a protracted military conflict that has taken many human casualties. The war in eastern Ukraine, trade restrictions on Russia's part and the heli rise in the natural gas dispute mean price increases, unfulfiable tax burdens and utility prices for the already weak Ukrainian economy. This has led to an economic downturn, a currency devaluation and a reduction in international reserves, resulting in a significant external financing gap for 2015.  The European Union must therefore make swift and effective efforts to restore and preserve the stability of the country. We need an economically stable, developing Ukraine, where people do not suffer and adequate living conditions are ensured. Macro-financial assistance is intended to contribute economically and financially to address serious problems such as a weak balance of payments and a budgetary situation. I voted in favour of the adoption of this proposal so that we can express our solidarity with a country and people at war with a nuclear power. At the same time, the European Parliament and the Council can bear witness to the Union's ability to act quickly, decisively and in accordance with its political commitments.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Ukraine's economy and finances are in extremely bad shape due to the wartime conflicts in the east of the country and Russia's annexation of Crimea. But the fact is that the economic crisis is partly the result of corruption and non-implementation of reforms from the period before the war conflicts. It is necessary to avoid the economic collapse of the country and therefore I support the provision of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. In addition to helping a country facing aggression, the European Union is in some way obliged to help to show that it is capable of acting quickly and fulfilling its political obligations.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This text aims to provide macro-financial aid to Ukraine amounting to EUR 1.8 billion. Various agreements have been signed with the country, including those on 21 March and 27 June 2014, by which the European Union and Ukraine signed an association agreement. Caution should be urged, given the geopolitical context of the region, when the stated objective is to "establish a thorough political association and economic integration between the Union and Ukraine". During the "orange revolution", attentive observers had already noted the presence of foreign advisers and suspicious movements of funds. This interference in a country's internal affairs is unacceptable. The power currently in place in Kiev has been installed under dubious constitutional conditions, in violation of an agreement guaranteed by different powers. One may wonder about the personality of some Ukrainian officials. In addition, there are "fundamental weaknesses accumulated over the years by the Ukrainian economy". Will the prevention of aid in matters, in particular, of the management of public finances, the fight against corruption or better tax administration, be enough to encourage the Kiev authorities to think healthier? So I voted against this financial aid to Ukraine.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, since I maintain that we should not be so hasty in allowing this assistance to Ukraine. Personally I consider that Ukraine needs all our help and support considering the complicated situation in the country, but I think the country should first show the commitment to make important and necessary reforms in order to get financial help from other countries.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am strongly opposed to a measure which allocates the exorbitant sum of EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine in the form of loans. In practice, there are no guarantees that Kiev can provide regarding the return of the sum, respect for human rights and how the sum will be spent.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine.  The continuing armed conflict in eastern Ukraine and russia's severe trade restrictions have further exacerbated the severe economic recession and the flight of capital that is bringing the country to its knees. The European Commission's proposal to grant an additional EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is therefore to be welcomed. Furthermore, in view of the extremely difficult situation in the country at the moment, I think it is absolutely important that the proposal is adopted in good time in order to allow at least two of the three tranches to be disbursed as early as 2015. Rapid adoption of the proposal would also demonstrate that the European Union is capable of acting quickly, decisively and consistent with its political commitments.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that Ukraine is facing a deteriorating humanitarian crisis and it is widely recognised that ongoing conflict there has caused this situation to become progressively worse. In this context it is disappointing that the Commission proposal does not include a proposal for a political agreement for a peaceful resolution of the conflict. Furthermore, the Macro-Financial Assistance of EUR 1.8 billion proposed by the Commission is tied to austerity through Macro-economic adjustments and structural ‘reform’. The proposal does not say how such structural ‘reform’ will improve the economy of Ukraine, or how it will impact on its people, as it currently endures a conflict that has seen approximately 1.2 million of its citizens internally displaced. Sinn Féin welcomes efforts to assist Ukraine in dealing with its humanitarian situation. Indeed I voted in favour of amendments improving the Commission proposal. However, given that the proposal is fundamentally based on a flawed austerity model, which I believe will not improve the humanitarian situation for the people of Ukraine, I abstained on the overall legislative resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the instrument of intervention and aid identified is not the best one to solve Ukraine's problems. The country's high debt situation originates in the civil war that bloods it and the Intervention of the Union as it was designed would in fact lead to the imposition of austerity measures on the population.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that approves EUR 1.8 billion worth of financial assistance to the Ukraine. This is an important continuation of the support that Europe has offered Ukraine during these difficult times, and I hope that this loan will further help to stabilise Ukraine's economy.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I obviously voted against this report, which I had already strongly opposed in its discussion and vote in the Committee on International Trade. At a time when Ukraine is plunged into the chaos of a civil war — caused by the refusal of the European Union and the United States to take into account the democratically and sovereignly decided annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol to the Russian Federation — the european Parliament's only solution, supporting the Commission, is to inject an additional EUR 1.8 billion into the Ukrainian economy, as if geopolitical instability could be resolved with large euro-dollars. This money, as everyone knows, will unfortunately be more used to continue financing the war than to a utopian economic, political and social development, unthinkable under the current conditions. Until Ukraine embarks on the path to peace, the money the Union will pay it will continue to fund death.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 This measure provides for macro-financial assistance (MFA) to the State of Ukraine. This sustenance is an exceptional EU crisis response mechanism, offered to EU partner countries facing serious balance-of-payments problems.  The Commission's request to grant an additional EUR 1.8 billion called for the development of a major assistance plan for the country. However, it should be remembered that the State of Ukraine is going through a very difficult period due to the continuing armed conflict in the eastern regions. This measure is important and noble, and for all the reasons set out in the document, I thought I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because this measure is part of a series of interventions aimed at dealing with a deep economic recession in the country, exacerbated by the armed conflict in the south-east of the country.  I agree with this type of exceptional crisis response assistance, because it is offered in order to help the Union's partner countries deal with serious balance-of-payments problems. Furthermore, in view of the extremely difficult situation in Ukraine at the moment, I believe that the Commission's proposal on ukraine's macro-financial assistance is approved in good time, in order to allow two of the three tranches (EUR 600 million each) to be disbursed during 2015.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EUR 1.8 billion macro-financial assistance proposed by the Commission, aimed both at reducing balance-of-payments imbalances and at supporting reform programmes in many strategic areas for Ukraine.  The situation of deep political and economic crisis in the country and forcing people to live in a climate of uncertainty and hardship cannot be ignored by the European Union.   In view of recent geopolitical developments and an economic recession that has exceeded the already negative forecasts, it is considered appropriate to intervene with this new tranche of aid to the Ukrainian State. The money granted, in the form of a medium-term loan, will finance, in part, the economic programme drawn up by the International Monetary Fund, which guarantees reliability and fairness.  The hope is that the funding allocated by the European Union will help bring relief to the Ukrainian people and raise the fortunes of a neighbouring state with which the Eu ropean Union has long established a relationship of friendship and trade.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The economy in Ukraine is experiencing a deep crisis which is being aggravated by the armed conflict in the eastern part of the country. The macro-financial assistance (MFA) proposed by the Commission is an exceptional EU crisis-response mechanism available to the EU’s partner countries experiencing acute balance of payment problems. The MFA will contribute to the EU objectives of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine. I have thus voted in favour to reaffirm the long-standing commitment of the European Parliament as well as of the European Union to the reform process of Ukraine.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the macro-financial assistance plan to Ukraine because I do not agree with it and because I do not think it is the right instrument to solve the problems facing the country. Ukraine is torn apart by the debts caused by the civil war. The war will last until the EU understands that a substantial part of the Ukrainian people have no intention of accepting either the EU or its political, economic and social model. The EU wants to impose austerity on Ukraine in practice. This approach runs counter to the real interests of the Ukrainian people.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Macro-financial assistance is an exceptional tool in reaction to the crises that the EU makes available to its partner countries with serious payment problems. This report proposes to provide Ukraine with financial support of EUR 1.8 billion, taking into account that this is in addition to the funds previously given to them by both the EU and the IMF or the World Bank. Since this aid is conditional on respect for certain requirements such as the implementation of structural reforms in the economic field (privatizations, deregulations) as in the political sphere, I voted against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote confirms what this Parliament has already said on several occasions, namely the need to support Ukraine in different forms and ways in its process of democratic stabilisation and economic reforms. The granting of economic support in this respect must be combined with the development and implementation of an important medium-term plan setting out the stages and objectives to be achieved.  The country's shortcomings and poverty squeath enormously in relation to potential and wealth and find the only plausible explanation in the absence of structural reforms. The European Union's support must therefore be directed in this direction, always bearing in mind the difficulties generated to the economy and political institutions by the precarious state generated by Russian aggression in the East.  As has been pointed out, the Union and the Member States should work hard, and beyond financial assistance, to contribute in all possible forms to inclusive and sustainable growth and development for the whole population. Starting with the launch of an incisive monitoring system on the use of the resources allocated, to avoid dispersing them or using them badly.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. ‒ The economy of Ukraine is experiencing an unprecedented crisis. The reform efforts of the new executive to address pressing challenges have been neutralised by the protracted armed conflict in the eastern regions of the country and the illegal annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation. The overall climate has triggered a negative spiral with economic recession, capital flight, sharp depreciation of the currency, depletion of international reserves and loss of access to international debt markets being only some, and significantly not all, of the devastating consequences. Macro-financial assistance represents one of the EU crisis-response mechanisms available to partner countries suffering from exceptional economic circumstances. The additional EUR 1.8 billion to be made available to Ukraine, as proposed by the Commission, will serve a number of strategic objectives by providing direct relief, by harnessing contributions of other partners, by signalling political encouragement and support to the reform efforts undertaken by the authorities and by strengthening reform commitments through conditionality. In this sense, timely assistance for Ukraine will create a virtuous circle contributing to the overall stability of the country.  The European Parliament has consistently expressed its support for assisting Ukraine and will continue to do so by adopting this proposal.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute crisis, rooted in long-standing structural problems and aggravated by the conflict with Russia and the loss of the Crimea region. Ukraine’s reform efforts have been complicated by the continued armed conflict, trade restrictions from Russia and the escalation of a natural gas dispute between the two countries. As a result, economic recession and capital flight have been more severe than expected, resulting in a sharp depreciation of the currency and a depletion of international reserves. While calling for the relevant EU authorities to monitor Ukraine’s economic performance and budget, I cannot but support this aid to Ukraine, so I voted in favour of granting the assistance subject to Ukraine respecting effective democratic mechanisms and the rule of law and guaranteeing respect for human rights.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. This speech reaffirms the long-running commitment of the European Parliament and the European Union to the process of reform that this young democracy is undertaking.  Ukraine's economy is now experiencing a deep recession due to macroeconomic imbalances and long-term structural problems, aggravated by the armed conflict that has broken out in the east of the country. In recent months, the Union has repeatedly expressed its commitment to helping the new Ukrainian authorities in their efforts to stabilise the country and to continue along the path of reform. In this direction, it urges the Group of European Socialists and Democrats to support the country's authorities in a tangible way and to confirm the EU's willingness to support neighbouring countries that undertake structural reforms in times of economic and political difficulty.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to provide financial assistance to Ukraine of EUR 1.8 billion in the form of medium-term loans, with a view to covering its residual external financing needs for the period 2015-2016 and to facilitate the stabilization of its economy. The aid also involves the implementation of a national reform strategy, relating to some of the weaknesses of its economy, notably in the management of public finances, the fight against corruption, the functioning of the tax administration and the business environment. Considering that it is necessary to respond credibly and strongly to the clear European choice, which Ukraine made in the last parliamentary elections last October, to strengthen ties with the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this vote, the European Parliament wants to grant Ukraine macro-financial aid of 1.8 billion euros in order to stabilise its economy and undertake an ambitious programme of reforms. The already fragile economic situation in Ukraine has been undermined by the armed conflict on its territory. I have therefore supported the granting of macro-financial aid from the European Union in order to help Ukraine, the Union's neighbour and partner, to carry out its reform programme and to revitalise its foreign trade. However, the European Commission will have to ensure that these funds are allocated properly.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 Macro-financial assistance (MFA) is an exceptional EU crisis response mechanism, offered to EU partner countries facing serious balance of payments problems. I voted in favour of a further additional MFA package in favour of Ukraine, because it will contribute to the pursuit of the EU's objectives of promoting economic stability and the development of the Ukrainian state. The new programme will also strengthen the economic reform commitments made by the Ukrainian Government and signal that the EU is ready to support all those countries that undertake important reforms at times of great economic and political difficulty.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. In Ukraine, the economic crisis has been greatly exacerbated by the armed conflict in the east of the country but also by the trade restrictions imposed by Russia, in particular the gas conflict between the two countries. As a result, Ukraine can no longer access international bond markets to finance itself. It is therefore important for the European Union to act in support. That is why I welcome the support of the new European financial aid plan for Ukraine, in particular the payment of a LOAN of EUR 1.8 billion over 15 years to fill the ukrainian balance of payments deficit. In return, the Ukrainian government will have to undertake a programme of reforms aimed at addressing fundamental weaknesses in its economy and governance. The draft Memorandum of Understanding includes a series of reforms: public finance management reforms, anti-corruption measures, reforms in the tax administration and in the energy and financial sectors.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that with the macro-financial support provided to Ukraine supported in today's vote, we have shown that we will not abandon the Ukrainian people and help our eastern neighbour. The Ukrainian people are not only exposed to the problems caused by the war, but also to economic problems. The uncontrollable rise in inflation has been causing difficulties in people's daily lives in recent times – wages in stores are multiplying from morning to night. The Ukrainian economy is on the brink of bankruptcy and it is in the Union's interest not to do so. By adopting macrofinancing assistance, the European Union contributes to the economic stability and development of Ukraine and at the same time to the wider Eastern European neighbourhood. In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more important from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting this report, fidesz MEPs from the European People's Party will help to improve the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the plan to provide 1.8 billion euros in medium-term loans to help Ukraine emerge from the economic recession. This plan must complement other international aid, such as the IMF's. The major economic difficulties facing Ukraine stem from a number of structural flaws but have been exacerbated by armed conflicts in the east of the country, trade restrictions imposed by Russia and the escalation of the natural gas supply conflict between Russia and Ukraine. A number of factors (such as the economic recession and capital flight in Ukraine) have contributed to a worsening of the country's situation, leading to a sharp depreciation of its currency (-60% in one year), high inflation (28.5%) depletion of its reserves and the loss of the country's access to international bond markets. Although the European Union has already provided unprecedented financial support to Ukraine, it was essential to vote for this new aid to help the country avoid bankruptcy. This aid is not unconditional: to benefit from it, Kiev will have to meet a set of criteria for reform in terms of budget, banks, energy or the judicial system.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as financial aid to Ukraine is being promoted in order to hit Russia

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 By adopting macrofinancing assistance to Ukraine, the European Union contributes to the economic stability and development of Ukraine and at the same time to the wider Eastern European neighbourhood. In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more important from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting this report, fidesz MEPs from the European People's Party will help to improve the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in the context of the serious economic crisis it is experiencing, which swells from long-standing structural problems and aggravated by the armed conflict with the eastern regions and russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. An ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme underway is underway under pinpoint under the IMF's financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations, with the economic downturn and capital flight being more pronounced than originally anticipated. Assistance of €1.8 billion will contribute to the EU's objectives of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and the eastern region of the European Neighbourhood Policy. Through cross-compliance, the programme will also contribute to strengthening the Ukrainian Government's commitments to economic reforms and a sign that the EU is willing to support countries undergoing reforms in times of economic and political difficulties.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU proposes to provide an additional €1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in the form of medium-term loans to help the country cover part of its external financing needs in 2015 and early 2016 in the context of the IMF programme. Ukraine's reform efforts have been hampered by the persistence of the armed conflict in the east of the country, the increase in trade restrictions imposed by Russia and the escalating natural gas dispute between the two countries. The economic downturn and capital flight have been more pronounced than originally anticipated, resulting in a sharp depreciation of the currency and a decrease in international reserves.  As Ukraine has lost access to international markets it needs this assistance.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Yesterday's Association Treaty, today's macro-financial aid, demonstrates a deliberate willingness of the European Union not to seek solutions to appease the Ukrainian problem. European countries do not have to take the substitutes of the United States in their game of absolute confrontation with Russia. So I chose to vote against this deliberation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The Ukrainian economy needs help because it is severely affected by long-term structural problems due to the armed conflict that has led to a deep economic recession and significantly higher capital flight than originally foreseen. As Ukraine has lost access to international debt financing markets, only additional macro-financial assistance from the European Union can fill the external financing gap, as Ukraine will need capital to carry out all the reforms and stabilise the domestic political situation. On the one hand, a kind of commitment and readiness by the European Union to support countries embarking on a path of reform at a time of economic and polar difficulties is to be welcomed, but on the other hand it is very important that the European Union is able to sufficiently trace how the funds provided will be used, especially in Ukraine, which has a fundamental problem with corruption and clientelism. Therefore, if the European Union has embarked on a path of full support for Ukraine, it must show that it is willing and ready to help and that it can act quickly, responsibly and stand by its political and economic commitments.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against a measure that allocates the sum of EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine in the form of loans – without any guarantee that Ukraine, given the economic and political and social situation, will be able to repay the loan. In addition, however, the EU's blind vision of hostility to relations with Russia on the Ukraine issue is to be condemned.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against macro-financial assistance to Ukraine as financial assistance to Ukraine is promoted in order to secure the EU a rival awe towards Russia.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposed financial assistance to Ukraine. Europe must stand up to Russia and its aggression towards Ukraine. I fully support these measures as a means of solidarity with Ukraine and its people. The European Union, in this instance, can use its power to benefit its own and neighbouring citizens through this well-placed financial assistance.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I would like to use the following explanation of vote.  In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more important from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting the report on financial assistance to Ukraine, fidesz MEPs are helping to improve the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted today on ukraine's chances, as the Ukrainian economy is going through a serious crisis and is rooted in long-standing structural problems, exacerbated by the armed conflict in the eastern regions and the illegal Russian annexation of Crimea. Macro-financial assistance is a specific EU crisis management mechanism available to partner countries in the Union with acute balance of payments problems.  It is important to state that in Ukraine this is a struggle for freedom, a struggle that rejects dictatorship. The ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme of the government, which came to power in February 2014, was supported by the IMF's Financial Assistance Programme and the Union's macro-financial assistance operations. The current package can also be seen as a kind of reinforcement in the fight against corruption.  However, it is necessary to ensure that financial support is in the hands of the Ukrainian people and not the oligarchs, and that they should not be allowed to use this financial assistance for military purposes.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, meeting in plenary session, today approved new financial assistance to Ukraine of 1.8 billion in medium-term financing.  This contribution will be linked to Ukraine's implementation of certain reforms in areas such as energy, the judiciary, the fight against corruption and the protection of human rights. I voted in favour of this financial assistance measure, provided, however, that the Ukrainian authorities undertake to honour their commitments. In order to ensure that these promises are turned into concrete actions for the people involved, I will periodically monitor the implementation of reforms and the use of funds through questions to the European Commission. If the pacts are not respected, I will be ready to re-evaluate these measures.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The European Parliament once again expresses its solidarity and great closeness to the Ukrainian people. The tension and military escalation in russia's neighbouring provinces has reached unprecedented proportions, but no less concern is the extremely acute and serious conditions in which the economy of the whole country is in. In addition to long-standing structural problems, the situation is now exacerbated by the armed conflict in the eastern regions and russia's illegal annexation of Crimea.  The proposal for macro-financial assistance suggested by the Commission will receive full support from the European Parliament. This macro-financial support measure is an exceptional mechanism; I hope that it will be the precondition for an even greater cooperation programme to support the Ukrainian people and society.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ukrainian people have faced enormous suffering and have the right to enjoy the opportunity to redeem themselves from years of political and economic adversity.  I fully agree with Mr Landsbergis' report on a proposal by the European Parliament and the Council to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine.  The internal crisis in the country has been aggravated by the ongoing armed conflict in the eastern regions, russia's recent annexation of Crimea and, above all, the escalation of tension between the two countries over the supply of natural gas.  The European Parliament has always expressed its support in assisting Ukraine which, as an associate partner of the European Union, has the right to fully enjoy an important programme of structural reforms and financial assistance from the European Union.  I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal to increase macro-financial assistance to Ukraine by around EUR 1.8 billion in order to facilitate and support the country's reform process and accompany it towards achieving its economic objectives.  Macro-financial assistance in this respect is a particularly effective mechanism that can help restore confidence not only in the efforts of the Ukrainian authorities, but above all in the people who are suffering most from the effects of this tragic situation.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I fully support the macro financial assistance project for Ukraine and i am pleased with the result. The decision to provide €1.8 billion in aid to our eastern neighbour is the largest financial package ever given by the EU to any third country. However, this is not as important as the political message that comes with assistance from the Union.  Ukraine is poorly managed, needs reforms, poverty reduction, civil society building and, above all, the fight against corruption and oligarchic structures. Ukraine has already lost 25% of its economy and part of its territory, which is why it is so important for the country to have an association with the EU, so that it also has reasons for its reforms. By focusing on these areas, the EU is contributing to strengthening the Ukrainian Government's commitments to implement economic reforms. In this way, we also promote pro-European and pro-democracy forces, which will lead to strengthening and our security.  The question of time is extremely important here. Ukraine's most pressing needs are already this year and two of the three proposed tranches will be issued later this year, including the first before the holiday. The bankruptcy of Ukraine would mark the victory of the aggressor. Without help, the EU will not cope with historic challenges. Europe stands alongside Ukraine. We believe in its imminent stability.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, because the exceptional crisis in Ukraine requires us to respond immediately and take actions that are no longer deferred. The two tranches of EUR 600 million each that Ukraine will receive from Europe in 2015 will allow it to carry out the structural reforms necessary to allow the country's economy to start again. It is right that political and diplomatic commitments and efforts should be ed by concrete initiatives of economic assistance.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Commission proposal, which has to do with new financial assistance to Ukraine, which continues the line undertaken with the 1 trillion aid granted in 2014. We understand that aid in these conditions, without proper monitoring and without the previous work of normalizing the area can only bring more corruption, war and human rights violations, further aggravating the problem of Ukrainian debt as well as its economic dependence. The Commission's proposal, on the other hand, focuses only on economic aspects, without addressing, with the precision it deserves, the structural and political aspects of the Ukrainian affair.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report along with my Socialist colleagues to ensure that Ukraine can avail of much needed macro-financial assistance. The Ukrainian economy is experiencing several problems and if facing a serious crisis. The EU has consistently expressed its support for assisting Ukraine in its economic and political stabilisation and reforms and this financial assistance is an expression of solidarity with the Ukrainian people and of support for them as they move forward.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has signed an Association Agreement with Ukraine which clearly outlined on one side Ukraine's choice to turn the path of democracy, on the other hand, enshrined the EU's commitment to Supporting Ukraine on its path towards democracy and progressive change. Ukraine is currently in a situation where, at the same time, not only is trying to implement the necessary structural reforms, but is also involved in an aggressive military conflict with neighbouring Russia. To wage war at the same time, as well as to achieve progressive change, would be an extremely difficult test for any country with a strong value and economic base. Meanwhile, Ukraine is a country that is still seeking maturity in many areas of the country's life. In order to support reforms by the legitimate Ukrainian government, to stabilise the country's financial situation, the EU must provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. On the basis of these arguments, I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal without amendments.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 By adopting macrofinancing assistance to Ukraine, the European Union contributes to the economic stability and development of Ukraine and at the same time to the wider Eastern European neighbourhood. In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more important from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting this report, Hungarian MEPs will help to improve the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 By adopting macrofinancing assistance to Ukraine, the European Union contributes to the economic stability and development of Ukraine and at the same time to the wider Eastern European neighbourhood. In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more important from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting this report, fidesz MEPs from the European People's Party will help to improve the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted against this Commission proposal, which has to do with new financial assistance to Ukraine, which continues the line undertaken with the 1 trillion aid granted in 2014. We understand that aid in these conditions, without proper monitoring and without the previous work of normalizing the area can only bring more corruption, war and human rights violations, further aggravating the problem of Ukrainian debt as well as its economic dependence. The Commission's proposal, on the other hand, focuses only on economic aspects, without addressing, with the precision it deserves, the structural and political aspects of the Ukrainian affair.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour as I believe that the European Union must contribute to the process of stabilisation and economic and political reforms in Ukraine.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Decision of parliament and the Council on providing macro-financial assistance to Ukraine due to the fact that there are serious structural problems in Ukraine, which adds to the difficult, problematic situation in the eastern parts of the country caused by the conflicts with Russia. The economic recession that Ukraine is experiencing has a negative impact on the reforms started, which aim to contribute to the stability and security of the region.  I therefore support the European Union's macro-financial assistance to Ukraine as a close strategic partner that will surely advance economic and social reforms in the country. This will also contribute to the stabilisation of europe's eastern neighbourhood, and it is necessary to establish, together with the Ukrainian authorities, a structured programme and guidelines that will strengthen the started democratic changes and raise trust in them.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this text granting macro-financial assistance to Ukraine to the tune of 1.8 billion euros, subject to political and financial conditions. But these conditions are far too weak for the European Union to allow itself such an expenditure. If Ukraine needs financing after the flight of capital and the deterioration of its balance of payments, it is common knowledge that this decision is motivated by the Association Agreement and the European Neighbourhood Policy, which I dispute—justified. On the other hand, we lack certainty as to the destination of these funds and their use on the ground: it is obviously not desirable for paramilitary and bellicose militias to receive such sums when a ceasefire has just come into force. Moreover, structural reforms of the economy are required, in the direction of a very broad liberalisation, which I cannot support. That is why I decided to vote against it.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The ongoing crisis in Ukraine has left the country in serious financial difficulties. The European Union should be doing everything it can to help alleviate this and to assist the people of Ukraine to rebuild their lives.  I support the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine for this purpose and encourage the EU to continue to push for a resolution to the crisis.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to provide Ukraine with an additional EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance. Ukraine is currently in an extremely difficult situation. The persistence of structural economic imbalances and the occurrence of armed conflict have plunged the country into a real recession. Thus, this aid will facilitate the return to a stable economy and will also support the new government in its desire for reforms. I welcome its adoption.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because, it is well known, that the Ukrainian economy is being hit by an acute and serious crisis, for the additional reason that the country's reform efforts have faced serious obstacles due to armed conflicts in the east, resulting in a sharp devaluation of the currency and the depletion of foreign exchange reserves.  As a result, there has been another significant external funding gap. Since Ukraine no longer has access to international bond markets, this gap can only be filled by additional official financial assistance. I believe that the Macro-Financial Assistance Act, which is an emergency EU crisis mechanism and is made available to EU partner countries facing serious balance of payments problems, should be made available.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report.  Providing macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is of high importance, considering that political support in Ukraine depends largely on economic sustainability and providing basic welfare to the citizens.  It is our obligation to aid an economy that had negative growth numbers in 2014 due to the crisis and violent intervention. The EU and also other international financial institutions have to be ready to continue with such assistance measures and loans. Nevertheless one of the conditions should be progress in conducting internal reforms in Ukraine, ensuring transparency on how the money is used and most importantly fighting against corruption on all levels.  I am glad that all major political groups have expressed their solidarity with the proposal of my colleague Gabrielius Landsbergis, even if the communists and extreme right have once again joined in not supporting Ukraine, or its European course.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report. The macro-financial assistance system, given to politically, economically and socially close partners of the EU, and only those which are under the IMF disbursement programme, has seen countries such as Ukraine, Georgia and Armenia benefit from these loans and grants, enabling them to stabilise and continue their economic and fiscal reforms.  These countries are our close partner countries in need of an urgent financial assistance and we have to take into consideration geo-political, strategic, but at the same time mutual, benefits the EU and these countries have from this type of financial and policy cooperation. Our position in the world is to lead and to assure our partners that we will be there to assist them when in need and support them in their path towards economic and structural reforms which complement the EU’s political and economic norms and values.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Ukraine’s acute economic difficulties, due in part to long-standing structural shortcomings, have been aggravated by armed conflict in the east of the country, Russia’s undeclared war and trade restrictions on it, and the escalation of a natural gas supply dispute between the two countries. I voted therefore in favour of the proposal, as it is important we help the country in the current extremely difficult situation in which it finds itself. It also gives a sign of solidarity with the Ukrainian people and of support for their desire for a democratic and prosperous future, within a democratic country.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the fighting with rebel forces seems to be waning, there is still no reason to be very happy. Ukraine's economy may be in a very tricky situation, but it must be remembered that this is a consequence of a previous policy that recorded corruption and oligarchs. The Committee on International Trade recognises that Ukraine is not a poor country and has come into its position, inter alia, because of delayed structural reforms and mismanageing. The EU does not have many guarantees that the money will actually get to where it will help the Ukrainian people. It certainly does not need oligarchs to be even richer and therefore more powerful. We fear the unstable situation in Kiev, and we are not sure whether the current wave of arrests is a manifestation of the rise of democratic values or a demonstration of the struggle between groups of oligarchs within Ukrainian society. Moreover, Ukraine does not pay much attention to stabilizing the situation in the east of its country. It often rejects the humanitarian aid offered and sends very little of its resources to the area itself, which I find unacceptable. The most beleaguered people in the current situation in Ukraine are the people that the government so often and gladly forgets, which is why I am not sure that macro-financial assistance to Ukraine will help the Ukrainian people and I am voting against the proposal.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Vote against. The text proposes to formulate requirements for structural reforms leading to fiscal reorientations and economic or regulatory transformations that are accompanied by a demand for open markets and liberalisation. This policy is justified by foreign policy, the Association Agreement and the European Neighbourhood Policy, which the National Front opposes. Checking the guarantees of democratic exercise is understandable, but demanding reforms in return for financial aid is unacceptable. It is sufficient that the European Union can have the assurance of good management of the funds allocated as well as guarantees of respect for fundamental freedoms. They are proof of a willingness to respect the commitment.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Ukrainian economy is going through an acute and severe crisis, caused by deep-seated structural problems, and exacerbated by the armed conflict of all known in the eastern regions. The ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme of the new government that took power in February 2014 has been supported by an IMF financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance operations. However, Ukraine's reform efforts have been seriously affected by armed conflict.  Additional macro-financial assistance proposed by the Commission on 8 January 2015 can make a significant contribution to a new international aid package to Ukraine. On the other hand, it should also catalyze a gradual return of trust and support reform efforts in the country through a political accompanying programme to be concluded with the Ukrainian authorities.  I voted in favour of approval at first reading, accepting the Commission's proposal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. I voted against macro-financial assistance to Ukraine for the following reasons: 1. There is no EU competence. Macro-financial assistance is a violation of the principle of subsidiarity, because the EU cannot provide financial assistance better than individual Member States could. 2. Macro-financial assistance is a bailout similar to that in the euro area. However, there is not even an accompanying programme with structural adjustment requirements. Instead, they are only to be agreed in the future, and it remains completely unclear what is to be agreed. On the other hand, Ukraine has already received macro-financial assistance since 2010, which should also have been linked to structural adjustment requirements. But no one seems to be interested in meeting these requirements. 3. Ukraine is at risk of bankruptcy. However, no debt sustainability analysis has been carried out, even though this is still being done even in the hopeless case of Greece. No one seems to be interested in the question of whether the financial assistance can be repaid. 4. The financial assistance covers only about 16% of Ukraine's acute payment needs. Who covers the other 84%? The Commission did not provide any information on this. What if Ukraine goes bankrupt after receiving our money because 84% is still missing? Taxpayers' money is being recklessly put at risk here.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: in writing. ‒ It is important that European countries support the development of Ukraine. Let there be no doubt that we support Ukraine and that we stand up for Ukrainian independence. However, it must be very clear that any proposal with a view to this must not be based on continued EU enlargement. The Swedish government recently (11 March) pledged to lend Ukraine roughly the equivalent of EUR 91 million, which we welcome.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support mp Landsbergis' report, which was created as recommended by the Commission on additional macro-financial assistance to Ukraine of €1.8 billion. The crisis that has affected the whole of Europe has left a deep mark on Ukraine as well. Getting out of the crisis has been compounded by armed conflicts on their territory over the past year. Ukraine is in trouble due to the lack of implementation of the necessary reforms and the mismanagement of the former Government with economic and financial instruments. The new government has started implementing reforms to stabilise political situation, financial reform and fight corruption, and reform the tax system and energy sector.  Over the past two years, the European Union has allocated €11 billion in financial assistance to Ukraine, and the macro-financial package aims to help implement structural reforms and create Ukraine's budgetary stability and help resolve the consequences of armed conflicts.  It is important to react swiftly to the crisis in Ukraine and to provide financial and other forms of assistance as soon as possible, so that ukraine's newly elected Government can more easily and efficiently implement the necessary reforms and become a stable and free state and meet the expectations of the Accession Agreement with the European Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because there is no other way out. What should be taken into account when talking about the macro-financial assistance granted to Ukraine? Firstly, according to the National Bank of Ukraine, the country's external debt has reached 96.5 percent of GDP and is now 126 billion dollars. Ukraine's economy continues to shrink and a large budget deficit is expected. Consequently, it should be noted that Ukraine is unlikely to be able to return the credit granted today in the near future. Secondly, it is not a non-repayable grant, it is a credit that the Ukrainian Government will have to give back. There were illusions in Ukrainian society and in the political elite that the European Union would help more significantly. A few days ago, Oleg Lyaško, leader of one of the parties in the ruling coalition, called on the US and the EU to pay back the USD 7.7 billion in Ukraine's debts, which Ukraine will have to repay to its creditors this year, including 3 billion to Russia. Unfortunately, after today's vote, the Ukrainian people will rather perceive the EU as a rich uncle who, in a situation where the relatives' family is in a difficult financial situation, gives them only a small loan and a lot of instructions on how to live properly.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union has made a long-term commitment to assist Ukraine in the reform process. The objective of providing macro-financial assistance, which complements the assistance of the International Monetary Fund, is to help economic and political stabilisation in Ukraine, which is an important partner of the European Union. The funds cannot be used for military purposes. The loan is necessary to avert ukraine's collapse. The condition is the fulfilment of commitments in the field of anti-corruption measures, the rule of law, tax evasion, the recovery of the financial sector ...

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, because I believe that it does not contribute to the consolidation of peace in the Ukraine region.
