In addition, they are to be made available by the EU. as a loan to Ukraine of 1.8 billion euros while: 1) the Euro Working Group illegally rejected Greece's legitimate request to be reimbursed 1.2 billion euros which by mistake of the Financial Stability Fund and the Greek Government were returned to the EFSF and 2) the Eurogroup illegally continues to refuse the return of 1.9 billion euros from the usury profits made by the ECB from Greek bonds.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this to ensure that the much needed assistance to Ukraine is actioned in a timely manner.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. Macro-financial assistance (MFA) is an exceptional EU instrument offered to EU partner countries facing serious balance-of-payments imbalances. The MFA will also serve to signal that the EU is ready to support countries that undertake reforms in times of economic and political difficulty. That is why I supported the measure.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ukrainian economy is going through an acute crisis, attributable to structural problems, and exacerbated by armed conflict in the eastern regions.  The European Union should help to support the financial stability of the country, with the aim of strengthening the most vulnerable sectors of the national economy.  That is why I have chosen to support, with a vote in favour, the Landsbergis report, which proposes to guarantee macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, through an accelerated procedure, which does not include amendments.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. "U2012 My most determined support for the proposal to provide a loan of EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine, as I believe that we must certainly help Ukraine to help Ukraine to contribute from the European Union to the way out of the harsh economic situation it is going through as soon as possible. Ukraine is a great ally for the European Union and we must repay this friendship with all the support we can provide at the moment, in which the country must also face a terrible armed conflict. From here all my support for Ukrainian citizens and my wish that this situation can be overcome as soon as possible.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is another example of the european nomenklatura's completely misappropriation of funds. The fact that a third country is to receive funding of up to EUR 1.8 billion is totally unacceptable. The budgetary situation of the Member States should be reason enough to reject a risky 'investment' such as this. It was only in September last year that we warned of the negative effects of the association agreement with Ukraine. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I support the Commission's proposal to grant macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. Russia's occupation has led to a severe economic and financial crisis in Ukraine, with its currency devalued, international reserves have been exhausted and access to borrowing on the international market has been undermined. For these reasons, Ukraine has faced major balance of payments problems. The eu's macro-financial assistance aims to help Ukraine ensure financial stability, reduce the country's balance of payments deficits, demonstrate support for reforms undertaken by the Ukrainian government and express solidarity with the people of the war-torn country. Ukraine's financial stability will contribute to its economic and political stability, while at the same time contributing to the security of the entire European region.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Macro-financial assistance (MFA) is an exceptional crisis response tool, which the European Union makes available to its partner countries with serious balance-of-payments problems. The report proposes to pay 1.8 billion euros to Ukraine. It should be noted that Ukraine has already benefited from this fund to the tune of EUR 1.610 billion, in addition to other European aid (neighbourhood policy, humanitarian aid) and international aid (IMF, World Bank) for a total amount of 40 billion euros over four years. This fund is of course subject to certain conditions such as the implementation of structural or macro-economic reforms. Out of friendship for the Ukrainian people, I refuse to see them subject to the yoke of the Brussels institutions in addition to the IMF. I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Ukraine is experiencing a serious economic crisis, which has been exacerbated by the military conflicts that plague its eastern territory.  Following the inauguration of a new government in February 2014, its ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme was underpinned by the IMF's financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations. However, Ukraine's reform efforts have been hampered by the persistence of the armed conflict in the east. Consequently, the economic downturn and capital flight have been more pronounced than originally anticipated, resulting in a sharp depreciation of the currency and a decrease in international reserves. This alarge additional external funding gap arose in 2015 and early 2016. As Ukraine has lost access to international debt markets, this deficit can only be addressed through additional official financial assistance. I therefore vote in favour of this support to help Ukraine overcome this difficult economic period.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Macro-financial assistance for EU partner countries is one of the crisis-response mechanisms that may be used in exceptional circumstances. The proposed amount of EUR 1.8 billion will act as a catalyst to reignite the reform effort in the country as well as improve the overall stability in Ukraine. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report as Parliament and the Union have made a long-standing commitment to the reform process in Ukraine.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The Ukrainian economy has been particularly marked by the conflict in the east of the country. That is why this new macro-financial assistance (AMF) for Ukraine, in the form of medium-term loans, deserves our full support. This assistance will enable it to cope with the weakness of its balance of payments, its delicate budgetary situation and, more generally, its economic difficulties. As Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said, "Ukraine is not alone." Europe unanimously supports Ukraine and the reform agenda of its new government. Our actions speak volumes more than we say. The European Union has already provided unprecedented financial support and today's proposal proves that we are ready to continue. This is European solidarity. This macro-financial assistance goes hand in hand with a number of reforms such as the reform of public procurement, the introduction of anti-corruption legislation, the adoption of international audit standards, the nomenclature of products and services, etc. I remain convinced that Ukraine has all the ingredients to become an important economy in Europe.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 We feel that we cannot vote in favour of measures that support a side in an unclear situation. The people must be given the floor in Ukraine and Europe should act as the external guarantor of the democratic process. Only once the Ukrainian people have legitimately chosen a government will it be possible to make political assessments.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Financial assistance previously provided by the Union, together with the IMF, for the Ukrainian Government's macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme, supported by the IMF's financial assistance programme and the Union's macro-financial assistance operations. However, reform has been hampered by the armed conflict in the country, the war without a declaration of war launched by Russia, and the trade restrictions imposed. The external financing gap created by a larger-than-expected economic downturn and capital outflows can only be bridged with additional financial support. On the one hand, Europe has an interest in continuing the Reform Process in Ukraine and, on the other hand, it cannot abandon Ukraine, which is forced to suffer Russian interference. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. It is necessary to promote peaceful relations with the neighbouring countries of the Union. The demands for reforms imposed in return for financial aid, which are a form of interference, cannot be accepted. The assurance of good management of the funds allocated and the guarantees of fundamental freedoms are sufficient and are the mark of a clear and respectful commitment to sovereignty. Therefore, it is not desirable to support these aids in their current form.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy of the Union aims to create at its external borders, maritime and land, a ring of security, stability and prosperity. Ukraine is experiencing an emergency situation that requires the support of the international community. This report approves a micro-financial assistance of EUR 1.8 billion to support the economic stabilisation and reforms necessary for the development of the country, granted in the form of loans.   I vote in favour of this support, stressing that the international community must react, with one voice, to the Russian invasion of eastern Ukraine.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. While Ukraine is in the grip of economic chaos, the European Union is considering coming to its rescue. But above all, it must be remembered that it is precisely the European Union, which, through a zealous Atlanticism, has helped to throw oil on the fire by supporting the real coup d'état that took place in Ukraine. The result is clear, the union's unconditional Russophobia, driven by a grime misunderstanding of the geography of a country cut in half, has led to economic disaster: rampant inflation (28.5%), deep recession, probability of default close to 100%, central bank's key rate at 30%, despite joint imf and EU aid. The Commission, with the approval of Parliament, has decided to grant 1.8 billion euros to Ukraine, and this, quickly, while at the same time it refuses for the moment any new aid to Tsipras's Greece... In these conditions I decided to vote against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. The European Union is providing a EUR 1.8 billion loan to Ukraine to help it close its balance of payments deficit because it no longer has access to international debt markets and can no longer borrow money itself. The Union will therefore borrow this money in its place and lend it at the same interest rate. I should point out that I voted for this text because it pre-has a Memorandum of Understanding in which Ukraine commits to implementing public finance management reforms, anti-corruption measures, changes in the tax administration, reforms in the energy and financial sectors and measures to improve the business environment.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Ukraine is going through a deep political and economic crisis, exacerbated by armed conflict in the eastern regions and Russia's annexation of Crimea. The country has benefited from financial assistance programmes from both the IMF and the EU, but unfortunately the results have been disappointing and there has been an additional need for external funding.  As an EP, we have repeatedly spoken out in favour of granting assistance to Ukraine, the EU's associated partner, in its stabilisation and structural reform process. We therefore agree with the Commission's proposal because we believe that, in view of the extremely difficult situation in the country at the moment, it is essential to approve additional macro-financial assistance in good time, allowing two of the three tranches of aid to be disbursed during 2015.  The European Union cannot stand by and watch, it must be able to act quickly, decisively and in proportion to its political commitments. We are sure that, thanks to the conditionality clause, this additional aid will contribute to the strengthening of the Ukrainian Government's economic reform commitments. It will also serve to signal that the EU is ready to support countries that undertake reforms in times of economic and political difficulty, as well as to highlight the credibility of its interventions.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 This report examines the Commission's proposal to launch macro-financial assistance to Ukraine of around EUR 1 billion and EUR 800 million in medium-term loans. The aid is part of a series of operations to deal with a deep economic downturn facing Ukraine, exacerbated by armed conflict in the south-east of the country. In particular, macro-financial assistance is aimed at reducing balance of payments imbalances in the short term, while supporting reform programmes through restructuring measures in many strategic sectors for the country. The assistance will be distributed in three parts of six hundred million each, the first of which will start as early as 2015.  In the light of the above, I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because I believe that the proposed additional MFA will be able to help mobilise a new international aid package to Ukraine, either directly, thanks to the proposed amount of EUR 1.8 billion, or indirectly, by mobilising contributions from other partners. It should also act as a catalyst for a gradual recovery of confidence and for supporting reform commitments in the country.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Ukraine does not currently have access to international capital markets. In the days before the conflict, Russia was its main economic partner. Obviously, this relationship has now deteriorated. The hryvnia has collapsed, people live on only a few dozen euros at Western prices. We must admit that there is a humanitarian catastrophe in Ukraine. This is the situation where the neighbour, the partner, must not measure whether or not to help, which is why I fully support the delivery of EUR 1.8 billion of macro-level aid to Ukraine. This is not just about economic indicators, but about the future of a society. The Ukrainian people have already expressed their preference for European democratic values over the oligarchic establishment. We must therefore help the government of our neighbour to move in a truly European direction with its reforms. Hunger and poverty, on the other hand, are not good catalysts and are often the triggers for inter-ethnic conflicts. I therefore call on the Commission to pay particular attention to the situation of minorities and to the development of an action plan to resolve tensions between nationalities.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in line with the policy of the S&D group in the European Parliament and on the ground that the process of democratisation and strengthening the rule of law and the economy in Ukraine requires consistent support from the Member States of the European Union.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I did not support this resolution because I believe that the loan envisaged by it in its current form will not produce the expected results for both Ukraine itself and stability in the region in the medium and long term.  I believe that a solution to the conflict in Ukraine should be found as soon as possible. We Europeans have set out the Minsk agreements as a way to reach a truce there, but the text of the resolution thus voted on did not support this.  In addition, I believe that with such a loan, Europe makes the country even more dependent on external financing, which will only delay in time finding lasting and effective solutions for the Ukrainian economy.  I am of the opinion that we as envoys of European citizens have a responsibility to them as well, and they must be reassured that their own contribution to the stability of the European continent will not be used maliciously in maintaining or enhancing military instability. Unfortunately, the final text does not contain this call, which discourages me from giving my support to this resolution.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: i scríbhinn. ‒ Tá sé soiléir go bhfuil géarchéim dhaonnúil san Úcráin i láthair na huaire agus tá sé aitheanta go forleathan gurb í an choimhlint ba chúis leis.  Sa chomhthéacs seo is trua mór é nach bhfuil moltaí ar bith do chomhaontú polaitiúil i dtreo réiteach síochánta den choimhlint le fáil sa togra seo ón gCoimisiún. Mar aon leis sin, tá an cúnamh macra-airgeadais de EUR 1.8 billiún atá molta ag an gCoimisiún bainteach leis an déine trí choigeartuithe maicreacnamaíocha agus leasú struchtúrach. Ní chuireann an togra seo in iúl conas a chabhróidh an ‘leasú’ seo le geilleagar na hÚcráine, nó conas a bheas tionchar aige ar mhuintir na tíre.  Cuireann Sinn Féin fáilte roimh na hiarrachtaí dul i ngleic leis an ngéarchéim dhaonnúil san Úcráin. Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na leasuithe a chuir feabhas ar thogra an Choimisiúin. É sin ráite, de bharr go bhfuil an togra seo bunaithe ar mhúnla déine lochtach agus ceann nach gcabhróidh le muintir na hÚcráine, staon mé ón réiteach seo.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. According to this report, Ukraine should receive macro-financial assistance of EUR 1.8 billion. It is still completely unclear how Ukraine will ever repay this money. Furthermore, I have serious doubts that the money will only be used for the purpose of supporting the currency and not for the continuation of the existing wartime conflict. On the basis of these facts, I voted against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to provide EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. The EU is thereby showing unwavering support for ukraine's reforms. Ukraine is in a very difficult situation as it seeks to implement the necessary reforms at a time when there is an armed conflict in the east of the country and part of Ukrainian territory - Crimea - has been illegally annexed by Russia. Russian trade restrictions and the th unfairness of the Ukraine-Russia natural gas dispute are also aggravating.  By providing additional macro-economic assistance to Ukraine, the EU confirms that it is ready to support those countries that are implementing the necessary reforms to the country in economically and politically difficult times. We have stressed the need for change in Ukraine, and alongside this it is also important to show that we are taking our political commitments seriously.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  Macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is essential as ukraine's economy is facing a severe and severe crisis. In this context, we must be in solidarity and help the country stabilise the economic and financial situation. However, solidarity is not possible without the commitment to the reforms that Ukraine urgently needs. The planned financial assistance will lead to a gradual recovery of confidence and support the reforms undertaken in the country, while implementing a policy framework to be agreed with the Ukrainian authorities. It should be noted that macro-financial assistance is an exceptional mechanism for the EU's response to the crisis, ensuring a sustainable way out of a difficult economic situation. This additional assistance will undoubtedly be important in order to prepare a new package of international assistance to Ukraine. It will also complement the support provided by other donors under the IMF-funded economic programme.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ukraine's economy is going through an acute and serious crisis, rooted in long-standing structural problems exacerbated by armed conflict in the eastern regions and Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. The new government's ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reforms plan, which took office in February 2014, was supported by an IMF financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations. Parliament has repeatedly spoken out in favour of granting assistance to Ukraine, the EU's associated partner, in its stabilisation process and economic and political reforms. In its most recent resolution on the situation in Ukraine of 15 January 2015, the European Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposal to grant an additional EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine and called for the development of an important assistance plan for ukraine.  In view of the foregoing, the rapporteur proposes that Parliament approve the Commission's proposal without amendment. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ This proposal for macro-financial assistance to Ukraine aims to further strengthen the european union-Ukraine link and support it in the fight against Russian aggression and the implementation of economic reforms. That is why, given the difficult economic situation rooted in long-standing structural problems and which is further intensified by the war conflicts in the east, it wants to support Ukraine with an additional 1.8 billion euros. 1.2 billion earmarked funds are expected to be realised in 2015. The commitment of the European Union and Parliament to the reform process in Ukraine will support Ukraine's legitimate leadership and make it easier for Ukraine to deal with a balance of payments crisis that threatens the country's financial stability. The European Union should also explore other ways to help Ukraine, such as facilitating the recovery of funds illegally transferred to EU countries by former Ukrainian political leaders, supporting Ukraine's anti-corruption efforts, establishing a joint investigative body to monitor the European Union's financial assistance to Ukraine, made up of Ukrainian and EU anti-corruption experts.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I fully support the approval of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, without amendments and further stalling given ukraine's extremely severe financial crisis, which is only further deepened by military aggression. One million people have left their homes, one and a half million are living in harsh conditions in the conflict area, 20% of the industrial potential cannot be used because it is located in occupied territory, and as many as 1 700,000 children are affected by a crisis whose end is not in sight. The economy will contract by 6% this year. The national currency of wrestling had the most serious 38% drop in value in the world last year. The country is estimated to need at least €50 billion to recover. In such a situation, the €1.8 billion we are discussing here is a modest but important contribution to Ukraine's attempts to protect its population, which is threatened by worsening economic and social situation more than military aggression. The EU needs to pass ukrainian exams because Ukraine is a matter of the future of the European project, a matter of determining values more than geographical borders. Ukraine is part of Europe by both criteria and therefore deserves our full support.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute and serious crisis, which swerves long-standing structural problems and aggravated by the armed conflict with the eastern regions and Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. As a result, Ukraine has lost access to international debt markets, and this external financing gap can only be addressed through additional official financial assistance. In view of this situation, the Commission proposed additional macro-financial assistance (MFA) on 8 January 2015. MFA is an exceptional EU crisis response mechanism available to partner countries facing serious balance of payments problems, as is the case with Ukraine. The additional MFA can make an important contribution to a new international support package for Ukraine, either directly through the proposed amount of EUR 1.8 billion or indirectly by mobilising contributions from other partners. I voted in favour of this resolution, which approves the decision on the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine and reaffirms the EU's long-standing commitment to ukraine's reform process.

name: Miloslav RANSDORF
text: in writing. \u2012 I have always supported macro-financial assistance for eastern partnership states. Even where I had serious doubts, as in the case of Georgia. It is necessary to distinguish very precisely between citizens and "elites", which oftentimes act against the interests of citizens. In the case of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, I voted against it because I do not accept the rationale working with the hypothesis of Russian aggression in the eastern part of Ukraine. Ukraine's turmoil was caused not by Russian interference, but by the irresponsibility and stealth of Ukraine's ruling circles from the very beginning of Ukrainian independence. Even before the Maidan events, Ukraine's GDP was 45% compared to 1992, compared with 260% in neighboring Belarus. Since the Maidan, gdp has accelerated further, at 15.2% in the last quarter of 2014. The effects of ukraine's new rulers' incompetence are frightening. Being praised by their Western sponsors means nothing, but it all leads to a social outburst. We have absolutely no certainty as to what European funds will be used for. Ukraine, for example, is to build a so-called The eastern wall, which is supposed to be 2,295 km long and cost more than $537 million. The funds for macro-financial assistance should stabilise the budget and help the economy and the social situation of the population, which is why I could not support this report.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will provide an additional financial aid to Ukraine of 1.8 billion euros, in addition to the 1.61 billion already paid in 2014. We recognize that this country, hit hard by armed conflict, is also suffering the consequences of trade and gas restrictions imposed by Russia, which lead to an economic recession, capital flight, and a depreciation of its currency. It is important that this aid is conditional on the commitment of structural reforms on the part of the Ukrainian government, with the aim of pushing a virtuous circle towards an exit from the crisis. Our work has been quick, allowing this aid to be granted to Ukraine in the near future, which is our responsibility as Europeans.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Yesterday, I supported the European Commission's proposal to raise EUR 1.8 billion in funds on the international bond market and lend it to Ukraine, with no additional interest compared to the rate that the European Union itself must repay to its external lenders. The economic crisis is raging in Ukraine. Not to mention that the country is being undermined by long-standing structural problems, such as corruption, compounded by the armed conflict in the east of the country, but also by trade restrictions imposed by Russia and by the escalation of the natural gas supply conflict between the two countries. Having lost access to international debt markets, Ukraine can no longer borrow money on its own. The Union has therefore done it for it and I welcome the strong political message that the Union is sending to Ukraine at the same time: 'Europe is firmly at your side!'. It should be noted that the disbursement will be linked to Ukraine's implementation of structural reforms such as better management of public finances, anti-corruption measures, changes in tax administration, reforms in the energy and financial sectors, and measures to improve the business environment.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Ukraine has been an important partner of the European Union, notably for trade relations established under the European Neighbourhood Policy. Nevertheless, in view of the constant violations of its territorial integrity, Ukraine has faced difficult periods of economic and financial instability in terms of its balance of payments, lack of liquidity, capital flight, among others, which leads to a greater need for external financing. In view of this context and given the new request for macro-financial assistance reiterated by Ukraine on 15 December 2014, I agree with this Decision, and it is true that this assistance should be exceptional and be a condition for Ukraine to carry out the necessary reforms for the political stability of its institutions, to strengthen its administrative capacities , preventing fraud, corruption and creating the necessary conditions for sustainable growth and development, which generates jobs and is able to carry out the consolidation of Ukrainian public accounts.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote totally against a measure that allocates the sum of EUR 1.8 billion to Ukraine in the form of loans. This intervention of economic assistance is the largest ever carried out by the European institutions towards a non-EU country and the third in a short time towards Ukraine itself. Furthermore, there are no guarantees that Kiev can give about: the return of the sum, respect for human rights, the way in which the large sum will be used. Finally, this type of measure, combined with the trade preferences already granted to Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia, only represents further serious interference in an economic area that has historically been of Russian influence and which is not of great commercial interest to our production realities.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Written. \u2012 According to the EU Commission's proposal, the EU will borrow EUR 1.8 billion from the capital markets, which it will continue to lend to Ukraine. Ukraine will have to repay the loan after 15 years. The loan is conditional on Ukraine's commitment to carry out structural reforms. Ukraine's economic problems are primarily caused by the crisis in eastern Ukraine. In addition, Ukraine has structural problems. Measures restricting Russian trade and the escalation of the natural gas dispute between Ukraine and Russia have also had a strong impact on the Ukrainian economy. The loan is conditional on, among other things, fiscal reforms, anti-corruption measures, changes in tax administration, reforms in the energy and financial sectors and improvement of the business environment. Above all, the EU's decision has symbolic solidarity value. Although I cannot believe in all respects that Ukraine will be able to repay the loans, I appreciate the impact shown by the EU very much. We must keep the EU and the countries that rely on its community of values together. That is why I also voted in favour of this report.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Macro-financial assistance is an exceptional tool in reaction to the crises that the EU makes available to its partner countries with serious payment problems. This report proposes to provide Ukraine with financial support of EUR 1.8 billion, taking into account that this is in addition to the funds previously given to them by both the EU and the IMF or the World Bank. Since this aid is conditional on respect for certain requirements such as the implementation of structural reforms in the economic field (privatizations, deregulations) as in the political sphere, I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. The Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute and serious crisis. The European Parliament has consistently expressed its support for assisting Ukraine, the associated partner of the EU, in its economic and political stabilisation and reforms. Today’s vote means we will assist the country financially in the extremely difficult situation it finds itself in.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I supported macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because the situation in Ukraine is alarming. People are starving, freezing, not getting the medical help they need... and the hope of an early improvement in their plight is in sight. I therefore want to believe that the macro-financial assistance provided will be for the people and not for the oligarchs who still influence political power and get richer in the poverty of ordinary people. Today, the people of Ukraine are taking to the streets again to express their dissatisfaction and to draw the government's attention to their poor living situation. Today, Ukraine needs not only financial help, but also help in combating corruption, fraud and implementing the necessary structural reforms.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EU granting Ukraine EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance for economic and political stabilisation and reform. The MFA is an exceptional EU crisis-response mechanism that is exactly designed for situations where EU partner countries experience acute financial difficulties. Ukraine is fighting a war on its eastern front with Russia. At the same time, the Council acknowledged the Ukrainian government’s reform efforts so far. We are obliged to support our partner in these efforts and ensure we have a well-functioning, transparent and prosperous neighbour in the future.       Within this state reform, there needs to be support for the different religious and ethnic groups in Ukraine. It is important that we do not overlook the struggles of minority groups, such as the Crimean Tatars and the Hungarian community, or religious communities such as Protestants and Catholics.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported eu macro-financial assistance for Ukraine in the proposed amount of EUR 1.8 billion. The Commission proposal foresees assistance to Ukraine, which is conditional on reforms and is in line with the conditions of the International Monetary Fund. Ukraine is in conflict, part of its territory is occupied, and the country is dealing with huge economic and social problems. We must therefore support her so that she does not fall to her knees, that she can develop further and use her enormous potential.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. \ u2012 I endorsed the European Commission's proposal for additional macro-financial assistance to Ukraine of €1.8 billion. I consider the approval of the proposal to be important, as it represents an important step towards the rapid disbursement of medium-term loans this year and next. The appropriations confirm the EU's commitment to continue aid to a country hit by a deep recession and conflict in the east of the country. The new macro-financial assistance complements the resources already contributed by the EU in the form of humanitarian and technical assistance and project support. I believe that aid and solidarity with Ukraine are very important, but we cannot just give them. We must demand a consistent implementation of reforms in the country in the area of tax policy and in the fight against corruption. Only then will Ukraine be able to achieve long-term stability and development. In addition, it is necessary to provide for supervision and to implement it so that the funds allocated are put into the right hands and are applied consistently and for the purposes of reform and for the purpose of improving the situation in the country. The fact is that the people of the country must benefit primarily from the aid, because the current economy in Ukraine is collapsing and people are emigramiing, which is unacceptable. It is necessary to simplify the procedures and to achieve more effective management of the aid programme. Ukraine is, in all respects, a country that urgently needs and needs to be approved.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of allocating EUR 1.8 billion in macro-financial assistance to Ukraine to help ukraine close its balance of payments deficit.  Ukraine is suffering from an economic crisis due to long-standing structural problems, now exacerbated by the armed conflict in the east of the country, which is preventing the implementation of the macroeconomic adjustment, as well as the necessary structural reforms. As a result of the internal conflict, trade restrictions by Russia and the escalating natural gas dispute, there has been a flight of capital, resulting in a depreciation of the currency, which makes it necessary to use external funding to implement structural, political and economic reforms in order to emerge from the crisis. I believe that it is our duty, as the European Union, to help a country that has demonstrated on more than one occasion its willingness to 'move closer' to the Union. I therefore believe that, by virtue of the principles of solidarity on which our community is based, it is necessary to guarantee Ukraine the financial instruments to emerge from its crisis and to implement the reform programme agreed by the future Memorandum of Understanding aimed at remedying the fundamental weaknesses that, accumulated, have led to the current deficit.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Ukraine is our neighbour who finds himself in a difficult situation, both economic and security. The country needs structural changes, improved governance, eradicating corruption or strengthening the business environment. I support the Commission's proposal and the vote of my colleagues in Parliament for this exceptional mechanism as a signal of support for the new government in its reform efforts.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Ukraine's economy is undergoing a serious crisis rooted in long-standing structural problems hampered by armed conflict in the eastern regions of the state and an illegal annexation of Crimea from Russia. After the new government took office in February 2014, its programme launched an ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reforms supported by the IMF financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance packages. In its latest Resolution of 15 January 2015 on the situation in Ukraine, the European Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposal to extend aid to an additional €1.8 billion. In the form of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, the EP called for the development of an aid plan for Ukraine. The Commission's proposal is also based on the Conclusions of the European Council of 18 December 2014, which calls on the EU and its Member States to be ready to further facilitate and support Ukraine's reform process, of course all in line with IMF rules.  In accordance with all of the above, I support the proposal to provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal because I do not believe that the European Union should provide further assistance to Ukraine again. Ukraine does not need more foreign money – Ukraine first needs to carry out fundamental reforms in order to increase competitiveness, especially in the fight against corruption. The provision of this assistance is not only not sensible on the part of the EU, but it can also distance Ukraine from solving these problems. Greece, for example, is a good example of a similar principle.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine of a maximum of EUR 1.8 billion, in support of economic stabilisation and a comprehensive reform plan for Ukraine. Ukraine is in a difficult balance of payments and liquidity situation as a result of the violation of ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity and the resulting military conflict. I also supported the resolution because, as a precondition for granting the Union's macro-financial assistance, it stipulated that Ukraine respects effective democratic mechanisms, including a multi-party parliamentary system, and the rule of law and ensures respect for human rights.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We have been witnessing the dramatic effects of EU policy in Ukraine for months. Instead of the EU promoting peace, it is promoting its economic and geopolitical interests. So we have a strengthening of the conflict, a continuation of the war, more deaths and human rights violations. The Ukrainian people are paying with their blood and misery, the West's insistence on breaking ukraine-Russia ties, integrateing the country into NATO and imposing the IMF's unpopular policies on the country's economy by fire and iron.  We voted against the report because it is just moving down this path. Where are the provisions that will require the Poroshenko government to respect the Minsk Agreement? Where is Ukraine's commitment that the resources given to it by the peoples of the EU will not be channeled into arms and equipment? How will the life of the Ukrainian people be improved when the EU wants to chain it to the IMF memorandums? Where is the strategy for transparency and the fight against corruption? Where is the plan for social and democratic reforms in Ukraine that will heal its wounds? All this, unfortunately, is being circumvented by the interests of the dominant circles.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 Financial assistance to Ukraine is being promoted in order to secure the EU, a rival awe towards Russia.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 Macrofinancing assistance to Ukraine contributes to the economic stability and development of both the Ukraine and the wider Eastern European neighbourhood. In addition to strengthening our cross-border economic relations, it is even more significant from a Hungarian point of view that by adopting this report, fidesz MEPs can contribute to the positive development of the economic conditions of Hungarians in Transcarpathia.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 In agreement with the Commission's proposal and the EiT's position of 19-20 March 2015, I voted in favour of the adoption of the report, including the MFA loan to Ukraine. I made my decision in the knowledge that it was an unusually large sum, because the political and economic stakes are high, not only for the Ukrainians, but also for the EU. It is also right in itself to contribute to the stabilisation of the economy of an important neighbour or partner of the Union, even if its financial stability has been shaken for structural or financial reasons. Ukraine, on the other end, is suffering from war damage, continued economic pressures and energy blackmail as a target of Russian expansion efforts, which make partner solidarity an EU solidarity, the eu's innermost cause.  The Putin regime's expansionist ambitions through Ukraine threaten to destabilise the whole of Europe, not least in the area of economic and financial structures. A loan under MFA rules can be an effective tool in the hands of the Government of Kiev to prevent this and to avoid financial collapse. At the same time, we must also make our Ukrainian partners aware that the EU has an important aspect of conditioning, especially with regard to the consistent and effective implementation of the reform programme undertaken. On the EU side, it is also important to recall the requirement that all Member States, without exception, represent these aspects in unity and consistently in their relations with the Russian and Ukrainian sides.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted no to the macro-financial assistance plan for Ukraine: it will not solve ukraine's problems, it is a neo-colonial instrument, it is a slap in the face to European countries impoverished by austerity.  Ukraine is a bottomless pit of debt because of the civil war that broke out because the country was torn apart by the decision to sign the association agreement with the EU. As long as the war lasts, Ukraine will not recover and will not be able to repay its debts. The war will last until the EU understands that a substantial part of the Ukrainian people have no intention of accepting either the EU or its political, economic and social model. The International Monetary Fund has made the granting of the loan to Ukraine conditional on compliance with the ceasefire. The EU makes macro-financial assistance conditional on reforms: that is, giving Ukraine a market economy through instruments such as tripling the price of gas and cutting pensions to an already starving population. It's the imposition of austerity. It is contrary to the real interests of the Ukrainian people: and many Ukrainians have noticed. While it gives 1.8 billion to Ukraine, the EU sighs 1.2 billion to Greece that no longer wants to accept austerity. The EU lends money to sow austerity. His money is the kiss of death.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: in writing. ‒ The situation in Ukraine is dire. The war in the east, with nearly 20% of Ukraine’s GDP, nearly a quarter of the nation’s industrial output, and almost all of the nation’s coal production in the conflict zone, has been hugely detrimental to Ukraine’s economy. The violent conflict in the Donbass has crippled Ukrainian production as well as its energy industry. The lack of coal has forced power plants to shut down, sending waves of blackouts across Ukraine. This is a danger that affects not only those people living in the war-torn east, but also those living in the relative safety of the west. As supporters of peaceful, democratic rule, it is our duty to aide the Ukrainian economy in its recovery. My group, the ECR, and I are happy to welcome the proposed macro-financial assistance to Ukraine. The proposed aid of EUR 1.8 billion in the form of medium-term loans will help Ukraine cover part of its residual additional external financing needs in 2015 and early 2016 in context of the ongoing IMF programme. It would be provided in the form of a loan that will be paid back and financed through a borrowing operation that the Commission will conduct on behalf of the EU.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. In January, the European Commission proposed to provide new "macro-financial" assistance to Ukraine in the form of medium-term loans of up to EUR 1.8 billion. This support should help Ukraine cope with the major difficulties it faces, including the weakness of its balance of payments and its budgetary situation, the Commission reminds us. The proposed envelope is the third macro-financial assistance programme for Ukraine since 2010. In 2014, Europe provided EUR 1.36 billion in aid under existing programmes. The payment of the last tranche of EUR 250 million is due to take place shortly, subject to the successful implementation by Ukraine of the agreed measures. Indeed, European aid is not unconditional: in order to benefit from it, Kiev must meet a series of criteria for reform, in terms of budget, banks, energy or the judicial system.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal is to grant an extra EUR 1.8 billion in macro-economic aid to Ukraine. This is important to show to the Ukrainian people that the EU stands united behind their country and supports their government.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Writing. \u2012 During the past year, Ukraine's economic situation deteriorated for a number of reasons: armed conflict in Donbass, corruption, ineffective governance and imitation of reforms. Ukraine is only granted another loan from the International Monetary Fund from full insolvency, which will one day have to be repaid. The European Union's macro-economic assistance should facilitate the implementation of reforms and stabilise the financial situation in Ukraine.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We voted against this Commission proposal, which has to do with new financial assistance to Ukraine, which continues the line undertaken with the help of 1 trillion granted in 2014. We understand that aid in these conditions, without proper monitoring and without the previous work of normalizing the area can only bring more corruption, war and human rights violations, further aggravating the problem of Ukrainian debt as well as its economic dependence. The Commission's proposal, on the other hand, focuses only on economic aspects, without addressing, with the precision it deserves, the structural and political aspects of the Ukrainian affair.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe that this macroeconomic assistance programme is important for the future of Ukraine. In any case, I am pleased to be able to vote for the report. Unfortunately in the past few years several countries have been bailed out without the European Parliament having any say in the matter.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The National Front has spoken out AGAINST this report. This text proposes a loan of 1.8 billion euros, the payment of which is carried out in tranches and subject to political and financial conditions. Seeking to promote peaceful international relations, the National Front refuses interference in the affairs of other states in return for financial aid. The assurance of good management of the funds allocated and the guarantees of fundamental freedoms are sufficient and are the mark of a clear and respectful commitment to sovereignty.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important for the European Union to show solidarity with the Government of Ukraine and the Ukrainian people in this way in the current serious financial and economic situation in the country.  I trust that this financial support will act as a catalyst to support reform efforts and thus to gradually regain confidence in the Ukrainian economy.  Finally, I believe that this report reaffirms the European Union's commitment to the Ukrainian reform process and, more broadly, indicates the commitment of the EU institutions to the EU's objectives of economic stability and development in the Eastern European Neighbourhood.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I did not vote favorably by including financial conditions of dubious aid to the Ukrainian people, including the IMF's conditional participation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The Ukrainian economy is going through an acute and severe crisis caused by structural problems and, mainly, by the ongoing armed conflict in the east of the country, which is causing trade restrictions with its Russian neighbor and very serious problems around gas supply. Ukraine's shortfall in foreign financing and lack of access to international debt markets make additional official financial support one of the country's few resources.  The European Parliament has repeatedly supported the provision of aid to Ukraine, so it welcomes the Commission's proposal to give Ukraine an additional EUR 1.8 million in macro-financial assistance and considers it positive to approve at first reading this Commission proposal based on the European Council Conclusions of 18 December 2014.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the granting of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine proposed by the European Commission, firstly because of the urgent need to mobilize international public aid for the neighbouring country, which is in the face of a serious crisis, aggravated by the armed conflict in the east of the country and the consequent instability that makes it impossible for them to access international debt financing markets.  Secondly, because the aid programme will support and boost Ukraine's much-needed internal reform process by being accompanied by a political agenda agreed with the country's authorities. This aid will therefore contribute to the achievement of the EU's objective of promoting economic stability and development in Ukraine and, more generally, in the associated countries of Eastern Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Macro-financial assistance is an exceptional tool in reaction to the crises that the EU makes available to its partner countries with serious payment problems. This report proposes to provide Ukraine with financial support of EUR 1.8 billion, taking into account that this is in addition to the funds previously given to them by both the EU and the FMIo by the World Bank. Since this aid is conditional on respect for certain requirements such as the implementation of structural reforms in the economic field (privatizations, deregulations) as in the political sphere, I voted against it.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because the Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute and serious crisis, rooted in long-standing structural problems and aggravated by the armed conflict in the Eastern regions and the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. After a new government took office in February 2014, its ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme need to be underpinned by EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 Ukraine receives EUR 1.8 billion in financial assistance from the EU. This is the largest Eu aid ever given to a non-EU member state. This aid comes in the form of loans, repayable at a maximum of 15 years and provided that Ukraine respects the democratisation of the country, as well as the rule of law and human rights. This support is to stabilise the country economically and to support substantial state reform. Together with the IMF and the World Bank, the European Commission will follow up on the reforms, where necessary in consultation with the European Parliament and the European Council. In this way, we as the EU can get the country back on its feet and safeguard its independence.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute and serious crisis caused by the armed conflict caused by the European Union in the face of NATO and the United States. Following the government's swearing-in in February 2014, the EU imposed an IMF financial assistance programme and two EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations, conditional on the usual structural reforms. This disastrous adventure has already cost the people of Ukraine and the European Union too much, who are the ones who pay the disdain of those who are in charge of the EU. The EU has broken trade, historical and cultural ties between Russia and Ukraine. As a result, it had to open its borders to absorb Ukraine's exports to Russia. The EU has also had to pay gas bills to Gazprom and has still had to shell out billions of euros when we are told that there are no funds to finance a simple public investment programme that is so lacking in the recovery of the economy. It is a scandal that we will not tire of denouncing and justice has yet to be done.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine is another example of the european nomenklatura's completely misappropriation of funds. The fact that a third country is to receive funding of up to EUR 1.8 billion is totally unacceptable. The budgetary situation of the Member States should be reason enough to reject a risky 'investment' such as this. It was only in September last year that we warned of the negative effects of the association agreement with Ukraine. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the strategy of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because I believe that it is Europe's task to protect states when it has the opportunity and when this possibility can facilitate the process of peace and stability of a territory. We are living in a time of great political uncertainty and it is our task to do everything possible to avoid the precipitate of certain very delicate situations.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I am opposed to the so-called macro-financial assistance of EUR 1.8 billion. Firstly, I see a parallel with the failed bailouts in the euro area. Those who oppose the bailouts within the euro area must also oppose bailout programmes outside the euro area. What fails in Greece is all the more so in Ukraine. Ukraine is already on the brink of bankruptcy. Secondly, the legal basis for macro-financial assistance (Article 212 TFEU) presupposes that the recipient country of aid is not a developing country. Ukraine is classified as a developing country by both the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. Macro-financial assistance is in breach of Union law. This is ignored. Thirdly, it is not a question of economic aid to promote the development of democratic structures in Ukraine. The truth is that we are talking about a geopolitical proxy war. The EU should be a project of peace, represent our own interests and not wage proxy wars – and if it does, it should at least honestly admit it to European citizens.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my Socialist colleagues, I voted in favour of the resolution on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because the Ukrainian economy is experiencing an acute and serious crisis, rooted in long-standing structural problems and aggravated by the armed conflict in the Eastern regions and the illegal annexation of Crimea by Russia. After a new government took office in February 2014, its ambitious macroeconomic adjustment and structural reform programme needed to be underpinned by EU macro-financial assistance (MFA) operations. I visited Ukraine in the years before Maidan, and saw for myself the extreme poverty facing communities. I have continued to maintain contact with Ukrainian civil society organisations, and know how important the relationship with the EU is, socially, economically, and politically.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. ‒ This Report calls for macro- financial assistance (MFA) to Ukraine. It is important that European countries support the development of Ukraine. Let there be no doubt that we support Ukraine and that we stand up for Ukrainian independence. However, it must be very clear that any proposal with a view to this must not be based on continued EU enlargement. The Swedish government recently (11 March) pledged to lend Ukraine roughly the equivalent of EUR 91 million, which we welcome.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I welcome the decision of the Commission and the European Parliament to supplement the macro-financial assistance to Ukraine by an additional EUR 1.8 billion. I voted today on the report on the increase in this financial aid, convinced that the EU must demonstrate its support and solidarity with Ukraine by all means available to it. The Ukrainian economy is going through an acute and serious crisis, which stems from the structural problems accumulated over time, which is aggravated by the armed conflict in the eastern regions and by Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea. Over the years, the EP has expressed its support for the economic and political stabilisation and reform of Ukraine, an associate partner of the EU. In its resolution of 15 January 2015 on the situation in Ukraine, the EP welcomed the Commission's proposal to supplement the macro-financial assistance to Ukraine by an additional EUR 1.8 billion and called for a major assistance plan for Ukraine.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The increase in EU funding to Ukraine is escalating the imperialist intervention of the EU and its US and NATO allies in that country and their confrontation with Russia, focusing on the rich and energy resources of the wider region and their transport routes.  This funding will not only not relieve the Ukrainian people, who pay with their blood for imperialist intervention and the choices of the local bourgeoisie, but also involve the spread of poverty and misery, the continuation of war operations and oppression. EU funds are not intended for popular needs, but for businesses. They are accompanied by a memorandum and supervision to promote a new round of unpopular reforms jointly planned by the reactionary Ukrainian government, the EU and the IMF to ensure the profitability of monopolistic groups.  The Ukrainian people have no interest in being behind any bourgeoisie, no imperialist. His independent struggle against the imperialists, to overthrow capitalist barbarism, for his own power, is the only one that can guarantee peace, mutually beneficial relations for the benefit of the peoples, popular prosperity, solidarity and the friendship of the peoples.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the macroeconomic assistance programme for Ukraine, as the European Union should assume some of the responsibility for stabilising the situation in ukraine. Of course, we will not solve all the problems for the government in Kiev, but we can offer him assistance that will at least partially catch the breath of the Ukrainian economy. Russian aggression continues, and its price increases every day. We Europeans were the inspiration for change in Ukraine. Now that the first wave of enthusiasm has come a difficult moment and doubt in the chosen direction of change, we cannot look away. Ukraine is facing changes and reforms that will be costly. The fight against corruption and the construction of an effective state apparatus will require investment in education and justice. If successful, we will have a stable and credible partner sharing our democratic values in a very fragile region of Europe. Such a perspective is worth a lot, and it is certainly worth the money that we want ukraine to offer now.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has strongly supported Ukraine in the framework of macro-financial assistance (MFA). After disbursing an overall €1.620 million in 2014-2015, it is now preparing to grant another €1.8 billion loan. In return for this financial "aid," the EU encourages Ukraine to implement reform projects. This could be moving if we did not know what reforms are planned. It is such conditionality that we all know so well: privatisation, free movement of capital to enlarge the EU internal market, labour reforms more consistent with the modern PARADIGM of the EU and imf called "cheap and unhumane labour". Moreover, so much was the EU's willingness to "help" Ukraine that it even supported and incited a coup by fascist and neo-Nazi forces, a situation which would naturally result in economic and social calamity as a result of the war. Again, the same hypocrisy.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the provision of macro-financial assistance to Ukraine because the Ukrainian economy is experiencing a crisis caused by long-standing structural problems and provoked by armed conflict in the eastern regions and the illegal annexation of Crimea to Russia. The recession and the capital flight are higher than expected, and there has been a devaluation of the currency and a depletion of international reserves. Ukraine therefore no longer has access to international debt markets and the resulting gap for 2015 and the beginning of 2016 can only fill additional financial assistance. As early as January 2015, the European Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposal to increase macro-financial assistance to Ukraine by €1.8 billion and called on it to draw up an aid plan, and now we have approved the disbursement of this aid. By approving the historically maximum amount of aid to a non-EU country, Europe has shown unity in its support for Ukraine, which is fighting not only for its own security, but for the security of the entire EU and for the values of democracy, so it is right that the EU should do its best to help it. The aid programme will also contribute to strengthening the Ukrainian Government's economic reform commitments. In this way, the European Parliament continues to support Ukraine, the European Union's associated partner, in its economic and political stabilisation and reforms.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – ... which I always find it difficult to vote in favour of a report on taxation where sovereignty and the right to decide are taken away from a country. However, it was true that this report was relating to tax affairs, but also to the ban on tax avoidance. We are familiar with the Lux Leaks case, the perpetrator of which was elected (Mr Juncker) Commissioner of the European Union by music. So this report was about preventing such and similar incidents.  It would be very good if the European Union also helped to assist the foreign currency creditors mentioned in my previous speech, and that, if it had a say in the sovereignty of the countries, it would intervene in such a way and with such content as to curb the various financial rows on other lines and to strengthen the rights and dignity of vulnerable people.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on the ECON Committee's annual tax report. The main part of the report deals with the problems of tax evasion and the importance of legally secure and well-thought-out tax systems. However, as is so often the case in this type of report, a number of very indigestible substantive policy positions are also included in this case. Tax policy belongs, for obvious reasons, to the national parliaments and not to Brussels. Since the report in question is characterised by a conviction to the contrary, I chose to vote against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. In view of the importance of the problem of tax evasion in the EU and the urgency in addressing it, we were waiting for a report proposing concrete measures to address the problem. In our view, the report lacks the prospect of social justice and the importance of redistributive character. Moreover, the imposition on large companies, multinationals and wealth does not reflect as a key objective. Finally, the report is clearly in line with neoliberal policies and the dominant model, as it calls for strengthening the European Semester, and proposes a tax policy under the European Semester.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – There were positive aspects to this report including the focus on tax transparency; However, much of what was being proposed lacked any real substance or force.  If there was a serious concern with effecting real positive change in this field, the proposals would not have been a simple re-packaging of a failed economic paradigm. Instead, there would have been concrete measures put in place in order to move towards real tax transparency.  For my party, tax evasion and cross-border tax fraud is a major concern as untaxed income is considerably reducing our national tax revenues. As Ireland tries to find a sustainable economic recovery it is crucial that we develop a healthier reputation as a transparent place to pay tax and face up to any changes necessary to create transparent global tax system where multinationals cannot escape their duties to countries, including developing countries.  There were also objectionable provisions in this report, which attempted to interfere with Member States’ taxation policies. Direct taxation is a matter of national competency and the EU has no role in dictating or interfering with Irish Taxation Policies or indeed in other Member States tax policies. It was for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis in Europe makes it necessary to set up fair, transparent, and simplified tax systems in order to combat tax evasion, tax avoidance and unequal tax competition.  In this context, Member States, together with the European Commission, should play a central role by uniting their capabilities towards the fight against tax havens.  That is why I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on Tax Policy.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Although this annual report on taxation raises the issue of further harmonization of tax policies, its main focus is the fight against tax evasion. It provides for strict supervision of rescripting practices and increased severity in the face of fraud. Following the successive tax events of 2014, such as the LuxLeaks scandal, which threaten our economy, urgent measures are needed. The report provides that companies guilty of fraud or establishing themselves in tax havens do not have access to EU funds, state aid or public procurement. Lawyers, banks or audit firms that assist in fraud will also be punished. All of these measures seem to me to be appropriate and legitimate. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report covers tax efficiency in the European Union. As a UKIP MEP, I believe that systems would be far more efficient if we were not in the European Union, and I cannot support the measures proposed for the collection of own resources. I note that a Financial Transaction Tax, which would disproportionately harm the British economy, is also proposed. Consideration of international taxation is better done by the OECD than by the European Union. This report has very little to commend it, and I had no hesitation in voting against.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted on the annual report on taxation, which was carried by Socialist MEP Eva Kaili.  This text recalls the extent of fraud and tax avoidance in Europe: every year, almost EUR 1 trillion escapes the tax revenues of Member States at a time when public finances have been hit hard by the economic and financial crisis. This resolution contains several strong messages that the European Parliament wishes to convey to the Council: the discussions on the Financial Transaction Tax (FTT) have lasted too long, the 11 Member States participating in enhanced cooperation must finally take their responsibilities to put in place this instrument of fiscal justice. Similarly, the Consolidated Common Corporate Tax Base (ACCIS), the first step towards tax harmonisation, must be mandatory in the European Commission's proposal expected in June.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which proposes a common approach to tax policy, which can serve as a pragmatic tool for growth. Tax fraud and tax avoidance result in the loss of around EUR 1 trillion in the EU each year. Eur 100 million of potential tax revenues. The main priorities of international tax policy are now to develop a comprehensive strategy to combat tax evasion and avoidance and to establish a global standard of administrative cooperation. Three priority areas are identified. Firstly, important initiatives are identified that can help ensure legal certainty, promote cross-border trade, help to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the Single Market, thereby boosting growth and employment. Secondly, coordinated and comprehensive action is needed to combat tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax havens. Such immediate action could be an alternative to the introduction of new levels or forms of taxation and would provide much-needed additional funds to promote public investment, growth and employment. Thirdly, the coordination of tax policies through clearly defined structural tax reforms that promote growth, employment and investment in the medium and long term.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. In the wake of the "LuxLeaks" scandal involving the current President of the European Commission, Mr Jean-Claude Juncker, Ms Kaili's report quite logically denounces tax evasion by calling for sanctions. The National Front, which calls for an end to aggressive tax optimisation practices, is of course in favour of it because it is the Member States and, with them, their honest taxpayers, who are the first victims. I have therefore voted in favour of this text, which is rather in the right direction, but I remain vigilant about the temptation of some to impose tax harmonisation on us which would deprive Member States of their sovereignty in this area.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. The report praises efforts to be transparent about tax evasion. However, it is optimism and blindness. European law establishes the free movement of capital between EU Member States but also with third countries. Thus, the tax optimization strategy with tax havens, usually insular, would not be settled in any way. The measures envisaged will only shift the problem through ever-increasing tax engineering by multinationals. Tax harmonization is a decoy, as competition will always push some countries to adopt aggressive policies. Having opened the borders, the Union is surprised that VAT, a tax from which it was initially impossible to avoid, is subject to these behaviours, and therefore proposes a harmonisation of rates, which would be contrary to all economic common sense, as the needs of countries differ.  Finally, we see the financial transaction tax, which the current Commissioner Moscovici refused in 2013 when he was Minister of the Economy... In short, this report ignores the will of states and the fact that they must remain sovereign in tax matters.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not vote in favour of the Kaili report on taxation. Although I contain some references that we can support, I cannot support a report that goes back to unacceptable positions, such as the demand for new own resources for the financing of The Union's policies and the desire to centralise even more the financial control of individual States.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I've abstained. The report has some very positive elements relating to the fight against tax evasion, not least big business, and strong action against it. I support these writings. On the other hand, there are wordings for generally increased fiscal policy coordination, support for the EU's market-liberal economic policies and elements of austerity policies. It forces me to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it presents the European Parliament with its annual report on tax policy in the Member States of the European Union. In this report, Parliament notes that tax fraud and tax avoidance result in the loss of around EUR 1 trillion of potential tax revenues in the EU each year, and these losses pose a serious threat to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems, as the tax burden increases for all honest citizens and businesses. For this reason, Parliament welcomed the Commission's proposal on the transparency of tax systems in the European Union, which will oblige Member States to automatically exchange information on changes in tax systems in the future. This has been identified by Parliament as the first step in the right direction.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent debt crisis has raised a number of new problems in the European Union that require proper adjustments to tax policies.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the report's targeted proposals will allow significant progress to be made in this problematic area, which is now being addressed by a special commission in the European Parliament. It is important to stress that regaining the credibility of fiscal policy and reducing public debt make it essential to ensure budgetary discipline and introduce structural reforms, while at the same time ensuring that fiscal measures aimed at growth are given priority and that taxes that have a greater impact on consumption than labour are imposed, as they are better for economic growth and employment in the long term. As the issue of double taxation and tax avoidance continues to cause significant problems and considerable budget deficits for the European Union, we call attention to the urgent need to find solutions to these problems, in line with our positive vote and in line with the action plan issued by the Commission.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
