text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's position on the annual report on taxation.  The fight against fraud, circumvention, tax evasion and havens through effective and simplified legislation in the Member States and compliance with Community rules are a high priority of the European Parliament in order to enhance the benefits of the internal market.  A joint effort is therefore needed in the definition of practices that distort competition and an EU common position on sanctions applicable to States that distort competition through particularly favourable tax conditions. I very much appreciated the report's emphasis on the importance of ensuring that SMEs can compete on an equal footing. In order to ensure a fairer and simpler tax system, the identification of bad practices and the monitoring of Community rules on tax policy must be strengthened by the Commission.  Tax decisions, however, are and remain the national prerogative: through intelligent structural reforms, Member States must be able to ensure greater transparency between tax administrations and taxpayers and act in the tax field to protect and stimulate growth and employment.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I welcome this report as well as the Automatic Information Sharing Agreement. I hope that its implementation will move relatively quickly.  He estimates that €1 billion is lost every year in the EU due to tax fraud and tax avoidance. Such a loss is a major threat to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems, as it increases the tax burden on all citizens and businesses who pay their taxes fairly.  A common approach can succeed in combating tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens, and improve the framework for the proper functioning of the single market through effective tax legislation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because I maintain that tax fraud and tax evasion strongly ruin our economy. I think that the differences between the taxation systems of the different Member States entail the creation of tax dumping which gives the possibility to the companies to choose where is best for them to pay taxes. This clearly forms an obstacle to the strengthening and the growth of our common market. Therefore I consider important the adoption of a common tax policy in Europe.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. How can a tax measure by a Commission led by a person who has been head of a Member State for years be credible, which has caused much concern in the other EU partners on the issue of tax avoidance?

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the annual report on taxation as a register of the report's awareness of the need for a comprehensive strategy on international tax policies and I note that it is interpreted as not separated from coordinated action at EU level which takes account of the need to enhance the benefits of the internal market and to exert unceasing and inexorable pressure on fraud and fraud. tax evasion. I also welcome the efforts made to abolish banking secrecy, as well as efforts to promote the competitiveness of the European banking sector, in order to avoid tax evasion outside the EU. I am convinced that legal certainty and the increase in cross-border trade must be enhanced in order to promote the potential of the single market, just as, in the future, it is strategic to increase public revenue also through a newfound confidence in the tax system. We must give a voice back to the honest taxpayer, who rightly insists on the general principle of fair taxation and on the responsiveness, in terms of public services, growth and employment, of what they are being asked to pay.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ There were positive aspects to this report including the focus on tax transparency. However, much of what was being proposed lacked any real substance or force.  If there was a serious intention to affect real positive change in this field, the proposals would not have been a simple re-packaging of a failed economic paradigm. Instead, there would have been concrete measures put in place in order to move towards real tax transparency.  For Sinn Féin, tax evasion and cross-border tax fraud is a major concern as untaxed income is considerably reducing our national tax revenues. As Ireland tries to find a sustainable economic recovery it is crucial that we develop a healthier reputation as a transparent place to pay tax and face up to any changes necessary to create a transparent global tax system where multinationals cannot escape their duties to countries, including developing countries. There were also objectionable provisions in this report, which attempted to interfere with states’ taxation policies. Direct taxation is a matter of national competency and the EU has no role in dictating or interfering with Irish Taxation Policies. It was for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a comprehensive approach to fiscal policy, which can be a pragmatic tool to promote growth and employment, and move in the direction of a better EU. Three main priority areas have been identified.  The first calls for joint action to reduce the administrative burden on businesses and tax authorities and to eliminate artificial obstacles and divergences between national legislation. Secondly, it recalls the importance of finding a common strategy to put an end to the crime of tax evasion, to combat tax fraud and tax avoidance and to combat tax havens. Finally, the coordination of the fiscal policies of the various countries is one of the important instruments for stimulating growth, employment and investment over the medium and long term.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is broadly in line with our proposals to the National Front to regulate taxation. I therefore support proposals such as the end of aggressive tax optimization practices or bank secrecy. Nevertheless, I note the constant hypocrisy of the European institutions on the subject, since they decide to sanction criminal tax practices after having turned a blind eye to the actions of Jean-Claude Juncker when he was in charge in Luxembourg. On the other hand, we will have to remain vigilant about the temptation to harmonize which would open the pandora's box of a fiscal union that would be contrary to the own interests of the Member States.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The measure we are discussing analyses global fiscal policy with the aim of promoting proactive taxation and economic and monetary growth in Europe. It covers three important factors: reducing legislative divergences between Member States, reducing the administrative burden on businesses and trying to reduce or rather put an end to the crime of global tax evasion. What I have noticed is interesting between the lines of the measure is that of the automatic exchange of banking information between Member States. For all these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the resolution.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it proposes a comprehensive approach to fiscal policy, which can prove to be a pragmatic tool for promoting growth and promoting economic and monetary union.  I particularly welcome three important areas in the report: action to reduce the administrative burden on businesses, the removal of artificial obstacles and divergences between national legislation, and coordination not only at European level but also at global level to put an end to the crime of tax evasion. Finally, I welcome the agreement on the automatic exchange of banking information between Member States and the prospects for its rapid implementation.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The Irish EPP delegation voted against the Annual Tax Report. While we are in favour of many aspects of this report, we do not agree that paragraph 25, which calls on the Commission to carefully study the introduction of a minimum corporate tax rate, is appropriate in this report. The EU Treaties clearly state that corporate tax rates are not an EU competence: it is for Member States to decide. We are firmly against aggressive tax planning and believe that the EU has a role in addressing tax evasion from large corporations, but Member States should have the freedom to set their own corporate tax rates.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on taxation because I believe that the development of good governance in tax matters can lead to a better functioning of the common market. The European Union should step up the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, as they represent phenomena that threaten fair competition and lead to a substantial loss of revenue. I support a comprehensive approach to fiscal policy to promote business-friendly and investor-friendly tax initiatives. Fiscal cooperation stimulates sustainable, intelligent and inclusive growth.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Whereas I support the fight against tax evasion and fraud, I have voted against this report as tax issues are and should remain a Member State (MS) competence. Furthermore the report assumes that tax harmonisation, financial transaction tax and CCCBT are a must, without considering that MS economies face different challenges and realities.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I agree with the content of the annual report on taxation in the EU, especially with regard to Parliament's commitment to combating tax evasion and avoidance and tax havens, as well as the need for greater fairness in taxation at European level.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. In view of the importance of the problem of tax evasion in the EU and the urgency in addressing it, we were waiting for a report proposing concrete measures to address the problem. In our view, the report lacks the prospect of social justice and the importance of redistributive character. Moreover, the imposition on large companies, multinationals and wealth does not reflect as a key objective. Finally, the report is clearly in line with neoliberal policies and the dominant model, as it calls for strengthening the European Semester, and proposes a tax policy under the European Semester.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is an excellent report which deserves praise and support. The lack of revenue due to fraud and tax avoidance - estimated at EUR 1 billion at European level - would in itself call for a thorough reform, which should find its way into the dialogue and discussions of the High Level Group on Own Resources, together with the introduction of a tax on financial transactions.  At Member State level, we all too often see complacent attitudes on the part of governments, which enter into secret tax exemption agreements with multinational companies to attract capital, but which, in doing so, introduce perverse mechanisms of unfair tax competition within the Union, causing harm to all citizens.  In addition to ensuring an increase in revenue - which could lead to further investment for growth - the Union and its States must strive to create a global system of legal certainty and taxation, as a basis for real growth in SMEs which, unlike the large multinationals, are incapable of taking advantage of the 'illicit' benefits of being able to move their tax offices to 'havens'.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report because, whilst it underlines the importance and necessity of fighting tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning and tax havens, I believe that it is imperative that taxation remains a Member State competence. I am in favour of respect for Member States’ competences as safeguarded by the treaties. Moreover, one has to understand the realities of peripheral or disadvantaged regions which require tax competition to survive. What is important is to make such competition, transparent.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the annual report on taxation. The resolution sends a clear message on behalf of the European Parliament: for a Europe that is moving in the path of full integration, we need greater coordination of fiscal policies and more joint initiatives in the field of taxation. The current heterogeneity of Member States' tax regimes and approaches, as clearly demonstrated in the recent LuxLeaks affair, is a dangerous obstacle to the completion of the single market in the EU and full economic integration and also promotes phenomena of blatant distortion of competition, generating real 'fiscal dumping' within the Union. We are showing positive signs of greater fiscal coordination, such as the recent agreement on the automatic exchange of information and progress on the definitive abolition of banking secrecy in the EU.  However, much still needs to be done, particularly with regard to the creation of an effective EU own resources system and in the fight against fraud, tax evasion and avoidance with the ultimate objective of a genuine European Fiscal Union closely linked to the European governance framework of the economy and the European single market.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to take stock of the main tax events of 2014 and demonstrates that even if the European Union's competence in direct and indirect taxation remains limited in the treaties and constrained by the unanimity procedure in the Council, the Union is increasingly obliged to invest in this key area. Indeed, in 2014 the co-legislators adopted legislative initiatives against money laundering and in favour of the automatic exchange of tax information and the European Commission has just proposed to make it mandatory to exchange information on cross-border tax decisions. However, there are still many initiatives to be carried out, as such, the report calls on the European Commission to put forward concrete proposals to combat the VAT gap, fraud and tax evasion, as well as to study the principle of introducing a minimum corporate tax rate. Considering that it is necessary, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, for the Union to move forward on the issue of fraud, competition and tax harmonisation within the internal market, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. The European Parliament has here wished to address the different European tax policy directions in the context of an ever-increasing integration of the internal market for the benefit of businesses and consumers. I am theor particularly in favour of us continuing our efforts to end bank secrecy in the European Union and the practice of tax rules by which Member States and some multinationals agree to attract businesses at the expense of the tax systems of other Member States.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 One thousand billion euros is the estimate of the potential revenue that is lost due to fraud and tax evasion every year in the European Union. This is a very serious phenomenon for every European citizen: in fact, the reduction in tax revenues has consequences for the less public money available for investment, which today is the main reason why we cannot get out of the economic and financial crisis that is gripped by our countries. In addition, these practices increase the tax burden for all other citizens and companies that act in compliance with the rules.  For all these reasons, I voted with full conviction for Parliament's proposal for a report on taxation, which also addresses the aberrant problem of those companies, often multinationals, that structure their tax position so as to transfer profits to low-tax jurisdictions.  Therefore, our objective is clear. We need to promote a fiscal policy based on inclusion, transparency and fairness. Building a path of good governance is the only way to achieve sustainable growth and fiscal justice at the same time. Finally, these policies will also enable us to reduce economic inequality, which is at the heart of our political battles in this Chamber.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The fight against tax evasion must be a priority for the European Union. This is the meaning of this European Parliament resolution which addresses a wide range of tax-related issues and lays the groundwork for the future work of the European Parliament's Special Committee on Tax Rulings. What we expect from this is a series of concrete proposals to effectively combat tax evasion and evasion, which cost Europe more than 2 trillion a year. What we expect from this is social and fiscal harmonisation to put an end to excessive distortions within the Union.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent debt crisis has raised a number of new problems in the European Union that require proper adjustments to tax policies. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the report's targeted proposals will allow significant progress to be made in this problematic area and which area is now being dealt with by a special commission in the European Parliament. It is important to stress that regaining the credibility of fiscal policy and reducing public debt make it essential to ensure budgetary discipline and introduce structural reforms, while at the same time ensuring that fiscal measures aimed at growth are given priority and taxes that affect consumption more than labour, as they are better for economic growth and employment in the long term. As the issue of double taxation and tax avoidance continues to cause significant problems and considerable budget deficits for the European Union, we call attention to the urgent need to find solutions to these problems, in line with our positive vote and in line with the action plan issued by the Commission.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it promotes non-healthy interventionism in the economy of the Member States

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the annual report on taxation in which areas of action for a fairer, more transparent and effective tax policy are identified. The report stresses the need to adopt fiscal policy measures that eliminate legislative discrepancies and administrative barriers between different Member States, boosting the single market. On the other hand, I agree that states' fiscal sustainability should be maintained by ensuring their tax revenues by taking immediate and coordinated actions, both in the EU and in the international context, in order to combat tax evasion, tax fraud, as well as to combat aggressive tax planning and tax havens. In this context, it is important to condemn and prevent the creation of secret agreements on tax exemptions for large companies and to stress the importance of automatic information exchange measures and to adopt general principles requiring the payment of taxes in countries where services are consumed.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. €u2012 A billion of potential tax revenues are lost each year in the EU due to tax fraud and tax avoidance, which is a major risk to the effectiveness and fairness of EU tax systems as it increases the tax burden on all businesses and citizens in good faith. This loss leads to less public money available for investments, which therefore translates into less capacity to encourage additional private investment. Companies take advantage of the complexity of tax rules and the lack of cooperation between Member States to relocate profits and reduce their taxes to a minimum. Therefore, enhanced transparency and cooperation is vital in the fight against aggressive tax planning and abusive tax practices. The package on tax transparency which I voted in favour of is, inter alia, to ensure that Member States have the information they need to protect their tax base and to effectively identify companies trying to avoid paying the share of their taxes.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  This report also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In the sense, it is important to note, since the report does not include it, that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF. In addition, there is also no mention of wealth tax, which is essential to combat inequality resulting from the increasing accumulation of capital. It is for the Commission to advise the creation of the estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented through the Country-Specific Recommendations. In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am convinced that, while fully respecting the competences of each Member State, this report can propose a comprehensive approach to fiscal policy. This can be an excellent tool for encouraging growth and promoting European monetary union.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to deepen economic and monetary union and boost growth, it will be necessary to adopt a coherent approach with regard to tax policy in the future and to propose a tax system that takes into account the characteristics of individual Member States. These tax policy measures in question should lead, in particular, to a reduction in the administrative burden for businesses and tax authorities, but also to gradually remove obstacles and inconsistencies between national legislations. If there is indeed to be a significant reduction in the crime of tax evasion and the fight against tax fraud, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and, of course, tax havens, immediate, coordinated and comprehensive action is needed at European Union level.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the own-initiative report by the ECON Committee, which endorses and agrees with the request to Member States to closely observe the Commission's recommendations on the economy and taxation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the annual report on taxation as it promotes intense unsymed interventionism in the economy of the Member States, while supporting the creation of an intergovernmental tax body under the auspices of the United Nations, to which I have no confidence.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this annual tax report which attempts to widen the EU’s competency into national tax policies. This is an appalling case of ignoring the principle of subsidiarity. Member States control the ability to legislate for a Financial Transaction Tax.  I am firmly against such a measure that would damage the competitive nature of the EU’s, and in particular the UK’s, markets.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Every year in the EU, an amount of eur 100 billion in potential revenue is lost as a result of tax fraud and avoidance. This phenomenon not only leads to a serious loss for the public office, but also, and above all, an increase in the tax burden for all citizens and companies acting in good faith. The European economy is in desperate need of investment. Tax avoidance takes away a large proportion of the public money available to stimulate private investment, at a crucial time to revive resources for employment and growth.  I therefore wholeheartedly voted in favour of Mrs Kaili's report, which first of all underlines the important agreement reached on the automatic exchange of information between European governments. I find the passage in which the European Parliament calls for the definitive abolition of banking secrecy within the EU from June 2015 particularly significant: it is also for this reason – as the report we have adopted states – that it is with concern that some Member States and certain multinationals conclude secret agreements to grant tax exemptions aimed at attracting businesses, damaging the tax systems of other Member States and the proper functioning of free competition.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on taxation because I believe it is absolutely necessary to have a global approach to fiscal policy that serves above all to promote economic growth in the medium to long term. It is important to work towards the harmonisation of tax systems, which will result in particular tax simplification for companies.  Furthermore, the fight against tax evasion must be a priority, because tax evasion, avoidance and the practice of tax havens are an odious example of social injustice at a time when the crisis imposes great sacrifices on European citizens and we can no longer allow it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. I abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that the problem of tax evasion in the European Union is urgent and requires to be at the top of the concerns of MEPs. However, we understand that there are some shortcomings in this report that cannot be tolerated if we are to tackle the problem of tax evasion in its entire breadth: we refer to the lack of references to social justice or redistribution as means of achieving equality. That is why we can assure you that the report is in line with a single perspective, that of the vast majority, barely subject to a debate that takes into account the social reality we face in Europe.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for this report which proposes a holistic approach as regards taxation policy across Member States, aimed at making the tax system fairer, and at cracking down on tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance. The European Parliament’s Annual Tax Report put forward concrete proposals to tackle immoral tax practices – including measures to make companies report where they make their profits and where they pay their taxes, and an agreed Europe-wide definition of tax havens that would see them named and shamed. However, I did vote against the recommendation that revenue from FTT should go to EU own resources, as Labour MEPs do not support the revenue being used in this way. I also abstained on paragraph 25, which called on the Commission to carefully study the options for the introduction of a minimum rate of corporation tax as a means of curbing damaging tax competition: whilst not against this in principle I have concerns that it would mean a significant shift in powers and stop the UK Treasury’s ability to set potentially lower corporate tax rates. I would need more detail before agreement.

text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the annual tax report because it sets out a clear and pragmatic position of the European Parliament on the priorities of international tax policy, namely the fight for a more transparent tax system and the establishment of a global standard of administrative cooperation. In particular, the administrative burden on businesses will be reduced and barriers to national legal systems from being removed in order to make more effective use of the opportunities offered by the Single Market, thereby promoting growth and employment across the EU. At the same time, given that tax policy ensures an income base and is one of the key elements of fiscal sustainability, transparency of tax systems will be sought. Finally, coordination in the field of tax policy will be strengthened, as only by combining actions and sharing relevant information can create tax policies that promote investment, jobs and growth across the EU.

We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent debt crisis has raised a number of new problems in the European Union that require proper adjustments to tax policies.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the report's targeted proposals will allow significant progress to be made in this problematic area, which is now being addressed by a special commission in the European Parliament. It is important to stress that regaining the credibility of fiscal policy and reducing public debt make it essential to ensure budgetary discipline and to introduce structural reforms, while at the same time ensuring that fiscal measures aimed at growth are given priority and that taxes that have a greater impact on consumption than labour are imposed, as they are better for economic growth and employment in the long term. As the issue of double taxation and tax avoidance continues to cause significant problems and considerable budget deficits for the European Union, we call attention to the urgent need to find solutions to these problems, in line with our positive vote and in line with the action plan issued by the Commission.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: Written. "On Wednesday, we voted on Mrs Kaili's report: the EU's annual tax report. We Moderates support the points in the report relating to measures against tax evasion and tax crimes. However, our assessment is that the report as a whole is capable of undermining the sovereignty of individual Member States in the field of taxation. We are against the introduction of an EU tax on financial transactions. We do not believe that the European Union should have its own power of taxation, but taxation should continue to be a national competence. We therefore chose to vote against the report on this basis.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The recent debt crisis has raised a number of new problems in the European Union that require proper adjustments to tax policies.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that the report's targeted proposals will allow significant progress to be made in this problematic area, which is now being addressed by a special commission in the European Parliament. It is important to stress that regaining the credibility of fiscal policy and reducing public debt make it essential to ensure budgetary discipline and to introduce structural reforms, while at the same time ensuring that fiscal measures aimed at growth are given priority and that taxes that have a greater impact on consumption than labour are imposed, as they are better for economic growth and employment in the long term. As the issue of double taxation and tax avoidance continues to cause significant problems and considerable budget deficits for the European Union, we call attention to the urgent need to find solutions to these problems, in line with our positive vote and in line with the action plan issued by the Commission.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that the problem of tax evasion in the European Union is urgent and requires to be at the top of the concerns of MEPs. However, we understand that there are some shortcomings in this report that cannot be tolerated if we are to tackle the problem of tax evasion in its entire breadth: we refer to the lack of references to social justice or redistribution as means of achieving equality. That is why we can assure you that the report is in line with a single perspective, that of the vast majority, barely subject to a debate that takes into account the social reality we face in Europe.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I vote in favour because of the urgent need to establish clarity and transparency in tax regimes. This will help combat tax evasion and evasion, and avoid unfair tax competition in European Union countries.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the annual tax report, as I believe that coordinated action and a common approach are needed at European Union level to prevent tax fraud and evasion and strengthen the principle of transparency, which also represents the objectives of international tax policies.  An effective mechanism should be put in place to address vat revenue gaps, manage tax matters responsibly in third countries and ensure the proper functioning of national tax authorities. In this context, I strongly support the fight against aggressive tax planning and tax havens with a view to focusing economic policy towards growth and achieving tax coherence.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I have decided to vote for this text in order to see an EU-wide process of equalisation. Indeed, differences in treatment, revealed for example in the LuxLeaks case, must no longer be tolerated in order to put an end to the social dumping and inequalities that we denounce and which the European Union has become a specialist. As long as bilateral agreements cannot be negotiated outside the Union framework, this type of minimum report must be defended, despite the serious shortcomings it contains, particularly with regard to the hypocrisy of the Union vis-à-vis Ireland, which has been granted financial aid without consideration, which obviously goes against the ambition of equalisation.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the annual report on taxation because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance, as well as aggressive tax planning, and because it supports, in particular, the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  This report also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to the establishment of enhanced cooperation in the field of financial transaction tax (ITF). In this regard, it is important to emphasize — since the report does not include it — that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF. In addition, there is also no mention of wealth tax, which is essential to combat inequality resulting from the increasing accumulation of capital. It is for the Commission to advise the establishment of the estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented, through country-specific recommendations. In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ This report provides a political response to the recent emergence of the LuxLeaks case. I agree with the holistic approach proposed as regards taxation policy, which I found well balanced.  The text identifies three areas of priority: boosting the benefits of the internal market through taxation policy; fighting tax fraud, tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and tax havens; and promoting viable tax coordination for a long-term, growth-oriented economic policy. While taking into account tax developments which took place in the course of 2014, the report calls for further actions to be implemented, like the adoption of a common approach on the fight against fraud and tax evasion, which I agree is urgently needed.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I supported the report on the annual report on taxation. It stresses, among other things, the need for a common approach to combating tax evasion and evasion. It also promotes better fiscal coordination for a growth-oriented economic policy. I welcome its adoption.

name: Eva KAILI
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because, I believe that a fundamental revision of the EU's own resources system is necessary, as making more own resources available in a fiscally neutral way will lead to a more transparent European budget. Tax fraud and tax evasion, estimated at EUR 1 trillion a year, poses a major risk to the efficiency and fairness of the EU's tax systems and increases the tax burden on all bona fide citizens and companies.  In addition, the loss of this tax revenue means that fewer public funds are available for investment. In general, we must in every way support the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning, as well as tax havens with a view to promoting sustainable tax coordination for a long-term, growth-oriented economic policy.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that tax policy should be under the control of the state and interference from Brussels, demanding an increase in tax rates would harm the competitiveness of our companies and the country, which is why I voted against the Report on the Annual Tax Report in parliament's plenary session.  The European Parliament gives its opinion on the tax policy of the European Union and the Member States on an annual list of european unions. While Parliament's view in this year's report emphasises the need to eradicate tax fraud and evasion, it did include a request to the European Commission to assess the possibility of setting a minimum corporate tax rate. I find the inclusion of such a requirement in the report unacceptable, and for this reason I voted against the report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Annual Tax Report 2013. While I am in favour of many aspects of this report, I do not agree that paragraph 25, which calls on the Commission to carefully study the introduction of a minimum corporate tax rate, is appropriate in this report. The EU Treaties clearly state that corporate tax rates are not an EU competence, it is for Member States to decide. I am firmly against aggressive tax planning and believe that the EU has a role in addressing tax evasion from large corporations, but Member States should have the freedom to set their own corporate tax rates.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Positive vote. We are always cautious about any policy that tends to harmonize, for fear of being taken prisoner of it, and we wonder how the European Union can reconcile sound fiscal competition between Member States with greater harmonisation of tax policies. Having said that, this is about fighting fraud. Some important measures are interesting and in line with our own demands, including strict supervision of rescripting practices and increased severity in the face of fraud, the principle of paying taxes where companies use public services, sanctions (revocation of approvals) against lawyers, banks or audit firms that have helped tax evasion, denial of access to EU funds. , state aid and public procurement for companies guilty of fraud or establishing themselves in tax havens.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. It is estimated that one trillion euros in potential tax revenues due to tax evasion and tax avoidance is no longer collected in the EU each year. This loss of tax revenue means that less public money is available to invest, which in turn means that less additional private investment can be encouraged, at a time when the Commission's stated focus is on employment, growth and investment. The agreement on the automatic exchange of information and the prospects for rapid implementation of information is therefore welcomed. In this regard, the definitive abolition of banking secrecy within the EU was requested from June 2015, as well as the conclusion of tax agreements also with third countries before 30 June 2015. On the other hand, the Commission's announced proposal for a compulsory exchange of information on cross-border resolutions is very welcome. That is why I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Writing. The annual tax report contains many passages with which I fully agree. Unfortunately, however, it is not uncharacteristic that good and correct texts should be used to accommodate controversial content and to have it adopted within the framework of the general agreement on the overall text. That is also the case here. In the middle of the text, the word is being spoken of as European tax harmonisation. To be clear, I am against tax harmonisation. Taxes must be different, because only tax competition protects taxpayers from excessive use by the state. Moreover, the tax burden payable in a country is the price of the public services provided by that country (infrastructure, education, administration of justice, public administration, health, internal security, national defence, etc.). Each country is free to decide for itself how much public services it wants to offer. When different levels of public services are offered, the tax burden must also be different. Tax harmonisation is incompatible with this and would interfere with the sovereign competences of the Member States. That is why I cannot agree to a tax report aimed at tax harmonisation through the back door.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ According to the European Commission, €1,000 billion in revenues are lost in the European Union each year due to tax avoidance, tax fraud and aggressive tax planning. By losing these revenues, Member States have fewer investment resources to boost economic growth, development and jobs, and the European Union has at its disposal fewer resources needed to further develop and create the latest initiatives, such as the Capital Markets Union, the Single European Energy Market, the Digital Single Market.  I supported this report because I believe that better implementation of tax rules and cooperation between Member States is needed, which would prevent aggressive tax planning, tax avoidance and tax fraud, while creating a favourable business environment for companies and reducing additional burdens for all citizens who pay taxes fairly.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Tax fraud and evasion cause billions of dollars in damage to the budgets of the Member States, as well as in the European Union itself. They are seriously damaging public finances and investment, which has negative impacts on the promotion of economic growth and job creation and, ultimately, on the European Union's lack of competitiveness. Despite the number of directives, measures and agreements concluded, these appear to be either insufficient or not effective. That is why the Commission and the Member States must urgently inebrate existing measures that eliminate the current unfavourable state of taxation and prevent the misuse of funds in the European Union. Clear and strict rules need to be adopted to cooperate with countries with the status of tax havens and to introduce transparent rules for the participation of companies based in tax havens in public contracts. Simplification of tax system rules must be strongly promoted, allowing for better and more effective control in tax collection. Clear and unambiguous rules must be adopted, the violation of which will be severely sanctioned. The action by the Commission and the Member States in the fight against fraud and tax evasion must be common and consistent.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because it makes society fairer by introducing a fairer tax rates for small businesses, and by putting forward sound, comprehensive proposals to crack down on tax evasion and aggressive tax avoidance.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Harmonisation of European tax systems is one of the objectives of the new Parliament. Although this is a matter for the individual Member States, the management of tax systems within the Economic and Monetary Union itself risks creating imbalances in the markets, making Member States with facilitated tax systems more attractive for investment than others.  That is why we must strive to establish common fiscal guidelines that will stimulate growth, employment and investment in all Member States. Mrs Kaili's report is a first step towards a global approach to fiscal policy.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Approximately one thousand billion euros of potential revenue is lost every year within the Community, as a result of the spread of fraud and tax avoidance offences.  This loss is attentive to the effectiveness, and fairness, of European tax systems, resulting in an increase in the tax burden for all citizens, and for all companies, which act in good faith.  No less importantly, the loss of this tax revenue reduces the share of public money available for investment, thereby limiting the number of private investments.  The Kaili report stresses that the fight against tax fraud, evasion and avoidance can only lead to tangible results if a common approach is adopted.  By sharing the message conveyed by this document, I decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. My support for the EU tax report, which proposes to make fiscal policy a useful tool for promoting growth in Europe, is 2012. I agree with the need to reduce administrative burdens on businesses and tax authorities, to remove artificial barriers and mismatches between national laws.  Work must also be worked on to ensure legal certainty, strengthen cross-border trade, promote the full potential of the single market and thus boost growth and employment. I also share that immediate action is needed to end the crime of tax evasion, combat tax evasion and avoidance, and combat aggressive tax planning and, of course, tax havens.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The annual tax report is about promoting the lifting of banking secrecy in the EU by June 2015 and strengthening the harmonisation of tax policy. It also wants to introduce financial transaction taxes as part of the EU's own resources and a strengthened framework for economic governance. Since this report seems to represent only more power for the EU, in order to finally be able to impose taxes on the states and their fire width, I voted against this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Annual Tax Report because I support the most important guidelines and initiatives contained therein in it to combat tax fraud, tax evasion, avoidance and tax havens. The report calls on the European Commission and the Member States to develop tax policies that promote growth, employment and investment and reduce the administrative burden on honest taxpayers.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This annual report on taxation claims to fight tax evasion: laudable intention. It calls for the abolition of bank secrecy, and also condemns "the implementation of secret agreements concerning tax exemptions between specific Member States and certain multinationals". But beyond intentions, the report lacks ambition. My group's proposals to shift the tax burden to the highest incomes or to introduce a minimum European business tax were rejected. But, above all, this fight against fraud is part of the European Semester, whose "country recommendations must be accepted". Finally, when it comes to taxation, the proposals aim as always to "eliminate the tax barriers and administrative burdens" on businesses. I abstain.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. Taking due account of the development of a tax system adapted to the specific characteristics of the economies of all Member States, as provided for in the Treaties, the report proposes a holistic approach to tax policy, which may prove to be an important tool for fostering growth and deepening EMU. Good tax control is essential to reduce tax evasion and thus channel more revenue to Member States. Good taxation is therefore essential for strengthening the single market, in order to achieve economic growth and reduce unemployment. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ It is unfortunate that this report made certain references to having a Financial Transaction Tax (FTT), which I could not support. Such taxation issues should remain within Member States’ competence.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The adoption of the annual report on taxation by a large majority of MEPs in the European Parliament underlines the importance of a European tax policy. Ensuring fair taxation helps to boost the Union's economy. The financial transaction tax is now a necessity. It could contribute directly to the European Union's budget by strengthening its own resources. I believe that the OECD is already working remarkably hard to ensure that developing countries can participate in the definition and reform of global tax policies in the same way as other countries.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of this resolution, in particular on the planned definitive abolition of banking secrecy. This important advance is essential in the fight against money laundering and fraud against both individuals and the community.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 It is estimated that €1 trillion in tax revenue is lost in the EU each year due to tax evasion and avoidance, thereby increasing the burden on decently taxed citizens and businesses, hindering investment support, thereby creating jobs and growth. Tax evasion, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and the fight against tax havens are therefore in the common interest of the Member States and their citizens. That is why I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The year 2014 was marked by the announced end of bank secrecy in Europe, but also by the LuxLeaks case, revealing the practices of some states in terms of aiding aggressive tax optimisation. The Kaili report takes a critical approach, rightly denouncing all forms of tax evasion and its corollaries and calling for sanctions. Victims of these practices remain the states from which profits are relocated and their taxpayers. As such, the idea of sanctioning the consulting firms that assisted multinationals in these steps must be supported, as well as the idea of depriving companies guilty of access to European funds and public procurement. Nevertheless, I remain clear in my opposition to any form of tax harmonisation that would be imposed on States by the Commission. Fiscal sovereignty is one of the last powers that require unanimity, it must remain so. Finally, we must demand the return of taxes evaded by fraud to the States of origin of profits, those where those same companies use public services.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. An billion euros of potential tax revenue sums is lost each year in the EU due to fraud and tax evasion, and it is therefore essential that there is an automatic exchange of information between Member States and the definitive abolition of bank secrecy in the EU from June 2015 which will contribute to increasing transparency in banking operations. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that there are potential benefits of the internal market through tax policy and i am in favour of presenting concrete proposals on how to tackle the obstacles that hinder the cross-border activity of individuals and businesses in the single market. Finally, I would stress that the stabilisation of a fiscal policy is of strategic importance in fostering economic growth in the medium and long term, as a transparent and stable taxation could enable investors to be strengthened.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The report praises efforts to be transparent about tax evasion. However, it is optimism and blindness. European law establishes a free movement of capital between EU Member States but also with third countries. Thus, the tax optimization strategy with tax havens, usually insular, would not be settled in any way. The measures envisaged will only shift the problem through ever-increasing tax engineering by multinational firms. Tax harmonization is a decoy, as competition will always push some countries to adopt aggressive policies. Having opened the borders, the Union is surprised that VAT, initially an unfraudable tax, is subject to these behaviours, and therefore proposes a harmonisation of rates, which would be contrary to all economic common sense, as the needs of countries differ.  Finally, we see the financial transaction tax, which the current Commissioner Moscovici refused in 2013 when he was Minister of the Economy... In short, this report ignores the will of states and the fact that they must remain sovereign in tax matters.  That is why I voted for it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. This annual report on taxation reminds us that tax evasion and evasion deprive the European Union of 1 trillion euros in revenue each year, to the detriment of citizens and businesses in good faith. The report also stresses that European citizens expect their politicians to take swift action to stop fraud, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. In order to do this, the text calls for the definitive abolition of banking secrecy and the development of automatic systems for the exchange of tax information between Member States and third countries. Finally, the report stresses that our tax policies must converge towards greater harmonisation and limit the barriers to SMEs. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report which, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity, which allows Member States to develop country-specific policies, proposes a comprehensive approach to fiscal policy as a key instrument for promoting growth and completing monetary union.  First of all, we believe it is essential to support a policy of reducing the administrative burden on businesses, which is therefore capable of eliminating artificial obstacles and divergences between the various national legislations. Our main objective should always be to ensure greater legal certainty, increase cross-border trade, fully promote the potential of the single market and thus stimulate growth and employment.  We believe that coordinated and comprehensive action is needed, both in the Union and at international level, to put an end to the crime of tax evasion: combating tax fraud and tax avoidance, combating aggressive tax planning and, of course, tax havens will continue to be one of our priorities. This could also provide a viable alternative to the introduction of new levels or forms of taxation and would provide much-needed additional funds to stimulate public investment, growth and employment.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The annual report sets out the path to be taken in fiscal policy in order to promote growth and deepen economic and monetary union.  The report identifies 3 priority areas in which action is needed. Firstly, action is needed to reduce the administrative burden on businesses and tax authorities and to eliminate artificial obstacles and divergences between national legislation. Secondly, immediate, coordinated and global action is essential, both in the Union and at international level, to put an end to the crime of tax evasion, to combat tax fraud and avoidance. Last but not least, fiscal coordination through well-defined structural reforms, within the Framework of the European Semester, is seen as a key instrument for defining fiscal policies that stimulate growth, employment and investment over the medium and long term.   In the light of the above, I have decided to support the report in a favourable way, because a balanced and development-oriented tax system is essential for generating sustainable growth. In addition, better results can only be achieved if a common approach is adopted in this area.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcome to the report. I believe that good agreements have been reached with regard to the exchange of information and the fight against money laundering. I would like to highlight two other issues on this subject. One is member states' practice of secret tax unifications to international companies; and the other is the foreign flight of European companies for tax avoidance. In recent months, several Member States have been found to have tried to win over multinational companies by offering them special preferential treatment, including tax reductions. The fact that there is competition for the favor of international companies between Member States is a fact. At the same time, in solidarity between states such as the EU, it is impermissible to maintain such practices. Moreover, this is unfair to other entrepreneurs, who expect clear tax rules to be fairly predictable and sustainable. I believe that a coordinated EU strategy is needed to address this problem, which is why I am looking forward to the European Commission's action plan on this issue. It is also a key issue to look at the so-called off-shore businesses, which are hotbeds of tax evasion and corruption. They are destroying the entrepreneurial environment, and this certainly raises questions about the political credibility of several countries.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report on the annual report on taxation. It is a well-drafted document which takes into account recent debates on the existence at European level of non-competitive tax practices, but also proposes measures to correct them.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: in writing. ‒ There were positive aspects to this report including the focus on tax transparency; however, much of what was being proposed lacked any real substance or force.  If there was a serious concern with effecting real positive change in this field, the proposals would not have been a simple repackaging of a failed economic paradigm. Instead, there would have been concrete measures put in place in order to move towards real tax transparency.  For my party, tax evasion and cross-border tax fraud is a major concern as untaxed income is considerably reducing our national tax revenues. As Ireland tries to find a sustainable economic recovery it is crucial that we develop a healthier reputation as a transparent place to pay tax, and face up to any changes necessary to create a transparent global tax system where multinationals cannot escape their duties to countries, including developing countries. There were also objectionable provisions in this report, which attempted to interfere with Member States’ taxation policies. Direct taxation is a matter of national competency and the EU has no role in dictating or interfering with Irish taxation policies or indeed in other Member States’ tax policies. It was for these reasons that I abstained.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report and its calls. I do believe we need to end banking secrecy, and to enforce and enhance taxation coordination in Europe, protecting competitiveness for businesses, social welfare for citizens and maintaining a level playing field between Member States. Taxation should only ever be understood as a tool used to boost market development and not to stifle it. At the same time, tax fraud is one of the main sources of disparity and market failure and this report sets out some very good proposals for the fight against this in Europe.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported Eva Kaili's report, although I have reservations about paragraph 25, which raises the idea of introducing a uniform minimum corporate tax rate, which I expressed by abstaining from voting on this point. A lower tax rate tends to be one of the reasons for some countries' attractiveness to foreign investors. From a general point of view, I consider opening up the debate on harmonisation of non-harmonised taxes to be rather risky, on the other hand, it is clear that unlimited tax competition with regard to this tax leads to a reduction in national income from corporations and the need to compensate for them with more economically problematic taxes, such as labour taxation. However, I am in favour of finding ways to avoid the undesirable scope of tax competition other than setting a single minimum tax rate.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. The report makes it clear that a tax system (if one wants to grant one to the EU at all) should be designed, which is adapted to the economic characteristics of the individual member states. Proper fiscal priorities must be set in order to stabilise or promote demand in the long term. In my opinion, a redesigned tax system only makes sense if precise rules are drawn up and they are subject to strict supervision. From this point of view, I have spoken out against this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report. An estimated €1 trillion in potential tax revenue is lost each year due to tax fraud and tax avoidance in the EU. This is a major risk to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems and will increase the tax burden on bona fide citizens and businesses.  A balanced and growth-oriented tax system is essential for sustainable growth and not yet sufficiently concrete measures have been taken. Taxation must be transparent, tax fraud must be tackled more strongly, tax barriers must be removed and administrative burdens on businesses reduced.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the Annual Tax Report. Concerted action at EU level is needed to combat tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens. Transparency standards must be included in future trade agreements. Member States must not use aggressive tax policies that have particularly negative consequences for businesses. In order to promote economic growth and employment, healthy and transparent tax competition between Member States needs to be maintained. National tax authorities, which are the guarantor of effective, efficient and legitimate national tax policies, play a special role. In addition, severe sanctions must be imposed in order to prevent companies from violating tax standards or to avoid liability for infringements committed.  It should be noted that tax policy must help to exploit the benefits of the internal market. In order to ensure long-term and growth-enhancing economic policies, coordination of viable tax policies must be promoted.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The core of the report is the use of taxation by governments and the EU as a means of redistributing popular income to the benefit of large business groups. That is why it calls for taxation to be integrated into the objectives of the reactionary EU-2020 Strategy, unpopular surveillance mechanisms, the European Semester and enhanced economic governance.  The inexpensive, hypocritical allegations of tax evasion, tax fraud, tax havens and multinational agreements with EU Member States on preferential tax treatment, in order to defuse workers' indignation at their heavy taxation, cannot hide the report's objective of enhancing, and through taxation, the profitability of monopolistic groups.  It openly calls for a reduction in corporate taxation, tax exemptions, benefits, aid to finance investments by monopolistic groups in profitable sectors, a "shift of taxation from work", i.e. a reduction in employer contributions, exemption of employers from their obligations in social welfare and insurance systems.  On the other hand, it calls for an increase in the taxation of popular incomes, with an intensity of the hunt for workers and the imposition of new taxes. In order for the people to breathe away the tax raid, the unpopular POLICY of the EU and governments, a conflict with the EU and the monopolies it serves is required, in order for the power and wealth it generates to pass into their hands.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that it is estimated that one thousand billion euros of potential revenue is lost each year in the EU due to tax fraud and avoidance; that this loss poses a serious risk to the effectiveness and fairness of the EU's tax systems, as it increases the tax burden on all citizens and companies acting in good faith; that the loss of this tax revenue means that there is less public money available for investment and, consequently, less opportunity to stimulate private investment, at a time when the Commission's stated focus is on employment, growth and investment; I welcome the agreement on the automatic exchange of information and the prospects for its rapid implementation; I call in this regard for the definitive abolition of banking secrecy within the EU from June 2015; It also calls for tax agreements to be concluded with third countries before 31 June 2015, and the Commission is invited to open negotiations with other third countries, including, not limited to, Singapore. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I support this report and consider it realistic and designed with the intention of bringing order to Member States' tax policies and taxation systems individually and at Union level. In addition to legal action, it is also necessary to take non-legal actions to increase public revenues, restore confidence in the fairness of our tax systems and reduce the burden on honest taxpayers. Coordinated action at EU level and a common approach can contribute to success in the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens, and improve the framework for the proper functioning of the single market through effective tax legislation. Regulated and fair tax collection could lead to improved economic situation, employment and public revenue growth, reduced tax burden on "small" taxpayers and changing public perception of unfair taxation. I find it unacceptable to have secret tax exemption agreements signed by certain Member States and individual multinationals with a view to attracting businesses and the very view that taxes must be paid where public services are used.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive planning and the fight against tax havens are essential to stimulate growth and employment in our internal market. I voted in favour of this resolution, which provides for the achievement of a comprehensive and unified fiscal policy, eliminating divergences in national legislation and allowing a reduction and simplification of tax obstacles to the cross-border activities of private individuals.  The resolution also aims to abolish banking secrecy by making it compulsory for companies with a cross-border impact to provide information on tax matters country by country, no longer spontaneously but compulsorily, information which will be recorded in a central archive and which will be available to all citizens for control purposes, ensuring transparency and fairness in tax practices.  We also call for a black list to be drawn up by 2015 containing tax havens and Member States that, through their tax policies, undermine internal EU competition, as a sign of a clear desire to change the current tax system, which is detrimental to our finances.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I support my colleague Kaili's report and congratulate her on her excellent work. It is estimated that €1 trillion is lost in the EU every year due to tax fraud and tax avoidance, and this loss is undeniably a major threat to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems, as it increases the tax burden on all honest citizens and businesses. In particular, I agree with the call for a fundamental revision of the European own resources system and views that allocating more own resources in a way that does not affect the budget would allow the Commission greater efficiency and independence and result in a more transparent European budget. I also agree with the call on the Commission to report annually to the Council and Parliament on the work and successes of the Platform for Good Tax Governance. We need joint action, as only a common approach can succeed in combating tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens, and improve the framework for the proper functioning of the single market through effective tax legislation. The loss of tax revenues means that less public funds are available for investment, which means that fewer additional private investment can be encouraged in a period when the Commission's objectives focus on jobs, growth and investment. It's something we can't afford in the moments of the financial crisis.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support MEP Eva Kaili's report on the annual tax report, as I believe that the Automatic Information Sharing Agreement will greatly contribute to preventing tax fraud and tax avoidance, which lose around €1 billion each year. Enabling automatic exchange of information will create a clear, simple and stable legislative framework that will prevent tax avoidance, transfer of profits to areas with lower tax rates and aggressive tax planning, the thus reducing the tax gap and providing more public funds for investment.  The European Commission's active involvement in the design of concrete proposals to create a legislative framework will allow for reducing tax gaps by 2020 and removing tax barriers hampering cross-border activities. The worrying fact that €177 billion in VAT revenues was lost in 2012 due to non-compliance and non-collection, justifies efforts to harmonise automatic data exchange systems, and I welcome the agreements reached by the anti-money laundering trilogue.  The uniform application of these rules throughout the Union will result in increased transparency of the system, tax revenues and funds earmarked for investment. Multiple benefits will be felt by all Member States, including Croatia.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the principles contained in this report, which aim to reduce tax evasion. At the same time, however, I believe that the European Union should not move towards tax harmonisation that would reduce tax competition between Member States. For this reason, I voted against paragraph 25, which called on the Commission to carefully examine the possibility of introducing a minimum corporate tax rate as a means of 'hampering harmful tax competition'. Since this point has passed and I do not consider tax competition to be harmful, I abstained from voting on the whole report, even though it contains some positive proposals.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns tax issues in the EU in 2014 and proposes a holistic approach to tax policy, identifying three main priority and complementary areas to each other. Firstly, it calls for specific tax policy measures to be adopted in order to reduce the administrative burden on businesses and tax authorities by removing artificial barriers and discrepancies between national laws. Initiatives are therefore identified that can ensure legal certainty, strengthen cross-border trade, promote the full potential of the single market and thereby boost growth and jobs. Secondly, it considers that tax policy is an important part of fiscal sustainability, as it guarantees revenue. It therefore reiterates the need to take immediate, coordinated and global action in the EU to combat tax evasion, tax fraud, tax avoidance, as well as to combat aggressive tax planning and tax havens. Thirdly, fiscal coordination, through well-defined structural reforms under the European Semester, is identified as the main instrument for developing fiscal policies that stimulate growth, employment and investment in the medium and long term. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's annual report on taxation.  This resolution, which I supported, addresses tax policy in Europe by examining three areas in particular: strengthening the internal market through reducing incompatibilities between national legislation, promoting tax coordination to generate growth and employment and finally combating tax fraud and evasion. We call on the European Commission to make far-reaching proposals against tax havens and tax evasion in the first six months of 2015.  An important element of this text is the commitment made by eleven European states to introduce a Financial Transaction Tax (FTT). This is an essential measure that all Member States should consider. In this context, I would like to add a nuance to paragraph 23 of the report, in which we call for the TFF's revenues to be part of the OWN resources of the European Union budget. The TFF must contribute to its own resources, but let us not forget to set aside a portion of the revenue for aid to developing countries.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this report, which I supported yesterday, Parliament calls for simplifying national tax systems in order to reduce the administrative tax burden on individuals and businesses; Removing barriers to cross-border activity; encourage more EU countries to join the 11 states that have introduced a financial transaction tax; introduce a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (ACCIS) for EU businesses; Increase the transparency of tax rulings (as they create opportunities for tax evasion and competition); Improving national parliaments' access to content related to tax rulings; Combating selective tax advantages for certain companies; to ensure that the European Commission establishes a blacklist of tax havens and countries whose tax practices distort competition by July 2015; suspend or revoke bank or advisory approvals from accountants or other financial advisors if they are proven to have contributed to tax evasion; transfer the tax burden from work to other forms of taxation and improve VAT collection. The fight against tax evasion must be a top priority for the Union. Parliament is following this in line, and I welcome that. Case to follow...

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the third (own-initiative) report that the European Parliament decides to make on the main tax aspects of 2014. This is an analysis of the current inefficiency and inequality of the European Union's tax systems, highlighting the four main problems we face at this level: tax evasion, tax fraud, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. By combating these problems and using a more efficient and effective fiscal policy, we will be ensuring the fiscal sustainability of our States and of the Union itself. Despite the aim of applying the principle of subsidiarity, we must adopt a concerted and bold policy that is capable of simplifying procedures, reducing administrative costs, increasing transparency, sharing information between States, preserving fair and transparent competition and promoting the conclusion of tax agreements with third countries.  In order to ensure good tax governance aimed at the completion of the single market and economic growth in the EU, it is important to strengthen the European Semester as the coordinating mechanism for member states' economic and fiscal policies. I voted in favour of this report which presents many ideas and guidelines for a responsible, transparent and balanced tax policy.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
