text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that fiscal matters, if used correctly, can be a driving force for growth and economic recovery. Europe can add value, not by imposing additional burdens on businesses, but by coordinating the fight against fraud, tax evasion and avoidance. While it is true that the responsibility for taxation lies with the Member States, which at the same time decide on social policies, we must prevent so many companies from exploiting the lack of transparency of European systems in order to evade taxes and not pay where they generate profit and where they use public services, the burden of which falls unfairly on taxpayers.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because, although the text contains some references that we can support, there is a complete lack of confidence in a European Commission led by the leader of a Member State that has caused much concern within the Union's other partners on the issue of tax avoidance for decades.  The most serious critical issues in the text, however, are the references to: increased and new own resources for the financing of Union policies, the request to the Member States to closely observe the EC recommendations on economics and taxation, and the defence of the so-called 'European Semester' mechanism.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ My vote is conditioned by the following reservation: in a single market, especially one with a single currency, it is to be expected that there will be demands for a level playing field across all business-related matters, including taxation, so that competition will occur under conditions that are fair and transparent. However, operational conditions for enterprises across the monetary area are not the same, because in the real world things shape up differently. Physical endowments are an obvious example of this. When the monetary zone operates as a federal system, or a so-called transfer union, mechanisms exist to ensure that those who are less well endowed with competitive attributes receive compensation for their handicaps. This is done by financial or other transfers, automatic or politically directed. None of this is possible in the euro zone. So calls for the harmonisation of tax structures, or even for ‘fairness’ in so-called tax competition, could inhibit even further the competitiveness of areas which find themselves at a disadvantage compared with better endowed areas within the monetary zone. In the absence of a well-organised transfer union, tax competition will remain a tool by which peripheral or disadvantaged regions can survive. The challenge is to make such competition transparent.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Given the importance of the problem of tax evasion in the EU and the urgency in addressing it, we were waiting for a report proposing concrete measures to address the problem. In our view, the report lacks the prospect of social justice and the importance of redistributive character. Moreover, the imposition on large companies, multinationals and wealth does not reflect as a key objective. Finally, the report is clearly in line with neoliberal policies and the dominant model, as it calls for strengthening the European Semester, and proposes a tax policy under the European Semester. That's why I voted against it.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in support of the Annual Tax Report while Conservative and UKIP MEPs voted against. This report calls for action to tackle tax avoidance, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. The report also called on the Commission to make the tackling of tax evasion a top priority as well as presenting effective proposals against tax havens this year.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the annual tax report and its common approach to EU tax policy, as it proposes measures necessary to establish effective tax legislation.  Automatic exchange of information and a single register are a necessary basis for starting to harmonise Member States' tax policies and better cooperation at European level. By applying additional measures, we will put an end to banking secrets and will establish a transparent and predictable framework for our businesses to make it more competitive at European level.   I would like to underline the essential call on Member States in this report on the need to identify as early as possible a common consolidated tax base that would be mandatory for European companies in the first phase and in the second phase for all other companies, except micro and small and medium-sized enterprises. This report, among other solutions in the fight against fiscal dumping, proposes innovation and a shift to an environmental tax, which I strongly welcome, considering that it recognises the environmental potential for the growth of the economy and the creation of new jobs.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I am in favour of tax policy being and must remain a national competence and therefore the EU must respect the different tax systems of individual Member States. What I cannot identify with, however, is that we continue to see tax evasion, tax fraud, the creation of new tax havens and tax avoidance. I voted in favour of the report because it contains many elements that can become an effective tool in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and which, in the long term, can create the preconditions for creating new jobs and sustainable growth. These measures are particularly important for a period when public debt is still high and investment is increasingly needed in the EU. I believe that EU citizens rightly expect us to put an end to unfair practices in the field of tax policies and, if they are violated, to appropriate sanctions against violators. I believe that, on the basis of the measures taken, we will be able to strengthen the harmonisation of tax policy, eliminate inconsistencies between national rules, which could strengthen cross-border trade, strengthen the single market, growth and employment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In the European Union, an estimated EUR 1 billion in tax revenue is lost every year as a result of tax fraud and tax avoidance. This loss heavily places a burden on the shoulders of European taxpayers, and as a result, there is less public and private investment at a time when the Commission is focusing precisely on jobs, growth and investment.  The annual tax report welcomes the agreement on automatic exchange of information and calls for the definitive abolition of banking secrecy and the conclusion of tax agreements with third countries by the end of June 2015. It also rightly stresses that taxes must be paid where public services are used and that a common approach at European and global level must be promoted, which will contribute to a more effective fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance. The report positively highlights the tripartite agreement on the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, which allows Member States greater transparency through unrestricted access to beneficial ownership information, and calls on the Commission to explore possible solutions for introducing a minimum corporate tax rate to limit harmful competition in the tax area.   On the basis of the above, and since a balanced and growth-oriented tax system is crucial for creating sustainable growth, I supported the annual tax report.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on taxation today. Every year within the European Union, some EUR 1 000 billion in potential revenue is lost as a result of tax fraud and eluments, in particular as a result of fiscal dumping.  The use of these practices appears to be one of the most serious problems in European tax matters. These days, in fact, the news of an investigation against a well-known multinational company, accused of an evasion of almost one billion euros against the Italian tax authorities. This is just the latest in a long list of cases of opaque tax transactions: just think of the case of Portugal, almost totally stripped of the tax revenues of Portuguese multinationals, attracted by the accommodating tax regulations of the Netherlands. The seriousness of this type of operation also appears even more serious within the EU, where capital generally moves from the countries most in need to the more prosperous ones, as in the case of Portugal. For these reasons, I am convinced that there is an absolutely need for European harmonisation in the field of corporate taxation, so as to prevent the continuation of operations which, if not illegal, are nevertheless harmful to the Union as a whole.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I appreciate the Commission's commitment to actively combating tax evasion and avoidance. It is important that both the EU institutions and society require more effective measures to increase tax transparency and ensure fairer tax competition within the EU common market.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒I supported the Annual Tax Report because it clearly highlights the fact that the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion, aggressive tax planning and tax havens is achieved precisely through a uniform approach and common tax policy measures by EU Member States. Targeted tax policy measures are needed to ensure that the single market is promoted and maintaining fair and transparent tax competition between Member States is conduci to growth and employment. Greater coherence on tax policies ensures that Member States' tax policies support the EU's broader policy objectives and promoting achievable tax harmonisation is a tool for long-term, growth-oriented economic policy.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I welcome the Automatic Information Sharing Agreement and the possibility of swiftly implementing it and call for the eventual abolition of bank secrecy in the EU from June 2015. There is a need to insist on the general principle that taxes are paid where public services are used, and I strongly condemn aggressive tax policies that get taxpayers to move their tax bases outside countries where they use public services or use the workforce that does so. I underline the fact that a common approach can succeed in combating tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens, and improve the framework for the proper functioning of the single market through effective tax legislation at global and European level. I highlight the key role SMEs play as drivers of growth and employment in the EU. EU policies should therefore be designed to keep barriers for SMEs to a minimum with further efforts to lift tax barriers and administrative burdens for SMEs.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the proposal. I agree with some of its parts – in particular, by highlighting the positive impact of favourable tax initiatives on entrepreneurship and investment, minimising tax policy obstacles for small and medium-sized enterprises and so on. However, I fundamentally disagree with some other parts of the proposal, such as the call for progress on a common consolidated tax base, which is a step towards tax harmonisation or a direct call for enhanced harmonisation of tax policy between EU countries. Moreover, the proposal calls for the introduction of a financial transaction tax, even proposing that the revenue from this tax should form part of the EU budget.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the Annual Tax Report, which points out that a common approach contributes to a more effective fight against tax fraud and evasion and tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and tax havens, and to a better framework for the proper functioning of the single market on the basis of effective tax policy legislation. In the EU, an estimated EUR 1 billion in tax revenues are lost every year as a result of tax fraud and tax avoidance, which is absolutely too much and which greatly undermines the efficiency and fairness of the EU's tax systems. I also voted in favour of the resolution because it stresses the need to maintain healthy and transparent competition between Member States in a tax area that will promote growth and employment and enable the European banking sector to remain competitive in the world, thereby preventing taxes from escaping from the EU.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 We do not want any interventionism in the economy of the Member States.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the annual tax report. I, too, agree that we should take a holistic approach to taxation, which can indeed be a practical tool for stimulating growth and deepening Economic and Monetary Union. However, I would like to talk about one thing at this time. I agree that the provision of a revenue base is an important part of the sustainability of the budget. This effectively requires the elimination of tax evasion in the Member States, the dismantling of the system of tax fraud and avoidance, and the fight against aggressive tax planning and tax havens. However, in the future, the European Parliament should also take into account the loss of tax revenue and the strengthening of the black and/or grey economy in certain Sectors or Products in certain Member States. I will give you just one example: the highest VAT rate in my country, Hungary, is 27%, which also a burdens a significant group of basic foodstuffs, among others. I am convinced that this form of distortion of individual tax systems in the Member States does not serve the Union's tax policy interests.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Tax justice and European fiscal coherence are our objectives for a Europe where citizens are at the same level as businesses and where the general interest takes precedence over the special interest. With regard to the text voted on this evening, immediate, coordinated and comprehensive action is needed on tax policy both within the Union and at an international level in order to eradicate tax evasion, combat tax evasion and evasion, and combat aggressive tax planning and, of course, tax havens. Immediate action could come in place of the introduction of new levels or forms of taxation and would generate much-needed additional funds for Member States to strengthen public investment and promote growth and job creation.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which offers a political response to  the LuxLeaks case. Fighting against tax fraud and tax evasion should be an absolute priority of the EU and Member States

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – We abstained in the vote on this report. We understand that the problem of tax evasion in the European Union is urgent and requires being at the top of Members' concerns. However, we understand that there are some shortcomings in this report that cannot be tolerated if the problem of tax evasion is to be tackled in its entire breadth; we refer to the lack of references to social justice or redistribution as means of achieving equality. That is why we can assure you that the report is in line with a single perspective, that of the vast majority, which is hardly subject to a debate that takes into account the social reality we face in Europe.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ After the LuxLeaks scandal it is more important than ever to begin to tackle the issue of distortive tax practices in Europe. If we want to protect the welfare state in Europe without overburdening our SMEs, it is of the utmost importance that multinationals pay the same rates as all other enterprises. In this sense, introducing a country-by-country scheme is fundamental to obtaining a clear picture on the real situation in Europe.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on urging the Commission to consider a minimum European rate in the IS; recall, for the nth time, the need for a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base; and require ITF revenue to be reversed in the EU budget. Also because of the call for an ambitious implementation of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive by the Member States.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. U2012 Tax fraud is a major risk to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems by providing states with less money to raise when these illegal practices occur. There needs to be a comprehensive strategy at European level to combat tax evasion, as well as fiscal agreements and greater coordination and transparency between Member States, low taxation and reduced barriers to SMEs, drivers of growth in the European economy. In this regard, this report substantially reflects many of these issues and is a positive tool for working and debating Europe's future in fiscal and economic matters.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Annual Tax Report because it reiterates the need to combat tax evasion and avoidance as well as aggressive tax planning, and in particular supports the automatic exchange of information on tax agreements between Member States and corporations. It cannot be that large multinationals manage to minimize the payment of taxes. Benefits must be taxed wherever they occur.  It also reminds the Council that it must adopt the Directive on the harmonisation of the corporate tax base, blocked by some Member States since 2011, as well as that relating to Financial Transaction Tax (ITF) through enhanced cooperation. In addition, the Spanish Socialists believe that derivatives should be included in the scope of the ITF and that wealth taxes are fundamental to combating inequality arising from the increasing accumulation of capital. We have also advocated that the Commission promote, through the Country-Specific Recommendations within the framework of the European Semester, the establishment of an estate tax in the Member States where it is not yet implemented.  In short, the Socialists reiterate that tax competition is incompatible with the internal market.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The European Parliament presents an own-initiative report on European taxation every year. As usual, the European Parliament has reiterated the need for a Europe-wide commitment to the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and tax havens.  But unlike in previous years, the report condemns aggressive planning practices, calls for the introduction of compulsory exchange between states on cross-border tax arrangements and calls for regulation to be introduced to address the erosion of the tax base and the transfer of profits on a European scale.  The text has included many requests made by the M5S such as country by country reporting for multinational companies, the one on greater transparency in the exchange of information and the establishment of a common consolidated corporate tax base. Of particular importance to the M5S is the request, which was then accepted, to divert the tax burden from labour and consumption to the financial sector. For these reasons, we have voted in favour of the report. However, since this is only an initiative, the text sends out an important message but does not make any changes to the status quo.  Particularly in the light of the recent scandals in Luxembourg, it is of the utmost importance to resolve on a European scale the problem of lack of transparency, aggressive tax practices through serious and stringent measures that do not give room for unfair competition between Member States.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. Given the importance of the problem of tax evasion in the EU and the urgency in addressing it, we were waiting for a report proposing concrete measures to address the problem. In our view, the report lacks the prospect of social justice and the importance of redistributive character. Moreover, the imposition on large companies, multinationals and wealth does not reflect as a key objective. Finally, the report is clearly in line with neoliberal policies and the dominant model, as it calls for strengthening the European Semester, and proposes a tax policy under the European Semester. That is why I have decided to vote against the report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues, I voted in favour of the Annual Tax report because the report proposes a holistic approach as regards taxation policy, which can prove to be a pragmatic tool to foster growth and deepen the European and Monetary Union. I am therefore surprised that UKIP and British Conservatives voted against the report.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The annual tax report is about promoting the lifting of banking secrecy in the EU by June 2015 and strengthening the harmonisation of tax policy. It also wants to introduce financial transaction taxes as part of the EU's own resources and a strengthened framework for economic governance. Since this report seems to represent only more power for the EU, in order to finally be able to impose taxes on the states and their fire width, I voted against this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of measures to combat tax evasion because I believe that it is Europe's priority to combat a scourge that is not only economic, not only social, but also a cultural scourge. Our political action must be able to trigger a process of redistribution and equality. And this can be possible through a widespread and just fight against tax evasion. The construction of a political Europe also involves this type of battle, so that the collective good is truly conceived as a good for all and for the benefit of all.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I reject the report on the EU's annual tax report. The Union has a massively limited competence in the field of tax law. Nevertheless, contrary to the Treaties, the Union is trying to gradually extend its powers. The annual tax report, an own-initiative report, is one of the tools for this purpose. The report is similar to a bus whose driver does not check the tickets: anyone can board. This not only does not do justice to the factual legal situation in the field of tax law, but increasingly undermines it. A large number of demands are of fiscal interest alone, and that is why the report must be rejected. However, among all the reasons that must lead to rejection, the following should be highlighted: the report calls for the proceeds of the financial transaction tax to be taken into account as part of own resources in the EU budget. This would have given the Union its own fiscal sovereignty and would finally become what many colleagues in Parliament and the Commission are aiming for anyway: the European Union would become an independent state. I don't want that.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual report on taxation. Tax policy by securing the basis of our revenue is an important part of fiscal sustainability. Immediate, coordinated and coherent action is needed to eliminate tax evasion offences, tackle tax fraud and tax avoidance, and to combat aggressive tax planning and tax havens, taking a common approach that should be implemented not only at European level but also globally.  Promoting effective tax coordination should be the main instrument for tax policy-making to stimulate growth, employment and investment. This is important in order to maintain transparent and fair tax competition between Member States that benefits growth and employment. Effective, efficient and justified national tax policies require the proper functioning of national tax authorities. It is also important to provide information between national tax authorities on best practices for learning from each other. Tax policy is essential not only for the social security of families and households, but also for competitiveness and job creation.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ With my European Parliament Labour Party colleagues, I voted in favour of the Annual Tax report because the report proposes a holistic approach as regards taxation policy, which can prove to be a pragmatic tool to foster growth and deepen the European and Monetary Union. I am therefore surprised that UKIP and British Conservatives voted against the report.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the annual report on taxation, adopted today in the plenary of the European Parliament. I welcome the rapporteur's concern to identify the essential pieces of legislation and actions that should be taken in order to increase public revenue, to restore confidence in the fairness of our tax systems and to reduce the burden on honest taxpayers. The report also shows that strong action must be taken both in the EU and internationally to reduce tax evasion, eradicate tax fraud and tax avoidance and combat aggressive tax planning and tax havens. The report proposes a holistic approach to fiscal policy, which could prove to be a pragmatic tool to stimulate economic growth and help EMU take deeper roots, taking into account the particularities of each Member State's economies and their sovereign competence to make specific decisions in the area of taxation.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The core of the report is the use of taxation by governments and the EU as a means of redistributing popular income to the benefit of large business groups. That is why it calls for taxation to be integrated into the objectives of the reactionary EU-2020 Strategy, unpopular surveillance mechanisms, the European Semester and enhanced economic governance.  The inexpensive, hypocritical allegations of tax evasion, tax fraud, tax havens and multinational agreements with EU Member States on preferential tax treatment, in order to defuse workers' indignation at their heavy taxation, cannot hide the report's objective of enhancing, and through taxation, the profitability of monopolistic groups.  It openly calls for a reduction in corporate taxation, tax exemptions, benefits, aid to finance investments by monopolistic groups in profitable sectors, a "shift of taxation from work", i.e. a reduction in employer contributions, exemption of employers from their obligations in social welfare and insurance systems.  On the other hand, it calls for an increase in the taxation of popular incomes, with an intensity of the hunt for workers and the imposition of new taxes. In order for the people to breathe away the tax raid, the unpopular POLICY of the EU and governments, a conflict with the EU and the monopolies it serves is required, in order for the power and wealth it generates to pass into their hands.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much appreciate this report, which is why I supported it. We need to talk openly about the fact that EU tax policy has its weaknesses. One of them, which I have been pointing out for a long time, is corporate taxation and VAT fraud. Empirical studies show that the public's negative perception of a company's tax policy can damage its overall position. Some surveys even confirm that 89% of the largest companies are concerned about how the media reports on what taxes they pay. I therefore endea way of obtaining a certain 'remuneration' for business entities that are transparent in their ownership structure and pay the State their fair share of their profits to the State. The fact that they act ethically should be materialised into a specific competitive advantage – a brand of tax transparency that could 'sell' to final consumers the fact that the entity is transparent and does not evad tax. We need to fight the grey economy and not just talk about it. I want final and tangible evidence from the European Commission that it will not settle for general statements alone.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This report does not point to the necessary break with the fiscal policy that has been followed at EU level, on the contrary, it reinforces the direction of tax exemptions, low taxation and tax forgiveness directly or indirectly that favour multinationals and large financial capital to the detriment of revenues that potentiate policies for workers and peoples. With some problems in this area, the majority of the EP is based on vague and ambiguous principles and without political relevance. See the reference to the "fight against" tax havens, tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning, the bottom problems that need to be resolved and for which the only proposal is aimed at its common approach, not presenting a single measure to put an end to them. Without this objective achieved, all intentions are merely words.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the annual tax report because it advocates a tax policy that promotes transparency, fairness and good governance, reduce the administrative burden on SMEs and micro-enterprises, remove tax barriers to cross-border activities, and is an effective instrument for promoting sustainable growth and social justice. In the EU, an estimated EUR 1 billion in tax revenues are lost every year as a result of tax fraud and tax avoidance, and this loss poses a significant threat to the efficiency and fairness of EU tax systems, as this increases the tax burden on honest citizens and businesses. The loss of tax revenue means that there is less public funds available for investment and, as a result, it is not possible to encourage so much additional private investment. Tax policy can be a tool for deepening economic and monetary union, taking into account the rights of Member States to create a tax system adapted to the specific characteristics of their economy, as provided for in the Treaties. It is good that the report mentions initiatives that can ensure legal certainty, strengthen cross-border trade, promote the realisation of the full potential of the single market and increase growth and employment.
